column5: This has a typical smooth toffee character of a festival pale ale. Sweet and chewy                                        ,this is tasty but lacks conditioning and sparkle. Brewed for the Leicester Beer Fest.

Ko�lak robiony w niemczech na Polski rynek. Jego parametry klasyfikuj� go jako podw�jnego ko�laka. Dost�pny w wi�kszo�ci sklep�w wielkopowierzchniowych. D�u�sza recenzj� oraz por�wnanie z 3 innymi ko�lakami pod tym linkiem https://youtu.be/o8DnlbU2OVI
Ocena wystawiona na podstawie wspomnie� z degustacji w ramach uzupe�nienia profilu.

Barwa bursztynowa i klarowna. Piana bardzo szybko zanika. Z wygladu bardziej whiskey niz piwo. W aromacie nuty karmelu                                                                                                                                     ,slodycz owocowa i slodowa. W smaku slodycz przelamana jest przez nuty alkoholu(nie wychodzi na pierwszy plan i nie przytlacza). Czuc rowniez cos ze sliwki i czerwonych owocow.

Butelka. Piwo barwy bursztynowej                                                                                                                                                                                                                           ,klarowne. Piana pocz�tkowo �rednio-obfita                                                                                                                                      ,koloru ecru                                                                                                                                                      ,drobno i �rednio oczkowa                                                          ,nietrwa�a � redukuje si� do�� szybko do cienkiego ko�uszka. Aromat niezbyt intensywny   ,z melanoidynami w postaci s�odkawo-karmelowych nut przypieczonego ciasta / opiekanego chleba oraz lekkimi estrami ciemnych owoc�w. Alkohol nie uderza w nozdrza. W smaku umiarkowanie s�odkie,troch� karmelu                             ,przypieczony chleb / ciasto                  ,rodzynkowa s�odycz                                      ,lekka kwa�no�� ciemnych s�od�w                                  ,nieco jednocze�nie owocowa. Alkohol wyczuwalny ale nie intensywny             ,jak na zawarto�� procentow� jest bardzo dobrze u�o�ony. Posmak nieco bardziej wytrawny,z nieznaczn� goryczk�,lekko kakaowy. Oczekiwa�bym nieco wi�cej cia�a.

Bordowe z obr�czk� piany. Zapach s�odkawy                                                                                                                                                                                                                  ,s�odowy                                                                                                                                                                        ,deczko czerwonych owoc�w. Delikatna nuta rozpuszczalnikowa                                                                                                       ,porzeczkowa                                                                       ,jednak dominuje sp�d od ciasta                                                          ,typowe melanoidyny. Goryczka nieistniej�ca. P�askie                                                                                                                                          ,ma�o cia�a                                 ,ma�o smaku.

Dobry ciemny ko�lak                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ,do�� mocny smak. Czu� karmel i chmiel. Blisko 8% alkoholu                                                                                                                      ,co jestem dobrym wynikiem.

Ciemno brunatna barwa                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      ,przejrzyste                                                                                                                                                                    ,klarowne. Piana niestety szybko opada do zera. Aromat bardzo nik�y. nie wyczuwam nic szczeg�lnego. Po d�u�szej chwili staje si� intensywniejszy: karmel          ,sk�rka chleba. W smaku troch� palonych nut                                        ,s�odowo                                                                                 ,ale niczym si� nie wyr�nia. Jedyny plus za idealnie zamaskowany alkohol. Do zapomnienia                                                                                                      ,niczym nie porywa.

barwa ciemna miedz                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         ,piana niska opadajaca do otoczki. Aromat ma�o intensywny                                                                                                                       ,ma�o z�o�ony                                                                                                                                                     ,sk�rka od chleba                                                                  ,karmel. W smaku s�odowe                                                                 ,karmel. Ale fanem ani stylu ani tego piwa na pewno nie zostane
Bottle pour. Sweet nutty malt aroma. . Flavors are sweet caramel with a hint of milk chocolate. On the sweeter side. Almost no hops.

Pivo z cieszynsk�ho Kauflandu. 500ml lahvov�. Sice to nen� z mojich obl�ben�ch styl�                                                                                                                                                                       ,ale kvalitu mus�m uznat!

Floral and light grainy aroma. Pale yellow                                                                                                                                                                                                        ,white head                                                                                                                                                                     ,good lace. Light sweet                                                                                                                                           ,bitter                                                                            ,floral. Test of 29.07.2004.

Bottle pours a clear copper with a large khaki head. Aroma of grassy hops                                                                                                                                                                     ,yeast                                                                                                                                                                          ,bready caramel malt                                                                                                                                              ,and grains. Taste of caramel and bread finishing dry with yeast and hops. Not bad.
Pours amber with a white head. Smells rosey with some caramel qualities. Tastes a little sweet with some tangy notes.
Clear gold with a white head. Biscuity aroma. Taste is malt with caramel notes and light herbal hops. Better than I expected.

500 ml bottle                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 ,date on back label of 12.11.10. I�m not sure if it�s a best by or a bottled on date. Served in a nonic pint glass                                                              ,the beer pours a mostly clear dark gold color with about an inch off-white head. Head retention and lacing are both decent enough. Aroma is bready and sweet malt,along with some corn. Doesn�t smell bad                                           ,but it doesn�t smell good                                                               ,either. Taste is pretty much all grainy malt                                                                                                                                                 ,along with a bit of bittering hops. Not bad,but not good either. Mouthfeel/body is medium,it�s a bit coating and is well carbonated. For the style,it�s not a bad brew. It�s not something I would drink very often,but if you can find a single bottle it�s worth trying. If I remember correctly,I think this was pretty cheap to buy.

500 ml bottle                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 ,no date. Pours a decent orange/gold with a highly active large creamy white head that lasts and lasts before receding to some nice lacing. The smell is typical euro pale fare ,just some pale malts. The taste is average for the style                                                                                                         ,it seems slightly heartier                                                        ,but overall the same� ol same �ol. Serving type: bottle Reviewed on: 03-10-2010 04:48:33

16.9oz bottle. Anything labeled "Premium" is gonna be sketchy. Filtered orange-yellow. Fluffy, soapy head. Off pungent Eastern-European factory swill aroma. Relatively straightorward trash Lager..A Pils? ..yeah right. Considering this beer probably costs like 17 cents in Poland, it�s tolerable. Sugary, extract tasting stuff. Some medium dark malt tones, reminiscent of that Mocne taste. Could actually get used to this one, not entirely reprehensible.

Cool, has a serial number on the bottom of the label. Mine says brewed by Litowel Breweries. Big pour into a 22 oz glass mug. A little smell of somewhat veggie hops but in a pleasant way. Big white creamy head that fades to a blanket. Yep, its above 5% and tatses like it. Some shades of cheap american pale high gravity but that goes away at times. Has a somewhat acceptable sizzle on the palate, but that fades too as the session continues. Very nice lacing like a wet white wifebeater tanktop on rachel welch in the 1960�s. Not bad overall, never quite gets to american malt liqour attributes.

500mL bottle, BB 11/12/10. Poured clear, bright golden with a short, tightly-bubbled white head. The aroma picked up honey and pale malts with just a little airy earth present.. some corn syrup as it warmed up. The flavor found honey and corny vegetal malts throughout.. sweeter honey was marginally tasty on the finish.. there was an element of dank on the middle that I couldn�t figure out.. OK overall. Light-bodied, dry, and grainy on the palate.. too syrupy to be refreshing.

clear bubbly yellow gold, medium white head, quite lacy. nice clean (if mild) malty nose, trace of grain, lemony. flavor is musty malt, grain and lemon. medium bodied, kinda sparkly mouth feel, lightly bitter finish. a nice pils. not exciting but refreshing and repeatable. a cheap. single bottle purchase from binny�s orland park.
bottle. bready lemons. doughy dirt. muddy grainy corn. didn�t like. not a typical pils. too much cardboard.
Light ambergold, small off white head. Malty alcohol, caramel with a light body. Test of 29.07.2004.

Jurand Browary Warminsko-Mazurskie--Jurand Mocne Malt Liquor--2006 16.9 oz. Bottle. 7.00% ABV. 35 IBU�s? (4.25 / 5.0) Mild lace head. Hazy bright golden color. Medium hop adjunct front. Rich malty clean mild sweet caramel butter body. Tangy sweet apple pear mild hop end. Malty spicy rich tasty Bock. Sampled 2/5/2006.

Tried again recently and got pretty much the same result. A little less drinkable than I recalled. Original rating follows. Dark gold to light orange body with a lightly off white head. The aroma has some dusty hay and old library books. There is also some light apple behind the dusty character. The taste has some sweet potatoes and caramel. There is also some light would in the finish. A decent brew.
Single from Garys. Solid long lasting Head. Cloudy Golden Color. Malty as well as sweet. Very Full taste

Bottle: Bronze, light white head and light lacing. Nose of sweet Slavic malt and hops. The flavor is sweet, high alcohol and decently malted. Finishes sweet and malty. Meh. Your typical Slavic malt liquor.
Bottle: Pours a lighter amber/orange color with an average white head. Nose is sweet and malty, pretty standard for a lager. Taste is sweet and musty malt, as well as some grassy tones.

Nice amber color,small white head that had a good hang time then faded slowly to leave a decent lace behind.Very light aroma,light malt some sweetness and maybe a hint of citrus in there.The taste was malty with some mild hints of lemon and the hops come on fairly well in the middle and end with a mild hop bitterness.Not a bad brew,it has a slightly heavy middle to it but not bad at all.

Finally a Eastern European beer that I could finish. Not that it was good it just wasn�t horrible. Had a real funky nose that was skunky and like the smell of a unused ziplock baggy. actually quite refreshing but still has that underlying skunkiness.

Mid-golden with the light haze of microscopic particulate topped with a large, slow-fading, white head. Plastic in the aroma (think "model car kit") with herbs, cereal malts, fresh sawdust and a tinkle of pee. Sweet, corn-syrupy flavor with industrial gasoholic leanings leading the way to a dry, alcoholic finish. Sweetness lingers and I can�t decide if I like it. The punch of alcohol saves this one. Binnys Beverage Depot/DiCarlo�s Armanetti, Willowbrook, IL 60527

Sweet malty aroma. Good label and bottle, lightly hazy honey gold beer with a big white head. Malty, just a little boozy, cakey at times. Not super bitter, but adequate hopping. Nothing fancy. Medium body, hop finish, loses CO2.
Pretty nice hefeweizen. Banana and a hint of clove in the right proportions. A nice summer beer. Murky orange pour with good head and lacing. Soft sweet finish. Tap at brewery.

Tap from the source. Hazy orange with a short white head. Not much in the nose, a bit more clove than banana in the mouth, touch gritty, half-sweet, low bitterness, low plastic astringency, strong carbonation with harshness but a little mineral in a medium-full body. Not great but fresh and I�d certainly order again. [2018.07.09: 2.9]

DATE REVIEWED: August 21, 2014... GLASSWARE: Weihenstaphaner weizen... OCCASION: catching up on some DVRs...APPEARANCE: dark copper body; very little effervescence; snow white head settles quickly to a sudsy, thin consistency; no lacing... AROMA: warm banana and aromatic bubblegum, with a hoppy citrus dimension; secondary scents like pepper and vanilla can be detected ... PALATE: intriguing balance of soft and strong--smooth mouthfeel but slightly heavier at the throat--revealing an ale character... TASTE: rather nondescript flavor, with lemon hints late and bubblegum, mint and grass--some malty sweetness too...OVERALL: bought as a bomber from the brewery itself, this brew compliments the humid August night well; an easy-drinking, tasty beer that I will seek out when returning to State College next summer....

Transfer from BA review on 4-30-12 - Served on tap in a pint glass Appearance � Served a super hazy orange color with a nice billowy white head. The head faded relatively fast to give only a light amount of lacing. Smell � Big aromas of yeast and a wheat-bready smell are most dominant. There are also some nice aromas of orange, lemon, banana, and a little bit of spiciness mixed within. Taste � The taste has a very pleasing wheat backbone. The wheat bread taste is initially complemented with a good dose of yeast cake and some spice. The taste starts out more on the maltier side, but as the taste advances it sweetens as more citrus orange and lemon come to the forefront. Other fruit flavors of banana develop more toward the end. The spiciness intensifies again at the end and when mixed with the sweeter fruit flavors leaves a spicy sweet taste on the tongue. Mouthfeel � Medium to just a bit above medium in body thickness with a slightly higher than average level of carbonation. The lighter body and the higher carbonation complement the style well and make it a very drinkable brew. Overall � A wonderfully flavorful session brew. This is one I think Otto�s should put on their permanent roaster.

WOW, one of the best beers I have had in a long time. Got this as a treat at a tasting. It reminded my of some beers brought back from Germany. Poured cloudy, with a nice white head. It had a nice banana and spice aroma and flavor. I can�t wait to visit State College!

Had on draft @ Otto�s brewpub, in the NeW location, in State College,PA .. . pours with decent foam .. lacing is dreamy .. . lots of cloves and spiced banana dessert .. . light mouth .. some good stuff here .. .. . . tap that stack of paper, makes us feel better!

Draft at brewpub. Pouts yellow with a nice amount if cloudiness and a half an inch of white foam. Nice banana notes on the nose. Big banana and clove notes on the tongue. Finishes clean. Very good example of style.
on tap-pours an off white head and cloudy yellow/orange color. Aroma is clove/banana, secondary medium malt. Taste is clove/banana, secondary wheat/medium malt, spice hops. OK effervescence.

An excellent hefe and I�m a big fan of the style. On tap at the brewpub. Cloudy, murky orange brown. Traditional bananas and cloves nose. Banana bread palate. Very full and rich. Sweet start and sour finish. Great!
On tap at brewpub. Cloudy dark orange with thin white head. Aroma is banana. Flavor is banana, caramel and hay. Refreshing and smooth.

On cask at the brewery. Pours a hazed dark brown with a medium sized tan head. Soft sweet roast on the nose. Medium bodied, smooth with sweet roast, cocoa, chocolate and a touch of coffee. Lingering sweetness balanced with a good bit of dark chocolate.

Transfer from BA review on 4-17-12 - Served on cask at the brewpub in a pint glass Appearance � The beer was served a deep brown color with a small tan head. The head faded rather fast giving very little lacing. Smell � The nose is quite light. There are hints of raosty malt with a very light coffee and chocolate aroma. Taste � The taste was of roasted malt up front. A dark bread mixed with a very light amount of roasted coffee and chocolate. There is a light sweetness of brown sugar and a very small amount of vanilla in the beginning and the middle of the taste. The flavors bitter more toward the end at the expense of the sweet, and leave a somewhat roasty and somewhat bitter flavor on the tongue. Mouthfeel � A nice creamy body with a lighter level of carbonation. Very classic for a cask with some accentuation of the body. The creaminess complements the roasty flavors quite nicely. Overall � It was worth a try, but one I would likely not go back to any time soon. It had a very nice mouthfeel, but was pretty average in every other category.
Well balanced good color, head retention. Flavor was moderate at beginning but fell off towards the end.

Had on CasK @ Otto�s brewpub, in State College,PA - if you can find it.. . light casky mouth .. deep roast .. slick aftertaste .. . a perfect session brew but still, could be fuller- put this beer on nitro!! .. . . nothing but a few butterfly bandages won�t fix..

Cask at brewpub. Pours black with a slow settling khaki head which leaves a fair amount of lacing in the glass. Nice malt and molasses on the nose. Mouthfeel is a bit thin as is the taste. Finishes clean. Solid but not as awesome as I�d hoped.

Sampled on cask this beer poured a very dark brown color - almost black with a medium sized creamy brown head that lingered and left great lacing. The aroma was dry, roasty and woody. The flavor was bitter, dry and roasty with light notes of vanilla and wood. The finish was long, dry, roasty and woody. Medium body. Not my style.
On cask at brewpub. Dark brown with half inch cream colored head. Aroma is nutty. Flavor is roasted nutty maltiness. Okay.

On cask at Zeno�s Pub - State College, PA. Crisp, dry roasty nose with lots of charcoal, some cracked black pepper, and a hint of red wine. Pours rather dark black-brown with an off-white rim. Flavors are bristling with ultra-dry roast characters. Seems nearly stout like or very traditional London-style with an almost smoky edge. The malt base is exceedingly clean, allowing for a showcase of roasted and blackened characters. This beer really belches charred dryness. The cask presentation quiets the carbonic edge, which might get a little aggressive with this much roasted acidity in the beer. Fresh, prickly and with a nice roasted character that is unique and enjoyable.

Cask at Otto�s. Very deep dark brown/almsot black with a frothy beige head and good lace. Aroma had lot sof chocolate malts with hints of roasted barley. Light hops all the way through for some balance, more chocolate in the middle, and a ligth bitterness in the end with hints of licorice. One of the smoothest porters I have had.
Draft at State College. Deep burnt sienna with tan head. Aroma of dark malt, chocoff, some licorice and port. Tastes roasty malty, with finishing chocoff and molasses. Great balance and complexity.
Ocena wystawiona na podstawie wspomnie� z degustacji w ramach uzupe�nienia profilu.
Ocena wystawiona na podstawie wspomnie� z degustacji w ramach uzupe�nienia profilu.

zapach do�� neutralny, zio�a, s�ody, troch� zielonych ro�lin, troch� kurzu i piwnicy. kolor z�oty, klarowny, piana bia�a, �rednio obfita, ale do�� trwa�a. w smaku wytrawnie, lekkie s�ody, stare ro�liny zielone, troch� zi�, kurz, lekka m�ka, troch� aromat�w bimbrowych i ogonk�w z jab�ek gdzie� w tle. nie jest odpychaj�cym, ale nie jest te� przyjemny. goryczka niska, kurzowa, zio�owa i zielona. nasycenie wysokie
Can. Golden color, clear, white foam. Aroma and taste: pilsner malt, a little local hops, moderately clear and watery.

Sentyment z gimnazjum, zobaczymy jak si� broni. G��bokie z�oto, niska piana, nawet si� trzyma. Pachnie zbo�em, mokrym zbo�em, do tego kukurydza i nieco moczu. Nie razi bardzo, ale za dobrze nie jest. W smaku pe�ne, tre�ciwe, s�odowe, zbo�owe, goryczka cienka. Browary Lubelskie maj� gorsze rzeczy.
Can, Fresh Market Polski, Wigston. Golden with an off white head. Sweet grain and corn with sudsy water. Stewed autumn fruits. Papery. Peppery. Dull.
Starsi mawiali, �e to piwo dla meneli. Odstrasza�o mnie to od niego do tego stopnia, �e do dzi� mia�em wra�enie, �e nie produkuj� go od 15-tu lat.
Sv�tle �lut� barva, p�na se vytrat� rychlost� sv�tla, v�n� m�rn� sladov�, st�edn� ��z, chu� sladov�, dozvuk sladov� a� nasl�dl� s pachut�. Nedobr� pivo.

Nothing terrible about it--it�s a standard light E. Eur lager on the watery side, with slight off notes in the aroma and metallic elements onward to the finish. Slightly unusual find at a neighborhood Tallinn grocery store (16.9 oz can)
500ml can - thanks Marduk! Bland aroma, some hints of pale lager. Watery palate. Sweet and corny taste. Tastes so watery. Hops are chemical and extracty. Drinks like 3.5 more then 5.0 it�s so watery.

Pours a deep golden brown from the bottle with fluffy tan head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma of musty earth, a hint of dark fruit, molasses and caramel, and booze. Taste follows, definitely big and warming, nice dark fruit and sweet maltiness, with a touch of earthy hop behind. Nicely done for a very uninteresting style, but a classic.

Pours clear caramel, minimal beige head. Aroma offers toasted malt and slightly tart fruit. Flavor features tropical and pomme fruit, toasted malt, sharp woody and caramel notes. Texture has fair fizz and OK body. Warm your winter.

2007 bottle! Trade from Cornfield many years ago! I took in a nice nose of plum and brown sugar. The head does a very good job of staying in the glass; it's only lost half its height in the first ten minutes. The taste still has some hop bitterness. Maybe not that distinguishable, or else just using mostly English hops. Alcohol is very warming as I sip it. The malt has more caramel, and a bit of roast to it. There is a bit of the papery note of oxidation, but that can't be avoided with an 11-year old beer, especially at 9% abv. That one bit of off character is very mild, and does not distract from the experience of a beer made to lay down for, well, three presidential terms. As with many cellared beers, there are some dregs in the bottom of the glass of dead yeast or hop particles. Holding the last of it back, then swirling into my glass, didn't offer much that was different.

Bottle shared. Pours a clear amber with a finger of foam that dissipates. Prune and raisin driven nose with some light brandy like character and malt. Fruit forward with good malt character a touch of oxidation. A nice and smooth winter warmer that was nice shared amongst friends!
Bottle. Pours a cloudy brown with small beige head that lasts. The aroma is bourbon and vanilla. Medium mouth, candy sugar, dark fruit, booze, sweet finish, very good.
650ml bottle. PRetty middle of the road barleywine, sweet caramel, missing some body.

Bottle at home. Pours a clear dark amber brown color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have some herbal hops sweet malts, caramel, leather, a moderate fruit character with a touch of bitterness to the finish. A touch on the thin side.

22 ounce bottle A bargain at $3.99 this was a decent barley wine with a Midwestern touch. Typical of many of the non-sour Upland beers it has some weaknesses. Overall though they are masked by a strong presence, great price, and well thought out winter warmer. Aroma / Appearance - The ruby red base is trapped under a bubbly head of foam. Musty leather, wet shoes after a winter hike, and sweet red vines tether it to the later months of the year. Hops are present but do not really take center stage. Flavor / Palate - Almonds, cherries, and fresh hops brighten the palate. Sweet aspects carry a chewy mouthfeel to a creamy and long lasting conclusion. A decent beer is slightly memorable and above average. At best though it makes a strong case for being a solid regional to fallback on when you get tired of Sun King, New Albanian, and other Indiana brands.

Bottle; Pour is murky brown / mahogany with a two finger, fine bubbled khaki head into this glass. The nose is mineral, dark fruit, caramel and toffee, with a hint of grassy hops present here as well. The flavor profile is malt forward initial, blending somewhat messily with the dark fruits ; sugar plum moves to brown sugar , with some biscuit and grass present ; Its not very impressive honestly - but its not bad either.

I�m not the biggest fan of sweet, heavy beers, I don�t know, I guess I was in the mood. Pours reddish copper, with a ring of foam. Smells is lots of caramel, toffee, and molasses. Very smooth, slick palate. Taste is lots bready, toasty caramel and other sweet flavors. Nice bit of spruce and pine in the finish. I don�t know if I would drink all the time, but it hit the spot this time. BTW, the label says 8.5%, not 9...

Cask, Swan Brewpub, Kent. Ginger orange colour. Malty sweet vinegary aroma. Crude. Taste is all over the place. Even the texture is unbalanced; watery in places, but mostly sticky sweet. Some obscure lemon flavour amongst mostly undeveloped malt. Dreadful stuff. No idea what style this is supposed to be - it's like nothing I've ever experienced before, or would want to ever again!

Half pint pulled at th brew pub in West Peckham (Kent), amber with a creamy off white head. A sweetish grainy malt aroma. A malty flavour, a bit atsringent though. A good bitterness throughout though.

Cask handpull at Swan on the Green. Fresh barrel on. Old gold colour with lasting beige head. Nice caramel malt and hop balanced nose. Richish malt fruit and more caramel in mouth, with good hop/malt finish. Overall a good balaced best bitter
Cask @ Oxford Beer Festival, UK Backlog 23 Oct 2004 Surprisingly roasted taste for such an amber beer. Nice hoppiness present.
Cask Conditioned at Oxford Beer Festival 04. A brown to amber bitter with light bubbly head. Hoppy sweet fragrant beer with a mid roasted malt base. A light enjoyable beer with sweet hoppy finish.
Cask, Swan Brewpub, Kent. Amber. Nice hoppy bitterness up front, crude orange flavoured malt in the middle. A confused mixture of the hops and malt in the finish.

Cask conditioned at The Kent Beer Fest, Canterbury. Amber to copper with slight white head. As with the other Swan beer at the festival, this has a big toffee caramel note, sweet and malty. A little sulpher, but rather thin.

Cask@Kent Beer Festival 2006. Hazy dark copper/nut brown, not much head. Nose has berries and barnyard (KBF was in cowshed, but this aroma came from beer). Fruity, malty and barnyardish! Not really hoppy, just some bitterness and alcohol in the aftertaste.
Cask @ 13th White Cliffs BF, Dover. 3 February, 2006 Sour aroma of sweaty feet... Candy and chocolate grows together with a slight lactic note. Malty toffiness ends this pleasant brew.
Cask handpull at Swan on the Green. Mid brown beer with disappearing beige head. Toffee malt and hop aromas, ok in the mouth with sweetish toffee and nice earthy dry hop finish

Dark chestnut brown colour. Slightly acidic, vinous, aroma with sweet malt, candy sugar and bubblegum nuances. Sweetish, fruity flavour with plenty of dry malt too and bitter coffee and sour undertones, but finishes quite soft and short of bite. Medium bodied. Quite complex, but lacks a bit of grip. A rather odd beer, but OK. Cask (gravity), Thurrock Beer Festival.

May, 2003 Swan Brewpub, Kent. The best of the Swan�s offerings. The Swan microbrewery opened in 2000 in a coal shed behind the pub. After almost three years of brewing it seems they still haven�t quite got everything right. I may have gone in on a bad day, but it must have been a seriously bad day for all six beers I tried to have the same taste of poor fermentation. Either they don�t really know what a good beer should taste like, or their yeast is very tired. Anyway, this teak colour brew was mostly successful and, given the poor quality of the previous 5, was actually quite tasty. There was a good depth of dry flavour with a firm texture. A bramble and alcohol warmth comes through in the finish. An overall leather flavour with just a hint of licorice, offset by a touch of immature development. There�s an old, slightly stale honeyed date in the aroma. [2.5] JUly, 2006Kent Beer Fest. Heavy. Intrusive sweetness. Quite rich and ripe. Noticable alcohol. Crude. Not good. Like a poor homebrew. [1.9]

Backlog, bottle that pours a copper shade with a medium head and decent lacing in the glass. Nose and flavor of apples, coriander, pear, oranges, and Belgian fruits. Body is medium to fuller with a slightly boozy finish at the 9.5 percent

Many thanks to Erzengel for sharing! A almost clear amber beer with a mid-sized most good lasting white head. Aroma of old riped apples, grapes, belgian yeast. Taste of sweet yellow fruits, peach, apricot, belgian yeast, quite nice!

And again thanks to kappldav123 for sharing. Unclear copper in the glass, nearly no head. Fruity with some malt on the nose. Taste starts fruity some sweetness, belgian like. Hints of resin. Some dry toasted parts in the aftertaste. Hidden alcohol. Nice!

Many thanks to kappldav123 for sharing this bottle! Interesting grassy herbal nose. The beer starts fruity smooth. Very mild with a cake-like texture. Oranges and christmas-spices. Round and deep, very mild with lots of christmas-cake in the aftertaste.
Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass dark golden, small head. Old malty aroma. Starts dry-malty, sweetish, notes of some sweets/sugar, malty-sweet background. Light woody hints. Not bad.

Hazy gold with small head of foam, some floaties. Has June 10th 2015 on the label. Raisin soaked bread , other dark fruits and some oxidation in the smell. Tastes like it smells, booze isn�t overly present. On the sweet side with the mouthfeel bordering on the syrupy side. A very nice drop!
Honestly found this pretty forgettable. It was ok but not anything special. It was ok but not interesting. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
750ml bottle pours an orange color without any head. Very low carbonation. Citrus and mild spice. Some orange peel bitterness. Mild sweetness. Would be better with more carbonation.

Bottle: pours cloudy darker orange with a thin white head, spicy and lightly alcoholic aroma, taste is not overly sweet, some dark fruit flavors, medium bodied with a pretty soft carbonation. Not bad.

Bottle. Seems to be DB today. Glowing orange, slightly effervescent, bubbly head. Spicy nose of honey, orange, some leather. Sweet hone and orange flavor, like a typical aged Belgian strong blonde. Nice prickly, fruity tartness in the background is the best part. Berries, oranges. Interesting.
Bottle 17/05/2004 Amber golden coloured with some alcohol. Bitter lasting malt finish.

Bottled, pasteurised, 500 ml. Copper coloured with white head. Sweetish full bodied special bitter, fruity malty with a biscuit edge, enough alcohol for interest and a hardy, floral hop note giving a decent finish. Enjoyable.

Bottled. Deep clear mahogany colour, capped with a shinny, lacy white head. Slightly gaseous. Sweet, honey malt aroma with contrasting hop complexity. Lovely smooth malt flavour, biscuity and varied. Not challengingly complex but enough to keep you interested. In summary, it�s best described as a miniature version (just less of everything) of the Fullers Vintage Series.
Not there best ale,quite an ordinary beer,hops and malt just don't stand out enough,a pity for a commemorative ale.
Pateurised bottle. A pleasant, but very run of the mill bitter. Smooth and bland. On a par with Fullers ESB.
Amber color, thin head. Raisin aroma with a hint of licorice. Hopbitter flavor with licorice. Some distant peach fruitiness and alcohol. Full of flavor, but somewhat lacking in balance.

Pleasant bronze appearance with several different tastes competing for your attention.But after the initial impact it settles down to be a fairly bland beer.After 175 years you would have thought that this brewery could have produced something a bit more exciting than this.

Bottle. Nice bright copper bronze colour, thin white head and moderate condition. Low caramel malt aromas, malty in the mouth,slightly fruity with a good hop bitterness developing in the finish. Other than that, little in its favour.
rich malty nose, dark bronze hue with a small white head, malty taste with bitter hop undertones, quite complex, some biscuity like notes, a worthy commerative ale (certainly not deletable)
Malty nose with peachy hints. Rusty colour with a small head that vanishes quickly. Decent flavours or malt and caramel with a dry hoppy finish. Not Jennings finest effort.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: On nitro tap at Widmer - Roasty and smoke aroma, creamy head. Tasted quite good. Nice lower alcohol alternative.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Nitro at Widmer... Poured almost black with amber highlights and thick, light brown head. Malty aroma. Nice roasted coffee notes with dark chocolates and creamy texture. Not hoppy or bitter at all with a strong malted grain character through to the finish.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: on tap at widmer. decent purple-brown colour with a nice beige head. chocolate and coffee aroma, a little thin but with some pleasant cream and after dinner mint sweetness and reasonable dryness. pretty drinkable anyway

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Creamy tan nitro head. Roasted coffee cream in the nose, with a creamy texture and a good dry palate. Mild roasted coffee and milk chocolate.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: (RBSG04) (nitro) Beige creamy head atop red-black body. Aroma is sweet, chocolate, roasty, coffee. Taste is medium sweet, roasty, chococoffee. Thin and creamy palate.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: On tap at the widmer brewery. Pours a dark red/brown, almost black with a tan head that stays forever leaving thick lacing on the glass. Roasty coffee aroma with a faint hop profile behind it. Taste is incredibly smooth and creamy, still on the thin side, as widmer�s stouts tend to be.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Tap@Widmer. I guess you could say that this is a textbook Irish stout, but one which doesn�t go over the top. Dry roasty mocha and chocolate, creamy and dry, coffee. A little bit thin though, still OK.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: O�Casey�s Irish Stout on Tap at the GasthausDark ruby black with tan head & some sticky lacing. The aroma is very dry & lightly roasted. Mouthfeel is creamy & sweet (bland) - nitro. The flavor has a snatch of roast but is creamy & mild.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: The bartender called this O'Caseys Irish Stout, and it is not actually a Widmer recipe, but is part of the Collaborator series of recipies from the Oregon Brewers Guild, a homebrew association. They hold regular contests, and the winners have batches of their brew made on Widmers premises, and put on a few local taps, including the Horsebrass Pub, and New Old Lompoc. Anyway, this was on nitro, so had a creamy long lasting head atop a black body, with a nice dry stout bitterness, a tad sweeter than Guinness. Actually quite good.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Good thick head that provided nice lacing all the way down. Very full bodied for a dry stout, hearty. However, the taste was somewhat lacking. Overall a good beer, much better than Guinness.
Not bad at all for a light beer. It's a sweetish, malty microbrew with more character than most light beers. Couldn't even tell it was a light beer.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Limerick Irish Red
column5: On draft at Carolina ale house. Nice clear reddish amber pour with Good off white head. Decent malty caramel notes but with a bright citrus hop character for balance. Pretty good and refreshing.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Limerick Irish Red
column5: On tap at Carolina Ale House. A run of the mill red ale that pairs well with pub grub. Easy drinking and balanced, but nothing stands out. Brewed for the masses, beer knurds should look elsewhere for flavor. Might be a good gateway beer. All that said, it is brewed skillfully and without flaws, and is a pretty reddish brown in the pint glass. -- rated with beerbasher/winphone

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Limerick Irish Red
column5: Draught at CAH under the name "Ale House Red." Pours a clear brown color with a slight red tinge. Nose is almost nonexistent. Taste has a bit of grains to it. Meh.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Limerick Irish Red
column5: Right to style. Dark orange to brown and clear. Thin tan head. Slightly sweet malty nose. Smooth medium bodied nutty bit sweet. Nails the style ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Limerick Irish Red
column5: This was a decent irish red but nothing special, slight hop flavor with a heavy malt backbone.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Limerick Irish Red
column5: Drank from the tap at the Galway Hooker Bar in Lake Norman, NC. Ruby red pour with a thin white head. Light aroma of sweet malts. Taste is dry, bready and thin.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Limerick Irish Red
column5: 6/9/10. On tap in the Charlotte airport. Orange-red pour. Generic malty beer aroma. The flavor is bread, crackers, some dry malts, and not much else. Not as bad as the brown, but not awesome.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Limerick Irish Red
column5: 12 oz bottle from a coworkers beer of the month club. Poured a thin rust colored body with a tiny foamy whtie head. Aroma of sweet wet grains, caramel, toffee and maybe even a touch of raisin. The body is far to thin and watery with a light touch of carbonation. Flavor of super soggy grains, wet grass, rotting caramel. Blah.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Limerick Irish Red
column5: Draft� This beer rocks!... Clear copper ale with a small, creamy, white head. Great, long-lasting retention. The aroma is simple, but fantastically malty � pure caramel and toasted malt. Medium-bodied with sparkling carbonation. The flavor is a direct reflection of the nose � sweet caramel and toasted malt with just enough bitterness to prevent sickly sweetness. Crisp, but malty, finish. Just the way I like it. This brew is just plain getting� it done for me. Can�t get enough. Reminiscent of the now-retired Lake Tahoe Crystal Bay Red Ale - RIP. Underrated... although I AM drinking this fresh; from clean draft line; and close to the source. Regardless, HUGE drinkability. World class malt bomb!

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Limerick Irish Red
column5: Red/amber pour into Sprecher pint glass. Faint aroma of caramel and roasted malts. A medium body with some bisquit in the flavor and a faint bitterness. A smokey roasted finish. Easy drinking.

Aromat winny troch� korzenny i takie orzechy w�oskie Klarowne miodowy kolor. Smak s�odki z lekkim orzechowym posmakiem Du�a pe�nia do�� du�o cia�a, du�a miodno��, lepkie, grube ci�kie og�lnie jak p�torak bardzo s�odkie

Barwa miedziowa, klarowne, aromat jest bogaty - suszone owoce, mi�d, zbutwia�e drewno, wi�nie, kwiaty, lekki alkohol. W smaku s�odkie, stosunkowo pe�ne, ponownie pojawia si� zbutwia�e drewno, suszone owoce, nieco kwa�no�ci, miodu. Bardzo dobre, zdradliwe
Bottle@Jespers - Reddish amber pour with no head. Sweet with notes of caramel and honey, berry fruity notes, herbal and floral notes, spices into the finish. Gorgeous.
Sample from 75 cl bottle. Clear amber golden colour. Sweet aroma with honey, fruits. Taste is sweet. Full bodied. Lasting sweet finish. Lovely.
Sample from a bottle.A clar amber coloured beer without a head. Aroma and flavour of alcohol, honey, spice and sweetness.

Aged light Amber slight pink hues. Aromas aged honey, wood, raspberries, jam slight alcohol, toffee, caramel. Flavors raspberry jam, aged honey, wood, cork, slight alcohol in nose, toffee. Highly sweet like liquid jelly alcohol mostly in nose. Good aged stuff.
Bottle. Clear amber. Sweet, honey, dark fruits, berries, floral, alcohol. Full-bodied, viscous, sticky. Good.
Can. A golden beer with no head. The aroma has notes of malt as well as a touch of straw. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and straw, leading to a lightly bitter finish.

Can 50 cl. Courtesy of MiP. Pours a clear yellow with an off-white head. Sweetish aroma of malt and brewing cereal. Medium-bodied, a little low in carbonation, fairly sweet malts and brewing cereal. No bitterness. 040409

Can 50cl. Clear light to medium yellow color with a small, fizzy, virtually none lacing, fully diminishing, white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, toasted, apple, papper, sugar. Flavor is light to moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20090404]
Can, 7.0% Yeasty aroma, slightly estery. Clear golden colour. Very small white head. The flavour is a little sweet, but not peppery as expected. More estery and yeasty, which is not too unpleasant.
50 cL can. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Dry grassy and slight chemical aroma. Sweet syrupy malt flavoured, cornish. Light bitterness coming through into the finish.

Rated: 29.07.2007 Can, 500 ml, 14.1 P Appearance: Initially head is fizzy, off-white, yellowish, no lacing, medium and very quickly disappearing, what lasts is only a grey ring around the walls of glass. Body is light amber, rather weak but still keeping the average level as for an Eurpoean Strong Lager. Body is clear, gently sparkling. Aroma: Apple juice, cheap plonk from apples, very weak aroma of honey, sweet, friuty, rotten apple, a hint of alcoholic nose and rotten wine grapes, form the aroma water seem to be of good quality but very heavy aroma. The warmer the beer is heavier and harder to nose, the beer is. Quite intensive aroma and like if the beer would be sweet with added extra sugar. Feaces and excrements are felt like from garden dump wase !!! Compost note is very considerable noticeable. Flavour: Makes your skin shiver and is all in all repulsive. Front is harsh alcoholic ans sweet (artificial sugar makes your mouth dry and parched). Your breath becomes skunky, after two or three small sips you can feel like having a strong hangover and being totally wasted. Flavuor of gone off, too fat sausage and old grease from whale or polar bear that is printed on the front of the can, very heavy, nasty body of the plonk is felt in your stomach like something undrinkable at all, motoroil I guess. I�ve vomited after 2 sips and after smelling this beer. Really! Toxic waste! Don�t aproach it! This is my third beer of that brewery and I am sure that they have real problems with brewing tehinques. Old, sweaty, greasy fur of a dog. Old oil, rape on your stomach. It tastes if somebody spit a loggie inside the glass. Plonk mixture of water and spirit! Palate: Body is medium, texture is wattery, oily, carbonation is rather flat. Finish feel is terrible, hangover, harsh alcoholic. I finally manage to drink the whole of it. Thank God it�s over.

Bottle. Pours a particulate filled golden with disapearing white head. Aroma is of light caramel and lightly malty and buttery. Flavor is malty, buttery, and has a slight bitterness with a hint of hop oil. Medium bodied and fairly flat, this has a smoky and dry finish. Actually, very smoky. Not too bad considering the last two beers I�ve drunk from that same shelf at the liquor store.
Canned. Deep golden colour. Frothy head. Papery, almondy aroma. Bock-like flavour with sweet maltiness and almond suggestions. Low on the hops. Medium bodied.

Bottle. Pours a clear gold with hundreds of small particles surmounted by a thin white head. Sweet caramel with a touch of buttered popcorn in the aroma and taste, along with some vaguely herbal hops in there somewhere. Not a beer I�d buy again on purpose.

No: 363 Pale yellow colour of the body, weak carbonation, mediocre white head, aroma is of sour, out of date barley and sourkraut, strong accidity mixed with rubber notes. Nasty and repulsive extremelly accidic, artificial flavour. I shared a can with Chmurarz and we weren�t able to drink the whole of it. Impression of raw rubber glue on palate. Yukkk...
Bottled (BB 08/2005) Golden color, small white head. Mineral, malty nose. Malty, minerally but plain. Some diacetyl. Malty finish. Hides ABV quite well, but that�s all.

column4: Genesee Brewing Company (Cervecer�a Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Intriged by the idea of a dark light I tried it. Fizzy, limp amber with no head and no depth. It was fine, but way past my price point. There is NO WAY I�ll pay $6 for a sixer of this.

column4: Genesee Brewing Company (Cervecer�a Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: (bottle - 12 oz) Another one of those beers that I didn�t think was still being produced. Light amber color with a decent amount of fizzy white head. Aroma is a mix of malts, dry hops, boiled cabbage and sweat. Kind of heavy smelling. The taste began alright with a decent malt and hop taste but then the middle of it was kind of sweaty and greasy tasting. Very odd to explain, but it didn�t taste all that great. Kind of dry and a little bit sour with some malts near the end. Pass.

column4: Genesee Brewing Company (Cervecer�a Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Kudos for looking marginally like a good beer and the malty palate. But too light overall with not enough going on.

column4: Genesee Brewing Company (Cervecer�a Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Large amount of foam that did not stay long. Color was a trasparent brown/amber. Flavor of some hops with corn and malt. Smooth and very drinkable. Even though it�s dark, it�s still a thin light beer. Better than most lights.

column4: Genesee Brewing Company (Cervecer�a Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: nez:discret peut etre un peut malte gout:legerement sucre beurre un peut. Rondeur tres peut perseptible.

column4: Genesee Brewing Company (Cervecer�a Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: easy to drink, i could see drinking 12 or so at a time no problem, light but with superb flavor, very smooth yet dark, unique.

column4: Genesee Brewing Company (Cervecer�a Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Light amber in color with a small white head.Hop and malt balance,but the hops are stale and lingering.The finish is very boring,nothing impressive.

column4: Genesee Brewing Company (Cervecer�a Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Clear orange color with a virtually nonexistent head. Stale plastically aroma with hints of cardboard, thick but not good mouthfeel, sweet in a bad way in the ending.

column4: Genesee Brewing Company (Cervecer�a Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Dark orange, almost red, deep for a light, medium quick-dying head. Nose very light, corny-sweet, inoffensive. Flavor/body buttery-smooth, maybe butterscotchy, but fairly bland; again, corn. No hops whatsoever. Above average for style.

column4: Genesee Brewing Company (Cervecer�a Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Amber color. Lighter aroma of some wierd hops, maybe corn. Flavor was syrupy and finished with this odd roasty and grainy flavor. Good for a light, but it is still a light.

Growler from the brewery. Apparently just a one-off this year, named "Barrel Roll Maibock" (slightly different title than above). Pours a golden/yellow with minimal head. Smells malty, with some straw/hay notes. Definitely some malt in the taste as well. Very smooth - this batch was listed at 7.2%+ ABV and you definitely don�t taste the alcohol content.
On tap at Coles, Buffalo NY. Pours a medium orange gold. Taste& aroma is fruity malts, caramel. Decent mouthfeel. Not bad
Draft at Laughlin�s. Poured light orange with a beige head. Malty aroma with a bit of caramel. Medium body. Flavor is similar to the aroma with maybe a hint of bread. Nice.
My favorite so far from Flying Bison. Great flavor that leaves you wanting more after each sip.

Tim hit a home run again. Recieved a growler full fresh from the brewery. Not much aroma, what is ther is a light spicy malt. Georgous light ruby hue. thin wispy head that cliongs nicely to the glass bu dissapates quickly, deep malt flavor wiht a touch of hop spicyness creeping in on the back of the palate. Just a touch on the thin side, but other wise a very good brew.

Which bock? Brewmaster said it�s been on since October. There certainly is no maibock called maibock. Even owner at annual Raceway brewfest could not describe it. Looked like a dopplebock, brown but with a thin head.

In a growler from the brewery. The color is a dark golden amber and the smell is dominated by a carmel tone. Sweet malts and more light carmel occupy the beer�s taste and there is also a nice bit of hops in it. A very good lager. A little flat but that could just be the growler. I will defenitly be filling my growler with this brew again.

Growler from Premier. I guess this was an old growler but it was chilled in the fridge so the age wasnt real noticable. Pours a clear deep gold/light amber with a nice fluffy white head and good lace. Aroma is light skunked hops, herbal and spicy upfront with a muted sweet malt background. Flavor was a little off- slightly harsh and skunked metallic hops with a light malt profile. Needs more malt presence and a sharp light munich bite to it. Ok, but I couldnt really finish the growler.

Draught pint at Cambridge Common on 4/29/06 Medium-high clarity in this deeply blonde beer, with some lightly baked straw notes and a hint of amber. White head is lightly creamy, medium in size and quite well retained for a draught beer, providing spotty lacing. Some sweaty hay, table sugar, and mildly spicy phenols (white pepper-like) are note initially in the nose, the pale malts coming off light, but fluffy, while the dry, hay-like hops add some complexity. Pepperiness on end nips at the nostrils, not too strongly and helps keep things in balance. Not really much in the way of heavy yeastiness or munich sourness (though there is a touch of light breadiness), more of a strong munich helles (but I guess that�s essentially what a blonde bock is, and who�s to say they need to use a large amount of munich malt). Some light creamy sweetness emerges as it warms, and the hops become a touch more crisp, still staying dry and straw/hay-like. Bits of fruit rise up as well, apricots, yellow-cherries and nectarines. Were it not for the crisp, clean yeast on the end (in the flavor) it would almost seem more like an ale yeast fermented at low temps. The flavor is spicy again, leading to an almost perceived roastiness, though it quickly sinks in to the creamy, honey-rich maltiness, not heavily thick, but definitely notable of a long boil, with some preliminary caramel notes. Soft, moderate to low carbonation is not intrusive, but helps mitigate the sweetness. Light bock-like melanoidins and a touch of sourness, but it�s a very easygoing bock. Phenols are a touch heavy on the finish, as it warms, combining with some dry breadiness, and it begins to overpower the malt, but the carbonation helps keep things fairly well cleansed. I didn�t note any alcohol in aroma or flavor.

Tap at Coles. Poured a clear light brown/copper color with a small bubbly head. Caramel, cherry aroma. Sweet, earthy chocolate flavors. Some good caramel and sugary hints. A lighter bodied, lightly malted bock than I expected but still a solid beer.
A special beer brewed for indoor football that has been kept as a secondary offering. Looks and tastes like rootbeer. Soapy suds. Very easy drinkable
Brown color, big tan head. Nutty aroma, some malt as well. Flavor was kind of earthy, a little nutty. A little thin. Decent.

The Destroyers are the local arena football team. I have to admit I never understood that sport. Light caramelly brown colour. Nutty aroma with wood notes. Watery body (I was warned this was a Newcastle clone). Hints of nuts, fruit.

Lightly hazed pumpkin shade. Quick, off white foam. Subtle aroma of hazelnut overtones, faintly hayish tinge, soft, spicy hops, caramel, raw malt toastiness, apple, and estery yeast flares. Gently carbonated, round mouthfeel. Moderately acidic flavors are proceeded my earthy flavors, Northern Brewer/Styrian-like round juiciness, walnut skin, and plum-like graininess. Finishes with a trace of yam, pale malt (most likely Munich), and cracker. Overall, too acidic and lacking the proper malt depth. Still, a noteworthy, locally produced Maibock.

Black with brown edges. Soft texture. Curious sourness. Sweet chocolate, toast, mild roast. Lightly burnt finish. Mildish bitterness. Sourish finish. Not a bad stout, but not overly exciting. Nevertheless, enjoyable and easy-to-drink.

Draught. Body is dark brown to black. Aroma is lightly malty (caramel, chocolate, roasted grain), lightly hoppy (grapefruit). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Light to medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation.
Rather thick, partially lasting head. Not thin, strong malt flavour, unfortunately acidic. An average Polish strong.
Nice head, malty aftertaste & good body. Could be less foam in the head. good with foods. Polish breww that needs to be marketed more.
Dark even for strong lager , white thick foam . Fairly light aroma ,not much there . Drinkable for its strength.
Fruity with softer hops . Impresive looking , true head , great lacing . Less sweet than most Polish pilsners , got more hops (lublin) . Medium body .
Pours a murky yellow on tap with minimal head or lace. Aroma of big wheat hefe esters, banana, spice. Taste follows, big esters, mild malt, minimal carb. Meh.

Name: Spring Wheat Hefe Weizen Date: 04/27/2008 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: hazy light orange, fine white head, bits of lace, Aroma: light sweet banana aroma with a hint of clove, Body: creamy body, Flavor: light wheat flavor, nice banana candy sweetness, hint of clove, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.1/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **/4
poured from growler into tulip. good stuff. pours a clear golden yellow with full fluffy white head, fruity aroma, fruity wheat thruougt, good, and impressive.

On draught at the brewpub and served with a floating lemon wedge. A dense yellowish gold color and light body. A slight citrusy character and pronounced wheat flavor, well-carbonated, but little banana character and only a slight hint of clove.

Unfiltered yellow, good head, and light body. Citrus, banana, spices, and wheat aroma. Lemony and hoppy on the palate. Clean aftertaste. A very good version of the Hefeweizen. Recommend during those summer nights in hotatlanta. **My only knock on this beer was the fact that the staff adds lemon wedge into the beer without asking first.**
A yellow beer with no head and no aroma. The flavor is slightly bitter and slightly sweet. A good balanced but below average beer.
From bottle. Transfer of an earlier rating without text recorded, rating only.
Clear golden colour with quick fading head. Has a certain skunky aroma which for me is generally a plus with lagers. Flavour has some corn and cardboard.

330 ml. bottle sampled @ home. BBF 25.11.2016. Sparkling clear industrial, looks suited for a commercial, industrial white head that is quickly gone. Smell is overly sweet cooked vegetables, vegetable oil, sweet plastic, nasty, industrial,� Taste is plaster, cooked vegetables, massive vegetable oil, corn, oily stale grains, faint cooking oil bitterness, grains. Watery industrial body. Cheap industrial affair, not good but not that terrible either. I wonder where they export this one to, ingredients are listed only in Dutch & French. Fine I suppose if you are looking to drinks some very cheap pale lager.
Bottle 0,33 ltr: Clear golden colored brew with an adequate sweet bitter taste. Another remnant of an InBev hostile takeover brand.

33cl bottle at home in the early hours of 7th Dec 2015. Light golden body, bright and clear: on top a deep white head. Almost odourless, maybe a grain/malt ester or two. Taste is leaning towards sweetness with a malty lead, but not much going on really. Bog standard European Lager/Pilsner: refreshing but lacking character or real flavour. I wonder where they export this beer too? I bought mine in Belgium.

Bottle at JH Ekseekwo. As an alternative to the Jupiler Crap I've been drinking all night. Too bad this is even worse. Smells like dog piss, drinks like a sugared version of Jupiler. Truly horrendous. People in this place seem to think it's cool to drink this, because it's something else but obviously they have no clue whatsoever.

33cl bottles on repeated unguarded instances in Meetjesland watering holes, plus consciously at Biermuseum, Ertvelde 2013. As remarked below, this "etikettenbier"/commissioned beer�s primary function is regional nostalgia for a now defunct brewery, and with it, the whole style of the (Belgian) Export, a once popular German import. Beneath the 70s label is: a none too clean, none too flavourful grain-amped and possibly corn/mais/rice-aided lager, which settles for tired cardboard-sweet malts carrying generic grassy hop bitterness stopping miles short of BE-pils bitter. Sticky edges, metallic body. A bit of a regional joke by InBev, though not too offensive to the non-sensitive palate.
33 cl bottle at home. Drank on January 2nd 2015 as Kr�ger Export Beer (4,8%).

One of those remnants of the Interbrew era, when local brands were bought only to keep them artificially alive in order to keep their faithful audience paying for them. This was, and is still, very popular in Eeklo, where the original brewery, which also produced stout among other beers, was located. It is an �export� in the Belgian sense of the word: standard lager in bottles of 33 cl. The beer itself is okay, with sweet pale malts, light golden colour and stable snow white head, and grassy hops in the finish; but it is still a boring mass-produced pale lager.
Mijn favoriete bier om door te drinken. Het zit grotendeels tussen de oren, daarvan ben ik mij bewust.

column1: Chumleys Wing And A Prayer Wheat
column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: Tap @ Chumleys. Blonde color with a thin white head. MIldly hoppy with not very much wheat or yeast in the flavor. Watery without the chewy palate of typical wheat beers. I could do this as a session beer, but I�d rather drink something better.

column1: Chumleys Wing And A Prayer Wheat
column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: WOW I just foudn this rating from back in December! Had this at Chumleys in the village. not very strong flavors, and VERY thin for a wheat brew... i was not impressed. no fruity flavors really. thin look, not cloudy like i expect from a wheat, with thin lacy head. i am making a weird face remembering it.

column1: Chumleys Wing And A Prayer Wheat
column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: Draught at Chumley�s, West Village, New York. Blond weisse style beers with a lacy white head. This beer lacks many of the strong sharp features of its European forbearers but is easy drinking. Served slightly too cold but still plenty drinkable.

column1: Chumleys Wing And A Prayer Wheat
column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: A rather metallic wheat lacking in wheatiness. Surprisingly hoppy and slightly dry. A huge disappointment. Contract-brewed by Chelsea Brewing.

column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: Hokay last of the list I found from eons ago. This was REAL thin (seems to be an attribute of this brewer) and was almost like swillin. didnt expect THAT when i paid $5 for a tiny ass glass... well, whatev...

column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: Just terrible. A Budweiser clone. Fizzy and replicating the oft-maligned American Standard style. Avoid.

column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: So I've just realized that I live pretty close to Chumley's and I had a hunch that their beer would be unremarkable since people go for Chumley's history and atmosphere, not its beer.The Sunrise Rye was more refreshing and less hoppy than the Wing and a Prayer Wheat. Slightly sweet and oddly fruity (just a touch). Best of the lousy beers I've tried at Chumley's today.

column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: As I sit in this 1920's-era former speakeasy, I feel charitable. So generous is my mood, I can almost forgive this Godawful beer I'm drinking. If it didn't say Blackberry on the tap, I'm not sure I'd really believe it has any fruit in it whatsoever. There's barely a whiff of berry and virtually no taste. Copper-colored.

Poured into a snifter, the appearance was a dark brown color with a foamy eggshell white colored head. Nice speckled lace. The aroma had some caramel and roasted malts, touch of sugar. The flavor was basically the same with some burnt toast to it. Sweet malty to almost sugary aftertaste. Quick sweet finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fair sessionability about it. Low carbonation. Pretty smooth along my tongue. ABV felt appropriate. Overall, I can see it as suggested by the brewer, but did it really come together as expected? In my opinion, not as much. It wasn�t bad, it just seemed to lean sweeter than I had hoped for.

Sampled at Big Brew Beer Festival (Morristown). Poured a dark brown color with a foamy khaki colored head. Aroma or caramel and roasted malts. Taste was the same, with a bit of burnt toast in the finish.
THis is a drinkable porter. I found it to have good balanced flavors, but it is a bit thin and the after taste is lacking. I could drink this, but I probably will not buy it again.

12 oz bottle. Pours dark brown with a 1/2" tan head. Minimal lace. Subtle chocolate and coffee aroma. Smooth, soft palate with little carbonation. Goes down like silk. Flavor is chocolate with roasted malt with a hint of coffee. Maybe a little hop in the finish. Nice, solid porter.

Sampled at High Street Grill Winter Beer Fest. Very nice porter to say the least. Pours black with a tan head. Full bodied with a nicely roasted malt, coffee flavor. Finishes very refreshing for the style. A pub I got to get to soon.
On tap at Rattle n Hum. Pretty tart for a porter, without much smoke or coffee flavor. Could this have been a little bit off? It was still a good pint.
Novare Res Portland ME. Draught. Decent but lacking in head retention. maybe its their lines? Decent porter but not earth shattering
good bu tnot great...black and a little mediciny...not a heavy pour...sweet and thick...
Black with a long lasting sandy head. Smells of paint. Tastes like roasted chocolate and cough syrup. Didn�t enjoy this too much. Sampled on tap at Perly�s Bakery in Easton, PA.

On-tap at the Publick House 8-07. Pours pitch black. Tan head. Malty nose with coffee tones. Flavor is heavy on coffee. Thick malts. Feel has a good carbonation and a nice thick liquid feel. Very drinkable. A nice hearty and robust brew. Well worth a try and pretty damn good as well.
It starts off tasting okay but leaves a lingering aftertaste of syrup that makes the whole thing taste artificial. Definitely not worth it, even for the cheap price.
Bottle. Blackish beer with a brown head. Chocolate and light roast aroma. Chocolate and coffee flavor with roast. Medium bodied. Chocolate and coffee linger with roast and light fruitiness.
Black with thin tan head. Aroma has toffee and sweet malt. Taste is sweet, malty and a little creamy. Has a little vanilla. Ok considering the price but kind of dull.

Pours near black with a tiny beige head. Aroma has roasted malts, molasses, hints of cocoa, and dark fruit. Taste is heavy in molasses with some decent toasty notes. Too sweet and syrupy for a stout. Wish it had more coffee bitterness. Would not buy again.

Too basic, very one note. Can do a lot better in the stout realm. Doesn't matter if you only spend $1.09 per bottle. This should be for large parties only. Not worth drinking on your own. Aroma is malty and enticing. Appearance is near black and does look appealing. Medium tan head. Taste is initially sweet malt that gives way to a one-note sourness all too quickly and that's all that is left. Not a great flavor to end on. Makes you want to take another swig so the aftertaste goes away.

Pours dark brown, almost black with a fluffy creme colored head. Aroma of dry malt. Initial taste is of toasted malt with smoked influences as it moves along the tongue. Palate is dominated by dry malt with a dry rice/malt element on the back of the tongue. Pretty good.
Nice unassuming stout, light chocolate, roasty, coffee aroma and flavor. Rounded mouthfeel. Okay beer.
bottled - very dark, almost black appearance. Sweet roasted chocolate aroma. Decent sweet chocolatey stout flavor.

12 oz bottle from Trader Joe�s, poured into a pint glass. Black pour with a khaki head, long lasting lacing. Mild roast and coffee with a little chocolate, some dark fruit and a hint of molasses. Medium body, would recommend to friends!

A steady poor produces a three-finger thick, light brown tinged, dark tan colored head. The beer is a rich dark chocolate color that shows a brilliantly clear, gem toned Brown color when held up to the light. The aroma smells of toasted whole grain, brown bread with a bit of a roasted Edge to it. There is a touch of burnt fruit underneath as well, and also a brown malt caramelized character. The body has a solid viscous texture to it that gives us beer a medium mouthfeel that is not heavy, but is still nicely chewy. Sweet dark malt flavors are balanced by a burnt and roasted grain character that lingers in a long finish. Flavors of cocoa, milk chocolate, and rounded, lightly roasted, smooth coffee also play a prominent role here. There is a burnt bitterness to the Finish, which also helps to nicely balanced the soft dark malt sweetness that is found here. There is a soft buttery note here that melts in well with the dark chocolate and dark malt character. This is a really nice beer, especially for the price. I think this may become a regular thing that is stocked in my beer fridge for when I want something chewy and roasted.

Cask, gravity at The Pig �n� Falcon, Cambridgeshire. Dark brown. Leafy hop aroma. Grapefruity taste with a curious hint of match head. Mid bitter finish. Not particularly kaleidoscopic, but quite quirky and enjoyable.

Cask, The Tap, peterborough. Deep ruby haloed with white. Sweaty alpha nose dusted with coffee and signature grapefruit hoppage. Lingering husky bitterness mingling with subtle coffee, choc and faint dankness splashes. Splinter of rummy cask wood, quite aggresive hop punchiness again, hint of strawberry. Soapy grower balanced out nicely with chocolate and nuts, and a more complex malt profile than is typical from Oakham.

Cask (Pullman, Helsinki) More an Old Ale than an ESB. Dark brown, thin head. Mellow dark malts and fruits in the aroma, but with a reasonable hoppy bent too. Taste matches that, full bodied, woody and fruity. Yet another classic from Oakham.

Cask, Leicester Fest 06. Dark brown with big bubbles. Aromas are very herbal with sweet spices, ginger and aniseed. Flavours are herbal and spicy with lots of bitterness following. Quite floral and earth in its hopping. Root vegetables and tea notes are also present. Dry and bitter on the finish. Pretty good.

1. Cask Stillage at the Formby Hall, Atherton 30/01/2003 Copper mid brown coloured with a hint of ginger. Slightly dry finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich (JDW) 10/02/2004 Mid brown coloured with some sour fruit flavour. Citrus aroma. Bitter lasting dry malt finish.

Hand pulled at the Bartons Arms, Birmingham. Copper coloured, with a loosely frothed head. Nice deep, boiled hop aroma, which carries through into the taste. A rich flavour, mouth-filling and lengthy. Crisp hops, wrapped in soft veg and sweetness. A hard edge too with a deal of bitterness. Boring to say, but it�s another excellent beer from Oakham.
Cask @ Angleterre, Helsinki Finland Backlog 1 April, 2005 Mahogany colour. Chocolate and dark fruits in aroma as well as taste. Reliable bitter aftertaste.
Cask Conditioned at The Brewery Tap, Peterborough, Cambs. Brown Amber beer with solid had. Perfumey aroma with light sweet hop and deep malty body, succulent and easy drinking. Rich fruity finish.
Cask Conditioned & straight from the barrel (gravity) at The Dolphin (beer fest) in Derby on 23/02/04. Dark amber brown colour. Quite fruity & malty, dry-ish. A bit of a fizz to it.
Cask (gravity) at Olde Dolphin (Derby)Heavyweight Beer Festival 2005. Deep reddish-brown, dry hopped aroma and strong hop tingle in the mouth, wash of dark fruits and malt in the finish.
A rather mild interpretation of an IPA. Low bitterness for the style, using Bullion hops. Needs more oomph!

Cask. Brewer's description: "...clean..." uh huh, it's so clean it's cleaned out. The smell is VERY slightly malty, the taste is MILDLY malty - and that's it. Not even the usual amount of filler malt that I always complain about. Doubtful that this brew has had any sort of hop waved in its direction either. Waste of money, time, taste buds. It's like drinking ghosts. Not even a beer for teenage trainee drinkers. Edit: finished the pint, is there any way to score it sub-zero? Awarded Winner, Most Pathetic Brew of the Year.

500ml bottle from Barley Mow�s taken in the van at Ilminster. Solid rustic gold, if a notch over-fizzed. Veiled with a huge rocky bloom of suds. Tenacious, too. Backbone of clean toasty pale malt with a linger of unsalted peanut. Grassy and noncommittal citrus over the top. Aroma of lemon sherbets and green herb citrus.

Half pint, cask at Mermaid. Filmy layer, clingy lacing, near clear golden-brown body. Ripe fruity nose, mid-sweet. Taste of ripe fruits with banana sweetness. Rounded mid-sweet ending. Easy to drink. Quite alright. (Shared with Finn, St Albans 27.09.2018).

Cask at the Bell, Waltham St Lawrence. An attractive pale amber pour with a tight white head; floral aroma; dry floral taste with a lasting herbal bitterness. A straightforward, very drinkable blonde ale, showing that good summer beers don't have to taste of citrus.
Cask (5%), 1/2 pint by hand-pump at The Bon Accord, Glasgow on 24 May 2018: caramel, grain aroma and flavour, golden, good white head, irregular lacing, creamy.

Pint on cask at the Halfway House, Pitney, Somerset. Pours clear golden, white head with lacing. Aroma: pale malts, hint of lemon. Taste: light sweet, sweet malts, floral hop, touch of honey. Light body, soft carb, light semi dry finish.

Bottle at The Shed, Seaton. Huge aroma of apple cider (appley) with decent appearance, fitting profile for the area. Taste is of apple cider and a slight malt vinegar. Palate is a but pub floor but very quaffable. Really enjoyed this one, very fresh! 8-4-7-3-15 Bottle at home from shop in Beer. Same as above with slightly fresher palate but more see through and less special (occasion I suppose). 8-5-6-3-14

Bottle from Woods Village Store, Colaton Raleigh. Amber with a small glow and a very thin head. Has a surprisingly light drinking texture for its strength, almost (but not quite) thin tasting, with a pleasant fruitiness in both aroma and taste.

Sampled from a bottle purchased at Dunster Deli. Hazy golden colour with a thin white head. Rather undercarbonated. Aroma of ripe banana, surprisingly. Taste is of malt, ripe banana, mango and peach. Is wheat used in this brew? Certainly tastes like it. Very nice, but a little thin considering the ABV of 5%.
Bottle. Golden with a small head.Some hops with a gentle spiciness Distinct lack of body is a downside especially considering its reasonable strength. Bit of a let down..
Honey, sweet aroma. Pilsenerlooks, bit darker; clear golden/yellow coloured. diminishing head. Taste is sweet, watery, hoppy and some fruits. Soft bitter palate.
Average beer when chilled, but warms up very quick and ruins the whole drink. The drink had quite a bitter taste and was made worse with it being warm. Very basic beer again.

column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: This beer is immensely mild and forgettable. I wish I'd had it side-by-side with Chumley's Labrador Lager so I could see which was blander and more Bud-like. Very little malt flavor, and reminiscent of a light beer. It's only saving grace is that it's not overcarbonated.

column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: On tap at the restaurant. Great, interesting, historic location. Beer itself was a pretty straight forward bitter. Didn�t offend, and complemented the burger nicely.

column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: Draught at the brewpub Amber color. Light caramel aroma. Some flavor of caramel and toffee and butter. Ordinary.

column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: Bottled, at Chumley�s, NY. Crystal clear amber colour with an attractive lacy bone head. A little thin an not as bitter as I�m used to in the UK.

column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: Like a bulldog, this "bitter" took a bite out of my esophagus with its strong hop body and penetrating wallop of bitterness. More like an IPA, really. Oh yeah, decent head with a copper body, but who really cares about that stuff.

column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: Draught at the brewpub Amber color; thin head. The aroma shows some good malt and hop. Some malt taste, a bit weak, a lot of caramel and a strong hopping, partially aromatic and resiny.

column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: Lacy head with sour smell, REALLLY thin, and not much flavor. easy to drink but not as enjoyable as it should have been

column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: Draught, at the Chumley�s, NY. Amber with a reddish hue. Decent lacy head. Rather sharp & cold. Not so much body, flavour or aroma as we�ve been having but drinkable. Thin but drinkable is the final consensus.

column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: Perhaps one's best choice when sitting in Chumley's is to order a pint o' the Drennan's Red (a better alternative is leaving altogether and walking three blocks to the Blind Tiger Ale House, but let's assume you're unable to leave because you've broken a leg skiing or you can't find the door in this hidden, remote 1920s speakeasy). Anyway, the Red is a decent amber ale with considerably more malt than their Bulldog Bitter and less hoppiness. That makes it a slightly underhopped amber with much more chocolate undertones than you might expect.

column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: Draught a hell of a long time ago, but like everybody else said, this was a thin stout and nothing special, but you were drinking it at Chumley�s, which was an incredibly special spot.

column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: Blackish brown pour. Nitro head. Nitro taste and aromas. Silky nose...at first. slightly sweet with a pungent tart sourness. This then turns into nothing but water. Nothing but water. Nothing else. Chalkiness. Flavors are immediately tart and sour, not much sweetness, maybe some in a cane sugar sort of way but nothing in the way of roasty sweetness. Dry chalkiness and then water. Silky again and then nothing but water. Pretty thin beer.Looks great though.

column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: big thanks to Connie and Michelle for introducing me to this place - - it�s a real speakeasy in Greenwich Village from the prohibition era - there�s not even a sign in front of the bar!! black opaque body, dark tan thin & short foamy head. edges are lighter brown in color. aroma is roasted malt and a little nutty, flavor is light but not too watery. starts roasted malt but has some caramel malt in the middle, then gets roasty again in the finish.

column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: Draught, at the Chumley�s, NY. A secret little nook that Austinpowers showed me. Black with a good tan/brown head. Lovely dark aniseed aroma with good length. Not dry but equally not creamy, wet or insipid either. I good drop this. In fact on New Years day this was the preferred beer of choice to smooth away the previous pain.

column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: After drinking a pint of this heavy brew, what felt like iron was my stomach when it came time to actually stand up and search for the door of this cramped, West Village bar-with-no-sign before bars with no signs became trendy in Manhattan. The stout is quite thick and somewhat roasty in a chocolate malt way and you've got to respect Chelsea Brewing, which contract brews all of Chumley's beers, for not skimping on the ingredients with this stout.
Golden color, with good foam. Nose. Malt, grass a little hay. Taste. Malt, light sweet aftertaste herbal Hop bitterness.
