500ml bottle share in 2016. Clear mid golden with a fluffy white head. Aroma of lychee, lager malt and straw. Flavour is typical helles. Not bad.
Clear golden colour, white foam. Bready, sweet malts, light bitter finish. Classic Helles, easy drinkable. Ok.
bottle bb29/1/20 dorata limoida buona schiuma discreto cereale morbida anche abbastanza secca amaro contenuto lieve erbaceo

Bottle picked up from Rewe Getr�nkemarkt, Zolling and consumed at home Attenkirchen, Bavaria. *Note abv as Garrold mentions is 5.2%. Pours gold with a good clarity, looks great, large rapidly diminishing white head. Typical nose, also hints at a sweetness to follow. Malty and with a lasting sweetness, bitterness is subtle, a touch of citrus, some grassy hops, good but could be a little more defined.
500ml bottle at home, Munich. Courtesy of Eva-Maria. Aroma ist light malt. Appearance is clear golden with a small white foam. Taste is light sweet and light to medium bitter. Soft carbonation. Good.

Bottle. Mitchell�s Wines, Sheffield. 5.2%. Clear, pale gold. Thin and fairly dense, white head. Nose has corn syrup. Some lemon. White bread. Taste is bready sweet. Minimal bitterness. Medium body. A tad sticky and cloying. Moderate carbonation. Sweet finish.

Ein ordentlich, s�ffiges Bier aus Bayern. Es �berzeugt durch eine Malzigkeit, welche nicht s�� ist und eine gut komponierte, frische S�ffigkeit hervorruft. Ein klassisches BIer, das nicht umsonst eine so lange Tradition hat.
Bottle. Pours clear pale golden with a white head. Aroma of heavy grainy, grassy, citrus, a bit earthy. Taste is sweet, light bitter loads of corn and grains, noble hops and grass, quite peppery,
bread, hay, grass, spruce, dough, leaves, golden, clear, sparkling, frothy, white foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, thin feel, creamy, lively, bitter, abrupt finish,
500ml bottle in 2012. Lightly hazy golden with a white head. Aroma of citrus, grassy hops and dried fruit. Malty sweetness mixed with more assertive bitter hop flavours.
Bottle from Crafty bottle, Lincoln. Hazy golden colour with a thin nothingy head. Aroma has malty caramel and slight floral. taste light sweet. Light grassy body.
Bottle. Pale Amber in colour. Hoppy; grassy hops. Fruity; citrus grapefruit and lemon. Malty; pale malts. Bitter citrus fruity hoppy throughout. Dry bitter hoppy finish. Drinkable. (2010-08)

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Appearance - golden with a nice fluffy head. Nose - odd base earthy savoury note. Like fish sauce or something. Lemon too. Taste - dried lemon and more savoury food notes. Almost a bit of fertiliser going on too. Palate - close to medium bodied with a tangy texture and a long dry tangy finish. Overall - it�s got a lot of intensity for 4.5% but not sure I like the flavour.

Bottle shared with Ashton McCobb. From Beers of Europe. Pours clear golden yellow with a thin white head. Aromas of earthy lemon, something savoury, marshland. Taste is bitter lemon, soapy lemon. Flavourful, but not in a good way.
on tap Oro leggero velato discreta schiuma media persistenza lieve note citriche discreto amaro lieve cereale

500ml Bottle: unknown BBD, poured at home on 19th June 2014 into an Abbot Ale glass tankard. Slight haze to the light golden body, full white head and carbonation bubbles rising from the off. Mild hop nose, otherwise odourless. Dry, hoppy, bitter and refreshing. Pleased to say there was no citrus flavours, aromas or feel within this beer.

Appearance: Clear amber with finger thick white head. Aroma: Citrus, biscuit, floral, mineral and slightly metallic. Taste: Medium bitterness and sourness with low sweetness. Palate: Thick smooth texture, light body, average/prickly carbonation, lingering fairly dry peppery bitter/sour malty finish. Comments: Very good and glass lace.
Bottle from Co-op; clear amber pour with frothy white head, malt and citrus aroma, nut and caramel taste a faint citrus hop bitter finish.

Bottle. Golden beer with a strong white head. The aroma is lightly bitter, and the flavour is bitter with a good degree of hopped'ness. Overall a reasonable golden ale. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: J.J. Wainwrights Evil Eye Honey Brown
column5: For a dark lager, this has some competition, shiner bock, killians and michelob amber boch; not too bad for macro brews. Wainwrights eye is peeken out from between the evil and the eye. 12 oz pop top can. Popped to release a slight sour aroma. Aroma is a little industrialized with metal hints. Pours darker than a pale yellow american beer but I don�t think this really qualifies as dark. Transparent with a couple small stream bubble originations. Now it does have a sweet hint in the smell. Head is alabaster and fades after a few minutes. Taste is not offensive but different in a Pittsburgh kind of way. Gentleman lager personality. This is definitely a good buy in the american lager arena. Price is half that of most other dark american lagers tasted. Finish is tingly on the back of my tongue. No real overwhelming or persistent linger. Not bad. On par with negra modela and lieny�s red.

column1: J.J. Wainwrights Evil Eye Honey Brown
column5: From Can. Poured dark yellow. Little to no head. White, fizzed out pretty quick. Aroma was not stong, but I got some honey and malt. Flavor was the same, with caramel notes in the end. I never saw this before and it wasn�t too bad. Kind of bland. Easy to drink a ton of.

column1: J.J. Wainwrights Evil Eye Honey Brown
column5: Some honey and malty odors. Tastes malty, with some hops, honey, and caramel at the end. Seems very alcoholic to me. Not great, but not bad for a BYOB strip joint.

column1: J.J. Wainwrights Evil Eye Honey Brown
column5: [can] Slight hint of honey in the nose. Not much of a flavor for a dark beer. Easy to drink a lot of. The scary thing is that I did not know they still made this stuff.

column1: J.J. Wainwrights Evil Eye Honey Brown
column5: This stuff is pretty bad. Typical cheap beer....harsh, nasty aftertaste, poor aroma, and burns goin down.

column1: J.J. Wainwrights Evil Eye Honey Brown
column5: Not bad for what I paid. hints of the honey brown part but not much. Its not much to look at so keep it in the can. Drink this at the end of the night.

column1: J.J. Wainwrights Evil Eye Honey Brown
column5: This beer doesnt even seem like a beer. IT has almost no palate, flavor or aroma thats could be misinterpreted as something close to being a distant relative of a beer. It has no taste if you have had anything else to drink in the past 24 hours it seems, but hell, I give them style points for making so easy to drink without noticing it.

column1: J.J. Wainwrights Evil Eye Honey Brown
column5: Not exactly terrible, but not really all that great. It's cheap (I paid $8 for 24 cans), and easy to drink. Kind of like a sweeter version of Sam Adams Light. Kind of

column1: J.J. Wainwrights Evil Eye Honey Brown
column5: Despite what Gsmitty80, who is coincidentaly, my brewing partner and buddy, I LIKE EVIL EYE! It's not a bad 10 buck case of beer and shit, you can pound it.

column1: J.J. Wainwrights Evil Eye Honey Brown
column5: Really cheap beer which is surprising because it is an american dark. Although it doesnt taste like one its something different for 10$ than an american standard.

On draught at the 21st Weekend of Spontaneous Fermentation. Pours a golden colour with no head. A subtle aroma of horse blanket, lemon and oak. Similar flavours and only very mildly tart with a dry finish. Very low carbonation and an oily mouth-feel.
Plastic jug at WSF.� Clear golden - no head.� Wooden. Sourness. Acetone. Solvents.� Sharpness. Sweetness. Harsh. Tarness. Far too harsh.
Tap at WOSF�10. Sour vinegar malt aroma. Hazy yellow color. Light sour vinegar and smooth light malt flavor. Nicely blended - not overly sour.

Cask gravity @ 17th Weekend of Spontaneous Fermentation 2008. Hazy medium yellow color with a virtually none appearance, virtually none lancing head. Aroma is apple tart, grapefruit, lemon, barnyard, leather, oak, vinegar notes. Flavor is moderate sweet and light acidic - vinegar with a long duration, and a dry dry dry finish. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat. (240508)
Draught @ Weekend of Spontaneous Fermentation 2008. Hazy pale yellow with no head. Slightly sour aroma with apple notes. Sour aroma with grapefruit, wood and pear notes.

Weekend of Spontaneous Fermentation 2008. 2 years old. Cloudy yellow wheat colored body. Huge prickly hay flavor, acetid and sharp. Buttery popcorn and peanuts in the middle just destroy any positives this one has. Arcid peanuts and yeast dominate... ugh.

Tap@SpontaneousWeekend08. Aroma of banana and oak with a hint of vinegar. Cloudy, yellow color, no head. Sweet, banana, sour, hint of vinegar, some oak. Quite young, lacks complexity, I�m not impressed.
Draught @ Spontaneous weekend �08. Hazy golden color, no head. Aroma sourness, wood. Medium body. Taste malts, sourness, some fruits (figs ?). NICE.

Nice clean Geueze not spectacular but woth seeking out. I think it is only available on tap in the lambic region of Belgium and is very hard to find. light citrus nose with a very balanced tart horseblaket bret.

(4 years and 4 months old - aged IN the breweries' pipes). Hazy, orangey colour. Slight white head. Superb maderisation. Nose of vintage Burgundy, 'horseblanket', citrussy, peppery, woody. Lemon-like acidity. Something sticky (I think it's my tooth plaque coming loose from me teeth). Extreme dry-effect. Lipsmacking left-over citrussy acidity in the aftertaste. Mind-blowing age( brewery-conditioning!) for this beer. Result is fabulous.
on tap color aranciata velata piatto piuttosto complesso Limone citrico buona acidita leggerissimo acetico vinoso buona secchezza buona acidita
Cloudy blond appearance with no head or carbonation. Aroma and flavour are very floral and much more complex than other lambiek. Good balance of sweet, sour and old barnyard funk.
Have to get used to this falt taste every time. But then it is the mother of all beers. Small head, somewhat opaque. (Antwerpen 201604)

Certain for a fact I had this during Toer de Gueuze. Cask, served flat, very hazy, metallic aroma with some sulfur and wheat. Taste, very sour, vinegar, lemonade and a little bit of cheese. Of the Jonge Lambik, this doesn�t rate too high for me.
Straight from the cask at Tour de Geuze. APPEARANCE: clear blond beer, no head. NOSE: very sour, oak, little fruity, funk. TASTE: dry, slight bitter, oak, very sour again. Nice!
On tap at the brewery. Clear yellow pour with a faint white head. Vinegar aromas. Watery with loads of vinegar. Not complex. Average body and mouthfeel.

Blend of wort from other lambic brewers (Hanssens doesn�t make lambic wort themselves) fermented at Hanssens and the basis of their kriek and geuze. Warm orange golden colour, quite �neig� character, very estery and fruity, lemon, orange, vinegar acidity, sharp but refreshing with a long finish.

At WE of Spontaneous Fermentation 2014. Hazy yellow with a small off-white head and a light ring of foam. Aroma is buttery with some white wine, hay, grassy and cheesy. Taste is also of hay with light funky, buttery notes, some residual sugars, grapes and grassy notes. Light body. Flat. Dry finish. Decent unblended lambic, but a tad too buttery for my liking. Still quenching.

From bag in a box at WoFS 2014. Hazy flat yellow pour. Cheesy aroma, grapes, really fruity/winey, grassy notes. Taste is tart, malty, funky, lemony, light gastric notes. Palate is light, almost watery. Good.

From the barrel @Hanssens Artisanaal. Hazy golden body with some fine bubbles. Low fully diminishing white head. Lemon- and tropical-fruty acidic aroma with notes of barnyard, wet grass and cellar. Clean flavor. Sour-fruity with lemon zest, unripe apples and grapeskin. Bone dry sour-acidic bretty fruit ending. Very good. [Toer de Gueuze 2013]

From the foeder, 12 months of age. Hazy yellow color, big fluffy white head that settles quickly. Aroma of dusty apricot, peach. Taste is bright citrus with abackground of subtle barnyards. Delicious.

column1: Murray Street Brewing Company Anniversary Mild
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: (Draught) Started with the cask conditioned and found it tasted acetic so I has them switch it for the draught. Medium, creamy, almond head and copper body. Orange and hoppy nose. Flavours of club soda, orange flavouring, berries and a watery smooth finish.

column1: Murray Street Brewing Company Anniversary Mild
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Non-cask.... light orange gold... hard to tell the lights were dim. There wasn't alot of body here at all plus a bit much in the carbonation. This is only the second mild ale I've had Trafalgar was way better then this. Pretty flavourless beer, not the worst though. I couldn't decern much in the nose just slight malts popping through.

column1: Murray Street Brewing Company Anniversary Mild
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Cask. Cloudy orange-copper w/ creamy tan head. Nice lacing. Sweet malty, metallic nose. Watery feel. Tasted like watery, unfermented wort. May have gotten some caramel. Almost no bitterness. Not sure if this is what a mild ale is supposed to taste like, but I didn't like it.

On tap at the Kulminator. Cloudy amber, no head, still. Fruity flavour, dried fruit, dark bread, stale bread. Some acidity. Light sourness in flavour. Light fruit. Very subtle funk. Some wine character. Soft biscuity finish. Acidity develops. Flat, medium body, gentle, juicy.
Bag in a box. Clear amber with no head. Aroma is malt, fruit, funk, apple and lemon. Flavour is malt, fruit, apple, funk, medium sweet, citric, little sour, little vinegar and a little dry.

Bag in Box @ Rbabarrap, CPH. Pours clear golden, no head. Aroma of malt, sourness, barnyard, wood, leather, grapes. Flavor is sourness, malt, barnyard, leather, wood, tart fruit, grapes. Medium body, soft carbonation, dry and light acidic finish. 080519

25 March 2019. At In de Verzekering tegen de Grote Dorst. Shared with the lovely Anke! 3 years old. Clear orange, no head. Aroma of green apple, wood, straw, barnyard, unripe plum & orange, leather, cheese, lemon. Taste is medium fruity sour, lots of apple, apricot, plum, quite yeasty, hay-like & lemony, restrained vinegar; only light woody bitter with a hint of leather, more funk, cheese & dust. Dry, tart, bit grassy hoppy finish, lingering lemon peel, hay & cheese. Medium body, oily texture, flat carbonation. Nice fruity & funky Lambiek!
On festival. No head. Red color, a bit hazy. Aroma is cherries, balsamico, nettles, rhubarb. Very sour taste

250 ml from tap, Kulminator, 2 years old. Unclear orange, no head. Basement notes, tart, white balsamico vinnegar, apple wine. Acidic sourness. Light bodied, no carbonation, sour finish, refreshing, interesting.

5y f6 5y 04/13 oro carico piatto velato acetico mela sidro note marsalata piuttosto acido buona secchezza aspro finale Earlier Rating: 2/3/2017 Total Score: 3.2 26/3/15 bag in box golden hazy flat brett wood sweet and sour oro velata piatta bretta legno agrodolce

28Apr2018 Bitter citrus fruits, funk, wood, honey, straw. Hazy gold, no head. Medium sour. More sour citrus fruits, lemon peel, lemon juice, lemon funk, oak, wood, flat carbonation, medium bodied. Decent. Keg at Lambiczoon, Milan.

Bag in box at Nacht van de Grote Dorst. 4 year old. Bit hazy dark orange golden with a few bubbles. Funk, vanilla, soft caramel, light red currants, lemon peel, soft herbs. Quite sour, under medium bitter and light sweet. Medium bodied with no carbonation. Pretty good actually!

Found on tap in Trieste of all places, bartender said it had been aged 5 years. Aroma is mellowed out lambic sharp cheese and fresh squeezed lemon juice. Looks clear copper and just tiny surface bubbles, just as a lambic should be. Flavour is notes of vanilla, licorice, oak smoke embedded in a huge acidic lemon body and taking on balsamic vinegar qualities. Palate has a smooth and filling presence, nothing is missed. A very fine lambic indeed.

Bottle. Smells a bit synthetic, like kids medicine - still its not too bad! Light cherry taste, a little sour, and fairly easy to drink. Easy to drink but it doesn't have the character of some of the 'proper' kriek lambics.
Rood met roze kraag, aroma en smaken van kersen, redelijk zoet, frisse zure lambic, hout, lekker complex, damn en dit vind de vrouw dan nu wel weer lekker, dat wordt delen... lekker spul.
Bottle. Clear ruby color without head. Aroma - Cherries, wood, candy. Taste - Fruity sour, cherries, red fruit, yogurt.

Farbe: kirschrot Schaum: kaum Nase: kirsche herb Geschmack: nur ganz leichte Kohlens�ure, eher s�� vor allem nach hinten. Trotzdem eine herbe Basis die das Ganze ziemlich gut macht. Ach ja und es schmeckt nach Kirsche. Eher wie eine Kirschlimo, von den Geschmacksnoten auch ziemlich nach Erdbeere. Leckere Fruchtlimo mit Bier um dem S��en einen erwachsenen Geschmack zu geben.
A very rich and full taste, sour and sweet mixing in together. Sweet overcomes the bitterness, elements of wood and a little bit of carbonation.

The unblended �raw material� from which the famous Lindemans Kriek is made. Deep wine-red colour, lots of cherry juice, sugary, a bit artificial and far removed from the fully authentic kriekenlambics made without sugar and with real sweet cherries, even a bit syrupy. Basic taste is more or less the same as the bottled version.
Bottle at globe. Reddish pour. White head. Like a cherry jolly rancher. Bubbly. Good for the style
Draft. Cloudy reddish color, flat. Aroma of tangy fruit, red wine, edge of citrus. Taste is sour cherries, full flavoroed and vinous. Delicious.

Slightly hazy ruby colour, no head. Aroma of cherry and aspirin. Sweet flavour, cherry, chalk and aspirin. Finish cherry, fruits and chalk. (Draught @ WoSF, Opstal 2013. Thanks for sharing, Uli! Part of Uli�s blind tasting of fruit lambics. 8 out of 10, not bad my friend, not bad at all!)

Tap at WoSF, 2013. It pours deep red-purple with no head. The nose is earthy, mouldy wood, cherry, cherry tunes, candy and faint medicinal notes. The nose is tart cherry, red grape skin, vinous, sharp lemon, plum skin and intense sourness with a dry, tart finish. Medium body and low carbonation. Sharp, juicy and damn tasty. Wow!

On tap at Fortnight Wine Bar in Providence, RI. Black-brown with thick medium-brown fine, head that sticks around. Aroma is soy sauce, chocolate, pumpernickel bread, more dark chocolate, more soy sauce, and some BBQ sauce. Mouthfeel is moderate-coarseness carbonation, medium-light burn, oily, slightly syrupy. Nice. Flavor is chocolate soy sauce with slight tartness and breadiness (maybe a sourdough?). Very good! I normally get soy-sauce from big stouts, but the BDSA is a nice take on it!

Dark brown to black. Red edges. Smells really good. Dark fruit, prunes, figs and pepper. Taste. Whoa. Oxidized, sherry and port with loads of dark fruit, wine barrel. Malt backbone is huge. Really lovely. Finish is like a very old port
Says retired but i had on tap at the source today. Dark fruits, raisin, slight roasted malts, bit of sour funk. Very complex layered flavors.
Tap at brewery. Dark pour. Rice, syrup, sherry. Dried fruits. Dessert wine like. Interesting

Wow what a nice surprise to find. Brewed again for their 25th anniversary. Dark brown pour with a reddish hue and almost no head. Nose is huge raisin with a hint of lactic tartness. Taste is wonderfully complex with lots of things happening, yet working together so very well. Raisin, oak, tawny port, awesomeness.
Barley heavy aroma with woody-nutty aroma. Deep brown, almost black in color. Very sweet with sour edges and a nutty-woody finish. A bit like a wild barleywine.

Avery Sour Ale Fest. Strongest brew at the whole fest. However no alcohol apparent. Sweet, but not overly sweet. Surprisingly not that full-bodied. The barrel adds some cool character to the brew. Some woodiness and nice tart flavors. One of my favorites of the fest.

On tap at Avery Sour Fest poured a hazy dark brown with a lingering ring of tan foam. Aromas of leather, horseblanket, cocoa and light fruittiness. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry lightly tart finish. Flavors of leather, cocoa, fruittiness, barnyard and light spice with a smooth dry lightly tart lingering funky finish.

GABF 2009. Pours hazy brown with an average, fizzy off-white head, somewhat diminishing with fair lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, caramel, toffee), light hop (herbs, grass), heavy yeast (dough, earth) with notes of cherry, wine, and brown sugar. Medium bodied, sticky texture, average carbonation, and a bitter finish. Long duration, moderate sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.

On tap at GABF 2009. Another great and really interesting beer from Cambridge. Pours a cloudy dark reddish-amber color with a small off-white head. Aroma is dark fruits, brown sugar, spices, oak, and orange peel. Flavor is sweet malt, spices, cherries, dates, orange, honey, candi sugar, red wine, and a little alcohol. Also a little oaky tartness to it that really adds to the complexity. Palate is medium-full with soft carbonation and very well-hidden ABV. This is a well-done beer overall.

16-Mar-14 (12-oz bottle: Obtained in trade with Eyedrinkale, thanks Mike!) This beer is black in color and capped by half an inch of tan-colored head that settles to a ring and patchy sheet. The nose is mostly roasty malts with a bit of chocolate, oatmeal, black olive, and dark fruit. On the palate, the flavors are roasty and chocolatey, with noticeable oatmeal character, cola, and some coffee, plus a hint of ashtray in the finish. The beer is medium in weight, light-medium in carbonation, and fairly dry in the finish. Overall, this is a fine oatmeal stout that's cellared particularly well for a 5% ABV beer.

Very light pale, beige head. Minor lacing on the glass. Mahogany in color, although the faintest of light will come through. Smell-Burnt coffee aromas. (I wasn�t going to write this, but I also detect some soy sauce/salty smells. This didn�t appear at all in the tasting.) Thinner mouthfeel than expected, but very flavorful. Unlike many other Oatmeal Stouts, this one has a definitive hop presense. Still, the major flavor component is burnt malts. No noticable chewiness. Nice balance on the carbonation. The taste profile is the best part of this beer. I don�t find this to be particularly spectacular or unusual. I find the higher hop content interesting and wish that it had more body, then I believe it would be a truly superior beer.

Bottle. Pours deep brown with a beige head. Lightly roasted malts, oxidation, light sweetness, and light toast. The oxidation isn�t overpowering. Really not that bad, especially for a 10 year old beer that has no business being aged for even half that long.
Bottle. Dark dark brown with a minimal head. Aroma is slight chocolate/coffee with a strange chemical smell. Taste is faint oats and coffee. This beer tastes old.

flavors of oats and cocoa it has a light bittering of hops. added flavor component of Earth it was a somewhat sweet and had a bottlecap metal flavor in the finish. That flavor once distinguished lingered through the entire tasting. some body but somewhat lacking leaving me unimpressed in that area still not insufficient. found in notes from 2007 and from the bottle. a bit of burnt coffee.
Black pour in glass. Pleasant aroma of Quaker Oats, chocolates, breads and dough. Taste is smooth, albeit average for the genre. Rated 10/6/03
A perfectly middle-of-the-road sweet stout. It might be a good session beer. Otherwise it had no real stand-out characteristics.
a good oatmeal a little past its prime though shouid have consumed it sooner

small tan head that settles quickly, some spotty lace. Clear, mahogany colored brew. Nose of light roast, lightly bready. Body is med/light, fairly thin on the palate, uneventful. Thin chocolate flavors with a light roastiness and a touch earthy, some caramel notes as well. Dry, roasty finish. Props to Robert for the bottle and my buddy shoeman for enjoying it with me, thanks Jim! Thanks for the lasagna also, well done!

Sampled with stegosaurus on our second Boston tour. I forget the place we had it at but I am sure he will remember.Dark pour with off white head. Roast aroma and in taste as well. Mouth feel was a little thin and it could have been balanced better. Not a bad brew but I was dissapointed a little.
A nice interpretation of the style. Very dark and malty with a pretty good hoppy signature. Somewhat bitter on the finish, but not bad overall.
Typical pale malt that is slighlty off tasting for the style, although not a bad lager.

Bottled. A hazy amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, and straw. The flavor is sweet malty combined with notes of caramel and straw, leading to a lightly bitter finish. Thanks Papsoe for sharing.

I had this, or at least a version of this at the May fest celebration this year. (09) It was the most amazing beer ever. I talked to the brewer and he told me he finished it Saaz hops. I have been trying to duplicate this beer at home ever since.

Active orange with a thin white slowly fading head and suspended matter. Aroma of caramel, toffee, malt, fruit and mild cornstalk and alcohol as it warms. Taste of Munich-esque malt, toasted and sweet malt, toffee, bread and dough. Finishes a bit spunky with some alcohol and mild vegetation.
(Bottle 35,5 cl) Courtesy of pepsican. Hazy amber golden with a small white head. Aroma of overripe fruit. Medium body with sweet caramel and overripe fruit. The finish is dry. 180808

Bottle. Hazy amber coloured with a small off white head. Sweet aroma of caramel, rye bread and coffee with notes of dried fruits. Sweet flavour of caramel, dried fruits and rye bread with notes of hops. Hoppy finish.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours cloudy orange with a lacing white head. Mild spiced and malty to breadish aroma. Spiced and hoppy flavour, dry breadish malt base flavour. Distinct spiced into the finish, breadish malt finish too.

Bottle. Fairly light aroma, better than any average american lager, some bready pale malt, light citrus lemon. Pretty weak pour, light bubbly white head, dissipates fairly quickly, no lacing, but the color is decent, copper-amber, some fiz. Malt flavor dominates this light bodied beer, sweet and nut grainy malt, not complex, bitter shows up and the very end, some lingering thats ok. All in all, I�m not too crazy about this one, but is was nice to drink.

Bottle. Pours an amber color with a medium size off white head. Aroma of caramel, malt and honey. Taste is lightly sweet with a earthy undertone. Flavors of malt, light hops and nuts. Mild and easy to drink with a light sweet finish.

I really liked this beer when I had it on tap at the Amana Colonies in Iowa. I later tried some bottled and it didn�t match up very well at all. Slightly sweet and smooth with a nice level of carbonation. Medium malt flavor - very drinkable.

Draft @ brewpub. Nitro pour, served too cold. Opaque. Aroma is clean, nice asphalt after the rain aroma. Burly roast beneath. Acidic finish is refreshing. Thick and creamy mouthfeel. Slightly milky flavor with a mild coal finish. Seems thick and yet is not all that flavorful.

Draught at the brewpub. Dark brown, creamy nitri head. Spicy grassy aniseed aroma. Dry and very roasty with notes of chocolate and sak� as well as bitter cocoa. Big, concentrated roasty flavours, marked powerful bitterness. More alive, more for real than the regular commercial Irish stouts.

tap at the brewpub - Pours near black with a lingering tan head. It smells of roast malt and chocolate. The flavor includes dark roast malt, chocolate, and a hint of smoke. It�s medium to full bodied and quite nice, easily the best of the five brews I tried at the brewpub.

Source:Tap in Dublin. Glass:Sampler. Appearance:Dark brown pour with a thin tan head. Aroma:Roast, coffee and milk chocolate. Flavor:Roast and coffee with anise and bitter chocolate. Palate:Medium/full body with soft carbonation. Overall:Good beer. Enjoyed much.
Dark brown with a small white head. Aroma of roasted malt with lots of chocolate. Dry and roasted flavour with a long finish

Cask @ GBBF 2008. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty caramel aroma with some hints of licorice and coffee aroma. Roasted malty coffee and dark chocolate flavor with some hints of licorice. Has a slightly sweetish roasted malty coffee finish with some hints of chocolate in the aftertaste.

Cask @ Great British Beer Festival, GBBF 2008, Earls Court, London, England SW5. Dark brown black color with a small, virtually none head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, coffee, sour. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (050808)
GBBF, Trade Day, 2008 First beer at GGBF 2008. Coffee. Clean, flavoursome, balanced, refreshing, very drinkable and gorgeous. I could drink this all day.
Cask at GBBF08. Good liquorice aroma. Black colour, no head. Thin mouthfeel. Quite roasted flavour, a bit rough.

(Cask at GBBF, London, 7 Aug 2008) Black colour with brief, pale brown head. Roasted, malty nose with notes of coffee and cocoa. Roasted, malty taste with strong black coffee, dark chocolate and a generous coffee bitterness in a clean and fresh finish. Medium body, dry. An excellent example of irish stout.

Cask, Frog & Toad, Gillingham. The four day beer festival ran dry after two and a half days! 23 beers with names of animals - all gone! Back in the pub itself they still had this, the house beer, brewed for them by the local brewery. The previous owners of the pub also had a house beer made by Flagship, and that was called Lucy, after their dog. The beer is a fairly standard bitter - quite dryly hopped. Nothing special.
Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy brown color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity yeasty wheat malty spicy aroma.

Bottle from Kris Wines. Slightly murky orange-brown colour. Smells fruity, with cloves, pear, plum and a hint of banana. Taste is nice blend of fruity wheat beer and a hint of malt. A very pleasant and thirst quenching glass of beer.

500 ml bottle. Helsinki, Finland. Murky orange brown colour with small off-white head. Fruity banana aroma with some caramel and some artificial touch. Caramel malt, wheat and mild yeast in flavour. Soft carbonation.

(bottled) This is like drinking a nice breakfast cereal. Drank from a Weisse glass it looked like a Weisse beer (go figure;) Nose is banana esters,clove ,dark malts that are pretty rich, ; A tangy palate ;rich and a bit sugary...Customary bananas..cloves, caramel and apple acidity ; Easy to drink and plesant dark weissbier .

500ml bottle (Helsinki Beer Festival 2011) 6 Bananaey butter, but a kind of smooth aroma. 3 Dark muddy orange. 5 Sharpish. Banana. Minerals. Cleaning fluid. 3 Fairly full palate. 10- Odd one, and the score flatters it, as it�s ot as good as an average 2.7.
Bottled at HBF2011. Slightly sweetish nose. Pale beige head. Slightly hazy amber colour. Wheaty slightly sour taste with some banana notes. Mild hoppiness.

It�s unclear, dark orange-colored with a huge, creamy head. The aroma is light with fruity notes of banana and other fruit and wheat. The flavour is sweet and has the same fruity notes as the aroma, but also a little caramel and the finish is slightly yeasty. It�s not one of the best, a bit �tame�.
50 cL bottle. Pours cloudy orange with a small white head. Aroma is spiced, phenolic and dry malty. Light roasted malty and phenolic dry yeasty. Dry estery and mild wheaty finish.
Bottle, 5.3%. Hazy amber colour. Small stable creamy off-white head. Mild bready flavour, hint of toffee or caramel. Good mouthfeel. Taste slightly past BB, but is not.

Light brown, cloudy. Mainly wheaty tartness on the nose with a hint of toast. On the palate - similar. Good toastiness but dominated by apple tartness. This lends the beer a hint of refreshment and some dryness late.
Bottle, thanks to shrubber85, honey brown pour with no head, aroma of malty maple, flavor is malty brown sugar, bready metallic, lighter finish

Sample at the Upland Tasting Room. Hazy amber-orange color with a medium white head that dissipates steadily. Strings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of roast malt, caramel and hops. Light to medium body with flavors of toasted malt, earthy hops and caramel. The finish is sweet with a bready malt aftertaste. Decent overall.

On tap at the Brewpub. Pours a clear amber-orange with a decent khaki head that leaves some thick, foamy lace behind. Nose involves sweet malt, dusty yeast, and light noble hop spice and earth. Pretty sweet flavor, but also fairly bitter. Medium to full bodied, oily, fairly active, with a long dusty finish. Very enjoyable, just about right as the style goes, and balanced between refreshing and substance.

Draft at the Upland Tasting Room. Pours a clear orange-gold with a small off-white head that leaves a sheet of lace. The aroma is mostly just malty - crackers, toast, bread. The flavor is cleaner and not quite as malty, with some balancing leafy and grassy notes. Light-medium bodied, with moderate carbonation and a dry, malty mouthfeel. Decent maibock.
On tap at Upland Indy. Poured golden amber with white head lace. Aroma of caramel malts. Light carb med bod. Rich taste of malt barley grains. Traditional.
Draft to taster at Upland. Looks solid; a transparent orange with off-white lacing. Smells and tastes of caramel, malt, and dough with a solid lager mouthfeel. Not bad.

Bottle shared by plank10. Thanks Nick. The beer is orange hued with a thin white head that leaves sparse lacing on the glass. The aroma carries grain, fruit, malt, sweetness. Smells like a bock. The taste follows suit, with a present sweetness throughout. Fruit, grains, and a bit of alcohol. Fairly thin in body. A decent beer, but not on par with the authentic German examples of the style. Serving type: bottle Reviewed on: 01-14-2012
Bottle. Grainy caramel malt aroma. Amber with a small beige head. Bready malt and caramel flavor with a spicy hop finish, a little boozy. Medium body, lively carbonation.
12 ounce bottle poured an amber caramel color. Aromas of sweet malt, little hops, caramel, and some toffee. Flavors are the same as aroma, decent beer overall, would drink again.

Pours a slightly hazy orange/gold with tan head. Sweet, malty scent.....bread, caramel. Taste is sweet, spiced...slight fresh hop bitter...breads and light fruit. Alcohol is very well hidden.. A pretty nice beer.
Hazy yellow pour. Cloudy. Aroma of citrus, lemon, and light malts. Light body. Flavor is light or orange and lemon. Some tartness. Lingering sweetness.

Draft sampler at brewpub. Cloudy orange color with an average rocky white head that diminished slowly. Moderate complex banana citrus wheat aroma. Light to medium body with a watery texture. Medium sweet flavor with a sweet spicy finish of moderate duration.

I had this at the Arlington location, 11/17/05, listed at 4.3% abv. Golden bodied - looks like it was filtered, not very hazy, but the aroma is strong and seems to prove me wrong - plenty of herbal clove and banana in this one! Taste was a mellow lemony citrus with floral notes and a big banana finish.

Mostly cloudy pale yellow, looks like there�s pulp in it. Thin ice-like head. Reserved aroma with some banana bread and bargain brewers yeast; overall pretty poor for a hefe. Light and refreshing, but flavor is absent for the majority of the time until the finish. Banana, wheat, vanilla and faint lemons take their time before vanishing. Disappointing.
[At the Denver location] An unclear dark orange beer with no head. The aroma is very light, but what is there is wheaty. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of banana, too much for me.

From a sampler at the Indy location: This brew is a hazy orange color with a thin white head and sticky lacing. Wheat and clove in the nose. On the light and slick side with a wheaty character and some banana flavor. The finish is fair but not very lasting. This is a so-so beer.
(Draught) Pours a cloudy yellow color with a small head. Descent tasting German Hefeweizen.

Poured a medium white head of small-medium bubbles. There was a lot of lacing on the sides of my glass. This brew had a cloudy appearance. It had a fruity aroma in my opinion. It was a fairly smooth drink with a slight bitter taste.

This brew poured a medium sized head of fine to medium sized white bubbles. It had a cloudy orange colored body and its receding head left an excellent lacing. I smelled an aroma of mild hops and tasted notes of banana, pumpkin and spices.
Draft at Rock Bottom Indy. From notes. Nutty caramel dominates taste and aroma. Good, but not great.

Date: February 14, 2012 Mode: Draft Source: RB Downtown Indy Description: Semi-opaque brown pour with almost no head. Roasted malt and maybe some coffee in aroma and taste. Somewhat thin and some carbonation, dry slight bitter finish.

Tap at Rock Bottom Indy. Pours clear brown with a small, creamy tan head, low retention with good lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, caramel, chocolate), light hops (woody), and light esters (dried fruit). Flavor is heavy malt (cookie, caramel, chocolate), light hops (woody), and light esters (dried fruit). Medium body, carbonation, and creaminess, low warmth, with a medium sweet finish.
Dark brown pour. Light body. Aroma is slightly roasted with a little coffee. A chocolate bitter taste with a slightly acidic finish.

10 oz. glass at the brewpub. A fairly dark brown beer with red. A one finger tan head. Aroma is roasted nuts and cocoa. The flavor also had those roasted nuts along with some molasses. Only the faintest hops were noticed. Very easy to drink it is both bitter and sweet. Pleasant.

Draught at RB Indy/Downtown. Dark ruby, black with highlights, very cool looking! Lacy tan head. Nose of roast and berry. Watery body. Taste of roast and mocha, light berry, sticky candy bar malt and faint toffee/chocolate. More impressive than any of their light beers - has some complexity and depth!

Growler shared for Brother Eric�s 30th. Pours very deep brown with slight transparency and minimal beige head. Nose is mostly sour stale malt...but my palate is a little off due to the spicy cookout celebration. Flavor is smooth, mellow, slight choc malt and sweet nuttiness. Very good style and flavor. One of the better "year rounds" from this location.
Had on tap at the brewpub awhile back. It was arguably my favorite offering I tried while visiting there.

Hazy brown with thin off-white head. Aroma is of roasted malts with some sweet notes. Roasted/burnt flavor, dry finish. Flat on the tongue. Not sure if what I had was a Brickway since it was noted as a robust brown similar to a porter. On tap at RB, Indianapolis.

draft at the downtown brewpub - Pours dark brown with an off-white head that laces well. It has a minimal nutty malt aroma. The flavor is sweet and full of caramel. It�s light to medium bodied and an easy quaffed session brew.

On tap at Tap That Growlers in La Grande Oregon. Pours a satisfying rich thick black brew with a nice fulsome tannish head that slowly dissipates. The aroma is big on dark chocolate, some coffee notes, and a bit of burnt sugar. Mouth feel medium with adequate carbonation. The tongue is hit first with a touch of burnt sugar followed by a big bold coffee and a slight astringent bite. The whole complex recedes leaving a bit of bitter on the back of the tongue and a warming alcohol and an underscoring of the coffee echoing off in the distance. Most enjoyable! Good job TG!

Pours a half finger of head on a black body. The aroma is rich roasted and burnt malt. Nice and dark. The taste has a deep chocolate flavor, burnt wood with a dry bitter burnt finish. The texture is smooth with light fizz. Very enjoyable.

On tap. Black color with tan head. Dark chocolate, sugared up black coffee, roasted aromas. Medium body with average co2. Sugared up black coffee flavors with chocolate, dark roast, metallic mineral___good.

Tap at Bailey�s Taproom PDX, 26/05/13, listed as 6.6% ABV. Light black with a thin ran head. Nose is big on roast malt, bitter chocolate, liqourice, dark toffee. Taste comprises roast malt, molasses, biscuit, chocolate, bitter roast. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, good roast bite in the finish. A most decent stout!

On tap yesterday at the TG brewpub on a beautiful summer night. This stout was a perfect comeback to the buffalo burger. I�m tasting roast malt, root beer, hops. slight dark khaki head. a little drying on the tongue but proper thickness & a hint of sweet. i taste roast malt, dark coffee, wood smoke, an oaken sour. I was wondering if this might be in the imperial stout category, but here its quite a bear, thick, easy drinking, walking an edge or two. just might br my best &#40non-imperial&#41 stout.

Tap at TFD Boise: Nearly a black pour with a nice creamy brown head. Very nice bits of lacing. Aroma is heavy on the roast with light amounts of coffee. Taste is again roasty with light coffee and a nice bittersweet cocoa sensation. Well balanced in flavor and has a nice creamy feel. Really quite enjoyable.

Black beer with a great tan head. Coffee and roast on the aroma. Light sweetness too. Mocha, roast, chocolate flavors. A little cola flavors too. A touch of earth/roasted bitterness in the finish. Nice drinker.
On tap at source in Enterprise, OR--Deep dark black, with a hint of amber and a great-looking grey-brown head. Chocolaty, creamy, muddy, and delicious. Very nice beer!

On Tap at Flying Pie in Boise. Pitch black with a very thick dense tan head. Nice roasted aroma with lots of chocolate, tootsie roll and Flavor is sharp roasted smokey goodness. Pretty full body, smooth palatte and soft carbonation. Leaves a slightly green hopppy bitterness at the end. A great middle weight stout.

Draft: Black but with brown highlights, 1 finger tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate and a nice fresh bread smell. Flavor is of roasty coffee with bittersweet chocolate notes and biscuits! I really like the biscuit flavor through this that separates it from other stouts. Its not real sweet and not dry either. A quite balanced brew.

The aroma is very sweet with notes of nuts and a little chocolate. The color is a hazy dark brown and it has a fine but collapsing light brown head. The flavor is a little odd: only slightly sweet - it is dominated by a malt bitterness with some roasted chocolate notes - it ends on a dryness from the malt bitterness. It is very (too) carbonated. The body is very thin.
Bottled. Mahogany colour. Neutral aroma. Thin, very lightly roasty with metallic finish. The emptiness dominates...

Pale lager color with small head. Barely noticeable flowery aroma. Slightly malty, very mild aroma. Bitter but short finish. No aftertaste. Light-bodied, watery palate. The name of this beer is "The hunt", and there's a picture of a moose in the label. Maybe I'm blind, but I just can't see the connection between those two. I cannot imagine a moose hunter drinking this stuff (pocket-warm) in the woods, either.
Pretty light, pale yellow. Mild nose with notes of malt and flowery. Light body, watery texture, notes of metal.
Bottled. Pale yellow. Neutral aroma. Thin and metallic with late harsh bitterness.

Very uninteresting pour, just another bright yellow with a slight hint of head on top. Has a strong scent of syrup on the nose, also some fruitiness. Taste is okay, a fruity mix with a hint of alcohol, and some corn adjuncts can be tasted too. Okay mouthfeel. Not bad.
i guess they don't make this anymore since they banned alcohol. corn syrup, fat in the mouth, bright golden
Bottled. Golden coloured with lively, brief head. Grainy alcohol aroma. Sweet and unclean, dominated by the flavour of various adjuncts. Harsh vegetable finish.
NOthing special compaired to some of the other brews they make. Some citrus flavor and a light head.
What I call a "dirty" flavor--grassy probably fits the bill, as argo0 says. Slightly bitter. Doesn't do anything for me, but my friends really liked it.
Clear yellow with small white head. Aroma is faintly smoky, pine. Weak flavor -- a bit grassy, and finishes a bit more assertive grassy. Watery body.
enjoyed this more than a similar beer produced by daleside. another one at the beerfest.

1. Cask Handpump at the Station Buffet, Stalybridge 16/11/2002 Definitely one of my favourite best bitters which has never disappointed wherever it�s been sampled. Golden coloured with orange and lemon fruits and a smooth bitter finish with some dryness. 2. Cask Handpump at the George & Dragon, Great Budworth 02/07/2003 Amber golden slightly citrus with a malt hop finish. 3. Cask Handpump at the George & Dragon, Great Budworth 25/02/2004 Amber golden hoppy and fruity citrus with a creamy smooth bitter finish. 4. Cask Handpump at the George & Dragon, Great Budworth 11/05/2004 Golden amber fruity citrus and hoppy with a slightly bitter dry finish. 5. Cask Handpump at the George & Dragon, Great Budworth 01/06/2004 Golden hoppy and fruity orange with a slightly dry lasting finish.
Wonderfully tasty traditional Northern hoppy bitter.Excellent session beer. (Cask @ Crown Inn Stockport).

Bright bottled from London Drinker festival. 36 hours ago. Clear amber session bitter. Beautiful aroma - warm and malty with suggestions of chocolate yet alive with citric notes from oranges. Neutral palate with medium to thin body. The hops make a big impact, though they are a bit blurred and on the whole are more bittering than fragrant. The chocolate notes are repeated in the flavour. This is a very tasty bitter which has stood up very well to being kept off the yeast for so long. Some of the freshness has gone, and the hops are not as precise, but the aroma is certainly more evident, and the malt quality better defined.

Mid amber colour. Clammy hop and stinky malt in the aroma. Clean flavour, but nothing very exciting comes through. Soft mouthfeel, with a touch of chewy malt. Slightly sour, citric hop finish. Worthy, but unspectacular. Cask, London Drinker beer festival.
Plain bitter appearance with a watery caramel aroma. Hopped flavour with a slight citric finish, but basically a plain slightly bitter session beer.
500ml bottle in 2013. Super pale golden with a white head. Aroma of grapes, straw and grassy hops. Crisp. Light peppery hop flavours and some residual lemongrass.

8th Feb 2019; hand-pulled cask pint at the Codsall Railways Buildings. Light golden body, fluffy white crown. Mild citrus leanings from the hops, a tad sweetness from the malts, not too exciting or different, but it did quench my thirst.

September 1, 2018 - on handpull cask at Wetherspoons Willow Walk (Victoria Station). Clear and bright pale gold with a decent mottled off-white head. Smells like a floral slightly chalky golden ale - taste follows; simple, well-made dry and floral golden, not earthshaking but pleasant to drink. Average body, mild carbonation, medium-quick grassy/floral finish. Went down a perfect treat with my Doom Bar ale pie - extra point!

Nov 2018 - Cask handpull at the William Morris Hammersmith as Nottingham Extra Pale Ale. I do love the old school pump clip, but from there it's downhill. Pale yellow, clear and still with a foamy beige head that endures. Aroma is bready, some grains, club in Neath, cheap grain whisky (watered down), little buttery. Body is smooth with soft carbonation. Taste is thin and papery, cardboard and dust, powdered stones and sawdust in water. Hmm, I like cask beer more than most but this tastes pretty much like drinking your gran's carpet. (4-4-4-4-11=2.7)
Cask at Ye Olde Trip to Jerusalem, Nottingham. Pleasant pale ale with a fruity flavour
Can�t believe this beer is only rated two stars. Such a lovely beer and they produced a really nice glass at Christmas time

(From the cask) Clear straw-yellow beer, with a thick white head, and minimal carbonation. Good lacing up the side of the glass. Aroma of lemon peel, caramel, biscuity malts, fresh cereal, and soap. Fairly bland and a little watery. Went well with fish and chips, but can�t recommend this one.

Bottle from Worldwide Alcohol, Chelmsford. Pours pale gold with a small white head. Aroma of hop, citrus, grain and yeast. Medium sweetness with medium to heavy bitterness. Light body and oily texture. Carbonation is average. Finish is sweet, and a bit rough.

Bottle @ Grahams. Pours golden with an offwhite head. Aroma of malt, grainy, sweet fruity hops, old hops. Flavor is sweet, malt, grainy, light corn, old sweet fruity hops. Medium body, average to lively carbonation. 160217
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are malt, bread, grain and hops.

Cask, The Lord Keeper of the Great Seal, Oadby. Golden brown with a dense white head. Aromas are sweet grapefruit and tropical fruit with soft spices. Flavours are dry, light malts with grapefruit. Some woody notes with a dry finish. Decent.

Cask at �Spoons, Milton Keynes. Gold with a white head. Some citric hop in the aroma, but �Spoons beer-chilling policy didn�t help close investigation. Some fruitiness and grain in the taste, and a mid bitter finish. Despite all that there is an overwhelming watery quality about this beer that renders it pretty ordinary.
Cask Handpump at the Marble Arch Inn, Manchester 26/10/2002 Golden amber coloured with some wheat flavour. Slightly dry hop finish.

Again brought upto the North West travelled 150 miles very well. I�ll take previous comments of citrus and narrow that down to a soft hint of grapefruit, light in the aroma but heavier in the taste. Nice dry taste with a little kick an unusual pleasant balance. On the finish of a pint i could say the thought would be in your head i hope theres more. Rep from S&N in this afternoon enjoyed both the Old Boy but was overwhelmed with this cask and really enjoyed it.

As expected, it�s deep gold in colour, with a distinct tangy hop aroma, which carries through very strongly on the palate. However, I also detected a little dry malt and spicy undertones to provide some balance and a little more complexity than the norm. Dry, crisp finish. A good example of the style. Cask (handpump), also at the Victoria, Lincoln (not at the same time as imdownthepub)

Cask Conditioned at The Victoria, Lincoln. Amber beer with thin head. Thinly flavoured but with a sharp interesting hop flavour, dry and peppery, showing a big late hopping. Keeps the interest through the pint.
Standard bitter appearance with a dry, hopped and caramel aroma. A watery hopped flavour with a dry finish, but overall the beer is very standard.

If it�s a milk shake, it�s an interesting one. It�s like if you buy a car from the classifieds and it turns out to be of the HotWheels variety; not technically incorrectly, but also not what you had in mind
Tap at Tommyknockers. Hot chocolate, sugar. Sweet with chocolate, cinnamon, a hint of wood and something reminiscent of strong ales. A passable milk stout.
Tap @ Black Door. Pours near black with a thin off white head. Milky chocolate nose, some toast. Roasty notes, chocolate, hint of raspberries as well.
Catch-up from last month. Can, rich, creamy and sweet, chocolate and light smoke notes. Delicious.

Rocky rootbeer foam-like head, leaves no lacing. Aroma of burnt toast or dark roasted coffee with just a hint of hops. Taste at tip of tongue of slightly sweetened coffee, almost drying, then maltiness and fading finish. The mid tongue flavors of nutty coffee are the highlight. Wish there was a bit longer finish or heavier mouthfeel. Not bad, but I wouldn't think it "award winning".

Can from Mace SCR, Dublin [100718] Pitch black, tan edges, frothy tan head, light lacing Aroma - Soft toasted malts, soft coffee grounds, dab of sweet chocolate syrup, soft burnt toast Taste of soft toasted malts, dark sweet malts, dab of dark sweet treacle, touch of dark fruits, sweet milk sugars Palate - Soft carb, medium body, smooth, quite sweet. Finish of dark sweet sugars, soft roast linger Overall - OK

Black pour, medium beige head. Aroma of roast, chocolate, toasted nuts and a hint of lactose. Flavor is chocolate, toast, char, roast, chocolate, a hint of coffee, and some earthy hops. Medium body, creamy to slick feel, medium carbonation. Good stuff, pretty standard for the style.

Canned @ Oliver Twist. Black with a medium size khaki head, some lacing. Sweet milk chocolate aroma, toast, molasses and rye bread. Silky mouthfeel, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Taste is a bit more roasted and ashes, still milk chocolate creamy. Grassy and dry finish with very mild bitterness.

The aroma of dark malt and sweetness. The taste is sweet. Same as the fragrance. Exquisite bitterness that fills the upper part of the mouth for a long time. Wonderful and easy to drink beer. Follow me @ Kung av �l @ Facebook for more pictures and ratings.
Bottle from Inn on the greens bottle shop black with a tan head with sweet roasted chocolate malts,coffee taste leaving a pleasant milk stout aftertaste,nice one.
Interesting IPA, not to hoppy. Taste earthy and woody. Purchased a bottle, pours dark black with a med. head.

Bomber bottle. Pours a hazy amber with a frothy white head. Very mild aroma of hops, like pine. Taste is mildly bitter, some pine, citrus notes, over a mild malt base. Finish is a bit bitter, a little pine. Would make a fine "pale ale" but not really hoppy enough to be called an IPA.
Aroma of malts and hops. A decent IPA but not great. The hops got lost somewhere. Get something else.
Poured a clouded copper-orange with a big white head. Nose of bitter hops and weak malts. Overall, the beer is unspectacular, especially compared to its label and name.

Rating #939 - Jan 25th, 2014 - Bottle from Coop. Love hop puns so naturally this caught my eye. Clear golden amber pour with a weak, white head that bubbles away to a ring. Aroma is strong with hoppy overtones, pine, resin, lemon. Taste is more of the same, dry hops and cakey malts dominating the flavour, with a dose of citrus zest and piney sweet notes. Nice.
Tap@Gotham Vancouver. One finger foam. Slight hazy. Golden. Fine herbal to fruity notes. Not a very intense bitterness. Guess a lot of like this hoppy but easy drinkable steak brew. Fine for me too.

Bomber poured a hazy amber with a small lasting ambe head. Aromas of biscuit, lemon zest, grapefruit, pine and light earthiness. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish.Flavors of biuscuit, earthiness, citrus and light pine with a smooth dry lightly bitter finish.

650ml bottle pours a golden orange color with a finger of white head that leaves some thin spotty lacing on the glass. Aroma is mild citrus and flowers with mild toasty malts. Taste is moderate hop bitterness with a light malt sweetness underneath. Medium body with some decent carbonation. Overall, an average IPA that is fairly easy to drink and a good place for those interested in this style to start with.

Unclear amber orange, big creamy off white head lasts. Mild hoppy aroma. Medium bitter hop taste dominates, soft malt background. Light to medium body, lively carbonation. Light bitter citrus finish. Basic. LBW (Lagerboys Be Wary)

crisp hops, and Great colour. Aroma is a bit thin for an ipa. As it warms the malts come on more and it is less initial hoppyness, there is always a pleasant hop on the back end, but it may be a bit too much for some. Not a bad go-to thirst quencher, if can get it at the beer store.
Hurt by age. Very flat. 2004 Bottle. Oxidized and some malt, apples. It was likely much better in the past.

Shared generously by daknole. Bottle pours deep amber/brown with an off-white head. Aroma shows tawny like oxidation with notes of burnt brown sugar, graham cracker, apple cobbler, and some overripe fruit. Flavor shows dates, caramel, and light hazelnut. Overall body is moderate to full, somewhat flat, and finishes with boozy warmth. The age seems to have given some extra depth, but it could definately stand to have a little more carb to break up the body a bit.
Clear light brown pour. Carbonation is gone. Sweet malty aroma, some oxidized notes. Flavor of apple, caramel, oxidized notes. 2004 bottle!

12oz bottle. Rating #130. Clear and very still, carbonation left awhile ago I guess, dark brown/amber color. Nice aroma, dark fruits and some apple and a bit of alcohol. Flavor is slightly off, plum and more light apple. Held up pretty well. (2093)

Bottle @ home, courtesy of Ughsmash. Huge thanks! Caramel-amber appearance with no head and little carbonation. Dusty, Belgian yeasty, dark fruity, dull caramel aroma. Caramel, fig, brown sugar, Belgian yeasty, caramel malty, slightly spicy, somewhat boozy flavor with a warming finish. Some oxidation. The beer�s settled out to something like a thin barley wine after all these years- way past its prime but fun to try anyhow.

Generous thanks to BenC for sharing...thanks Ben! - Pours rosy amber with no head to speak of. Toffee and butterscotch on the nose, with some sharp alcohol. Faint spicing. Not much here at all. The taste...whoa. Waay off. More butterscotch, toffee, and all sorts of candy sweetness. Cloying and sticky, with a weird sweet malt aftertaste and a bit of booze. Watery and a bit thin, but still slick. Waaay past it�s prime, but really happy to have tried this.

2003(?) Vintage 3/03/2010: New Glarus Unplugged Triple... Aroma: Malty and boozy; faint fruits and plenty of complex sugars; Appearance: Dull copper; mostly clear; pretty much still/no carbonation. Flavor: Slightly oxidized, but an interesting flavor combinations of toffee, caramel, plump and fuzzy fruits, mequite honey; slightly oxidized; plenty of alcohol, but not burning; adequately sweet and malty (the nuances of the original flavors have most likely collapsed over time). Palate: Medium to medium-full, slightly syrupy; flat. Overall: Unique flavor and aroma; that I am not able to put the descriptions into words at all since its characteristics are unlike anything I have had before; seems more like a thinned out, well-aged barleywine rather than a Triple; a bit of carbonation would probably bring this beer back to life; not too bad at all if it pushing 7 years old! 12 fl. oz. bottle (twist-off cap) from awaller05 via trade. Thanks Andy! Rating #127 for this beer.

12 oz. bottle shared by shigadeyo. Thanks Craig! Pours a hazy brownish amber color with zero head. The aroma had big ripe fruitiness with sweet malts and a little boozy; much more like an English barleywine now. The flavor was also more like an English barleywine with a sweet caramel maltiness and ripe fruits. Dry at the finish with a hint of the spices it probably had fresh. The alcohol was not present in the flavor, but was warming and I would say bigger than 10% now. Medium bodied; this has held up pretty well to be 7 years old.

Bottle shared by shigadeyo. Poured hazy dark amber pour with a minimal frothy white head that mostly diminished and has little lacing. Moderate to heavy toasted malt and grapefruit hop aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy prune sweet flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate duration. Good complex brew and maybe a little old.

12oz Bottle. 2003. Flickr &#40http://www.flickr.com/photos/26049401@N08/3849794613/&#41 A very moist, vinous wet apple cider presents in the nose. Aged, but smooth. A nip of pale caramel and a long glissando of ice cider. With a surprising snap from a twist-off, the beer pours a thinly hazed, but mostly clear, bronzed-golden, tanned, but bright. Little head, but a sparkle of carbonation. Graham cracker smacks first, then a sharp acidic tang of fruit cake, calvados, and gooseberries. Warm and lightly oxidized, but not obliterated by time. Not dusty, nor tasting of wet-cardboard. Instead, a very well melded spice, pale fruit, and cookie dough flavor. Palate is yielding, with a nice balance of alcohol, crisp sugars, and yeast flavors. The mature fruit flavors that ink at aged liqueurs and dried figs is probably the best aspect of this beer�s age. Surprisingly, and pleasantly, enjoyable. Thanks Jason, so much, for this special opportunity to reach into the back-catalog of New Glarus and give this a try before it completely fades into the fog of time.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a slightly hazy yellow gold with a white head that dissipates very slowly to the edges and laces slightly. Aroma has notes of pine and weed with a good amount of backing sweet grains. Flavor has some grass that is slightly dank with a hint of pine and backing earthy grains.

I had this as part of a sampler at the brew pub. This is one of their better beers and totally unique, making it worthy of trying...The loook is fine, nice and clear but not a piss water gold...What stands out about this beer is the aroma. At first I thought I was nuts but since this was the first beer of the night I went with instinct and my beer buddy finally agreed. It smells like marijunia, throughout. I kept looking around to see if someone was smoking outside, and they weren�t. The taste is ok, not as great as the aroma, not pot taste just a light non skunky pilsner. If you like the smell of weed give this is a shot.

On tap at the brewpub. Reviewed from notes. Pours a lint straw color with a nice white head and some lacing. Nose brings a good dose of Noble hops backed by a bit of grain. Quite strong and nice. T wage has similar elements, but they aren�t as forceful. Feel is fairly thin with fairly high carbonation. Drinks quite well and is a pretty good American example of the style. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 10-11-2010

Draft� RBSG 2010� Hazy straw-colored lager with a small, creamy, white head. Good retention. The bouquet is restrained, but I�m able to pull peppery hops and pale malts. Medium-bodied with tickling carbonation. Snazzy, peppery hop bitterness. Crisp, bitter, tongue-numbing finish.

Draft at brewpub. Pours a murky golden amber with average carbonation, and an earthy mouthfeel. Nice bold flavor of pilsner malts and biscuit, countered by good dose or European hops. The Noble hops are definitely sensed. Dry finish. I am somewhat surprised by the low ratings.
Tap. Pours a clear yellow. Notes of herbs, hay, grass, a little skunk. Typical. Ok not great
on tap-pours a thin white head and hazy straw color. Aroma is light malt/wheat, lemon/grassy (saaz?) hops. Taste is light malt/wheat, tart lemon/grassy/earthy hops, yeast. OK effervescence.
draft at brewpub - Pours hazy and yellowish with some lacing. The mild aroma has some hops presence. There�s a good hops flavor and finish in this medium bodied brew. Nice pilsner.

Pallid yellow, rather clear, under a thin white head that leaves watery streaks of lace. Weak aroma with some mild green pepper. Light honey sweetness over German hop bittering, yet leaving an "off" aftertaste. Dry, almost "crisp". On tap at Arbor Brewing Co., Ann Arbor, MI 48104

A good pils, and something I could have pints of. Creamy, cloudy, peachy, lots of lace. Noble hops. Good bittering, and yet nice balance. Understated carbonation. One of the best of their abundant lineup.
Yellow orange pour. Musty aroma. Taste is a bit like a pretzel and malt. I like it, but not a favorite.

10 oz mug from Gerst Haus. This stuff ain�t bad at all. Get it in a fishbowl unless you want their icy mugs. They literally will freeze the beer. Decent body but incredibly smooth. Light and tasty. I can drink many of these no problem.

Light, refreshing, very drinkable, and decently malty. It tastes incredibly clean and flavorful. I would have guessed this to be a Mild or Bitter. The style is so balanced and sessionable you would have guessed it to be English. On tap at Melrose Billiards, Nashville, TN

I drink this at Gerst-Bavarian Haus, Sportsmans and Smitty�s in Evansville, IN. All three are on Franklin St. The beer itself is not extremely flavorful, not bland by the least. Light tan head, amber pour, very smooth. Friday Lunch specials with the great Catfish basket and a 22oz fishbowl of Gerst Amber Ale for less than $10 is always a plus!

Gerst is actually a lager. I work at the Sportsmans in Cool Springs and the owners own the rights to Gerst but its contract brewed by Pitt. Brewing Com. I think the ABV is around 5.3 not a whole lot of flavor but very drinkable.
Amber, decent sized white head. Mildly caramel aroma. Decent malt profile, clean and thinly bodied. Smooth, and very little hop flavor. Surprisingly not bad.

When in Nashvegas, check out the Gerst Haus, the decendant of the Original Gerst Brewing Company employee cafeteria. This place is chocked full of great beeraphernalia. We used to buy kegs of Gerst for our parties. A fine amber ale. Very nice balance for those who are not used to a beer with color or flavor. I've nothing but fond memories of this one.
Pours a medium amber with a ivory/beige head. Aroma and flavor are mostly of malt and caramel. Not a terrible beer, but below average in the amber category.

On tap at the Sportsman's Grille in Nashville. Pours a clear amber with a medium off-white head. Light malt aroma. Medium bodied with a kind of bland malt flavor, along with a little caramel. Finish is short and sweet. Not too great but a nice find.

Draft 0.15l at Cafe De Engelbewasrde Amsterdam, The Netherlands. 23.01.2017. Pour it hazy golden color with medium white head. Aroma yeasty with some grainy character. Taste malty, some grassy note, yeasty smooth maybe even too much, some apples, after taste skunky, strange, light to medium body, average carbonation, OK.

Draft at Caf� De Engelbewaarder, Amsterdam. Near clear amber with a big off white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, yeast, light citrus and fruity hop notes. Flavour is light to moderate sweet and bitter. Medium bodied with a fluffy pillow soft texture and soft carbonation. Pretty nice and definitely tops regular Palm.
Nice deaught beer in Amsterdam. Good malty taste and even some hops at the enda. Palate also with some freshness.
Geen slecht bier, maar ongefilterde bieren zijn sowieso al niet mijn favoriet en dit is geen uitzondering. Leuk om eens te proberen, maaar daar blijft het bij

Tap 20cl. Poured into a tulip tasting glass @bier museum Brugge [5-3-2016]. Hazy medium golden, good two finger off-white head, good retention and lacing; aroma grain, yeast, spices, lime, lemon grass; taste medium sweet and slightly bitter, grainy, malty, citrusy, average duration, sweetbitter finish; medium body, watery to oily texture, soft carbonation; fresh and pleasant but not great.

On tap, 20cL. @Bruges Beer Museum. A sparkling golden orange opaque beer with a big creamy white head ; great retention ; ok lacing. Roast, spice, pear, caramel, biscuit. Medium sweet, light dry refreshing, bitter note. Medium body and texture, flat, sweet roasty biscuit finish. Overall, beautiful, enjoyable, unusual aromatic nose for me (nitrogen?) ; 1-dimensional.

On tap at Engelbewaarder. Cloudy brown orange colour, white foam. Lovely soft mouthfeel, great carbonation. Fresh. Fruity, yeasty, estery. Bit of yeast bite, actually. Some caramel malts. Very pleasant and highly refreshing and drinkable.

Keg at Hotel Centrum, Beersel as �Ongefilterd Palm Hoge Gisting�. Amber orange, still, hazy, big foamy dense off-white head. Aroma is apple, yeast, citrus, musty notes. Body is medium to light, smooth, low carbonation. Taste is apple skin, dry, some cucumber notes, soft mints, papery dry finish. Not bad.

Keg at Hotel Centrum, Beersel, 20/11/15. Clear golden with a decent off white covering that retains well. Nose is light citric peel, straw, grain, bread dough, floral notes. Taste comprises sweet malt, lemon rind, light wooded tones, stale bread, grain. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. So so.

On tap at �Caf� De Engelbewaarder�. Hazy, golden amber with a medium large, fluffy, slowly diminishing, tan to white head. Sweetish-malty aroma of caramel, sweet malts and a bit of honey. Sweetish-malty taste of caramel, bread and a bit of honey, followed by a short, slightly bitter, yeasty finish. Medium body, slightly creamy and smooth mouthfeel, flat. Nice stuff.

Bottle. Hazy light golden body with a short white head. Aroma of lemon, straw, biscuit, corn. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Light on aroma and flavor.
From notes, rated at Great American Beer Festival. Will add more notes if I get to rate this again. Good Kolsch.

On tap at Blackstone, pours a clear pale blonde with a small white head. Aroma is very light, with straw and biscuity malt. Flavour is similarly light, with straw and cereal malt. Dry and easy to drink, but not authentically kolsch-like.
Sampled at Great American Beer Festival 2019 in Denver, Colorado. Light, clean, malty, sweet.

On Tap at Blackstone Brewery, Nashville, TN, 4.5.16. Light gold. Malty aroma with a little bit of fruity hops. Sweet and grainy taste and a little buttery. Light-to-medium body, fizzy, sweet and a little buttery finish.
Pours a bright yellow with a thin white head. Aroma is earthy and herbal hops, some bread malts. Flavor is sweet bread and earthy malts. Light body and a light drinker. Decent.
12 oz bottle. Hazy gold with an average white head. Aroma is of grain, grass, light florals. Taste is of grass, straw, grain, weeds, florals, and herbal notes.
Super easy to drink! I was a little apprehensive ordering this since I felt that almost all Blackstone beers are heavy. This one was light and tasted like a normal beer.

Tap. Pours clear pale golden, medium white head, creamy, nice lacing. Aroma is grassy, grain, bread, perhaps a hint of urine. Flavor follows, light sweet, fairly bitter. Light body. Fairly standard for style other than bitterness

On tap at the 12th Street Tap House in Nashville. It poured a clear yellow colour with weak white foam. Light on the aroma and flavour. Fairly true-to-style, but not as crisp and grainy, noble hoppy, and minerally as a classic German or Czech Pilsener. Light body, strong carbonation, dry finish. Good and drinkable on a hot summer night in any case.
Pours golden with a white head. Aroma of malts, yeast and hay. Taste is grain, grass and pine.
Draught at the Blackstone Restaurant, Nashville, TN. Clear pale yellow golden colour with a tiny white head. Weak malty aroma. Mild sweet hops and malt in the flavour. Quite easy.
Light yellow pour with a white head. Aroma is faintly herbal, while the flavor is slightly grainy but mostly nonexistent.
Gold pour with creamy white head and lace. Paper, and light malt aroma. Wet paper, and semi sweet start with a dry finish. Very light earthy bitter.

Super clear and fizzy, glass-like golden. Aroma is a slight champagne nose, little bit of pale malt. Crisp pilsner taste with noticeable hop presence, but not so much hop flavor. Easy drinking and very clean.
Nearly clear yellow, quick white head. Aroma is caramelized sweet malt, hay, grassy hops. Taste is a big grassiness, sweet pale maltiness.

Draught. Pours sparkling yellow with an average, white head, lasting with fair lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (husky grain, hay, straw, cereal), average hop (grass), average yeast (sweat) with notes of corn, butter, and pear. Light bodied, thin texture, average carbonation, and a bitter finish. Long duration, light sweetness and acidity, moderate bitterness.

Source:On tap at the brewpub. Glass:10 oz pilsner glass. Appearance:Poured a clear yellow with a thin, bubbly white head. Aroma:Aroma was bready, with hints of yeast and grass. Flavor:Zesty citrus and biscuit malt, with a mild bitter finish. Palate:Light body with solid carbonation. Overall:This is probably targeted at the Bud Light crowd, but I thought it was an excellent, light drinking beer.
draft at restaurant in nashville,tn.pours hazy gold,no head,slight hop aroma,nothing going on in the taste dept.Nt very good.
A well-balanced American version of a dry Irish red ale. The hops provide a smooth floral flavor and aroma without being pungent. The flavor is a complex mix of spices for an enjoyable aftertaste.

Cask at the brewpub. Pours a clear amber with a thick creamy white head. Aroma of sweet and bready malts. Flavor is certainly malt forward- crackery, bready, slight fruit and floral notes. Mild bitterness in the finish. Ok, drinkable, but not very complex. 6/4/6/3/13 (3.2/5)

Draft. Pours a deep reddish amber with a medium-sized off-white head. Aroma is spicy, floral, grassy hops and caramel malt. Flavor is spicy/bitter and caramel. Slightly astringent mouthfeel. Tasty and drinkable.
Pours a deep copper color with a tan head. Aroma is caramel, toast, floral, and slight grassy hop notes. Flavor is malty, caramel, some biscuit, and a bitter grassy, almost astringent, hop finish.

Sampled at Schlafly Repeal of Prohibition festival. Pours copper with a soapy tan head. The aroma has sweet toasty malt, nuttiness and overall clean smoothness. Medium crisp body with light carbonation. The flavor starts like the aroma, but is a bit metallic and medicinal. The finis is very minerally and a touch sour.
(draft at Schlafly Repeal of Prohibition) Dark amber with malt aroma, some hops. Flavor is mostly caramel malt but a definite floral hops presence.
Dark amber with a beige head. Floral hop and sweet malt aroma. Floral hop and pine taste but finish is sweeter than bitter. An excellent amber with some hop kick.
On tap at the brewpub. Clear red body with a thin off white head. Aroma is basic malts, caramel. Taste is great sweet caramel body with a floral grassy bitter finish.

2009 Tap. A lower end amber ale. Surprising amounts of hoppiness that clash with the malts that typically predominate amber ales. Aroma of strong hops with a light maltiness. Dark orange-brown with not much head. Not that great.

Date: November 08, 2008 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear deep red, fine white head, thick spidery lace Aroma: sweet bready aroma, nice floral hops Flavor: sweet malt flavor, nice caramel sweetness, bready character, lots of floral and citrus hops, touch of earthyness, light bitter finish Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.2/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: *4

Clear dark gold with a pinkish hue. Nothing bad in the arom, but nothing good either. there is a thickness to the body, but hardly any flavor- kind of like lettuce. Chewy but dry, this beer is empty. On Tap at the brewpub.
Pours a clear golden-orange body with a lacing off-white to beige head. Smells of bubblegum and little banana. Flavor is sweet corn and cream. Finish is somewhat sweet with a faint hoppiness.
Noogfest High 5. Sample from a growler thanks to Butters. Golden orange, white head. Aroma is malty, caramel, fruits, toffee. Taste is the same, sweet fruits and toffee.

On draft at Woody�s Smokes and Brews. Pours a very clear dark gold with fair near white head. Very faint banana notes and honey. Flavors of sweet vanilla, corn, DMS, and some alcohol heat in the nose and tail. Very slight grassy hop bitterness in the finish. Pretty much spot on for BJCP heller bock style. But I didn�t personally care for it all that much.

Growler from Blackstone. I poured this beer, walked away for 10 minutes and came back to a glass with an amazing spider-web design left by the head. The aroma is honey, wheat, apricot, cherry, and I could tell there would be roast in the taste. Strong flavor of roast caramel and some citrus. Pretty good overall, not a good session beer though.

5 hour hold growler brought back by my buddy Erik. Pours a dark gold with a decent white head. The nose is pretty sugary with some corn, crisp hops, and pears. This is a very sweet lager up front and in the sticky finish. There are slightly rosy notes along with wood, corn husks, and paper. I�m not a huge "light-colored lager" fan in the first place and I found this one to be a bit heavy on the sucrose flavor.

Tap. O.k., skip visuals for a minute, this smells like my mom. Seriously. The heavy perfume she would wear when I was a kid, the smell of Winston�s smoked throughout the day, the smell of sweat and defiance she had getting back from a shift at whatever crap job she worked to support 4 of us, all that was brought to mind. This has that perfumy indignant thing working. Orange peel and light cherry cough drop flavor. This has a slight amber edge to the pour. There is more than a little cherry here. A bit sticky, maybe the best maibock I�ve had, I�d have to check on that. The thickness makes it hard to discern, but damn, this has a nice finish like sugar daddy with warm pretzel, and a warm muffin note too. Ap-4 ar-10 tas-7 pal-3 ov-17

Daft at Restaurant. Pale color in the glass with a white head that left great lacing. Light citrus in the aroma. The flavor found spices and lemon with a grainy aftertaste. Medium body, creamy texture, and a hint of bitterness throughout. Not bad!

On tap into a 10 oz. ale glass. Lemon zest and yeast in the nose with some light bread. Clear gold yellow in the glass with a mostly diminishing medium sized white head; oily and spotty lacing. Smooth, medium to full bodied. Tastes of rye bread, honey sweetness, and pistachio strong in the finish. Spicy and noble hops; a bit mealy with a bit of DME on the finish too. Late astringency mars the mouthfeel. I found this beer to be bland and weak in the flavor for the amount of body this has. It ended up syrupy in texture; I�ve had thicker beers that felt lighter because they balanced their feel with their flavor and ingredient palate. On reflection, I should have known how this beer would play in my mouth watching the slow carbonation struggle up through the middle of the glass in a clear beer that was lighter in color than I expected. A disappointment overall.
Pours a foggy gold with a medium head and thin lacing. Aroma and flavor are malty and spicey with an underlying sweetness. An enjoyable beer.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: On draft-Poured a dark red color with anice white head.Aromas were of light malt and caramel and a light sweetness.Taste was of light malt and light bread and caramel,overall an ok beer,but not the best maibock I have had.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: on tap-pours an off white head and amber color. Aroma is medium malt-sweet caramel, bready. Taste is medium malt-sweet caramel, bready, secondary hops bitterness, alcohol. Occasional. OK carbonation.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Tap at the brewpub. Clear orange in color with a nice lasting white head. Malty and nice hop aroma. Big malty hoppy flavor. Nice malty clean flavor. Very nice beer. Well balanced. Very drinkable.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: 2005 edition. Clean malty aroma. Big delicious malty clean flavor. Nice malt sweetness. very drinkable and authentic. Tap at the brewpub. Clear yellow-oranage, lasting white head. Malty, with a slight licorice aroma. Flavor of big malt, nice hop bitterness and balance. Dry finish. This may be old. 6-5-6-4-12

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Nice dark amber color, with a great malt, fruit, and hop nose. Very complex finish, with a fruity, slightly heavy mouthfeel presence, but tempered with a good malt/hop presence. A very nice maibock.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Deep red/auburn with pitted rocky pure white head. Excellent head retention.
