Initial sweetness is balanced with sharp bitter bite midswallow, ending with a light lingering sweetness in the swallow. Bready notes emerge at finish. Top it off with a strong malty nose and you have a great beer.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Fairly light mouthfeel for a stout. Dark brown with small, quickly dissipating head. Smelled like freshly brewed dark roast. Excellent roasty bitterness on initial swallow. Sweetness emerges mid swallow and makes its way into the aftertaste. Very good stout.

Bottle 50cl. Light unclear light to medium yellow orange color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, caramel, moderate hoppy, moderate yeasty, rubber. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20090321]

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Almost clear amber golden with a dense shaving foam style off-white head leaving laces. Fresh and lightly citrusy nose. Medium body, lightly tart fruitiness and then a vague smoky note that hardly is intended. 210309

Bottle, 4.5%. Weak caramelly hop aroma. Cloudy orange colour. Very big tan head. The flavour starts off with a little malt and fruitiness. There is also a mild, yet distinct smoke note. Low bitterness. High carbonation.

Bottled. A hazy dark golden beer with a huge off-white head - over carbonated or infected. The aroma is sweet with notes of hops and flowers. The flavor is sweet with notes of elderflowers and an acidic edge of an infection.

50 cL bottle. Pours slight cloudy orange with a huge off-white head. Dry ashtray/tobacco and light spiced hops aroma. Mild smoked and light citric flavoured with a light bitterness showing through. Ends dry, slight malty, smoked and bitter.

Bottle. Golden and lively with a large cream foam. Aromas are buttery and salty malts with some spices. Soft citrus with yeast. Flavours are sweet toffee malts with bubblegum and soft citrus. Yeasty and spritzy on the finish.

Cask conditioned @ Black Boy, Winchester. Starts off malty sweet, toffee with a slight buttery edge. Fruity hops come through slightly on the finish. Buttery toffee verging on diacetyl type flavours prevented me from enjoying it more.
[Cask conditioned at Oliver Twist, Sotckholm] Golden amber coloured. Slightly fruity aroma and flavour. Dry and bitter finish.

Copper colour. Fruity aroma. Sweetish palate with more fruit. Some restrained bitterness coming through late. Distinct hoppiness of the finish. Medium bodied and smooth. The sweetness and the hop character were rather strained bedfellows, but it worked quite well. Just a touch too sweet to score higher for me. Cask (handpump), The Black Boy, Winchester.
Hazy light amber, no head. Sweet re siny aroma. Grass, raisn and toffee in flavour with a unclean short finish.
bottle from brewery batch 110609sg, hoppy aroma, hazy golden colour, minimal head/foam, medium bitterness, light sweetness, smooth bitterness, medium body, slick feel, average beer
From A Bottle.Cloudy light amber in colour with a medium head,citric aroma,taste is dry with some honey and a bitter finish.

Bottle conditioned. Amber gold, good rocky white head and good condition. Strangely chocolaty aroma for a golden beer, honeyed malt and a touch more chocolate in the mouth and a dry powdery (chocolate?) finish
Bottle conditioned. Amber gold, good rocky white head and moderate head. Hoppy aromas mixed with apple fruit, hoppy in the mouth becoming very bitter in the finish and ultimately strangely soapy.

30-Mar-14 (660-ml bottle) If "Diablo" is yet another attempt at a Duvel knock-off (like seemingly all these "Devil" beers are), then this is probably the worst I�ve tasted. It�s bready and yeasty with some light, grassy and fruity overtones, some coconut, a light grassiness. Aromas are bready and doughy, some tropical fruits, but not much going on here. The beer is medium in weight, medium in carbonation, and smooth on the palate. Hazy, golden in color, and capped by half an inch of white head that settles to a ring. Overall, pretty boring and not worth drinking any more than necessary to finish writing my review.
Bottle from perfect pour. Pours golden with very little head. A bit fruity on the tongue. tastes metallic and funky and not in a good way. Finish lingers a bit. Nasty stuff!

Old paper review from summer 2009. Decent light gold, a little icky with the moldy looking floaties, small white cap with good retention and ropy, slippery lacing. Thick fruity aroma, guava, mild spiced yeast - appealing but the fruitiness misses. Fresh dark tropical fruit taste with a touch of citrus, mild yeast, slight well placed bitterness, too warm = too sweet. Not bad, not all that far off from some US versions. (**update- I doubt that last statement!)

poured copper color into glass with offwhite head. there was a very light lacing on side of glass. very little hop odour to this one was a little malty (sweet). although there was some alcohol as well. if more hops would have been much better beer.

Picked this up at Corti Bros. in Sacramento, one of the better selections in the area. Pours a deep amber, not much head. Smell and taste are very sweet, bitter citrus, and sadly that carries onto the taste and mouthfeel. An almost metalic taste, but not off-puting, just bitter sweet battery, is that bad?? Good beer, not great, maybe it�s a code date issue.

Beautiful golden pour covered by a gentle white slice. Softly estery (green, unripe banana), vegetal and gently malty, bready, almost cakey maltiness. It starts off very sweet on the tongue and the fact that hops are almost absent does not help to redeem that. The light mineral aspects growing towards the finish feel slightly metallic. Pretty simplistic, linear palate in which a growing amount of alcohol is felt with each sip.I did not notice any major flaws compared to other raters, but the general dullness, heat and sloppy crackery malts are not great qualities either.
Sample at Julio�s Spring Beer Fest (disclaimer - memory somewhat blurred after perhaps a few too many samples) Not impressed
Pours a medium golden yellowish color. Aromas of fruit, yeast and some pepper. Flavors are sour, yeasty, and a touch of sweetness at the finish.

My bottle, labelled in english, states that this is a Belgian style ale. It pours a slightly hazy deep golden with a frothy white head. Aroma is sweet grains and hard-rock candy. The palate is sweet and slightly sticky, grainy with hints of banana. No spice, no yeast, nearly no bitterness. It is more like a euro strong lager to me than anything. In keeping with the label, the appearance and profile of this beer are more in keeping with a Belgian blonde (albeit a rather poor one) than an English ale.

Bottle. Pours a clear golden color with a small white head. Nose is lightly spicey with a sticky sugary note. Palate is medium and tingly with a nice finish. Flavors of light spiciness, coriander maybe, with a light toasted malt note and some sticky honey and caramel notes. The description listed here is wrong, this is what my bottle says " This is an Andean Strong ale with a creamy head, a smooth beginning, a fruity light profile and an explosive finish! Aged 3 months prior to bottling"

Rated on 10-09-2009 (Bottle) This beer pours a small fizzy white head with a short retention, mostly transparent/slightly hazy pale yellow body, fizzy, lively, fast rising carbonation, floaties, and one ring of lacing. The Aroma is malty, vanilla and hops. The Taste mimics the Aroma and this beer has a dry finish. The Palate is tingly and this beer is medium bodied. Overall, this beer has a lot of sediment in the bottom of the bottle and the flavor of this beer just did not leave me wanting it again. The taste seems disjointed and all over the place. This is a beer I do not recommend.
A little bit of hay, a little bit of honey, a little bit of butter. Not particularly impressive in any capacity.

22 oz. bottle, $5 at HyVee in Iowa July 2010, kept in the fridge since then. First, I want to respect this for being, as the label says, totally sourced from Argentine-grown ingredients. And for being brewed, if you�ll Google Map the location, in a village so far up in the Andes that anyone stepping out back for a smoke is in Chile. That said: Pours a golden color with amber highlights, some particles floating around. Sudsy head. Smell is malty and beery, a touch of fruit ester. There may also be a note of bacterial contamination, but I can�t say for sure. Taste seems pretty square within the Blond Ale style. They�re calling it an Argentine White Ale, but I only get barley malt here. Slight note of wood smoke. Just slightly tart. A bit of dead yeast way in the background. Frankly, I kind of like it. Maybe it�s the luck of a well-sealed bottle kept on a shelf without too much light. Ah, but trying to pour the rest of the beer into the glass brings up a big chunk of sediment.

Bottle: &nbsp Straw in color, large rocky white head, spotty lacing, mild carbonation. &nbsp Looks okay at least. &nbsp Soft grassiness and floral notes on the nose. &nbsp Little bit of DMS/Band Aid on first sip. &nbsp Otherwise a bit mealy. &nbsp Not as bad as other seem to be rating it, but certainly not great. &nbsp Loads of straw or grasiness on the tongue, especially on the finish. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate. &nbsp Some fruit skin on the finish. &nbsp A little bit of a metallic twang emerges after the finish. &nbsp Honestly, not as bad as everyone says it is, but certainly not great.
Appearance: clear golden. Aroma: light vanilla, lemongrass. Taste: bitter, light citrus/lemon. Finish: medium, bitter, mineral notes. Notes: Boring, not very good.

bottle from the distro 6/4/10. darker pour than expected and slightly hazy. oddly medicinal aroma... bitter dried herbs, spicy hops, dust and old stale grain. the flavor is medicinal as well... terribly bitter and dirty. crisp sharp texture is irritating and drives the awful flavor further into my tongue. this may be the first beer i have truly spit out... curiosity won�t even let me swallow this crap. yucky... 3/4/1/1/3/1.2

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a large sized head of yellow brown colored bubbles that were mostly diminishing and left behind a semi-hazy with floating particulate yellow white colored body. The mild aroma was floral and malty. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of floral coriander hops and malt. An OK brew just nothing special.

This beer is very different. It smells salty and tastes salty with some underlying fruit characteristics. Good carbonation and froth but lackluster. Probably a good food beer but not with pizza or wings.
Sample at Julio�s Spring Beer Fest (disclaimer - memory somewhat blurred after perhaps a few too many samples) And again, not impressed
Pours a golden yellow. Aromas of pale malt, some hops, some citrus. Flavor of light malts, citrus and some hop bite.

30-Mar-14 (660-ml bottle) I guess as these Jerome beers go, this is one of the better ones, but this still isn�t that great. It pours a black body with almost no head. The nose is lightly roasty, but also has a prominent black olive component, some soy sauce, and light blackberry tartness. On the palate, it�s not so much roasty, but shows black olives, coffee, dark chocolate, some tobacco, dark berries, and earth. There�s some tartness here, and not just a hint, and this is a bit off-putting. The beer is light-medium bodied and seems quite thin for a stout. Carbonation is light as well, and the finish is reasonably dry. Overall, this is below average stout. It�s thin, tastes like black olives, and has an odd tartness.

Rated on 10-06-2009. This bottled beer pours a medium sized tan fizzy head with a short retention, opaque black body, very little carbonation, and spotty amounts of lacing. The Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, and dried fruits. The Taste mimics the Aroma. The Palate is tingly and thin. This beer is light-medium bodied. Overall, the Aroma is better than the flavor. The texture is too thin for this beer�s style and does not come across as a true Stout. This is a beer that is not on my "want to drink again sometime" list.

31st July 2009 Oapque black beer. Light crisp palate. Smooth malt, sourish like a good porter. Very light smoke, barely there. Mild sour fruit. Smooth, almost creamy, dark malt and a nice minerally finish. Finally a decent Argentinian beer!

22 ounce bottle (labeled Andean Stout). Served in a pint glass, the beer pours dark brown/black with an inch tan head that stayed around for a while. There�s also a good amount of lacing. Aroma is nice and sweet, the brew smells like dark fruit (raisins, prunes), molasses, chocolate, coffee and some charred/burnt malt. The flavors are the same as the aroma, but not quite as strong. I do like the taste, but it does seem a little weak in comparison to the aroma. Mouthfeel/body is medium, it�s a little bit coating with moderate carbonation. Overall it�s a decent enough brew, I�d buy it again in the future. It�s certainly worth trying for just $3.99 a bottle!
This is a good smooth dark Irish style ale. Smooth molasis malts with a a soy sauce aroma

Bottle: &nbsp Black, large light brown head, nice lacing. &nbsp Nice roasted malt nose, some lactose like sweetness. &nbsp Fairly roasty on the tongue, start to finish. &nbsp Not a big malt base, very little hop which is welcomed. &nbsp Slight ash on the backside. &nbsp Moderate to thin body and mouthfeel. &nbsp More astray on the finish. &nbsp Simple, but straight forward and respectable.

660mL bomber thing from Cleveland Park Liquors. The pour is a deep brown with no head formation. Scant, weak, large bubbles form and subside. Nose is salty black olives. Taste is olive juice, astringent bitterness, salt, chlorine, pool cleaner. Non existent palate. Drainpour. Needs a new brewer probably.
poured dark and dirty into glass, light brown head with little lacing left behind, a malty sweeter stout than I am used to, a medium body and carbonation, takes a bit of getting used to.

Bottle from World Market. Opaque black-brown pour with a brown head leaving sparse lace. Chocolate, licorice, coffee, cherries and dates flesh out the aromas from this surprisingly light-medium bodied stout. There is a tartness early and in the finish and then a metallic aftertaste as if I bit my lip. With the medium carbonation and relatively light body, the mouth feel is lacking. Interestingly, this stout is sweet and sour early, transitioning to umami and sour at the finish, with minimal bitterness throughout. I thought this could be a nice sessionable sweet stout, but the metallic aftertaste ruins that idea. I�d try it again, but would like to have it closer to the source.
Older bottle never opened from Thomas. Pours thin. Slight cola and chocolate flavor. Carbonation fades. Not too impressive.

Clear black hue with a thin and sticky light beige head. The nose has some earthy caramel and some biscuity chocolate. The flavor is much the same, soft and medium bodied. Light caramel and light biscuity tones with a very light and semi-dry chocolaty tones. Meh.

On tap as part of sampler. Dark amber color with minimal head. Lightly chocolaty and lightly bitter. This whole beer strikes me as a little thin and watery from appearance to finish. Perhaps they were trying to be truer to style, but I prefer the Americanized version of this beer.

Pours dark molasses brown. Moderate head moderate lacing. Prominent dark chocolate and espresso combination that is a great balance of sweet and bitter. Mild carbonation and medium body. Long finish of mild bitter hops and roasted malt. This is one of their best beers.

Tasted on tap at Nashville brewpub in standard pint glass. Opaque dark brown color with creamy beige head. Some retention and lace. Bready, nutty, hints of dark coffee and chocolate. Conservative hops bitterness, very little in aroma. Fruity ale yeast esters. Medium carbonation, crisp dry finish. Satisfying, true-to-style porter, but otherwise unmemorable.
Sampled at Franklin location. Dark brown, beige head. Aroma of burnt malt. taste is milky sweet with roast, pretty good. Medium body and carbonation.

Sampled at Bosco�s Squared in Memphis. Dark brown with a bit of red. Big roasted notes and a well hopped porter. This brewery seems to like well hopped beers. Decent chocolate and coffee. Those hops make this a different take on a classic style. Nice.
Opaque dark red with a creamy tan head. Roasted grain and mild caramel aroma and taste with a chocolate finish.
Amber-brown with a thin light tan head. Aroma of hops, malt and chocolate. Flavor of roasted nuts, coffee, chocolate and hops. Slightly bitter finish. B
Dark brown-orange with a lasting off white foam. Aroma is chocolate, nutty, caramel, roast. Taste is astringent roast, chocolate, caramel, light malt bitter finish.

Draft sample at Boscos Memphis. Poured a clear brown color with an average creamy off-white head that was mostly lasting and produced good lacing. Moderate roasted coffee malt and chocolate aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium roasted coffee sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Sold drinkable brew.

This is the first beer that I've had that was brewed from a recipe in Charlie Papazians' book that I didn't brew myself. I couldn't have brewed it any better. No homebrew taste at all ;.) A good brown ale. Had it cask conditioned, but Charlie autographed a bottle personally to take home!
Pours a dark amber with a thin cream-colored head and thin lacing. Nuts, honey & malt in the aroma and flavor. A good ale, smooth drinking.

Had on tap in Nashville and it was cask-conditioned. Dark brown with tan creamy head, some lacing , medium-bodied. Aroma was what I expected, nutty and sweet with a hint of fruit. The taste was a little less nutty and a little more sweet. Balance was okay, a little more dry hop characteristics would have made this a top-notch brew. Still, it worked great with the steak I had for dinner.

From a sampler: Pours a brownish-amber color with a thin off-white head and thin lacing. Light malt and honey aroma. Medium- to light-bodied with both sweet malt and tart hops flavors. It also has a long and lightly bitter finish. A decent Brown Ale.

Draught. Pours pale yellow with a large, fizzy, white head, mostly lasting with good lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (straw, grain, meal), light hops (grass), heavy yeast (sweat) with notes of paper and dust. Light bodied, thin texture, lively carbonation, and a chalky finish. Average duration, light sweetness, acidity, and bitterness. Pretty good blonde ale; light and refreshing.

Tap at MBBC. Pours a clear golden color with a small white head that fell off quite quickly. Aroma is almost non existent maybe some malt if you really dig. Flavor is somewhat on the malty sweetish side with maybe some honey and some mild hops in the finish. Super lite and quite nice on a hot summer day.
Draft at the brewpub. Very clear yellow. Some citrus aromas. Grainy and macro like flavors. Just eh...

Tap @ brewpub: Pale gold with a ring white head. Mildly sweet and grainy flavors with a soapy aftertaste. Aroma is mild. I guess its a good refreshing drink if you have been walking around Manhattan Beach and need a break.

Sample at the brewpub. This beer is a clear pale yellow-gold color with a thin bone white head that burns away quickly. Spotty lacing on the glass. The aroma is mildly hoppy with a bit of grainy malt. Light-bodied with lively carbonation and a light hops character. Some sweet malt is present too. The finish is short and mildly bitter with a touch of spiced hops aftertaste. Alright for what it is.
On Tap @ brewery Very clear golden blonde Initial sweetness fair light craft brew.

On tap at brewery, 01/07/08. Light golden, crystal clear, thin skin of foam. Almost no aroma; what�s there is hard to ID. Typical corn flavor. Sweet off the bat, but fades quickly. No hop, no malt to speak of. Yawn.
Light gold color, small white head that lingers. Aroma and taste of light malt, bread, honey. Light and easy with no bad flavors. Decent for a blonde. Tried on tap at the brewery.
Tap @ Brewpub: Clear, pellucid yellow, no head or lacing. Nose of faint malt, subtle hop. The flavor is toasty, balanced and grassy. Finishes clean, still obviously thin and made with pale malt.
Pretty standard beer, kinda tasted like a bud light. Nothing really special about it. It had a really light aroma, and dry finish.

Draught. Pours clear pale yellow with a fizzy, white head, mostly lasting with excellent lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (grain, meal, cereal), light hops (grass), heavy yeast (sweat, dough) with notes of corn. Light bodied, dry texture, soft carbonation, and a chalky finish. Average duration, light sweetness, acidity, and bitterness. Closer to pale lager or malt liquor than a Bohemian Pilsener.

Tap at MBBC. Pours a clear golden color with a nice white head. Aroma of malt bread spicy hops. Taste is crisp malty spicy hops. I remeber it was great with the Thai chicken pizza sitting in one of the front windows open on a warm summer afternoon. Great session beer.

This is ok, but does not taste nearly as good as it looks or smells. It is dark gold with a medium, creamy head, slightly off-white, that slowly shrinks and leaves nice lace in even rings. The smell is mostly bready with some honey, citrus and flowers. It�s quite malty and very nice. The taste, though, is mostly just crackers with some white bread, with cracker aftertaste and a dominant, rather bland bitterness of grass and lemon pulp. The flavour is weak and not ciomplex but it holds up well to food.
Tap @ brewpub: Yellow gold with ring head. Grainy aroma as you would expect. The flavor is crisp with typical grain hairspray flavor with a sweet aftertaste. It�s actually not bad for a Pils.

Sample at the brewpub. This beer is a clear golden color with a medium and fluffy white head that burns off slowly. Thin rings of lace on the glass. Aroma of Saaz hops and sweet malt, along with sweet spices. Light, effervescent body with a tart hops and spice flavor backed up by woody malt. The finish is fairly hoppy and bitter and leaves a spiced aftertaste. I believe the bartender told me the brewer was from the Czech Republic, so maybe that is why I enjoyed this beer the most out of the ones I tried.
Assistant Brewery Jake and Brewer Karol gave me some of the Pils direct from the tank, unfiltered. No off flavors, tasty, fairly rich with nice, lightly hoppy finish.
Not sure if it's intentional but this has something of an oaky flavor. Sweet with a dry hoppy finish.

Draught. Pours hazy pale yellow with a small, fizzy, white head, mostly lasting with good lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (cereal, bread), light hops (grass), average yeast (dough) with notes of banana and lemon. Light bodied, sticky texture, average carbonation, and a metallic finish. Average duration, light sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.
Draft at the brewpub. Murky orange color with little head. Aromas and flavors of heavy wheat twang. Some citrus aromas, but not much else.

Tap @ brewpub: Pale gold with a thin white head that glides over the top of the beverage. Mild flavor, not very yeasty. It�s pretty similar to the Beach Blonde, but with a fuller body. Pretty tasty and easy to drink.

Sample at the brewpub. Not sure why a perfectly good Doppelbock name was wasted on this beer, but whatever. Served with a lemon. Pours a hazy yellow color with a medium thin ivory white head that diminishes slowly. Latticework lacing. Wheaty aroma with some citrus fruit. Light-bodied and fruity with wheat and light spice flavors. The finish is soft and fruity with a lingering wheat aftertaste. Decent overall.
On tap at brewery, 01/07/08. Called Dominator Hefeweizen on my visit. Properly cloudy and light yellow with good head. Wheat aroma and flavor. Not much else in flavor profile. Blah.

Actually called the Dominator Hefeweizen. Cloudy, light gold color with small lingering head. Light wheat aroma with the addition of slight sweetness and subtle spice in flavor. Neither banana nor citrus in flavor. Drinking it right now at the brewery!

Tap @ Brewpub: Dominator Hefeweizen: Super cloudy orange, light head and lacing. Nose of funky wheat, lame american style with a stale and overpowering wheat smell. The flavor is band, finishes shitty. Bad.
Cidery, appley oakiness are all something of a surprise and whether intentional or not allow a little interest. No traditional clove or banana flavors.

Tap at MBBC. Pours a clear orange color with a nice white head that fell off very quick. Aroma is of malt slight caramel lite hops. Flavor is caramel malt slight hoppy bitterness. A nice lite pale ale great on a warm summer evening.
slightly blonde in color. little flat. nice lace. Decent pale ale but not a rave.
Lemony, citrus flavors, a rereshing CPA. Mild biscuity tones. A decenet light bodied refresher.

Tap @ Brewpub: Murky orange, light carbonation. Light head and lacing. Nose of starchy wheat and tons of banana/clove ester, nice intensity, not much finesse though. The flavor is ok, a bit brash and sharp, but tasty after a spell of mediocrity and blandness.
Much better than Manhattan's version. Light pear tones in the flavor, very lightly spiced. Soft banana aroma.
From tap at the brewpub. Pours clear ans golden amber to orange with a small bitter and dry note. Dry herbal and bitter finish.

Sample at the brewpub. Pours a clear orange color with a thin and foamy off-white head that dissipates slowly. Sticky strings of lacing on the glass. Citrusy hops aroma with malt behind it. Medium body with a citrusy hops flavor balanced by sweet malty notes. The finish is hoppy with a lingering bitterness left over. Decent IPA overall.
Draft at brewery / restaurant. Pretty mellow for an IPA, not much hop flavor or aroma. Ditto what alexanderj said.
Tap at brewpup; poured an amber color w/ not much head. Flavor and aroma were fairly subdued; not bad, just could have been more assertive. Both featured grapefruit, citrus and caramel malt.

Tap @ Brewpub: Pellucid Copper, nose of crisp, citrusy hops, mainly orange. Faint head, no lacing. Some malts show in the nose, but the flavor is more sweet with them along with lighter hops. Nice finish and a spicy lingering mouthfeel. Eh, ok.

Sparkling clear, light amber body with an off-white head. Aroma is medium sweet, grapefruit, pepper, light earthy. Taste is medium sweet, grapefruit, some pepper, light caramel. Light carbonation, medium body. Definitely the highlight of my visit to the brewery.
Moderate hoppiness, good dry bitterness in the finish. Light biscuity tones. Not a bad IPA.
Golden with a white head - Mlat in the aroma - Maltbody with hardly any bitterness - Sort malt finish - This was just ok

column1: Hair of the Frog Railway Porter
column5: Very flat. Mono-dimensional, with only roasted barley notes present. Boy, this really needs carbonation!

column1: Hair of the Frog Railway Porter
column5: No strong aroma present even as the brew warms. There are some hoppy hints in the flavor, but no malts, chocolates, or coffee. It needed more character and depth to be a good porter in my book.

Normal cheap crap. Has some more taste than the very worst beers of our world, but not enough to warrant drinking it. Descriptions are futile. Basically this is an Irish beer, given a German/Dutch name to compete with the crappy lagers that those two countries import to Ireland. Seeing as this has only three ratings, it is not competing well.
18/05/06 Ireland. Good golden body with average white head. Nothing really stands out too much so it was fairly easy to drink, some grassy bitterness and a hint of corn.

Standard lager color, medium sized vanishing white head. Corny and sweet, boring aroma. Thin bodied. Very dull flavor: slight corn and sweetness, aftertaste is slightly hopped and dry. Medium carbonation.

Brewed by Guinness and once upon a time available throughout Ireland this beer is now only available in Waterford City, Ireland and the surrounding hinterland. Canned Hoffmans can ocassionally be found in other parts of Munster. Hoffmans is a refreshing alternative to Guinness' Harp Lager, but after the acquisition of Cheerys Brewery by Guinness production was quickly curtailed to ensure Harp remained the dominant Irish lager. Hoffmans has a very light complexion, is a very smooth beer to drink with little after taste. Very refreshing and a good choice for someone not in the mood to drink traditional Irish Ales or Stouts.

Sampled draught at Svensk Fat�lsfestival, Nyn�shamn Ruby/red in colour. Grapefruit cascade hop aroma. Sweet, clean and very soapy. with bitter orangey finsih. Strikingly similar to what an average American brewpub chain offer as a regular beer, but over here it's a rare thing...

Sampled draught at Svensk Fat�lsfestival, Nyn�shamn Reddish amber, despite the fact the name means "golden beer". Aroma of malt and almond. Medium dry and malty with pleasant toffee flavour. The grassy, orangey bitterness sets in early. Besides a relativley strong almond flavour it is rather discrete, and really complex.
Keg at the Chiswick Memorial Club. Pours a deep chestnut with a lasting tight foam. Roasty malt and an unappealing winey sourness - either they don't sell much or it's the first of the day.

Keg at the Bugle, Reading. Pitch black with a thin ring of cream head, tawny brown when held to the light; dusty malt aroma; watery texture with chocolate malt flavours and a milky coffee finish. An OK keg mild, but not a patch on the modern cask alternatives.

[Keg at The Bugle, Reading] Astonishingly, in all the time I�ve worked in Reading amongst its many Courage pubs, I�ve never come across this beer before, and as a lover of milds I was quick to try it. It pours deep brown, almost black, with a moderate but lasting creamy head. There�s very little smell, which makes your first taste more of a surprise. This is dominated by beautiful deep, roasted malts, with a hint of coffee in the background. Unfortunately, once you�ve enjoyed the first hit of flavour you realise that it is a little weak and watery, and feel that it could have been much improved by being cask conditioned rather than merely kegged. That said, it still has a few surprises up its sleeve. There is an unusual twist of lemon in the finish, and a growing gentle smokiness in the aftertaste. It leaves an odd mixture of dryness and syrup on the inside of your mouth. There are certainly many better milds out there than this, but considering this is a relatively low ABV kegged effort invented by a brewer whose other beers weren�t that much cop, this is actually a pretty decent effort. I wonder if, now that Wells & Youngs have taking it over, they might produce a cask version�? We can but hope�
Searles, Hunstanton. Very milky coffee dusted with chocolate. Puff of smoke. Earthy, slightly burnt aroma. Pitch body draped with beige. BOTESF? Oh dear.

Keg at The Plough, Little Bourton, Oxon. Very dark brown with beige head. Thin, almost flavourless mild, although there is a touch of heavy roasted malt. Quick and carbonated on the finish. Not great.
Draught at Mariners Arms, Braunton, North Devon. It pours a very dark beer with a nice creamy head. Initial flavours of olive oil. Watery. A rather weak finish follows. Decent, nothing more.

Draught. A black mild with a whitish short-lived head. The aroma is dry and a bit thin. The taste is decent: roasted malts are very prevalent. Mild tasting like it should be, with a short finish. Does the trick and better than expected.

Smooth and rich. Silky and creamy texture but lacking flavor. Dark brown color with red and burgundy wood hues in places. Rich toasty tan head. Flavors of toasted malts, toffee, coffee and cream� but all fairly light and pale. Bread and crackers up front, then a fluid, wet yeast flavor in the watery finish.
well this fellow is actually 3.2% woo hoo, eh thats the highlight guyz. Well fine then, fuck off..............

May, 2003 Keg, Wheatsheaf, Sittingbourne. I was heading for a pub I knew, but was drawn to this one because of the sign saying "Built 1778 - A Real Ale Pub". Once inside I noticed that the only cask ale they had was Master Brew. Damn. However, they did have this. Keg it may be, but it is a mild, and this is the deep South. A rare find. It certainly looks like a mild and, surprisingly for a Courage keg, it tastes like a mild. It�s been served too cold, but it does have a gentle sweetness backed up by a little roasted barley and licorice. Very tasty. There is a little off-putting tingle from the gas carbonation, but otherwise I was impressed. [2.9] Oct, 2006Hen & Chickens, Chatham - an ex-Truman pub. Gentle roasty mild tasting mild. Rather attractive. Keg it may be. Courage it may be. But it tastes good. [2.8]

Sampled draught at Svensk Fat�lsfestival, Nyn�shamn Pale yelloew with rich head. Sweet malt dominates. This lager feels fresh, but slightly papery and has a grassy bitterish finish. Unremarkable, but certainly drinkable.
(Draught at Rover, G�teborg) Smokey malt with some american hops. N�rke has better smoked beers to offer.
Dark amber to brown color. Nice malty and smokey aroma and taste. Maybe not enough complex, but pleasant.
Bottle. Amber in colour with a tan head. Aroma of smoked maltand a little hoppy. Roasted malt in the flavor with some smoke and a bit of bitterness in the aftertaste.

Draught, alc. 5.6% Nut brown, small creamy off-white head, some lace. Flowery hoppy nose. Honeyish, Cascade hops are evident in the flavor. Medium-bodied hoppy, like drinking hoppy British bitter. Smoke is quite weakly underlying there. "Svensk�l" is very misleading name :)

(Draught@Pikkulintu, Helsinki) Slightly hazy reddish color with a smallish, tight and creamy head. Roasted-malty aroma with dried, dark fruit and some smoke. Fruity, somewhat smoky toffee aroma. A very nice, slightly smoky "dark" flavored brew.

Draught, at The Rover. Dark brown with beige head, mostly diminishing, good lacings. Aroma heavy malty (smoke), light hoppy. Flavor moderate sweet, heavy acidic (smoke) and bitter, long duration. Light body, watery, flat carbonated.

(draught at Akkurat, Stockholm) Reddish brown with a gigantic beige foam. Tarry and smokey aroma of ham and licorice. Dry smokey flavour of tar, rope and ham with a light grapefruity note. Dry tarry aftertaste. Rather extreme. Really good!

Keg @ Akkkurat, Stockholm 9 September 2005 Nice subdued smokey aroma. Quite full bodied with licorice, dark fruits and chocolate flavour. I think this beer is still under development from this small brewer and changes from batch to batch. Still, it�s a very nice and well balanced brew with a good hoppy/smokey aftertaste. Me like.
Slightly artificial but pleasant citric nose - like a soda popsicle. Cloudy brown. Citric fruit center, a bit spice. Quite nice.
An opaque brown beer with a small off-white head. The aroma is of roasted bread, prunes, and chocolate - and so is the flavor, but the body is thin.

Draft on tap at the brewpub (Flossmoor, IL). Stopped in to try the new sour and tried this for free. A recipe I remember from my high school days as a busser, but never tried. I guess Todd�s trip back is what I owe this to, oddly. Pours a murky hazy golden hue, a good haze with a moderate frothy white head, laces well with a thicker layer. Aromas are orange peel, citrus, and coriander. Touches of spice mix with bread dough, flaked wheat, and mellow yeast. Crisp and refreshing, well balanced with a good mellow orange bite. Into the end lingering coriander, sun tan lotion, and dry flaked wheat offers bread dough, touches of light hops. Sweeter, citrusy, and fairly clean on the finish with lingering spice. Nice and fresh. Enjoyable, as much as I don�t want to admit it.
Nice job on a style that is not really my favorite. This refreshing wheat has an appealing cloudy pour, with a strong brisk orange-lemon citrus flavor and bright acidic finish. Good winter wheat.

Strangely, they�ve never had this on tap as Flossmoor when I�m there. I had it at the Maple Tree Inn (a great place for brews) in Blue Island a couple of times. Nice light hazy yellow with a respectable head. A floral, grassy aroma with a bready yeast smell. A full mouth-feel with a citric taste and mild spicing. A truly excellent drink. Maple Tree Inn, Blue Island, IL

Tap: Light cloudy yellow - like fresh pineapple orange juice. Light yeasty aroma with pineapple core/stem, some soft dough and oranges as well. . . Pulpy mouthfeel, that is surprisingly clean. Thick orange flesh, lightly spicey finish. Well done ToddA!
Very opaque - just what I like to see in a wheat beer. Light floral nose - yeast, citrus, wheat and lemon included (yes, I'm aware that lemon is a citrus). Fairly light taste...toasted biscuits.
Cloudy yellow with small white head. Aroma is banana, light lemon, wheat, medium sweet. Taste is light sweet, wheat, lemon, and trace of banana. Light body.

Draft...RBSG2003... Murky, pear juice-colored beer. Small, creamy white head with great lacework. The aroma is of banana and clove, coriander, orange peel, bubble gum and butter. Perfectly-balanced flavor. Fruity and spicy up front. Astringent and lightly pungent on the backside. Very refreshing! Light-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and light carbonation. Not even close to being my favorite style, but a very good, high quality wit nonetheless!
Light, malty , yeasty aroma . Same goes to taste. Good ingredients are not always guarantee of good beer guys
Cloudy yellow appearance with thin long lasting head. Moderately wheaty with slight clove and banana notes. Nice.

With a beautiful, cloudy lemony appearance and a fresh, fresh mildly sweet aroma, I was expecting something special. But the taste didn't quite deliver - it seemed a bit flat. But the professor in me thinks it has potential, if it would just apply itself!
Appearance is chestnut brown, with a small foamy off-white head. Aroma- malty and treacly, nutty hints. Taste- very nutty, malty brown bread, raisin hints, hop bitterness, caramel malt.

Gravity Cask Half Pint at Wallington Beer Festival, Wallington, Surrey in Oct 2010 - Chestnut/Dark Brown in colour. Malty; toasty malts, caramel, chocolate notes, slightly nutty. Hoppy; earthy hops. Sweet-bitter malty leading to a dry bitter finish. Very drinkable. (2010-10)

Cask-conditioned at the Seven Stars, Bristol, October 2016. Dark brown with a slight off-white, head. Aroma of sweetish berry fruits and leafy hops. Flavour was also sweet with a touch more fruit, touch of chocolate and short, bitter, finish. Good.

Cask at the "Southern Ale Adventure" Beer Festival at the Prince of Wales, Farnborough. Interesting to see that this hasn�t been rated for a while, so presumably it�s making a comeback - to me, this is everything an English bitter should be. It�s a bright chestnut colour with a loose cream head; the taste is a spectacular combination of Kentish hops and treacle toffee; leading to a dry finish. A really satisfying pint.

14th July 2011 Chelmsford Beer Festival. Hazy darkish brown beer. Suddy white head. Light semi dry palate. Fresh malts - mild chocolate and a little coffee. Nicely balanced by mild dark orangey hop. Semi dry finish. Bitter aftertaste.

Cask, Kings Head, Kingsdown, Kent. Dark reddish brown looks with a slight beige head. Fairly subdued sweet malt aroma. Largely unremarkable malt driven flavour. A little thin and watery with some hop bitterness towards the finish. Drinkable, but not especially worth lingering over.

Cask @ 11th Ayrshire Real Ale Festival. Mahogany brown colour, white bubbles. Aroma is caramel malts, bit of fruits. Flavour is caramel malts, licorice, slightly sweet, slightly bitter. Bit of roastiness.

Cask conditioned at The Kent Beer Fest, Canterbury. Copper colour with white head. Slightly honeyed toffee tasting beer with a rich malt and quite sweetish. Honey nut loops in the finish, quite unexpected.
Cask at Cloisters ...On tour with Fin ... Deep copper ... thin white head ... sweet malt nose ... nice soft fruity and toffee malts.
Cask, gravity, at Wellington Arms, Bedford, in the Welly Winter Festival of Ale. Dark amber- brown. Hairy malt aroma. Sweet malty taste, nicely balanced with a mid bitter finish. Good one.

The head brewer brought a dry-hopped version of this to a bar here in Bellingham along with a few other kegs. This has a definitive fresh-cut grass aroma that is really remarkable. This with a sharply citrusy flavor that actually doesn�t overload your taste buds with high IBUs makes this a very solid effort. The shy IBU is in no way a sacrifice of flavor, but rather the other way around - similar to the LaConner DH. My only qualm here is a slight lack in mouthfeel as the beer seems to drip off the palate before a finish can really take hold. Aside from this slightly watery character the beer is surely a solid output from the brewery - according to the brewer, the dry-hopping is a deviation from the recipe but surely one that should become permanent.

Nice copper color. Head sticks around pretty well. Nice hoppy aroma. A bit light bodied for the style but a good brew none the less. Very quaffable. Good hoppy finish (Cascade, Culumbus mix). I think I had about 5 pints.
Can. Pours a clear golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty sweetish grainy aroma. Sweetish grainy corn flavor. Has a sweetish malty grainy finish.
Sample at SRBG. Pours a clear pale gold with an average white head. Aroma of malt, grain (corn), and metal. Taste is the same. Ugh.

Can @ Presidential Suite. Thanks, Sean. Clear golden pour with a white head. Smells like total garbage. Like actual trash. Soap, corn syrup, cooked vegetables, corn, and banana. Really metallic, too. Gross. Flavor is quite sweet but also extremely vegetal and metallic. Apple juice and banana esters. Certainly boozy, too.

Can shared at the RBSG presidential suite malt liquor extravaganza. Thanks, assholes! Pours a pale gold with a small white head. Pretty clean, actually - pale malts, corn, sugar, and minerals. Light-bodied, with a sweet mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Not too much going on. Good for drinking while loitering outside 7-11, hiding it in a paper bag, waiting for some other shit to do.
Can at RBSG. Malt Liquor night. Pours clear yellow. Nose/taste of lemon, alcohol and harsh metallic grain. Medium bodied.

Can, big thanks to homer321. Clear golden orange color. Thin off-white head. Leaves good bits of lace. Medium to bigger body. Kind of crisp lighter carbonation, lightly crisp, but light rough edge to it. Moderate bready taste, some corn. Little bite in the finish. OK stuff. Rougher than other malt liquors I tasted tonight. Couldn�t finish my tiny sample. Kind of harsh. Ehh.. Roughest beer I�ve had in awhile.
@ the pussy palace. Pours a pretty clear golden appearance with a white head. Candy corn, sweet, hay aroma. Pretty fucken sweet flavor. Cotton candy and bubble gum prevalent. Too sweet for my taste.

Can share thanks to Homer321 via Francis. Fairly clear orange color, white head, seems pretty @ tame. Fruity, malty, sweet, almost citrusy note, more apple fruity character comes through as is sits. Very fruity, juicy, sweet, apple juice, semisweet, notable alcohol flavor in finish. Might be a wave.

Can thanks to frank. Nose is slightly rotten fruit with some table sugar. Hazy pour and small white head. A ton of pepper and alcohol in the flavor. Kinda bad for a malt liquor. A lot if residual sweetness and candy.

This beer is a sad void into which the hopeless sink and never return. It reeks of over-ripe apples and straight-out poison. Before I even smelled it directly, just catching the aroma from afar, it sent pangs of nausea through my gut. Up close, it is actually almost a little better; the apple note becomes more cidery and the poison note, more subdued. Still, I was deeply, deeply frightened at the prospect of actually drinking this garbage. Doing so reveals a taste more or less like those foamy circus peanut candies, which is to say it tastes like stale cotton candy and nothingness. As it warms--and I do not recommend letting this happen--the sweetness builds allowing this grievous mistake of a beer to linger on the surface of the tongue. This beer is not only bad but actively malicious. It will not let you forget it. With each sip, I hate myself a little more, making the next sip of this strong and vile elixer both more necessary and more harrowing. Whatever though. Never tried it before and a rate�s a rate.

Bottle conditioned. Pale gold, good white head and moderate condition. Big fluffy yeast sediment. Initial aroma is worryingly sulphurous but this almost dissapears in the mouth. Good mix of sweet malt and hop flavours with a creamy vanilla note lurking and a distant egginess. Aftertaste develops a good level of hop bitterness. Ignore the aroma (if possible) and you will find a surprisingly pleasant and refreshing pale bitter.

column1: Boundary Bay Scotch Ale - Highland Reserve
column5: From Bottle - pours caramel brown with a malty sweet aroma and a hint of smoked peat. My first sip is sweet with a bit of smokiness at the back. Aftertatse is toffee. Quite good!

column1: Boundary Bay Scotch Ale - Highland Reserve
column5: 6 oz. sample on tap at the brewpub, pours a hazy dark amber with a small beige head. Aroma of scotch, caramel, maple syrup - no hop presence. Flavour of caramel, non-boozy scotch (de-alcoholized scotch, so to speak), maple syrup, with a pleasant sweetness level that doesn�t cloy. Well-made and superior to their regular scotch ale I�d say.

column1: Boundary Bay Scotch Ale - Highland Reserve
column5: On tap at the brewery. Pours a dark shade of amber with a trim beige head. Smells and tastes of black licorice, toasted malt, toffee, and peat. Totally decent.

column1: Boundary Bay Scotch Ale - Highland Reserve
column5: Pours a red/brown. Aromas of dark roasted malt and fruity aroma sweet, malty flavors with a hint of smoke. Finishes with a touch of dry bite.

column1: Boundary Bay Scotch Ale - Highland Reserve
column5: Pours hazy dark amber with a dense off-white head. Aroma of smoke-infused caramel. Sweet, lightly smoky caramel, nuts and all manner of malty goodness. This one really hit the spot.

column1: Boundary Bay Scotch Ale - Highland Reserve
column5: Thanks go out to thethrone for this bottle I poured it into a snifter and it produced a finger worth of white head that turned to a thick lace. The body was a burgandy brown when held to the light Nice malty nose touch of dark fruits and a light roasted note filled my head. The flavor followed the nose to a "T" the medium body with good carbonation. Quite drinkable, nice kick back and relax brew which is what I want right now. Thanks again Throne

column1: Boundary Bay Scotch Ale - Highland Reserve
column5: Draft. Poured a storm cloud gray body with hints of amber and a frothy off-white head. Aroma was smokey roast barley, caramel malt, and slightly coniferous. Flavor was again smokey roast barley, sweet caramel malt, and slightly piney. Palate was somewhat weak bodied and finished a little too phenolic. Overall still a good scotch ale.

column1: Boundary Bay Scotch Ale - Highland Reserve
column5: Draught @ the brrewpub. Pours a dark amber/brown color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty caramel aroma with some hints of smoke. Also some hints of alcohol. Roasted malty caramel flavor with some hints of hops and dark fruit. Has a wariming malty caramel finish with some hoppy hints in the aftertaste.

column1: Boundary Bay Scotch Ale - Highland Reserve
column5: On tap at Trumpeter Ale House in Mt. Vernon, WA--Poured a thick deep chestnut-brown body with a fluffy beige-tan head. Smokey, malty, gritty, chewy, spicily hopped nose. Rich, sticky, piny, sugary flavor. Complex, great sipping brew. Love BB!

column1: Boundary Bay Scotch Ale - Highland Reserve
column5: Taster - Washington Brewers Festival - Kenmore, WA Aroma � Huge scotch ale aroma. Very peaty with a nice hops and malt biscuit aroma. Appearance � Dark Amber in color, clear with a thin head. Flavor � Very nice scotch ale. Had tons of peaty smokiness with a great hops backing and the malt build was great. Palate � Great Scottish Mouthfeel, nice texture with a dry finish. Overall � A very nice beer with a great flavor the spice was grassy and light. A very nicely built beer.
Cask: Deep brown with loose tan head.Lightly toasted nose. Light roasted flavor with dry malt finish. A thin porter, made to seem even thinner by the cask. Ok, but a poor choice for cask
Pours a golden yellow with a white head. Aromas of bread/malts/hops. Crisp flavor with hints of hop/malt.

Draft: Yellow pour with a medium white head and light lacing. Nose is mild of yeast, breadiness, and fruit? The taste confirms a hint of fruits with light breadiness and hints of bitters. Different than I expected, but not bad.

Truly there was just not very much too this beer. Light and almost sour grainy aroma, which follows into the mouthfeel that is almost what I would think this came out of a green bottle. Perhaps they have developed some kind of new filtration system, which passes the beer through a green bottle and sunlight to create this really unimpressive beer.
Almost non existant aroma. The typical hazy gold pilsener appearance. Flavor was musky and not very friendly on the palate. Very unimpressive from this usually good microbrewery.

column1: Olde Burnside Highland Fling Spring Ale
column5: Lightly cloudy golden color with a fizzy cream colored head. Clean tangy hops dominated this beer offset just enough by light yeast. Maybe some very light fruity overtones. Nice blue glass bottle and resealable top... probably the best thing about this beer.

column1: Olde Burnside Highland Fling Spring Ale
column5: Cold 33.8 oz blue swing top bottle: Pours a clear golden amber with very minimal ivory bubbles. Aroma is of apple and hops. Fizzy on the tongue. Taste is mainly bitter with notes of fruit. Moderately bitter aftertaste.

column1: Olde Burnside Highland Fling Spring Ale
column5: Large blue swingtop bottle: Pours lightly cloudy light orange with a thick white head, aroma has apples, flowers and earthy hops, full bodied for the style, nice strong carbonation, long grainy ending, starts and ends lightly bitter.

column1: Olde Burnside Highland Fling Spring Ale
column5: slight hints of fruityness to the nose, Very light golden in color light body, well balanced and yes, it is refreshing.

column1: Olde Burnside Highland Fling Spring Ale
column5: I have to agree with most of what has been posted on this light, tasty ale. Again, I buy it fresh since it is a local brewer. I share it with my friends who are �afraid� of craft brews, they love it.

column1: Olde Burnside Highland Fling Spring Ale
column5: Pours out coppery with a white head. Smells of bread, nuts, grapefruit and sugar. Tastes appley with some mellow spicey notes. Great think lively mouthfeel.

column1: Olde Burnside Highland Fling Spring Ale
column5: 2005 1L swingtop bottle, quite beautiful as all have said. A very sparkling, shining golden appearance, a deep, true golden color, with just a hint of light copper. Very hazy, with sediment suspended in minute particles all throughout the glass, I really love when that occurs. Creamy, yellow-flecked white head. Very well-retained and leaves immense sheets of lace plastered to the glass. Aroma of sugar cookies, nutty hops, very earthy and lightly bitter. Light floral notes and some lemon sorbet with honey on it. Begins with a big, sticky bitterness, that clings to the tongue, backed up by some notes reminding me of orange-blossom honey. Very pleasing, creamy mouthfeel, fresh and unfiltered. Ends very dry and bitter, as magic_hat says, it has a bit too much on the bittering and not quite enough hops flavor. Lots going on on the finish, but it�s mostly hops driven; peppery, soily, nutty notes from the boiled hops with some light toasty malt, almost worty-sweet. Some light flowers and honey linger, and the hops bitterness steadily builds on the palate, really dulling the other flavors by the end of the bottle. No alcohol apparency, with a dusty, lightly dirty (not in a bad way) yeastiness. Well-made beer, but let�s have less hops bitterness and more hops flavor.

column1: Olde Burnside Highland Fling Spring Ale
column5: This is a pretty good Spring Pale ale, but it has room for improvement. The bittering hops are a little too intense, and it could use some finishing hops to cover up a little. This is borderlining an IPA. Good malt backbone, a nice fairly dry beer. A little unbalanced, but good none the less. And I love the 1 liter swing top bottles, great for us homebrewers.

column1: Olde Burnside Highland Fling Spring Ale
column5: Bottle #1881. Bottle opens with a thunderous pop. Pour is a very carbonated one with a big light tan fluffy head. Mildly hazy amber/honey color. Citrus orange aroma with hints of honey, pepper, and notes of smoked pine. Yeastly banana to start. Gives way to intense hoppy bitterness. Lots of Cascades in the finish. Orange hints in the middle. Good Stuff!

column1: Olde Burnside Highland Fling Spring Ale
column5: Bottle #1718, The never ending frothy head, nice lacying, with a copper amber appearance. Very fragrant with herbal & floral aromas and a hint of lemon. Medium bodied with a ton of hops. I could of used more malt complexity but a very good beer. Another fine seasonal by Olde Burnside.

St Stefanus Blanche version from Waitrose in a 330ml stubby bottle. A fairly ordinary wit beer. Disappointing considering the St Stefanus Blonde is a lovely beer, but then now I realise it's a just a branding excise.

St Stephanus Blanche version that I have bought at one monoprix, at Paris. Tasting it at Paris, in my hotel room, the last year. The color is yellow and troubled, normal carbonation, white foam. Personally, it is not my favourite witbier, industrial flavour, syrup of glucose, sweet, fruity, you get some whear, few hop, it is not subtle and well balanced.
Somewhat cloudy poor, big white foam head. Some banana in aroma, barley in taste. (Velp 201909)
St.Stefanus Blanche, bottle from Waitrose. It was OK - didn't really taste entirely like what I'd expect of a blanche, quite a rich taste to it. OK though.
Cask. Pours hazy golden with a White head. Aroma fruity hops, lemony, slight malty - Caramel, light foral. Taste is bitter, with some citrus, light bready, and some grassy to it.

Cask (handpump) at the Cask Pub & Kitchen on 17 January 2011 - meet the brewer night, with 10 Mighty Oak beers on tap. Thought I�d rated this before so notes rather sketchy. Bright copper. Good condition. A solid best bitter with a decent balance of caramel & berry fruit tinged malt and spicy hops. Just a touch of citrus. Moderate bitterness. No complaints here but I generally prefer my session beers to be a bit more hop driven.
21st August 2007 Warning! Early amateur rating! Low carbonation. Fruity start. Lingering bitter finish. Okay.
WHY? WHY DID I EVER DRINK THIS? Get me a BLATZ ASAP! Somehow this stuff passed my lips 20 odd years ago, and I have never forgotten or forgiven!

From a 12-oz can pours a clear light golden yellow colored brew with a fast dissolving white head that dissipates clean. Aroma of corn grits, floral hops and some breakfast cereal. Taste is light bodied, very metallic, with a morning corn flake breakfast cereal. Finish is quite gritty, corn aftertaste and more metallic aftertaste. Another historical beer brand that is not even a shadow of its glory years. Would like to have tried the Kingsbury Pale Lager of the early 1950s when it was real beer.
Can bought in Japan. Thin yellow colour, hardly any head. Herby grainy unpleasant aroma. Watery mouthfeel. Sweetish grainy herby thin unpleasant flavour

True this may have been a sub par beer but i am sure many people like myself from the town it is from remember sneaking their first KB out of their dads fridge. So it holds a special place in my heart.
Realy not the worset (?) beer out therr. Yes it is on the light side, Light but not watery.

Something is wrong with me this Beer was okay to me. I went to the doctor and asked about it He just shook his head in disbelief. I guest I can be proud that I like the poorest rated beer on the planet.

column2: New York, New York, United States
column5: Quite possibly the star of the show down at Chumleys Pub. A very sweet lager with low carbonation makes for a pleasant loungin' afternoon at Chumley's while the Pub's house chocolate lab coughs incessantly like it's got a hairball down its throat. Oh well, Chumley's is nonetheless a charming dive of a former 1920s speakeasy that serves nine beers brewed for it by Chelsea Brewing and this honey lager is one of the beers worthy of a taste. Possessing a hint of citrusy goodness, this lager is mild and inoffensive.
From old tasting notes. Brassy gold color. Big rocky white head. Mild malt nose hints at thyme. subtle malt flavor with hints of honey.mlightly carbonation. Refreshing.

Someone found this one in its cellar, vintage 1994, so 11 years old. Gold yellow colour, with a small white head, quiet a lot of carbonation, so it doesn�t seems dead afther all this time. Rather skunky aroma, light madeirisation, some fruityness left. Flat body and a flat finish, with an old-bitter strange ending which is not really enjoyable. After all, still interesting for a beer of 4.3% after all those years

Old grain, faint dusty hop aroma. Very grainy and chunky in the mouth. A bit unclean and wet at the finish. A rather tasteless experience. Claims to be brewed by the Dakota brewing co. but it�s actually brewed in Minnesota. ND needs to get with the beer revolution and craft their own brew. Hopefully one better than this.

Bottle: Had after fishing a couple days, basically a lawnmower beer. I was a little disappointed, I thought this was from ND, because the case said Dakota Brewing company and made no other mention of state, but it is actually from MN. A little hoppy, crisp. Nothing special.
I don�t get it! Everone in the town I�m in is buying this stuff like its a real beer! Its way to light, and frankly way to blah! Pass it up like a stripper with a rash!

Pale yellow in color with little to no head. Aroma is sweet with notes of grain or corn. Flavor is sweet and malt, watery. It tastes a little off, not much hop presence. My bottle says it made by Dakota Brewing Company - Cold Springs, Minn.

Nearly no head at all and what was there faded pretty fast.Mildly malty sweet aroma,with a mild hop presence.The flavor was relatively the same as the aroma.malty sweet,low carbonation,slightly hopped.the after taste was nothing special mostly water a little malt and hops.over all it's a pretty basic poorly done brew.
A - citrus and floral A - mid gold and frothy T - sour P - mid to thin O - ehh...

Tasted this in The Esquire House, Glasgow (JDW) in June 2010. Cask, handpump dispense. Crystal clear pale copper in colour with a thin white head. Short aroma of thin crisp apple. Thin mouthfeel and poor lacing. Thin pale malt base gives digestive biscuit with dried raisin fruit. Thin bodied aftertaste is dry and metallic. Tang of hop resins continue into the dry bitter finish with oak wood tanins. An ok session bitter but nothing exceptional.
Cask @ Bon Accord. Copper colour, off-white head. Aroma is caramel malts, bit of fruits. Flavour is caramel malts, fruits. Slightly bitter and dry.
Cask @ The Bon Accord. Medium brown colour, not much head. Toffee malt aroma & flavour with some ash. Slightly bitter aftertaste. Very average bitter.

Cask (gravity dispense) at Wandsworth Common Beer Festival @ Le Gothique on 25 March 2011. Amber colour. No head to speak of. Quite fruity and rather sweet. Hop presence in the flavour is quite modest. Soft mouthfeel. Nothing particularly wrong with it but too sweet and short of bite for my taste - could do with pepping up a bit.

Cask at Turf Tavern, Oxford. Lasting medium smooth foam. Red-cupper color. Dry wood/pine needle hop aroma. Nice English hop taste that lasts long time. There is also fruit esthers and a litle caramell. Alltogether an good refreshing beer with a balanced bitternes.

[Cask at the Back of Beyond] Light amber, moderate white head, slight fizz (superb condition - well done Wetherspoons!). Apple and caramel at first followed by a tasty spiciness. Straw and earth come through in a moderately bitter finish that is well balanced against the sweet start. Decent bitter - although obviously very variable in both quality and flavour based on earlier reviews!
Cask conditioned? at a Wetherspoons. Amber with slight head. this tasted old, tired and frankly a little off. Spoons at its worst unfortunately. Floral fruity, tart and poor.
Cask at the Back of Beyond (JDW), Reading. Gold with a dense cream head; clean grainy aroma; fresh, sweet, grassy, flavour; lacking finish. A rather basic bitter.

Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Amber with a small white head. Sweet malt aroma with some pear fruit coming through. Fresh citric tatse with just enough bitterness in the finish. Another tasty, easy drinking session beer, which B & T do so well.

column1: Hair of the Frog Centennial Pale Ale
column5: Very mild hop notes and also little carbonation. For something labeled "centennial" I would expect more hop, as is the case with Founder's Centennial IPA. Maybe they aren't referring to hops, I'm not sure.
Bottle, in US. Backlog entry. Entering my historic scores for US beers whilst visiting New York. No tasting notes kept, just rating.
A little bit more malts and hops than their regular offerings; otherwise it was still a fairly generic pale lager at inflated prices. Drinkable but the price is telling why its no longer made.

12oz bottle (Old Notes)-Pours a clear golden with a decent head. Aroma of grains, hops, and hay. Taste of the same. This light bodied brew is not bad as I was expecting worse coming from a green bottle.

Reviewed from notes. Pours a clear golden with a thin white head and little lacing. Nose brings forth some grain and a bit of some Czech/German hops. Taste is about the same, with a bit of grain but mostly just faint hops and some carbonation. Light feel with a good amount of carbonation to carry what little flavor there is. Drinks okay, but probably has a bit too much carbonation and not much real flavor. Serving type: bottle Reviewed on: 10-08-2010

At least they included the whole world in naming this beer instead of just naming America. This has a pretty smooth flavor with a skunky aftertaste. Luckily I didn�t have to pay for my encouter with this watered down "select" beer

Anheuser-Busch Brewing Company--Anheuser World Select Lager Beer--2004 12 oz. Bottle. 5.00% ABV--20 IBU�s.? (3.5 / 5.0) Pilsner. Green Bottle. Light lacy head. Clear thin bright light golden color. Delicate mild floral hop front. Smooth light sweet caramel pils light butter body. Clean smooth light citrus hop end. Crisp & mild. Sampled 5/4/2004.
Seemed like a bud gone through the "green" phase turning an mediocre pale lager into a skunked one. Not so extraordinary.
I�ll keep this one nice and short. It basically tastes like a watered down Heineken. Maybe even a little more skunked tasting.

Had this one 3 years ago, and I didnt write this one down, so Im going a little off memory. Tasted just a liitle bit better than straw tea, but thats what most pale lagers taste like. Im not sure what makes this the world select....Oh, its the "fancier" bottle. Not saying it was terrible, just not "select". (Who selected it?)

WOW, this really is world class, world class crap. Poured a light yellow color with a white head. Aroma was pretty minimal, bready and grass. Flavor was really watery, grassy and a slight bitter corn flavor as well.
Bottle from Edeka Hamburg - clear golden color, small, diminishing white head. malty, awful sweet, metallic. a very poor Hell, maybe the worst I ever had. bah.

Beer with yellow color, light aspect, soft bitterness, average carbonized, some foam on top, (shared a 50cl bottle beer with PG, bought it at "LIDL", Ourense, ES #1014)(#133 DE)(#18 Baden-W�rttemberg).
Pours golden with white head. Apple-malty aroma and taste. Notes: bottle from the Shopette, Jul �19

Bottle with some heads in philly. Orange golden color with average head. Nose and flavor are pure trash with some skunk, oxidized hops, weird herbs, dumpster, and belgian fruit. Pretty much everything that could go wrong with this, did. Terrible drain pour

From a bottle slightly hazy pale lager, almost clear. Has a decent recognizable lager aroma. Taste on the other hand is big old country pilsner sharpness. Yes, little kick in there. Unexpected considering, this was labeled as a friendly lager, and it smelled like one too. Good solid pilsner fer sure. Pretty close to the old german country.

Decent pale golden pour w/ a thin white head & good lacing. The aroma is mild & kind of soapy. The taste is fairly harsh w/out much flavoring. I can get it down but this isn�t something I would want to have again!

12 Fl. Oz. Bottle. Poured clear, yellow with a nice size head, and lots of lacing on the glass. Aroma of grain and hops. Taste is semi sweet, grain some malts combined with a very nice bitterness from hops. Quite refreshing, very drinkable.
Cloudy straw yellow color with white head. Aroma of lemon and grass. Grain, hint of pepper with lemon. Pretty decent pilsner.

Bright gold appearance with an average size white head and a fair amount of lacing. Grain field aroma dotted with citrusy hops. Bitter, dry, acidic taste modestly balanced by biscuit-like malts with a crisp, peppery, herbal aftertaste. Medium bodied, decently carbonated mouthfeel leads to a short lived finish.

Bottle at home in CT - picked up in VT. Pours crystal clear yellow with a foamy white head. Clean cereal on the nose with hints of corn, grass and lemon rind. Light-medium sweet flavor with biscuity malts, further cereal, some bitter hay and grass, faint lemon zest, crackers. Light bodied with average carbonation. Finishes with nice balance, further crackers and biscuits, slight dry and grassy bitterness. Very drinkable lager,
A very bitter lager with a slightly sweet aftertaste. Hints of grapefruit and citrus zest. Not particularly malty for a lager. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Definitely more pilsner than lager, lots (too much?) of refreshing bitterness but I find it a bit too much for summer beer.

Pale muted orange. Creamy white head. Light lavender sweet honey and corn nose. Creamy mouthfeel. Bitter orange peel, sweet pie crust and astringent bitter finish. I still like it quite a bit. A less juicy humulus lager
Another recovered rating from the cabin up north... Pours light brown with minimal head. Earthy aroma mixed with spice and sugar. Flavor is citrusy hop with a dose of caramel sweet.

Bottled.Average sized frothy ecru colored head that tried to stick around but eventually fell to a thin layer; some spotty lacing remained. Nice malty aroma redolent of toasted grain and some brown sugar along with a bit of citrusy hops. Flavor upfront was of sweet caramel malt that carried through to mid-palate where a toasted grain-slightly burnt pastry crust character emerged. Hop character also emerged mid-palate; the hop flavor faded by the finish and only the bitterness remained long into the aftertaste. Palate seemed light bodied and somewhat watery. Refreshing and drinkable enough but I�m not so sure about the burnt pastry crust note and the seemingly watered down feel of this bock. I would still accept one though if offered. Thanks Slikwily!

Clear coppery color Firm, bubbly, off-white head, if a bit brief. Aroma: fresh, zesty, grassy, clean, herbal, vegetal, and sweet. Spicy, traces of toffee, subtle alcohol, a bit medicinal, with a turbulent sweetness. On the palate, a syrupy sweetness up front. A good, gripping, tasty body and texture. Nice taste, medium body, good, sweet finish. Dries up quick, though. Caramelly sweetness rides through. A decent, but unremarkable bock.

Deep copper/amber colour. Mild malty aroma with a slight hoppiness. Flavour is mild and pleasant too but not particularly interesting. A very drinkable bock (actually I wouldn't mind having quite a few of these)...
Aroma of malt. Light brown with no head. Flavor...I could swear this is Sam Adams. Does calling it a bock make it a bock? I say no.
Decent caramel, and chocolate flavor. Mild and sweet body with good bock profile. Smooth and very drinkable.
Not a bad Bock. Thanks Slikwily. Orangish, brown. Malts & hops mix well in the aroma. Flavor is pretty sweet. The finish is dry and somewhat sour.

Voluminous, seafoam head, PA colored brew, acid-flashback cowboy label. Very lagered maltfunki aroma. Some acidic caramel malt twang without much else going on. Medium-light sweetness. Twangy, cidery, long acidic finish. Needs help.

No real aroma to this - has a nice thick white head with a lot of lacing. Light copper colored appearance. The flavor was not as malty as most bocks - tastes and feels more like an amber lager. Smooth drinking though - goes down well - stays strong to the finish. Would be good for session purposes.

Heavy amber color with a small lid of antler colored suds. Sweet caramel malt and brown sugar aroma. Hints of alcohol and mild floral/dry grass hops. Sweet malty start with a buttered toast finish. In between there are some light fruits (raisins, pears and peaches). Not to heavily fruity to distract. Thick feel on the tongue, but light on the finish. Mildly acidic in the late finish which helps cleanse some of maltiness away and leaves you with a dry finish for the style. Kudos to slikwily for forwarding this one on to me. A very drinkable bock.
Fresh grainy nose, deep burnt orange color. Smooth sweet caramel malt with notes of nuts. Dull broad hopped with with a tingly spicy note (not to much). Good balance and full body. Nice.

Draught pint at the brewery with Muzzlehatch on 3/11/06 Deep milk-chocolate brown, with some lighter hay-yellow highlights and much a muddy sea through the middle, but the colors lighten on the edges and the clarity becomes only lightly cloudy. Head is intially full and beige on this one, but again, it recedes fairly steadily to a ring, with only a film left on the glass. Smells of thick yeast, heavy caramelized sugars and some buttercream, with some light almond/hazelnuttiness and a sour, munich-like maltiness on the end. Moderate strength. Upon first sip, it�s quite a bit to take in. Another heavy (dare I say TOO unfiltered) texture places thick, caramelized malts all over the palate, while a light bit of honey mixes with graham cracker sweetness and then wanes yeasty. Too much yeast, yet not nearly enough attenuation (some type of sugar addition perhaps). I don�t know if this one still aimed for the "Mexican Coffee", there were light coffee notes from the darker brown malts, I suppose, but it just plasters the palate with sugars and yeast and does come off a bit worty. I was really hoping for a Vienna, which this seems to be nothing like. No alcohol apparency, low to moderate carbonation, chewy, sugary texture.

OK, so this is supposed to be a "spiced" Vienna; this is supposed to have a subtle combination of "Mexican coffee" spicing (cinnamon, white pepper, chocolate etc) to complement the malty smokiness of the basic Vienna recipe. Except this is being consumed in an airless, smoky, dank pub where its impossible to get any subtleties of anything. Maybe a hint, if you put all of your limited cranial capacity into it. Nnnahh the beer ain't worth it. Next please.

On tap @ Vermont Pub & Brewery. Cloudy pale straw pour with a soapy white foam. Pretty much just a basic Hefeweizen here. Some banana, a bit of lemon, and a light clove note. Subtle cracker and biscuit. Kind of sweet, maybe a touch tangy. Pretty light overall. I guess it�s fine. Not really much going on here.
Sample on tap at brewpub. Aroma is of yeast, cloves, and bananas. Nothing spectacular, but refreshing enough.
On tap @ the brew pub. Pours a cloudy pale yellow color with decent white head. Aroma is very herbal and citrusy. Taste is light and really refreshing. Very herbal with lots of citrus.

Where and how On tap at brewpub Aroma not very clean. Wet cloth , musky cellar feel. Behind golden malts with banana notes. 5- Appearance Top: white fine cap, mid sized Base: hazy amber-gold. Palate : soft, easy going with softer carbonation. Medium bodied with average finish. Taste:almost none hop presence. Blend of wheat and golden malts. Straight and fairly clean. Other notes Average Weiss, beyond poor aroma it was OK.

The aroma is like an old, sour rag. Not very appealing. It has a touch of fruitiness to it, somewhat reminiscent of a cherry cough drop. It has a bit too much body and is lacking in carbonation. I feel like they could do better.
On tap at the brewpub. Pale yellow with a nice white head. Light sourness, banana, wheat, very faint cloves. Moderate carbonation and mild body, nice finish.

On tap at the brewpub. Poured a hazy pale gold with a white head that dissipated to the edges and laced nicely. Aroma had a tart lemon note with some sweet grains and a bit of a yeast note. Flavor was quite bland with some sweet wheat and a hint of lemon, but not much else.
Tap at the brewpub. Pours a hazy golden color with a small white head. Aroma of light banana, clove, wheat and light citurs notes. Flavor of citrus notes, light sourness, banana, clove and wheat.

Hazy golden color with a small, white head that left light lacing on the glass. Aroma of some toast, clove, citrus, and light banana. Taste of citrus, tart wheat, light banana, spicy clove, with a dry finish.

On tap at brewpub. Pours hazy gold with a thin white head. Aroma is straw with weak clove and a hint of banana. Thin palate with enough effervescence to be interesting. Flavor is typical hefe flavor with the interesting twist of sour mash. It�s just a bit funky, sour and tart. Enjoyable, interesting brew.
Weak caramel nose, some roastiness in the flavor, very low sweetness, slightly acidic finish, dry, just ok.

Poured into an English pint glass, the appearance was a fairly dark burnt orange color with a finger�s worth of white foamy head that died off in a slow way. Light lace. The aroma had some candied fruits, subtle earthy hops, light tobacco, and some sweet herbal qualities. Caramel malts somewhat seem far underneath. The flavor yields to the malts, somewhat bready to roasty and then those candied fruits with the herbal and earthiness flowing in for some balance. Lingering robust malty aftertaste with a crisp malty finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fair sessionability about it. Herbal and earthy tones seem to play against the carbonation for a good normal feel for a Scottish ale. Overall, without the peatiness, I�d say this was still nice all around. I could have again for me, definitely one for the colder months.

Bomber into a glass. Pours a caramel orange ruby. Head is of medium body, does not retain and mellows fast. Tan brown in color, faint lacing, decent carb bubbles. Aroma of sweet and chewy malts, granola, salt, sour apple, candied dates, mild dark fruits. Taste of sweet and sticky malts, orange, plum somewhere, or dates, amber waves, more malt feedback, and some booze though abv is a mystery. Fun drinking brew, soft on the pallate with a great sweet fruit aftertaste. Drinks easier than it looks. Great for this awful winter.

Cask at the brewpub - Great Barrington. Pours amber-gold with a creamy tan head. Dried berries in the nose with bready malts and suggestions of leaves. Medium sweet flavor with simple, bready malts, mild creamy toffee, faint cocoa. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Sweet finish with more bready malts, some caramel, ripe fruits. Quite tasty.
Pours brown with a thin white head. Smells sweet and fruity. Tastes caramelly with some brown sugar and hints of figs. Decent.

Very nice malty aroma. Fairly plain bottle and label. Brown beer. A little starchy, some toasted cereal, fruity, more of a brown ale. Very faint peat, light vanilla vapors. Mouthfeel is pithy. Finish is grain bitter. Thanks to DW.

Bottle: Good nose - carmel, dried fruit, sour dough. Clear copper color, no head. Sweet and bitter flavors. Fruity, grape, apple, cherry, carmel. Smooth and sticky. Tasty brew, though I'm not a fan of this style, very drinkable. Ok overall

Extremely pale, almost yellow; weak earthy-floral nose, really wondered if I got the wrong thing here. No, there's enough earthiness to qualify as a Scottish, but the malt is very subdued, it is quite hoppy at the end..just unbalanced and weird.

Pours the color of freshly mown straw; the head is white, fluffy and resilient. Aroma is of lightly roasted malt, floral hop essence and hints of wild prairy grasses. Light butter notes, along with sourdough toast are understated, yet present. Pretty big mouthfeel for a pilsner, and yet incredibly smooth and creamy. A full flavored, refreshing pilsner, with good sweet malt front and balanced hop on the back. Somewhat grainy, citrus essence combines with a grassy, roasty flavor. All subtle. This pilsner kicks ass. I think I can say, and I don't often say this about any beer. but this is the finest pilsner I have ever imbibed. Cheers to Phil Markowski for winning me over again.
Straightforward, well-done yellow beer. Decent hop zing that hangs around a while. Goes a little acidic as it warms.
Light golden, little head; sweetish, slightly woody, very fresh, strong earthy hoppiness throughout; aroma too light for this to be really memorable, but I'm glad I had it.

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: Pours with a golden body topped by a medium thick white lasting head with good lacing. Slightly sweet yet bitter grassy hop aroma with a good malt balance. Slightly bitter hop flavor with some piney, grassy notes and a touch of saltiness and sweet. Light bodied and slightly dry.

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: WARNING. Should you choose to follow this and the four reviews that follow, you will be put to sleep by the sheer boredom and dullness evidenced in this totally derivative sports-bar-ish trustafarian-seeking brewpub's products. There will be nothing even remotely of interest discussed in these reviews, unless I decided to go off on a major tangent about some girl, or some band or movie, or goddamn GWB or the just-as-stupid-if-slightly-less-venal pack of Democrats chasing his sorry ass around. BUT if I stick to the beer, you'll get something like this: pissy yellow, fruity but low-key nose, soft sweet tonguefeel, bitter dry finish without much real hop character on to the next winner.
An unclear amber beer with a small white head. The aroma is sweet malty with strong notes of berries - which matches the flavor pretty much.

(Bottle 33 cl) Clear, pretty amber colour with a fine, creamy head that leaves a fine lacework. Lovely berry-aromas. Lightly sweet berry-flavours with a dry finish. Soft and very pleasant fruit beer. 280705
Bottled. Orange coloured with a small white head. Acidic aroma of berries with grainy notes. Flavour of berries, grain and malts.
Nose of various berries, defintely black currant. Amber to reddish colored body, medium white head. Good berry flavor, a bit sourish.
