bottled. decent example of the style - hazy golden, massive fluffy head clinging to the inside of the glass; aroma of banana smoothie; light grassy hop, vanilla bean

Serving: from bottle--purchased at Allend�rfer. Aroma: light banana. Appearance: large, rocky, white initial head with good lacing and mostly diminishing longevity. Cloudy medium-yellow body. Taste: lightly sour and lemon and banana initial flavor and finish with average duration. Palate: light body, watery texture and lively carbonation. Overall: not bad.
Tap. Just a bit of maltiness in the aroma. Malty flavor, with just a bit of soapiness in the finish. Fairly clean palate but not much going on in this beer.
500ml Bottle - Golden with a white head. Notes of white bread, straw, hay and lemon can be detected in both the aroma and the taste.

(bottle) hazy golden colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of candle wax and floral hops, almost like nosing a clynelish, with a touch of green apple, some vanilla and caramelized grain. flavour is mostly green apple and bubble gum, slightly starchy, with a faint touch of pale malts and some ripe peaches in the light-bitter finish. medium-bodied with averge carbonation. a bit green perhaps, but flavourful enough.
Heller, trocken getreidiger Beginn. Mild w�rzig, deutliche Noten von Gerste, trocken bleibend, geringe W�rzigkeit. Monoton, mittellanger Nachhall. 8/9/10/8//9
From bottle. Transfer of an earlier rating without text recorded, rating only.

Bottle from Bamberg - alc. 4.9% - hazy pale yellow color, white head. full body, taste is dough, crackers, hay, floral hops. low sweetness, finishes rather dry. very nice! drank it through restfaktische postrealit�t.

Draught @ Dremel, Wattendorf. Pours cloudy yellow with a small white head and lacings. Good malts, crackers and grass with a slight lemony twist. Dry and crisp. Some vague unclean yeasty hints that disturbs more and more as the beers warms. What a shame. Still quite drinkable however. Soft and quaffing.

Draft at the brewery in Wattendorf. Hazy gold with a fine and sticky head. Medium bodied, rich with moderate to low sweetness and similarly low but we�ll matched bitterness. Yeast acidity is pulpy and zesty and a little doughy. Faint aroma hops are lemon and herbs. Malt is toasty and bready and it tastes of saltine crackers and honey, good malt integration. Good restrained semi-sweet/off-dry Helles landbier, very drinkable. Fine and creamy carbonation is silky soft whole malt is baked baguette and toasted grain pureness. I imagine with the yeast settled or filtered this would be the tits. Dry, yeasty / doughy, good bittering hop grip. Silty and coarse finish.
On tap at the Brewpub. Tr�bes goldenes Bier mit sch�ner cremigen Schaumkrone. Geruch leicht malzig, fruchtig. Geschmack w�rzig, fruchtig, Karamell, leckeres Bier.

Das Helle besitzt eine recht gut haltende Schaumkrone. Geschmacklich ist es malzig, hefig-blumig leicht hopfig-s��, etwas herb-spelzig im Nachgeschmack. Fazit: �berdurchschnittlich, f�r ein Helles vielf�ltig, mein pers�nlichen Geschmack trifft es aber nicht so ganz. Test vom 28.12.2010, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,10,10,9,-,10 - 10,05

The beer in the glass is good golden yellow, with staunch head and many small CO2 bubbles. Hoppy-sour smell with a hint of yeast and orange. The beer starts hoppy, grainy, pleasantly sour yeasty. Overall, very mild and balanced. The aftertaste shows balanced hoppy, yeasty, slightly sour. The further course remains dominant sour yeasty, the hops come through clearly noticeable.
Dunkler, mild s��-getreidiger Beginn. Angenehm r�stig, minimal bitter, spritzig. Rund w�rzig, langer Nachhall. Gut. 10/9/10/10//10

Das Dremel Dunkel ist haselnussbraun, leicht tr�b mit hellem Schaum. Es riecht malzig, leicht ger�stet und karamellig. Geschmacklich zeigen sich nussige Aromen und etwas angebrannter Zucker. Es hat ein angenehm weiches Mundgef�hl und zeigt zum Ende eine erfrischende herbe und trockene Note. Ein tolles Dunkles aus der kleinen Brauerei in Wattendorf.
Draught @ Dremel, Wattendorf. Pours cloudy amber with a small white head. Tart Dark fruit, nuts, caramel and butter. Quite filthy and undrinkable.

Gravity keg at the Goldener Adler in Muersbach-Germany, based on Manuele advise who "whispered" a new possible recipe. The guy who poured, upon my question, presented it as a Keller-Bock which sounded quite strange to me...anyway. Pours a very bright and unfiltered brownish-orange color, with a medium off-white cap. Nose: roasted malts, well-hidden caramel notes and after getting warmer a bit of spirit-like alcohol warming feel. Mouth: nutty, soft body, again roasted malts. Low-medium carbonation and a very pleasant nice end. It talks to a dunkel but apparently is just a "vintage" Franconian Keller. Tasty!

Bottle from a REWE in Bamberg. Copper coloured, with a slight, white, head and touch of carbonation. Sweet, brown sugar and berry fruit aroma. Flavour was similar with some toastiness in the finish. Fine.
On tap at the Brewpub (Steinkrug) Dunkelbraunes Bier mit beiger cremigen Schaumkrone. Geruch leicht r�stmalzig, Karamell, leicht schokoladig. Geschmack nach Karamell, Schokolade, r�stmalzig, klasse!

Das dunkle Dremel sch�umt sahnig-fein, aber nicht sehr hoch auf. Den Duft kann man als karamel-s��lich beschreiben. Das kann man dann auch im Antrunk schmecken: Erst Karamel, dann R�stmalz (verhalten, nicht als Explosion), dann brotig-malziger Abgang. Mal ganz was anderes. Vom Kollegen Frankenland wei� ich, dass bei Dremel "handwerklich gebraut" wird, also jeder Sud ein bisschen anders schmeckt. Dieser, aus dem meine Flasche stammt, sei nicht so gelungen. Das erkl�rt wohl auch den Hauch von zu lange getragener Socke, der �ber dem ganzen Geschmackserlebnis liegt und eine bessere Bewertung verhindert. Dennoch: ordentlich Test vom 19.1.2010, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 9,10,9,9,4,9 - 8,90

Im Geruch moderat malzig und leicht schokoladig. Antrunk s��lich. Danach trockener, schokoladig mit hintergr�ndiger Fruchtnote. Leider wirken die an sich sch�nen Aromen etwas verd�nnt. Im Schlu� wird das Bier bitterer. K�nnte kr�ftiger sein. Trinkbar aber allemale. Ein Dankesch�n an Frankenland f�r dieses Bier aus einer Kleinstbrauerei. Auch hier keine Flaschenwertung, da kein Etikett die Flasche ziert. Test vom 17.12.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche

Pours into the glass a hazelnut brown beer with a beautiful, delicate, pearly head. The Dunkles has a caramel malt aroma, subtle nutty-malty and roasty-sweet. It is also malty bitter with sweet flavors in the background. The aftertaste shows hoppy-bitter. The further course is also nice hoppy-bitter. Another well-balanced Dremel beer!

bottle, mit Dank an Frankenland! Hazy brown colour, large and creamy off-white head. Malty nose with caramel. Malty base, caramel, biscuits and some floral hops in the lingering caramelly finish. Good!
on tap-pours a white head and cloudy gold color. Aroma is citrus-some orange hops. Taste is pine/metallic/citrus-orange hops, secondary medium malt.

Date: 11/29/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub hazy dark yellow, wispy off white head, streaks of drippy lace, sweet malt aroma, sweet malt flavor balanced by floral and citrus hops, touch of malt candy sweetness, light lingering bitter finish, Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.8/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

On tap at the Vista location: Slightly hazed golden hue with some head and lace. The aroma has notes of grassy and herbal hops, apple ester, corny and biscuity malt. The taste has a twangy fruit and pale biscuity malt character. A hint of DMS on the short profile, not much depth. The mouth feel is light and lively. A very average paint-by-numbers APA.

This beer poured an amber/orange mix with a thiny sheet white head. The aroma was filled with citrus and hops while also mixing in a strange bready/grainy presence. The taste yielded something a little different. Some lemon and orange dominate with a malty tang right up front. It ends dry with a slight malty, dare i say raisinesque quality. Not too bad, but very unoriginal. The sweetness becomes too much to handle by the finish.
A typical yellowish amber color with the moderate head which leaves with a quickness. Hoppy yet malty on both the aroma and taste, boring, nothing special here. No sac what so ever.

column2: Banmai, Mueang, Pathum Thani Province, Thailand
column5: Bottled. Pale yellow. Corn aroma. Very light bodied and clean mouthfeel. Decent bitterness in a papery finish.

column2: Banmai, Mueang, Pathum Thani Province, Thailand
column5: The astringency of a bitter urine soda fades into practical nothingness...I would have preferred a complete one, in this case...With its green bottle, green label, skunked aroma, fake brewery name in bold letters (Klassik Brauerei), this pathetic Thai brewery is so obviously trying to reach the German tourist macromarket, they are repulsive and insulting even before you taste their decrepit swill...

column2: Banmai, Mueang, Pathum Thani Province, Thailand
column5: An awful cereal cough syrup aroma hides a synthetic grape juice taste...Petrified dry roasted malt cannot save this massacre as even alcohol heat shows through, even though it is fairly weak in percentage...
Butelka w Tajlandii w 2002r. Kolor jasnos�omkowy.Zapach s�odowo-owocowy.Smak lekkie dro�d�e, s�odowe, kwaskowe.Nagazowanie s�abe.Pijalne piwo.
Elusive dry flower cookies amongst cereal flakes...On the back of the palate, Chinese shadows emulate a rice wine fruitiness...The sun goes down after having missed most of the day...

Found this "brewpub" on one of many tuk-tuk rides through the city...We were happy to find this one early in the day when no one was there...Look at the website and you'll see what I mean...As for the beer: This perplexing eraser mousse does leave a nice lacing...Light and creamy, this "pilsner" is not to style, has no style and is not to my liking...

A metallic astringency circles the hops and does not help the thinness of this beer to be a bit more pleasant...Exotic pale fruit (rambutan or longan) don't help me understand what this is exactly...And it doesn't make me want to taste too much...

Clashing strong whisky notes stab at roasted cherries...Hop bitterness is clueless and decides to side with the alcohol...This "stout" is the biggest misnomer I have ever seen and tasted...At best, an American Dark...
Cask@the pier(brewery tap), Ilfracombe. Golden amber beer with small head and good lacing. Aroma is faint malts. Taste is light malts, a touch of hop bitterness and grass. A little dull.
Tied at the brewery tap. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is caramel and fruit. The body is a bit thin.
Gravity at Tucker�s Maltings Festival Watery, very light body, too thin for me. Light aroma of English hops and slight sulfur.
Cask@Leicester Beer Festival 2010. Bronze beer with a strong head. The aroma is weakly bitter, and the flavour is strongly toffee. Overall an average highly bitter beer.
Cask, Leicester Fest 10. Golden with a small head. Aromas are grain and cardboard with some citrus. Flavours are biscuit malts with weak lemon. Quite flaccid and boring.

Tasting notes from Norman Knight (2004). Amber-brown with thin head. Sweet malt and biscuit aroma notes. Fruity malts with balancing citrus flavours. Dry finish. Nice, but prefer the "toad" for a session.
Cask at The Norman Knight, Whichford, Warwickshire. Amber with a small white head. Sweet malty aroma and flavour. Good bitterness to follow. Simple session ale, drinkable and enjoyable.
Cask Stillage at Wilkie�s Tavern, Warrington 30/11/2003 Amber coloured with fruit and hop aromas. Slightly dry lasting finish.
[Cask at Volunteers Arms, GBBF 2005] A hazy amber beer with a small beige head. The aroma is sweet estery combined with diacethyl. The flavor is sweet malty with strong notes of caramel.
Cask conditioned and handpulled at the Brunswick, Derby. Looks like I got the rogue barrel, then; barnyard aroma, salty taste. Not promising.

Had many of sessions with this one at the Norman Norman Knight, but the notes are from 2003 Harbury Beer Festival. Pale Golden with thin head. Citrus / grapefruit hop aromas. Mild malts balance out the hop citrus flavours. Sessionable with dry finish.

Champion Beer of Warwickshire. Cask at The Norman Knight, Whichford, Warwickshire. Mid gold with a slight head. Hop and apple aroma and a fruity taste, suggesting grapes. The finish a little thin perhaps, but overall very enjoyable..
Cask Stillage at Wilkie�s Tavern, Warrington 30/11/2003 Golden coloured and very hoppy. Slightly dry malt finish.
light in colour but not in taste, second time I�ve had this in the pub. reckon it will fly out like the last time
Very pale and anaemic in colour. The aroma is fresh and slighty sulphurous. Not too malty but lightly fruity with a nice licourice dryness. A good session starter.

Cask Conditioned at The Norman Knight, Whichford. Light golden beer with fluffy white head. Big hoppy citrus grapefruity notes, a clean and astringent flavour with gentle malt balance. A particularly drinkable beer on a warm summers day.

15 Year Bitter. Poured a rich amber color with little, but persistent, head. The aroma has a nice malty fruit character with nice hops in the finish. The flavor is also quite enjoyable. Dominated by caramel and fruity malt, it has a nice balancing hop finish. Flavorful and easy drinking, this is a nice session ale.
Almost no aroma percepted, even when warm, and then, jsut a smattering of dusty hops. Malt character moderate, fair bit of caramel. Some bittering hops show late, but overall short of character.

Cedar coloured, very persistent off-white head. Wonderful aroma -> pine, hops, a bit of lemon rind, a good amount of sweet malt to balance. . . Adequate flavour - a good representation of the style and a very nice session ale.

Vibrant red; light aroma � had to work hard and then only maybe found some earth, slight cherry�these were so light though that ambient aromas really are all you could expect to enjoy as a casual drinker. Predominantly caramelly, with toast, some chocolate malt and a subtley emerging bitterness.

Berry pepper sprinkled on earth and loads of hops...In a thin body like this, this hoppy overhaul kind of buries the fact that it's not that complex...A grand Marnier-like alcohol appears, although this is not strong at all in alcohol...A puzzling wine of a bitter that should probably be billed otherwise...
Reddish amber - ruby, small white head. Strangely sweet, light roasted malt, gentle bitterness. Drinkable ESB needs some more depth, slightly too soft as well.
Unfiltered auburn-copper w/ small head. Fruity, caramel nose w/ hint of hops. Thinnish feel. Fruity, malty character w/ some earthy woodiness.
(draft): Clear red/brown with virtually no head. Aroma is moderately sweet, floral. Taste is moderately sweet, earthy/floral, malty caramel, finishing earthy bitter. Medium body, undercarbonated.

tap-Goose Island Clybourn-RBSG-6/29/03. Aroma was very hoppy. Appearance was ruby red with a slight rocky head. Palate was full bodied and smooth. Flavor was full of earthy british hops, and a nice malt backbone. of the 3 beers i had at GI, this was the best.

Tap @ GIBC, RBSG2003. Seemed to have a bit of West-Coasty hops, but doesn't. Has some of a sweet Maris touch without the hi alch I usually associate with that malting. Graprefruit. Nice red color. No lingering head. Not as good as I had hoped.

Cask Conditioned, Plough, Bodicote. Amber brown in colour with a thin white head. Thin flavoured light bitter with gentle sweet malt and a soupcon of bitterness. Some fruit tang, but overall a gentle drinking session Ale. One of the pubs stanby's, always on and always popular.
BB1993 at Chris O. Clear amber with a small white head. Aroma of dried fruit, prunes and apricot. Smooth malty flavour with fruit, and a touch of tartness.

Bottle 275ml. @ chris_o�s Pre-GBBF Shindig 2008. [ Vintage 1993 ]. Clear medium amber color with a virtually none appearance, virtually none lacing head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, vintage, oxidised but okay, toffee. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily - syrupy, carbonation is flat. (020808)
Bottle at chris_o�s who�s next in the train tasting. Alround rating: Honey pale malts, nearly no body, oxidation is clear, stoody up well you could say, but id rather have somethign else.
Bottle at Chris o�s�1993-copper,viney fruits, odd wattery but mellow fruit, dates. little honey
Chris_o�s GBBF Shindig 08. 275ml bottle from Shropshire. Vintage 1993. Oxidised but quite malty and toffee accented. Reasonably interesting and tasty.

Had this at Chris O�s pre GBBF tasting, 02-08-08 cheers for a wonderful day Chris Pours very clear and almost chesnut in colour. The nose has really softened out over the years, aroma had more than a nod to diluted malt whisky with some sweetness. Some almonds in the mouth along with a touch of icing sugar. I used to drink this regularly in the late eighties and early nineties as it was my most local brewery so it was a great and welcome surprise to see Steve bring a bottle of this along , cheers Steve. This actually tasted better than in the pub, certainly in the last few years of its life as a brewpub, as in the last few years of its existence the quality and consistency of Bodicote beers slipped somewhat.

A Mes rate: Bottle at Chris O�s Pre GBBF Tasting Thanks to Steve for this 15 year old rarity. Red amber colour with the head not surviving. Kinda like an old man who has lost his hair. Sadly this has decended into the grips of petrol. Lots of caramel, the hops are totally gone but the aged flavours of the malt still work pretty well. I would never have this to have expected this long actually. Impressed.
Bottled, 1993 vintage. Amber colour, small head. Aroma is raisins, slight maltyness and caramel. Flavour is wood, sweet malts, fruity hops along with earth and raisins.
1993. Clear amber with tiny short lasting head. Sweet aroma with honney and prunes. Sweet flavor that disapoints a bit. Not as strong as the aroma.

Cask Conditioned at Plough, Bodicote. This mid brown beer is the most popular of the Bodicote Beers. Named after the house number of the Pub this is a strongly flavoured bitter with plenty of dry hop quality. Sharp malt flavours complement the overall taste. Jim has been brewing at the pub since 1982 and has a regular custom from many appreciative locals.

Cask Conditioned at Plough, Bodicote. Jim's strong Winter Warmer, mid to dark brown, fluffy head. Strong alcohol flavours dominate the drinking of this beer, little subtelty, just out and out brandy like flavour.

Oxford Beer Fest. Gravity. Mine was called Old English Porter with an abv of 4.4% - and I have a website which lists both the Porter and the Old English Porter, but the brewery's own website doesn't list the Old English. Waffle, waffle, waffle. It's late, and I've a belly full of beer. What am I saying? Who knows. Who cares. Who will even read this. Uhem. Murky brown. Initial hit is very pleasing - a huge rush of licorice and sasparilla - but soon fades into a mustiness of little distinction. Some sour fruit and aged oak notes. Some slightly rancid raspberry. gets more interesting. Flavours swirl around. Mmmm. A curious beer. Fruit flavours becoming stronger. Interesting.

Cask Conditioned at The Plough, Bodicote. In my opinion, and many others, this is Jim's finest. Dark Ruby Red almost Black in colour with a thick malty head. A blast of fruit and nut flavour bursts into the mouth on tasting. Ignore the strength rating, this varies enormously, at Banbury Beer Festival a Cask is held back for 6 months and is really in peak condition. This a chewey dark flavoufull beer that warms the cockles.
Cask Conditioned at Plough, Bodicote. Pale yellow amber beer, thin white head. Not subtle, a straight hoppy pale ale, thinnish little character.
Pint on tap at the Grazing Harts. Thin white head. Hazy golden pour. Easy drinking.
Cask pint at the Volunteers Arms, GBBF. Pours golden yellow with a white head. Aroma of malt. Bittersweet taste and finish. Not sure this is anything like it used to be.
Bland by modern standards. Better than John Smith's. They've skimped on late addition hops. Heathen is ten times better but hardly anyone sells it.
Can't see how this beer is so popular. Pours ok, a nice light gold. Not much head tho. Slightly bitter, not really much else to it. A poor pale from a decent brewery.
cask dorata leggera velata citrica agrume morbida lieve pepato discreta secchezza abbastanza amaro finale
Cask at the Queens Head, Stourbridge. Pours light gold with a small head. Aroma has some sherbet lemon. Taste is a little sweet with some straw and lemon. A bit bland.

Cask at the Fat Cat, Ipswich. Pours very pale gold with a small bubbly white head. Aroma is floral, hoppy, fruity notes of grapefruit, peach and pineapple. Medium sweetness, moderate hoppy bitterness. Body is quite light, slight sticky texture, average carbonation. Bittersweet finish. Nice one.
Tried at the Strugglers, Lincoln. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is light citrus. taste is light sweet and grainy. Medium body.

Appearance slightly cloudy dark yellow in colour. Not much going on the old bugle, some floral notes and bitter hops. The taste was of floral blossom, hops, grass, some caramel and a really bitter hoppy aftertaste. I would give it another go, to make sure my tastebuds weren�t deceiving me, but I wasn�t impressed.

Cask at the Nursery Tavern, Coventry on 26th October 2016. Slightly hazy gold with thin whitish spot-lacing foam. Herby hoppiness and yeasty notes in aroma. Fruity in-mouth with peach, citrus and bitter orange peel. Sharp finish of citrus peel and some grassiness. Smooth, somewhat clingy mouthfeel and medium body.

I have purchased this beer, two years ago, at the rewe/Karlstadt center, at Freiburg, drinking it in our rented flat, at Freiburg, two years ago. In my point of view, it is a classical pils that you could find thousands in Germany and so rare in Switzerland. There is a refreshing side, herbal one, dry malt, watery, hop for pils, light and acceptable.
Bottle. Pours clear pale yellow. Aroma is grains, noble hops, mostly pale malts. Body is light and thin and only bitterness, low sweetness and carbonation, but at least dry. Not much to find.

22/26.09.2018 - 0.33l bottle from ganter brauerei shop, bb 03.05.2019, ~0.90�. pours a clear pale golden with a frothy head. aroma of hay, grass, mild eggs / sulphuric notes. flavour of grass, slight eggs. ok.
Sch�nes frisches Pils, nicht zu pl�dderich. Angenehm s��, leicht Heu, etwas bitter. Nicht die Welt aber durchaus trinkbar.

18 month aged draught. Dark copper with minimal head.Site lists it as an American Strong Ale but at the brewpub they were calling it an Imperial IPA. It was obviously hoppy and floral and orangey-citric but it didn�t have the big kick I think of for an Imp. IPA. Smooth, slightly bitter medium body with flavours of orange and caramel sweetness with a fairly dry but nice long finish. Very drinkable.

On tap aged 18 months at the brewpub. Golden orange in colour. The aroma was of floral hops with some caramel and oranges. Flavour was of hops, mild malt, oranges and caramel. Medium body. Alcohol is very well hidden. Finishes long and slightly dry and bitter. Very well done.
Like a barleywine-light. Very nice malt aroma and flavor-hops seem to have faded since it was aged a year. Could use a bit more carbonation to keep it from being cloying, but a nice beer overall.
Aged for one year and a half. Redish amber color with a medium white head. Floral hops aroma with caramel. Flavor of floral hops and caramel, bitter finish. Light to medium body, soft carbonation.

18 months old version - tasted on DDC 6th anniversary. Splendid lightly cloudy amber body topped with a large and lasting off-white head. Its definitely hoppy aroma is accompanied by a complex and quite pleasant mix of caramel, toffee and sweet hints. Taste generates a hoppy party in your mouth. There�s also some vineous, smokey and brown sugar notes. It ends with a gorgeous bitter final. I may seem to be generous in my rating, but that version is undoubtedly outstanding!

Average score posted.Original: Assertive citrus (orange) hop nose. Opaque orange-amber with decent off-white head. Fruity and sweet with a strong hoppiness. Alcohol noted in the finish. On tap at the brewpub and at Mondiale de la Biere 2003. (7-3-7-3-14=3.4) Re-rated at 6th anniversary party. Aged 18 months - what a difference (7-4-8-5-16=4.0) Mild floral hops, caramel, dark fruit all meld wonderfully in this complex, spicy aroma. Opaque burnished copper with strong, dense off-white head that recedes slowly with some lacing. Very assertive and clean bitterness with huge chewey malty caramel flavours. Light floral hop notes. Syrup-like thick mouthfeel. On tap at the brewpub.
Amber and hazy robe. Caramel and orange nose. Sweet taste: mango, orange lemon, caramel. It doesnt really make its 8% ABV. Good beer, but this style holds many superior contenders.

rich carmelly backbone with moderate hop ribs on the nose. big body, slight alcohol comming through. yeasty with lots of light fruit, caramel(quite sweet), foresty flavors with a good hop bite. lots of alc to finish. warming.
(Cask) Orange color, very fruity aroma(mostly orange with a bit of grapefruit) with a handfull of hops. Big hop bite but balanced by a caramel like sweetness.
(Draught) Cloudy, deep orange yeast. Highly carbonated. Almond head. Yeasty, spiced orange peel nose. Nice bitterness. Mild orange flavour with a lasting bitter, spice stuck to the roof of my mouth.
Pours dark brown with little beige foam. Fragrance of coffee, dark chocolate, vanilla and a good base of dark fruit. On the palate, toasting, cocoa, vanilla, tobacco and light hops.

What was supposed to be a Hefeweizen, Hoppy Hefe was a bit too much on the hops. What we have here is a hoppy Hefe. Clear golden yellow, like a pilsner. Could be a hoppy pilsner instead. Overall, pretty damn tasty.
SLightly malty, somewhat hoppier than I would have expected. QUite an interesting brew for what it was supposed to be. I have still not decided about this one.
Not much here. Unimpressive. No real discernible flavors. I think this has less flavor than a Shiner bock.

column1: Bluegrass Luna de Miel Raspberry Meade
column5: A pink mauve mead with a very thin off white head. In aroma, sweet fruity honey, raspberry jam, ok. In mouth, sweet honey with light raspberry jam, light acidity, light cork, ok. On tap at Main st location.

column1: Bluegrass Luna de Miel Raspberry Meade
column5: With Kris at Louisville KY at Bluegrass brewery. Reddish colored beer with small white head and no carbonation. Fruited aroma. Medium palate. Finish is fruited sweet raspberry.

column1: Bluegrass Luna de Miel Raspberry Meade
column5: On tap at Bluegrass, pours a hazy dark amber with a small off-white head. Nose brings out lots of fresh sweet raspberries and moderate honey sweetness. Flavour is pretty weak, with moderately sweet raspberry, some pith and light honey. Not much depth or elegance. Meh.

column1: Bluegrass Luna de Miel Raspberry Meade
column5: Pours hazy, reddish honey-golden with a nice buff head. Honey dominates the aroma while letting floral and fruity notes to share the stage. Strong flavor is mainly honey with straw, floral and raspberry notes. Firm texture has a strong and persistent fizz. A honey of a mead - get moony!

column1: Bluegrass Luna de Miel Raspberry Meade
column5: Bottle during RBWG. Pours a ruby with small off white head. The aroma is fruit and honey. Thin mouth with nice honey flavor, light berry, very nice.

column1: Bluegrass Luna de Miel Raspberry Meade
column5: Draft sampler pours reddish with a thin white head. Aroma of raspberries and honey. Taste is much the same.

column1: Bluegrass Luna de Miel Raspberry Meade
column5: Tap @ Bluegrass: Murky pink body with hints of rusty copper. A lightly foamy & gray-tinted head fizzes out on top pretty quickly. Smells like herbal raspberry tea; sweet raspberry candy notes with undertones of herbaceous leafiness & mild grass. Taste is the same way, like a semi carbonated raspberry tea drink. Sweet raspberry juice, tea leaves, grass, & some finishing notes of residual sugar. Carbonation is a little prickly & weird. Tasty, but kind of spritzy & thin overall.

column1: Bluegrass Luna de Miel Raspberry Meade
column5: Draft at third street location. Now is honey and raspberry. Sweet as expected. Honey flavor is really convincing.

column1: Bluegrass Luna de Miel Raspberry Meade
column5: 2/28/14. On tap at the brewpub. Served as "Raspberry Meade." Pinkish pour, no head, okay legs. Sweet raspberry and honey aroma, a touch of an herbal aspect, meh. Sweet raspberry flavor, honey, herbal, black tea in the flavor. Meh.

column1: Bluegrass Luna de Miel Raspberry Meade
column5: Glass at BBC on 9/13/13. Clear blush in color with a medium white head. Aroma of dry white wine, raspberry and honey. Flavor of raspberry soda and honey before a thin finish.
Tap. A medium golden color with a laced white head. A flowery rye aroma. Smooth in flavor with a touch of sweet and sour. An enjoyable light beer with a medium body.
I would drink it again, but I won't drive to FL to get it. The aroma wasn't terribly enticing, the taste was average and the balance was a little off. Maybe I just got a bad bottle.

Well Ahoy there Matey's! When I was young, I'd influence my father's beer purchases based on which cans I thought looked cool. Now, Chloe says "Hey beer drinker, look a pirate beer, that's cool!" So I buy the pirate beer. It's nowhere near an English Pale Ale, I'm not so sure it even is an ale. It's mostly pale yellow, fizzy, malty sweet with little hops. Actually, it's very fizzy. and full of big chunky floaties. Oh well, the label is fun.

Frothy foamy white head. decent carbonation for sure. light amber/orange color. Light caramel and sweet pale malt aroma. some cereal grains, sweet. no bitterness, but a somewhat complex malt finish and a very drinkable body.
12oz bottle(9/02)-An orangish amber body with an aroma of hops and malt. taste was the same with a pretty decent hop flavor. Not bad.
Had this beer on 10/2/2002. Aroma is mild malt scent. Color was an orange/amber with ok carbonation and head. Taste is mild with a nice hoppyness. Overall I think its a good beer.

Poured with a very impressive head, which provided great lacing. Actually, the appearance was very nice for a pale ale. Hopping was detectable in the flavor and aroma with some citrus overtones (but not a lot of grapefruit going on).

Man it�s 92 degrees at beer thirty in the morning is the Valley. Yeasty and hop citrus aroma. Copper color to the body with small white head that settled to a thin layer on top of beer. Left some good lacing. Carbination was good with some some good bubble action in the body. Dry hop citrus flavor. Left a dried fruit aftertaste. Sight bitterness and coll and crisp on the palate. Good Beer.

Bottle poured a cloudy orange color with lots of floaties and a light skim of a head that layed across the top of the beer. Aroma of Malt, hops and citrus. Flavor is medium powered hops and citrus,oranges with a clean crisp hops finish. Good, easy drinking, refreshing beer. I have stood at the same place that the gila monster is sitting on the label!

Slightly cloudy copper amber color, no head to speak of, hop citrus aroma, nice not overbearing, Hop taste comes right in on first sip it was almost to bitter, more bitter than flavorful. A good thirstquencher

Color: a clear, bright apricot, with tiny, yeasty(?!?) travellers swimming hither and thither. Head: small, brief, white. Aroma is soft amd swept clean, but slowly unfolds with malty tones of caramel and nuts. Faintly fruity, otherwise lacking in hops. On palate, a bit sharp, at first, with a coppery twang. Eventually, hops assert themselves, but the mouthfeel was not a pleasant experience. The roughness I felt subsides some, and the pieces come together more in the middle. Still, the flavors compete a bit too much. Something about what I could only call a "dull, ringing aftertaste" spoiled this ale for me. Body is medium, texture good, but not a smooth ride, when that�s what�s called for with a pale ale.

Draught at Mogollon Brewing Company, Flagstaff, Arizona. Clear dark orange beer with no head. Weak fruity and little hoppy aroma. Hoppy flavor, quite thin specially in the finish. Orange notes also. Some dryness.
Picked this up in four corners country in Arizona. Beautiful copper color with one hell of a hop assault on the tastebuds. Eye-opening, bitter aftertaste. I�d definitely buy it again.
Clear medium orange color, with a small white head. Very nice, IPA-ish hop bite, very criosp with a solid malty body and overall wood-like characteristics.

0.3 litre glass at the brewery on 31st July 2018. Light golden body, clean and clear, on top a white crown that lasted. Semi-sweet affair, with malty molasses to the fore in both the aroma and taste, nice hop balance though, easy drinking in the afternoon sun on their patio.

(Tap) Es hat eine goldgelbe Farbe, ist klar filtriert mit einer wei�en Schaumkrone. Das Aroma ist s��lich hopfig, getreidig und einem klein bisschen DMS. Der Geschmack ist schlank, im Hintergrund leicht getreidig, oben drauf kommt eine blumige Kopfnote mit einem s��lichen Abgang mit einer starken Nektarnote. Die Bittere k�nnte st�rker sein, fehlt aber nicht.

On tap the the brewpub. A crystal clear golden yellow coloured pour with a sticky white head. Aroma is light grains, fresh honey, honey monster cereal. Clean. Flavour is composed of semi sweet pale malts, crisp cereal malts, very easy going. Palate is semi sweet crisp, moderate carbonation. Crisp finish with a touch of metal. Very sessionable.
On tap at the brewpub. A clear pale golden beer with a mid-sized most good lasting white head. Aroma of mild grassy and fruity bitter hops. Taste of grassy and floral bitter hops, hay, nice.
2l Flasche. Gelbes Pils mit toller Schaumkrone. Malziges Aroma, schmeckt malzig nach Getreide.
Draught at the brewery. Clear pale yellow with a white head. Aroma light to medium malty (caramel) and hoppy. Flavor light to medium sweet and bitter. Medium body. Nice.

Tap (@Steinhuder Strandterassen, Steinhude): Pale golden to golden,clear, medium-sized and slowly collapsing loose white head; sweet pale malt and herbal-spicy hops in the nose; mild to moderate bitter-sweet flavour, not too light bodied, very smooth; slightly lingering pale-malty and nerbal-hoppy finish. Surely not exciting, but nevertheless very well made and heavily quaffable...
Form the tap, cristal clear with foamy white head. Nose of good citric hops and grass. Tadte is astringent hops herbal and refreshing. Decent carbonstion... Good pilsener
At the Hannoversches Bierfest, draught, on June 7, 2014. Clear straw yellow color, white head. Malty, grainy, sweet taste. Fizzy mouthfeel, medium low bitterness. Sweet, malty scent. Clean, nice.

Tap @ Brewpub. Pours clear pale piss yellow with a white head. Lots of hay and grass. Smooth and dry. Good hops and unfortunately some late paperish notes. I reckon it can be in better condition. But still quite drinkable.
Fles 50cl thuis. Zoet, wat waterig, licht kruidig. (2-2014).---------------.
500ml Flasche. Klar und dunkelbraun mit kleiner Schaumkrone. Spritzig. R�staromen. Malzig. Etwas d�nner K�rper.
Passivt a faulty batch. No real discernible taste, except for slight malt notes and and sweet notes like dates ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

0,5 l bottle. Backside label: Brewed and bottled at Privat-Brauerei Z�tler. Pours out in a dark brown, small head. Malty on the nose. Taste is mid dark malty, sweetness in the middle part, dry and lower sweetness in the end. Not really complex. Easy to drink, easy to forget.

Ein sch�nes Durcheinander: im Netz finde ich die �Postbrauerei Allg�u� (verantwortlich: Herbert Z�tler), die �Privat-Brauerei Z�tler� (verantwortlich: Herbert Z�tler) und die �Postbrauerei Karl Meyer Nesselwang� (deren Logo, abgesehen von der Ortsangabe im Schriftzug, mit dem der �Postbrauerei Allg�u� identisch ist). Hier liegen die Besitz- und Brauverh�ltnisse auf den ersten Blick etwas im Unklaren. Genauere Recherche ergab, da� die Postbrauerei Nesselwang von Z�tler �bernommen und in Postbrauerei Allg�u umbenannt wurde (Quelle: Z�tler Post Nr. 82/2010). Ob seitdem alle oder manche Postbrauerei-Biere auch bei Z�tler gebraut werden, ist unklar. - Aber nun zum Bier: Tiefes Kastanienbraun mit r�tlichem Schimmer. - Nase r�stmalzig-nussig. - Antrunk mild karamelw�rzig, schwach s��, leicht aber deutlich r�stmalzig. Leicht kremiges Mundgef�hl, durchschnittlich rezent. Schwach gehopft. Deutlich r�stmalzbitterer Abgang. - Sehr harmonisches, nicht allzu kr�ftiges aber s�ffiges Dunkles. - Vom Fa� im Restaurant Aquila, F�ssen (24.4.2014). ===== According to the brewery newsletter Z�tler Post (no. 82/2010), the former Postbrauerei Karl Meyer Nesselwang was acquired by Privat-Brauerei Z�tler and re-named in Postbrauerei Allg�u. However, it remains unclear if their beers are brewed by Z�tler now.
Ins Glas ergie�t sich ein dunkelbraunes Bier mit sch�ner Schaumkrone. Geruch r�stmalzig, Karamell, leicht w�rzig. Geschmack angenehm r�stmalzig, leichte schokoladige Noten, leicht w�rzig.
50 cl bottle. Dark brown colour with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of roasted malt, caramel, bread and fruity notes.
Deep malty and slightly sour. The latter might be due to the beer being 2 years overdue. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle @ home. Pours dark amber with a ligght tan head. Aroma of wheat, light roasted malt, caramel. Flavor is rather sweet wirh wheat, light yeast, caramel, little sweet fruit, hint of chocolate. Thin body, lively carbonation. 151113
20.09.2013. 0,5l Bottle. Dark amber colour with off-white head. Lots of aromas of dark malts. Caramel sweetness, grassy hops and dark malts. Low on bitterness.

Draft at the brewery on 31st July 2018. Deep golden body, clean and clear, the head a fluffy snow white crown. Fairly sweet (like the other two I drank on their patio) with malty molasses ruling the aroma and taste, some hop balance and there is a light fruitiness to the whole brew. Liked it.

Hopfiger recht s��er Antrunk. Dabei schmeckt der Hopfen k�nstlich nach Kaugummi, das Bier erst sp�t durch herb w�rzige Aromen harmonisch. Dann aber durchaus gelungen und s�ffig, passend hopfig herb. 11/6/9/9//9
Draught. Clear golden colour with a decent white head and a good lacing. Aroma and taste of malts, grain and fruits. Nice palate. Lasting taste.

Draught @ Rupp-Brau, Feggendorfer Strasse 10, Lauenau, Lower Saxony Germany 31867. Clear medium to light dark yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate to light light heavy malty, grain, hay, dusty, sugar. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long duration, alcohol, malty bock flavor. Body is medium to light full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light alcoholic. [20100715]

Draught at the brewpub. The color is beautiful, warm golden and the head is creamy. The aroma has notes of flower, fruit and malt. The flavour has sweetness and notes of malt, fruit and the finish is slightly dry. It is very harmonic, straightforward and pleasant.

Draught at the brewpub. Clear golden colour. Big stable white head. The flavour starts off fruity and flowery, perhaps some elderflower. Also quite caramelly, almost candylike. The alcohol comes in next, it is quite distinct without becoming too much. There is also a distinct bitterness that balances off the sweeter flavours well. A very good, flavourful and well-balanced Doppelbock.

Draft. A dark orange beer with a lazing off-white head. The aroma is a bit light, what is there is sweet with notes of alcohol and malt. The flavor is sweet alcoholic and malt, as well as faint hints of butter, leading to a dry and rather bitter finish which has a slight alcohol metal tinge.

(On tap) Clear, fully golden with a white head leaving laces. Aroma of malt and alcohol. Very full-bodied with loads of malt, a high degree of sweetness and a distinct alcohol but never in an unpleasant way. Some bittering hops nicely balance the sweetness to make for a very harmonious Heller Bock. 051106
I hate to say it but their strongest was the best. This was the first summerversion in May, the winterversion was finished. The difference is the colour dark in the winter, but lighter in the summer.

I had this beer together with a pig shank (Schweinehaxe). The same beer was also present in the briliant sauce and in the sauerkraut. The beer is pricking on the tonque on the sweet side. A little alcoholic but generally good.
Tap @ Hellmuth, Wiesen. Pours Amber Brown with a small creamy head. Buttery nose and flavor. Sooothing and undrinkable. The 3 Hellmuth beers were all unclean on my visit July - 17.
Malzig, crispy, leicht s�ffig-s��. Hohe Drinkability, kernig, cremiger Abgang. Bek�mmlich.

Clear amber with a medium off white head. Aroma had caramel and toasted malt. Flavor had toasted malt, caramel and toffee hints. finished rather dry and roasted for the style. one of the better m�rzens around.
At the Bad Staffelstein bierfest, 15 August 2014. Copper coloured, with a decent, off-white, head. Sweet, with plenty of caramel and some berry fruits, before a decent, bitter finish. Good.

Draft at the brewery in Wiesen. Cloudy, rich red-brown colored body with a creamy off-white head. Malt aroma shows notes of bread, caramelized sugar, apple, sweet toffee. Quiet hops show light spiciness. Medium-full body, sweet, syrupy, chewy in the mouth. Not much depth, and the malt character and flavor balance doesn�t align much with my tastes.
On tap at the Brewpub. Orangebraunes Bier mit ordentlicher beigen Schaumkrone. Geruch leicht r�stmalzig, Karamell. Geschmack nach Karamell, schokoladig, leicht w�rzig.

On draught at the brewpub (the landlady called it "Dunkel"): Deep golden, unclear, visible carbonation, small beaten-egg-white-like foamy layer, sweetish-caramelly nose with a slight barnyardy touch and mild hoppy traces; moderate bitter-sweet flavour, light to medium bodied, not "ungespundet"; slightly lingering bitter-malty finish. Decent franconian brew...

Bottled, alc. 4.9% Ruby red color, big creamy tanned head, lace. Wheat bread sweetness in the nose. Medium-bodied, malty. Sweetish, ashy, short finish, quite refreshing. Not very typical dunkel (only outlook).

Tapbeer only in this tiny brewpub. Orange colored, just a bit hazy, the beer is not filtered. Hardly any head, malty flavor with a bit of a barnyard smell. Just a bit soapy. Full bodied with a fine hopbitter aftertaste. A treat on a hot humid day.
Im Zapfhahn Bamberg. Schon in der Nase sehr malzig, im Trunk dann ausgesprochen karamellig, malzig, kernig, s�ffig s��, hinten feinbitter. L�uft!

0,5 l Flasche. Braunes Bier, stabiler, grobporiger, relativ flacher Schaum, sch�ne Gardine. Riecht nach Schokolade, schmeckt dann auch nach dunkler Schokolade, malzig. Im Abgang dann sogar leicht herb.
Amber lager that tastes a bit oxidized and stale to me. Otherwise it seems well balanced and a good beer. d&S Dresden

Bottle 50cl, a clear amber beer with medium off-white head and correct retention. Nose is on toasted caramel, milk chocolate, leather. Aroma is nice on spice, dry caramel, toasted caramel, nice retro-nasal on blond caramel and diacetyl, body very pleasant; finish on toasted caramel and tannin notes, marzipan. Nose surprise
From bottle at Caf� Brecht, Amsterdam, 30.03.19. Dark orange amber. Fine foamy and persistent off-white head and lacing. Excellent aroma of softly roasted malt, figs and heather
Super bright golden colour. Puffy, uneven head. Aroma is primarily bread. Taste is pretty sweet and malty.
Ausgewogene Mischung aus verschiedenen R�stmalzen mit hohem Wiedererkennungswert. F�r ein Dunkles sehr s�ffig und leicht trinkbar. Mein Favorit unter den dunklen Bieren.
0,5l Flasche. Dunkles Bier mit einer sch�nen Schaumkrone. Riecht nach R�stmalze, schmeckt auch so, etwas hefig.
Brownish and a bit red color. Almost no foam. Aroma of roasted grain,hops.Pleasant and strong taste of caramel, toffee. Long caramel palate with soft carbonation. Super
Bottle 0,5lt - red brown color with white head - strong caramel Taste and moca - leaves a bitter taste that lasts
Tap @ Brewery. Pours clear Golden with a creamy White head. Grass and White bread. Chewy. Good malts. Dry finish. Chalky and rustic dry bitterness. Nice
on tap oro carico velata buona schiuma buona persistenza cereale un filo rustico nota delicata lieve erbaceo finale

�Stern-Br�u Vollbier�, Flasche (50 cl) von Hopfen & Malz, Berlin-Wedding. - Etwas dunkleres Goldgelb, klar. - In der Nase kernig brotiges, nicht zu s��es helles Malz und gut krautig-herber Hopfen, Grapefruitschale. - Antrunk brotig hellmalzig und sauber gerstig mit angenehm aromatischer kr�uterig-zitrusfruchtiger Herbe (Limette), zart s�uerlich, jedenfalls nicht so malzs�� wie viele Helle. Mild rezent, vollmundig. Im Abgang leicht trocken mit recht kr�ftiger, zart s�uerlicher Hopfenherbe (Pampelmusenschale). Langer bitterer Nachtrunk. - Kerniges Frankenlager mit prononcierter Hopfenherbe und kr�ftig gerstigem K�rper, der an ein Festbier denken l��t. Ausgezeichnet.

Gravity cask @FrankenBierFest (Rome). Pours golden with a medium and persistent head. Aroma of cereals, bread, malt, lemon. Flavour is easy, simple, balanced, a bit thin. Light body, medium carbonation. A bit poor...

Gravity keg at Franken Fest in Rome Italy. Gold brigh semi clear color, medium white foam. Nose is pretty much lemony, lemon grass, hay. Great. Mouth: soft carbo, more rustic barley, sugary lime juice. Surprisingly good! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From draft at the brewery in Schlusselfeld. Clear and sparkling rich gold with a fine white head. Medium bodied, chewy and rich in the mouth with a strong caramelized pale malt character and substantial roughness. Hops are herbal and green and lends it a strong bitterness and against the moderately-low sweetness. It�s also strongly carbonic and sulfuric and a little too rough which seems like short lagering. Has the richness and sharpness more suited to Festbier and Bockbier than Helles, not exactly drinkable given the roughness, but also not overly flawed.
Klares goldgelbes Bier mit einer ordentlichen wei�en Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, getreidig s��. Geschmack getreidig, sehr malzig, leicht bitter hopfig, s�ffig.

column1: Dieu du Ciel! Menace de Dieu
column5: Cask on Feb.9, 2006. Orange golden ale with a thin white head. Light caramel and crisp hops in aroma. In mouth, good malt base with peppery hops, light citrus and medium bodied.

Bottle from Brigadier...thanks Nathan! Was looking forward to trying this one after a weekend of lots of dark, sweet beer. Pours clear yellow with little cascading bubbles floating up to a small foamy white head. Aroma is lightly peppery and sweet, with sweet, crackery malt. A touch of spicy hops. Taste is herbal hops, white pepper, and not much of a malt base. It�s mineral and dry, with real pale malt. Carbonation bites way too much, but the body is light like I expected. Not too bad.

Keeps a great white head over a light gold body, brilliantly clear body. A little bit of green apple fruitiness with a faint banana ester and a nice clean low grainy malt aroma, no hop, and a very subtle hint of DMS as it warms. Flavor is slightly grainy malt with a hop back up in the finish and aftertaste; very well balanced and clean for the most part. A slight bit of fruitiness in the finish as well. Not what I'd expect from a cream ale, but pleasantly surprised. Not terribly complex, but what cream ale is. Carbonation is high and body is on the fuller side of light w/ a slightly dry m/f. "Very quaffable" as Garin would say. I say it's very good and thirst quenching, better than the standards IMHO, if only a bit overhopped for cream ale style.

Had this at B&O Brewing in Youngstown - The waitress set it down and said "Cream Ale" - I later found out it was a guest tap from Buckeye. Aroma is citrus. Body is clear yellow - good head and lacing. At first, I was confused - flavor is citrus up front, very creamy and malty, and the finish is super crisp, filled with a peppery, spicey hop - except for the clear body, it almost seemed like a Wit or Hefe. Then she said "Cream Ale" - wow - Usually that reminds me of Genesee and I run screaming from the room. I could happily drink a couple of growlers of this while mowing my lawn.

Barwa g��bokiej czerwieni, klarowne. Piana �rednia, jak na styl, do�� trwa�a. Aromat lekko dziki, wi�niowy, zapowiada, �e piwo b�dzie kwa�ne i tak te� jest. Wytrawne, intensywnie wi�niowe z pestkowym posmakiem. Goryczka jest, ale z wi�ni, nie chmielu, wysycenie wysokie. Bardzo dobry kriek.
Ruby, bold, ruthless. Cherry nose, cherry body, cherry taste. When a beer gets so high you don't need further words. Excellence.

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: I'm not sure if it was from the yeast they used, but the front of this is very bright but acidic. Malts were grainy and slightly chalky, but full of roast. Finish was short, roasted flavors lingered.

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: On tap as "Happy Tappy ESB". Pours deep amber with no head, tiny ring of suds and no retention. Caramel malty nose. This has a nice body, starting with a caramel sweetness. As the British pale malts and accompanying Fuggles hops decorate the back of the tongue (and lengthy at that!), a fruity ester finish provides the end of a nice pull. This feels complex, while not too heavy. Good integration here, and very well done. Very good for a session. (If only the appearance were just a shade nicer... a bit more pillow on top would make this an honest brew.)

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: Very nice bitter. Has a flavor like a good English ale. Finish is very dry and refreshing.

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: Medium brown color - thick white head with good lacing. Malty flavor with a dry biting and bitter finish. Very clean,quenching and enjoyable.

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: It seemed a bit dry like the other OBX beers I sampled with a similar malty overtone but laced with an apple-like caramel flavor in there. This isn�t a bad beer but its nothing out of the ordinary either. This one is now known as the "Red Flagship ESB."

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: Light golden brown, with white head. Hoppy aroma. Lots of flavor--citrousy. Good finish. This one really tasted more like an IPA to me, but it is still great.

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: Burnt orange with a resident light foam topping. Immediate hop flowering in the nose. Taste is hoppy, yet toasty and reminds me of cracked wheat.

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: Starts malty, with a very pleasant biscuity flavor in the middle. It finishes with a surprisingly strong hop flavor, earthy in profile, probably the Goldings speaking up. I'm not a big ESB fan, but I liked this one.

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: A nice, assertively hopped, ESB. Malts were fruity and bready, but thin. Hops are the main show here - this was nearly as hoppy as their IPA. Long bitter finish. Nice and sessionable.

Cask (handpump) @ Kings Head (Station Tavern, Free House), Huddersfield Station - St. Georges Square, West Yorkshire, Huddersfield, HD1 3EB. ABV: 3.4%. Clear medium orange yellow colour with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, caramel, fruity, light to moderate hoppy, grapefruit. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20120121]

Cask, gravity, at the Pig �n� Falcon, St Neots, Cambridgeshire, in the Bank Holiday Extravaganza Beer Festival �11. Amber. Faint straw aroma. Taste is fresh and grassy, with a slight metallic suggestion. Mid bitter finish. Not my favourite of the day.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Malt Shovel, Northampton. A light gold coloured beer with a whitish head. The aroma is sharply hoppy, which follows through to the taste. A little light in body and needing more malt to provide balance. Tasty but lacking substance.Score 3.2 Subsequent rating scored 2.7. Average becomes 3.0

Cask conditioned at The Woolpack, Banbury. Pale Gold with white head. Dry, grassy hoppy bitter, light on the palate, with a lasting crisp bitterness. Fresh and very enjoyable as a session beer. Good stuff.
Cask Handpump at the Borough Arms, Crewe 10/05/2005 Golden coloured and very hoppy. Slightly bitter crisp lasting malt finish.
As fresh as cut grass, the aroma is good. Looks OK, too, being dark bronze in colour. The beer itself is quite thin in flavour but is redeemed by the moreish, dry finish. A reasonable session beer.
Standard bitter appearance with a watery and slightly sea breeze aroma. A lightly hopped flavour. Overall a pleasant lightly hopped bitter.

10/19/18. On tap at the brewery. Definitely old school here. Orange pour with a nice off-white head that sticks and laces well. Floral aroma, earthy, touches of black tea and caramel. Floral hop character, medium bitterness, some spice, grass, tea, and earth; lingering caramel sweetness. Not terribly made, but definitely old school and just not my style.
Has a pleasant rustic "working man's" character. Unpretentious, straightforward pale ale with more malt background then most.
On tap @ the brewery. Yellow pour with grainy nose. Soup bullion barley and lighter hops. Kind of goopy mouthfeel. Very average.
B-. Pours a clear straw color with white head. Great aroma but has a somewhat harsh finish

Out to brunch with family and all my aunts and uncles were getting bloody mary�s and pressured me into it and the odd thing about getting a bloody mary in this part of world is it automatically comes with a chaser. so opted for this La Crosse local. fine orange pour. nose is earthy hops. tastes bready, earthy, malty, and some orange zest. medium carbonated. fine straight up pale ale.
Not too impressed with this. Had it in a bottle and poured into glass. Decent color and aroma but the hops bitterness didn�t do it for me

Golden with frothy white head. Decent head retention and lacing. Floral, grapefruit, and fruity aroma. Medium bodied, lemon, and nice creamy texture. Medium bitterness, mild dryness, ok balance. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle poured a clear tarnished gold with a small lasting amber head. Aromas of bread, citrus, light dankness and light earthiness. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of bread, earthiness and light pine with a smooth lingering earthy finish.

12 ounce bottle. A white head sits atop a rich yellow glowing body. A subtle but fresh hoppy aroma can be noticed from across the table. The flavor is mildly hoppy and unlike so many pale ales out there, this ones got a light maltiness backing up the hops but not so much that it�s filling. Great Wisconsin beer love it.
Draft. From notes. Herbal and citrus hops with bready and caramel malts. Not too shabby.
Bottle. It poured a rich brown color with a tan head. It's aroma was roasted malt, chocolate and a nice nuttiness. It was semi-sweet in taste as well.

10/19/18. On tap at the brewery. Dark brown pour with hints of red edges under a small off-white head that fades to a ring but sticks. Hint of spice and floral on the aroma, light caramel and nuts. Toasty flavor, bread, toast, biscuit, hint of caramel, nuts, spice. Nothing special.
Not a huge fan of this brown ale. Malts aren't aggressive enough. Neither sweet nor roasty. Weak caramel and toffee. Tried with the family in 2018 at Northern Lights.

Tap at the LaCrosse, WI airport. Pours pretty, a rich woody brown color with a foamy ivory head. Nose is straight nuttiness and roasty malts. Pretty straightforward for the style to the point of plainness. Just simple roast, nuts and some earth but nothing to distinguish it.
Nice "Session" beer... roasted malts, nutty, sweet... but enough hops to counter the hops. perhaps a bit thin.

Deep chestnut amber-brown hue under a thin ivory foamy head. Gently earthy cocoa nose with a touch of toast. Light flavor with dark roasty tones and a hint of sweetness. Crisp semisweet dark brown body. Meh.
pours a maroon amber brown with a medium tan head. Caramel malt aroma. Malt forward taste with a hint of nuttiness. Sweetish finish and linger. Good.
12 oz bottle pours brown with a off white head. Aroma of malts, spice and earthy. Taste is toffee, roasted malts and nutty.
On the thin and light side of the brown ale scale but pleasant enough. Light earthy, nutty notes keep it from being a total snooze.
Light and not very memorable. Tasted fine tho, just sort of generic overall
I had this at Pearl Street Brewing. Pours cloudy gold with a white head. Taste banana, sweet, clove. I thought this was good. I would drink this again. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

10/19/18. On tap at the brewery. Lightly hazed orange pour with a small khaki head that fades to a ring. Light banana aroma, hints of citrus, spice. Light flavor, effervescent, banana, dough, touch of spice, just a hint at citrus and cream. A bit light/thin and one dimensional. Eh.
Looks the part but drinks more like a wheat ale than a hefe. Some wheat but have to use your imagination to get much banana or clove.

Overall not bad. My gripe with this beer is it is too bland. There is cloves and subtle banana but notthe punch I want Carb level is good and bubbly. I would buy again if there was no other hefe around.

Appearance�s a hazy, dull amber with a very short lived head and no lace. Aroma�s not bad with traditional banana/ clove characteristics. Flavor�s like nose, though a bit shallow. Body�s on the thin side. Ok beer, but not my fav Pearl Street.
Gold color. A little cloudy. Lightly sweet. Typical hefeweizen flavors, banana and clove, but the palate is too thin and the flavors are too light, almost like a kristalweizen.

Refrigerated 12 oz. brown squat bottle poured into a weizen glass. Pours hazy golden with very small white head. Aroma is grainy, medium body, lower carbonation, and little lacing. Taste is grainy, with of flavors, and hints of banana. Not interested in trying again.

2 oz. pour, on tap at the brewery�s taproom, as part of an 8-beer flight. Consumed on 5-14-14. Yeasty aroma features scents of bubbelgum, candy, overripe banana, and a touch of salt. Excellent smell. Pours a hazy, cloudy, light gold. Effervescent. Off-white head. Flavors of bubblegum and lemon / tonic water tartness. Light body. Frothy in the palate. Insubstantial palate effects. Overall, an enjoyable hefeweizen, and quite enjoyable for an American example of the style. Grossly underrated here at RateBeer, in my opinion.

Murky maize with a quickly withering medium white crown. Aroma is a bit odd at first then is grassy and herbal with lemon, bready malt and yeast. Taste is a bit strange too a mishmash of herbal notes, lemon, yeast and comes off a bit sour and bland.

I had this one at the taproom inside the brewery. It was served in a pilsner glass adorned with a wedge of lemon. It looked good on that hot afternoon with its big rocky head and cloudy yellow-orange hue. It smelled a little like banana taffy and nutmeg. The first sip left me with a white moustache ;) The flavor was as exciting as the alluring aroma. Tart and tangy with a honey sweet finish. I had to ask the quite attractive bartender for another! A also asked her what the story was with the curious name of this beer and she told me it was a double entendre. I played it like I knew what she was talking about and quickly Googled it when she was off pouring someone else a beer. When she came back, I asked her to explain this play on words and she said that "hefe" means yeast in German but "el jefe" (pronounced el hefe) means "the boss" in Spanish. I asked her her name and she said "call me el hefe".

column1: Pearl Street Morning Glory Hemp Porter
column5: coffee, chocolate, earthy, woody, black, hazy, brown foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, creamy, thick feel, average carbonation,

column1: Pearl Street Thats What I'm Talkin Bout Organic Rolled Oat Stout
column5: 10/19/18. On tap at the brewery. Black pour with a small khaki head that sticks. Roasted malt aroma, hints at coffee, smooth chocolate, some caramel and cream. Good flavor, silky body, some chocolate, coffee, caramel and cream. Tasty enough.

column1: Pearl Street Thats What I'm Talkin Bout Organic Rolled Oat Stout
column5: Taste: Rich, chocolate bittersweet and black malts, oats, smooth mouthfeel. Toasted baker's chocolate, molasses, malt nose. Black/Brown, mostly opaque, smaller tan head with some ringed lace. Medium Full body.

column1: Pearl Street Thats What I'm Talkin Bout Organic Rolled Oat Stout
column5: little to no head, looks like coke. medium carb, watery and light, but a nice roasty flavor comes through. not bad but not great

column1: Pearl Street Thats What I'm Talkin Bout Organic Rolled Oat Stout
column5: Aroma is Coco, dark malt, and roast. flavor is similar to knows, starts out a little on that sweet side and then finishes a little on the dry side. Body�s both chalky and silky with ok carbonation. Decent finish.

column1: Pearl Street Thats What I'm Talkin Bout Organic Rolled Oat Stout
column5: Black brew sitting under an impressive head of tan foam. Roasted malt dominates the smell with both sweet and bitter notes. Chocolate is there and provides most of the bitterness. Chocolate is on the sweet side in the taste. Roasted malt gives the bitter, I taste the oats in the background. Smooth mouthfeel. A nice brew, imho. Thanks Tyler!

column1: Pearl Street Thats What I'm Talkin Bout Organic Rolled Oat Stout
column5: Good flavor, but watery and very flat. This bottle also had a moderate metallic flavor from oxidation.

column1: Pearl Street Thats What I'm Talkin Bout Organic Rolled Oat Stout
column5: At the end of the day most of the time Organic is a label to get you to buy bad beer- not this time. Enjoyable Stout- great choice now that the weather is cooling off. Small brewery doing something right!

column1: Pearl Street Thats What I'm Talkin Bout Organic Rolled Oat Stout
column5: Bottle. Nice aroma. Thick, syrup feel detracts from from the overall quality. Good taste (I�ve become bias toward stouts, porters, nutbrowns, etc.) Not a thirst quenching summer beer, but a nice autumn brew.

column1: Pearl Street Thats What I'm Talkin Bout Organic Rolled Oat Stout
column5: 2 oz. pour, on tap at the brewery�s taproom, as part of an 8-beer flight. Consumed on 5-14-14. Labeled as "Pearl Street That�s What I�m Talkin� �Bout Rolled Oat Stout." Scents of chocolate, coffee, char, and oatmeal (I am happy to say that I noticed the oatmeal scent before I read the full name of the beer that indicated that it contains oats). Pours an opaque dark brown with tan head. Looks like cola or coffee. Some effervescence. Flavors of char and dark maltiness. Tastes good. Medium body. Forgettable palate effects. I was hoping for more smoothness from the oats. This is a solid, well made, and enjoyable beer, better than I expected, and underrated at this site.

column1: Pearl Street Thats What I'm Talkin Bout Organic Rolled Oat Stout
column5: Bottle from the brewery. Black pour - cool looking. Beige head. Toasted oat aroma, more of the same on the taste. Maybe a hint of coffee in here. Palate is a touch thin. Pretty decent brew.

On draught in a snifter. The sign on the wall says it�s a barleywine. Cloudy, golden & orange color with an excellent head, nice lacing and very small bubbles. The aroma is sweet, malty, orange and some hops. The flavor is sweet, malty, orange with a very smooth hop profile. The bitterness is not what you get in a NW barleywine but there is plenty there. This is a very smooth beer that is quite drinkable given its perceived alcohol content (8-10%?). Excellent beer!

Tap. Pours a murky but bright orange color with a rocky white head and good lacing. This has a nice citrus and fruit aroma. Big hop flavor with a good malt background and a velvety smooth texture. I don�t know if the one I had was aged or new but it was very smooth. Great beer.

Tap. Nice-looking in a wine glass: glowing orange-amber, level and foamy head. Very sharp aroma, saying "Yield to incoming bitterness and hoppiness". And indeed, that's what comes. It tastes similar to an Arrogant Bastard, with the expected strong citrus-grapefruit flavor and aggressive Chinook hops. Mildly off aftertaste made me ponder giving it a 3 in palate, but if you're gonna run with the big boys, ya gotta be able to handle it. A good beer.

This was the best of show at the TCBF - IMO. Even with a smaller pour it shows what I like in a barleywine, complexity of malt and hop as they play happily in the Texas sun as it eats my lunch. My notes became much as others by this point leading me to but a sketch and recollection that I will be having this again. Yum.
Bottle - pours black with a tan head. Sulphuroc aroma. First taste is really sour, then there is a light roast flavour. Not much to say about this one!
Explosive head out of the bottle not a good start. Unbalanced sourness predominates over a bad char and spice base. Unrefined to say the least. Maybe a bad bottle.

Bottle (640ml). Poured opaque with a huge, tanned, fluffy head which filled the glass, but with time it settled to a average sized head which was mostly diminishing. Aroma had unpleasant sulfuric notes (like all the other bottled St Peters brews I have sampled) with strong notes of acidic dark grapes, tart blackberries and hints of roasted chocolate malts hiding underneath the mess. Flavor was offensive with strong acidic notes, sour dark grapes, tart blackberries, notes of burnt plastic, roasted chocolate malts that�s are petty much non existent and a dry metallic finish. Light to medium bodied with lively carbonation, dry texture, watery mouthfeel and a bad finish. All the St Peters beers I have had (all bottled) have been an utter waste of money, judging from some other ratings I must have picked up 3 bad batches from 3 different brews, although I still don�t think I would bother buying any of them again.
Nice roasted malt nose, but mouth is thin and sour, though backed up with solid roastiness. Unbalanced and mediocre at best.

A fairly pleasant stout if you get a good bottle. After striking out first time around, I took the risk and picked up a second bottle of this and my decision was vindicated. Lovely aroma of creamy chocolate with a touch of roasted coffee. On tasting it drops a little, with a bit of a minerally watery flavour coming through. That taste was the same as what dominated the dodgy bottle, so obviously it�s a fault of some description but I have no idea what. Anyway, it was fairly pleasant drinking if not a little on the sweet side. Would have it again but coming in a pint plus sized bottled I�d probably want to share it.

Good to see St Peters� products turning up in bottles. Their stuff seems to be a bit hit and miss but this sweetish stout/porter is more the former than the latter. It took a bit of encouragement to summon a short, reluctant head but it hung around well. The aroma is all soft mocha coffee or perhaps coffee ice cream. Quite a few sugars in there - in fact it summons images of a leaner cousin to Redoak�s Belgian Choc Stout, in smell at least. If I have a criticism, it�s that it�s a bit thin - like it�s going to lack guts. Medium-bodied but with a nice thick finish. Soft chocolate malt flavours, sweet and very gentle. Classic souring finish but with very low bitterness for the style. Milk chocolate with some vanilla essence. Very much at the dessert end of the stout scale. Very easy drinking - if all stouts tasted like this, they might even find a mass market. The kind of stout you could take home to meet your parents. Polite and well rounded. Won�t rub anyone up the wrong way. (640ml bottle from Liquor on Parade, Kingsford. 5% abv)
On tap at The Union. Burnt sugarcane, licorice. Good kick in the first sip, but drifted away from there, with a bit of a dregsy finish.

On tap at the pumphouse brewery. Pours a dark reddish brown with a medium ivory colored head. Has a great roasted chocolate aroma. Flavor is of berries, roasted and chocolate malts and seems to be quite milky. The finish is long with a substantial chocolate residual. Low in hops.

pretty odd stuff. dunno if you'd call it a stout, had no creaminess, no texture to speak of. dark purple with detergent froth. first pint was exciting - plenty of burnt bitterness, roof-of-the-mouth malt, nice and warm. the 2nd and 3rd pints weren't as satisfying, each beer was flatter than the one previous and the flavour less complex - just a hit of burnt stale hops and it was gone. anywaze, interesting and unlike any beer tasted previously

another one of the one-off cask ales at the suit-infested nags. there's no way this qualifies as a stout, but whatever it is (porter? old ale?) it's not that bad anyway. just not a stout. clear darkish red with no head (of course), just a dribble of white foam round the side. flavours are fairly fresh and inyerface, but don't come together very well - heaps of coffeeish chocolate malt, round Goldings dryhopped flavour, and fairly powerful hoppy (as opposed to roasty) bitterness. in fact there's no discernible roastiness at all which is weird for a "stout". oily, vanilla and licorice tinged yeasty finish. not a lot of guts in the malt department either.

column1: Grand Rapids Irish Amber Rye Ale
column5: Had a draft at their brewery. Golden pour. Foamy white. Crazy bitter and almost offensive Leaves a bad aftertaste

column1: Grand Rapids Irish Amber Rye Ale
column5: After sampling a few Grand Rapids Brewing ales during "Irishfest," I forgot the names of the seasonals! I've found the name of this one, so here goes my rate. This ale was amber colored with a thin tan/white head. Flavor was, alas, very thin and weak. Grains were discernible, but the body lacked complexity and character. Not an impressive offering. Now...if I can only find the name of their seasonal stout...

On tap. I got the sampler at this brewery/restaurant while watching a football game there. This APA is not their best brew; they have a very good Red Ale and a Belgian that is quite nice as well. This APA is fairly typical but had just a bit of something odd, paper-like in the finish. Probably worth another try.

(tap) I found Laguna Beach BC, and headed it. I only had time to have one beer and decided for the Pale Ale. The head was... pretty un-beer like, reminded me of pop or macro-brewed beer. It was cloudy, dirty brownish color. So, first impression wasn't all that good. But it was fresh, a typical pale ale flavor. Nice aroma, nice hoppiness. It was really quite enjoyable. Wish i had had time for another.

Sample at the brewpub. Pours a hazy light amber color with a medium thin white head that diminishes steadily. Stringy lacing. Light raspberry and earthy malt in the nose. Light-bodied with notes of tart raspberry, wheat and bland malt flavoring. The finish is short and tart with a light raspberry aftertaste. Forgettable overall.
11/1/07 - Sample at brewpub. Raspberry + American Wheat + ick + skunk + bad after taste = eh. This may have been old. Not a ver good representation by an otherwise good brewery.

Pinky-, honey-gold, light lacy head. Raspberry, light vinegar, malt aroma. Slight sulphury notes there amidst the raspberry. Lightly sweet. Grassy tones near the finish. Medium light body. Quick finish, lightly bittered with berry vapor. Kinda nice, but I think I liked the apricot variant a notch better.

Draft... Hazy orange ale with a small, fizzy, white head. Grainy, fruity aroma with notes of mash, wheat and very subtle raspberry and red apple. The flavor has all the same characteristics as the nose and it leans only a hair on the sweet side of balance. Medium-bodied with lively carbonation. Crisp, dry finish. Refreshing. A pleasant surprise as I�m not really into fruit or wheat beers.

Sample at the brewpub. Pale, hazy salmon color; weak, though fairly fresh fruity aroma with a bit of grassiness. Soft body, nice fruitiness, bit of lime with the red raspberry, just a tiny bit of sourness at the end.
s wit with rasberry flavors. the fruit content of this is ideal giving this a sweet body as well as a pleasant tart fruitiness. one of the better fruit wheats.

Not in their usual line-up but it should be. Raspberry very subtle in the aroma in lieu of wheat. But it is in the flavor where the subtledly yet distinctly soothing combination takes place (with raspberry doing much better now). A hazy, off-pink/peach color. Good stuff! (on tap, Pennsylvania Microbrewers Fest 2003)

Came home after a hard days work, looking forward to a cold beer! I saw this in the supermarket, so I decided to try it. It was ice cold and looked so beautiful in the glass..Hmmm.. looking forward to enjoy this!! It was horrible!!! Taste like shit! So sweet and just very bad. First time in my life I had to pour down a beer in the sink. Thankfully I had another beer in fridge that saved the day. I'm sure this one is made for those who have serious problems with alcohol... cheap cheap cheap.
awesome beer for the expirienced drinker, may as well just buy a lot of it!
I can understand why this beer is so cheap. The overall look is actually okay. As a pilsner it has a light color which i like, however, the taste i awful. Overall i rate this beer a 1/10
Tanie i dobre!! Najta�sze a zarazem najlepsze piwko na Norweskim rynku. Troch� wali chujem ale da si� prze�y�. Polecam.

Blik @ Nes P� Hedmarken. Goedkoop pilsje meer kan ik er niet van maken. Vreselijk kerstboom groen blik met een groot fout bierglas erop. Waarvan de inhoud uit een waterige inhoud met mout bestaat. Dit alles met een gemiddelde bitter. Uiteraard lekker doordrinkbaar als het moet. Vlak 1 dimensionaal en ruikt nauwelijks, slap. Toch valt het nog mee voor een pilsje kan echt erger
330 ml bottle. Golden body with a white head. Aroma is grain with a hint of fruit. Flavor is weak malty with a hint of fruit. Watery body and no aftertaste. Boring.
12.09.2003, 0,33l bottle. Pale golden colour. Body is thin and the beer is a little sour.
A golden lager with a surprisingly lasting and creamy head. Not much of an aroma at all. Watery and thin. A little bitter but nothing extra.
(Bottle + can). Contract brewed for Coop Norge (Norwegian cooperative grocery stores). Standard golden pilsener, nothing offensive, nothing to be happy about.
Canned. Golden colour, near no head. Rather sweet and fruity with hard mouthfeel. Tremendously boring.

Canned(500ml). -this beer is dedicated to all Ferencvaros fans, and for those who don't know Ferencvaros is hungarian sports association (football, handball, waterpolo, etc.) golden coloured, medium white head, lots of bubbles, hoppy notes, just an average lager

On tap at Dark Horse in Marshall, MI. Wonderful ruddy brown, not entirely clear in the glass. Excellent Chocolate and Roasted malt aroma. A tad watery, flavor is quite mild, low on nuttiness, which I like. Hops very subdued.

Geruch fruchtig frisch, leicht alkoholig. Auch geschmacklich kommt das weitgehend durch. Zus�tzlich fallen getreidige und florale Noten auf. Im Mittelteil herb-w�rzig. Hier und im Endteil auch recht bitter. Wunderbar weich. Durchaus brauchbar.
Sampled at the Biergarten. Hazy orange golden. Bready malt, tutti frutti esters and some phenols. Dry, low bitterness.

Sampled after Caesar nearly killed me following him on a bicycle uphill to this place. Great biergarten but after nearly dying from dragging my fat ass up that hill after cycling about 50 km up and down around Bamberg already today, not even the beer could help me anymore. Though that was mainly because the beer wasn't very good. Nonetheless, I'm happy I got there and got to try em. Alive and well. Beer btw is hazy, white head, wheat, banana, yeast. Body is decent, carbonation is quite firm. 6-3-6-2-11.
Vom fass @ brauhaus. R�gi sz�p id�ket id�z� s�rkert nyugd�jasokkal t�mve petyh�dt nyugalommal szurcsolgetve vas�rnapi soradagjukat
From tap at Brauerei Greifenklau. Aroma is lots of banana, bubblegum, bready wheat, some spicy clove. Sweet flavour, medium body. Okay-ish, but a bit too much of a bubblegum aroma.

On tap at Greifenklau, Bamberg, 4.10.17. Orange gold with a quickly-dissolving white head. Dyacetil takes over the nose, some banana beneath. Banana taste, a little sour, some clove and bubblegum, but also some dyacetil. Full body, ripe banana finish with some caramel and some green notes. A little disappointing due to the off-flavor.

Aroma; fruity toffee, banana, plum, caramel, sugar, fruity leaves. Look; off white head on deep golden body, surprisingly clear, somewhat hazy last pour. Taste; plum, juicy caramel, old but fruity banana, coriander note, ginger note, clove note, candy sugar - and average lasting juicy finish. Feel; alright body, soft n fruity. Overall; nice fruity hefe. [50cl.btl xp01.10.17F b@Greifenklau Bamberg summer2017]
500ml on tap at the brewpub. Aroma is light bread, light citrus. Appearance is cloudy yellow with a fine white foam. Taste is light sweet, slightly bitter. Very well balanced. Great Weizen.
Bottle from the pub. Amber orange beer, small head. Aroma is wheat, fruit. Taste is the same. average weizen
Tap at the brewery. Aroma is sweetish wheat, bubble gum, fruity. Taste is the same, not *too* minerally (but still Franconian Weizen-like), a bit sweet bubblegum. Oily mouthfeel. Okay.

Two half-litres at the brewery on 8th Sep 2018. It's clear this year! Lovely bright reddy brown body with a beige head that hung around. Caramel aroma and taste, so fairly sweet, some hop action calms it all down nicely though. Went well with my Currywurst.

On tap at Greifenklau, Bamberg, 4.10.17. As Laurenzi Marzen, 5.2% abv. Hazy amber-red with a white head. A little grainy aroma with some caramel, toasty and some nuts. Grainy and bitter taste. Full body, fizzy, bitter finish but then some candy and graininess.
On tap at the brewery. Hazy brown amber beer with beige head. Light milk chocolate flavour some hop sting on finish some caramel. Extremely drinkable though. Went well with my bratwurst and fries.
Bevuta a Bamberg. Color arancio torbido, ha profumo erbaceo e floreale, sentori di malti tostati e fieno. Molto buona

Tap@Greifenklau Bamberg. Appearance: cloudy deep orange with off-white head. Aroma: flowery hops, malt. Taste: some sweet and medium bitter. Palate: smooth, medium bitter-sweet body, low CO2. Overall: nice

(draught) pours a hazy ruby-amber colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of cherries, bubble gum, light honey and roasted malts, with a hint of ash. flavour is mostly just roasted malts, slightly grainy, with a hint of yeast, tobacco, butter and nettles. medium-bodied with average carbonation.

Draught at Brauereigasthof Greifenklau in Nov., 2011: Yellowish orange. creamy and fluffy white head. Repelling nose of dirty malt and considerable huskiness (popcorn) with a hint of soap.
