Now if they could just bring back the Hammerhead Porter, which hasn�t been on tap for like 9 months and that I somehow missed the whole time...ahh, anyway. Orange color with an off-white head and a little effervescence. Mild and very bready, going well with one of their pizzas. Nice sweet malts that are an interesting and original take on the style. Well done!

Had on tap at the brewpub in Austin. Dark golden to light orange pour with a decent white head. Aroma has some fresh lake water accents with a brief hint of honey. Flavor has some sweet honey notes as well with some underlying cotton candy sweetness. Very smooth and drinkable with a thick creamy mouthfeel. One of the best brewpub lagers that I have come. Not strong in any one category but all around a good drinkable lager.
Nice. Somewhat herbal for a lager and fairly flavorful, as is just about everything brewed by Bitter End. Perhaps my favorite of their brews on tap on this day. Fairly mild.

(Bottle, 0.5 l - BBE 09/2020, from a Waitrose, 20191016) The beer poured copper coloured and clear. Its head was medium sized, white and it lasted long. Aroma had earth, malts and caramel. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were earth, grass, toasted malts, caramel and bitterness. Aftertaste was malty and bitter. A tasty malty brew with toasty notes.

zapach do�� s�odki, s�odowy, lekkie toffi, sporo �wie�ej trawy i ��ki, troch� kwiat�w i kruszonki, orze�wiaj�cy i przyjemny. kolor miedziany, lekko opalizuj�cy, piana bia�a, �rednio obfita i ma�o trwa�a. w smaku raczej wytrawnie, lekki karmel, sporo kurzu, ogonki z jab�ka, piwnica, odrobina tektury, suszone zio�a. raczej pozytywnie ale bez sza�u. goryczka niska do umiarkowanej, piwniczna, zio�owa. w ustach pozostawia lekko zakurzone uczucie. nasycenie umiarkowane.

Clear oramge to amber colour, medium sized dense yellowish off-white head; aroma of toasted rye bread, nutty, floral and some toffee notes; taste of toffee, biscuits, some honeycomb toffee and nutty notes; easily to drinkable
Sweet, malty, slightly floral taste (and aroma). Some hints of fresh lemon hops. The finish is dark, biscuity and malty, with a mildly floral, bitter aftertaste.

A bottle at the Three Lions in Maji Square near Yuan Shan MRT, on Jayne's leaving day. Aroma: fruity. Appearance: opaque dark amber, minimal lacing. Palate: light-bodied and smooth, soft carbonation; predominantly bitter finish. Taste: lightly-bitter, vanilla and cardboard jostle for attention. Nothing special.

500ml can brewed in Dorset at 4.4%. Translucent, sheeny orange-brown. 50/50 head, dissipating fairly quickly. Faint meadowy aroma, bit of grass, bit of zest, further nosing reveals toffee malt. Low carbonation. Does what it says on the tin - malt backbone, vaguely in the lager style but with more breadth and depth (bit of biscuit with the bread), supporting overtures of lemony and floral hops, with shades of bitterness and carefully not-overdone sweetness. A fine thirst-quencher, with more to it than your lager offerings - well designed for just this niche I suspect. Pleasant but unlikely to be anyone's favourite ale after they've had a few different ones; eminently sessionable and seems designed to not overdo it on the flavour - a good or bad point depending on your intended purpose, however here the clue is in the name - this is a swiller, a thirst-quencher, and for one of those it brings good flavour alongside refreshment. For savouring purposes, this won't upset, but will come off a tad bland. Give this to your lager-drinking friends and see what they think!

Light amber colour with a full off-white head that doesn�t linger, faint aroma - musty, biscuity. Likewise the taste - soft biscuits and malt, but undemanding and not complex. The label tells us that �ferret� is Latin for �little thief� and that the beer is named after a ferret that once stole a taste of it. I like to learn something with my beer. Drinkable, the best on the rack at the local co-op.

Bottle from Waitrose, West Byfleet. Weak malts and boiled veg aroma. Chestnut. Thin white head. Sweet-sour berries with more malts into the finish. Light bitter core. Light-medium bodied.Slick if on the thin side. Average-fizzy carbonation. Abrupt finish. Decent enough bitter. Not something I go out of my way for other than that it's a Dorset tick.

500ml bottle. Pours a clear orange-amber with a medium, creamy, long lasting, ecru head that leaves curtains of lace. Sweet aroma of biscuit malt, toffee, mild orange and floral hops. Sweet flavour of biscuit malt, caramel, faint orange peel and floral hops with a dry, mild, bitter grass finish. Light body with a thin, watery texture and soft carbonation. Not bad, just boring. Easy to drink.
Beautiful amber ale. 4.4 vol. REFRESHING. badger make great ales. Really good session beer

Aroma; fruit, sugar, acid. Look; off white head n pale yellow clear body. Taste; sour fruit, sugar. Finish; malted. Feel; normal body. Overall; lemonadeish. [0.33 clear b�gelflasche/ patentkorkflaske/ swingtop-btl@Melfar2018]

330 ml bottle as Catch the Cat - Das energy bier (old rating). Slightly hazy body with a medium sized off-white head. The aroma is weird and difficult to place otherwise than something sweet and artificial, nothing that reminds of beer here. Flavor is just the same, artificial sweet Redbull or Battery some kind of energy drink. No malt, no hops, no hope. No wonder this one disappeared.

(Bottle 33 cl) Comes as "Catch the cat - Das Energy Bier". Yet another of these creative German "Mischgetr�nke" - they really will mix anything for you...This is 80% Hefe and 20% capirinha flavoured pop with added taurine and caffeine. Sort of a chemical lab on bottle... Looks hazy golden with a somewhat indefinable sediment. Weird, fruity sweetness. But did I really get a kick out of this? Cool blue swingtop bottle though. 190103

The aroma is extremely sweet from caipirinha - like a Red Bull. The color is a slightly hazy light yellow and it has a fine lasting head. The flavor is weak at first, then turning caipirinha sweet, just to disappear fast. All in all a thin weizen added too much sweetness. If You want a beer to give You a jolt try Cambridge Brewing Co. Expresso Stout.

This beer has next to no aroma only a slight note of fruit. The color is orange or amber and it is slightly unclear with a small fast disappearing head. The flavor is fruity and it has a good bitterness from a good hop. It is not very sweet - and is rather thin - so I don't think of it as a Scottich Ale.
Cask Stillage at King�s Meadow, Reading 03/05/2003 Dark brown coloured with some wheat flavour. Dry with a full roast finish.
Cask Conditioned, The Hand in Hand, Brighton. Deep black red beer with beige head. Weak in flavour, thin on the palate. Slight chocolate malt and some bitterness, but low grade mild.

How: Cask. Where: Great British Beer Festival (GBBF), 2013. Appearance: Pale yellow colour with a small white head. Aroma: Sweet, citrus, malt. Body: Medium body, low carbonation. Flavour: Bitter hops, malt, citrus. Comment: Almost too bitter, nothing that really balances it.
More murky that hazy, muddy amberish,aroma of caramel and malt, tastes of fruity malt and quite dry, Underwhelming.

Cask at the Hand in Hand, Brighton, on 29th August 2009. Clear gold with thin, smooth white head which laces side of the glass initially. Citric hop aromas and some grassiness before a spicy kick hits the roof of the mouth, this spiciness is not unlike that of Orval. Quite a dry finish on a smooth slightly textured mouthfeel - beer full of condition. Delicious and easy drinking - well-crafted beer.

Cask at the Hand in Hand, Brighton, 16th July 09. Slightly hazy amber. Nose has apples & citrus. Quite mild flavour and a soft palate & finish. Rather too restrained for the average Ratebeerian I fear.

Cask@KemptownBrewpub. Citric and veggies aroma. Hazy, light amber color, off-white head, no lace. Sweet, sourish, light medicinal, hint of caramel, carrots. Average mouthfeel. Couldn�t finish a whole pint of it.

Cask condtioned handpull Hand in Hand, Brighton. Pale copper colour with thin off white head. Very earthy bitter, really very good intense hop on finish. Earthy hop aroma, almost astringent towards the end. Not exactly subtle, but interesting.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Hand In Hand Brighton. Tried over two successive nights and an average score given. The first night this tasted green and slightly off; the second night is tasted fresh and good. I necked the first pint in no time. It�s a mid brown beer with a nicely conditioned bubbly head. The dry hopping doesn�t really come through that well although this is doubtless due to the hops used which would be the English variety. Instead I got some fruity malts and a little bitterness. As mentioned - variable, but it was very good on night 2.Score 2.9 Subsequent rating three years later scored 3.5 and then in 2010, 2.6. Average becomes 3.0

Hand in Hand, Brighton. Very hoppy bitter which almost over-powers the toffee malt. This is the most intense 4% beer I�ve had in a while - could easy go the distance against Fuller�s ESB. Wow! Hoppy! Like chewing hops! Fresh and stunning. Clearly dry hopped.Not really my style of beer, but English-hop hop-heads would drool.
Cask Conditioned at Hand in Hand, Brighton. A refreshing mid brown bitter with a thin white head. Crystal malts predominate early on then plenty of hoppiness with a dry mouthfeel.

Cask condtioned handpull Hand in Hand, Brighton. Hazy reddish brown colour with pinkish head. Very strong hop again, bit too much alpha acid throws it out of balance. Some toasty malt. Some nice cherry fruit in mouth with slight fruit aroma. Malts are decent, not sure of this one. Not horrible, but just slightly odd.
Bottle. Malty, buttery toast nose. Pours pale gold. Flavour is slightly sour but balanced reasonably by more of that sweet malt. Not bad, but unremarkable.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Hand In Hand Brighton. I could pretty much write the same about this beer as Ye Old Trout except it had slightly more body. Again the taste is on the fruity side and tasted a little homebrewish and green. Very disappointing and overpriced as all the Kemptown beers were bearing in mind they�re brewed on site.

[Cask at The Hand in Hand, Brighton] A deep red beer witha small white head. The aroma is light, but malty. While the flavor is sweet malty with notes of roasted malt and strawberries. The only thing bringing this close to dragon blood is the color.
Cask Conditioned at The Hand in Hand, Brighton. Specialy brewed for St. Georges day this is a malty dark beer with plenty of alcohol notes. Some bitterness though not particularly rounded.

I like the initial earthy taste. It�s classic and respectful, like a 1960�s Rolls Royce. But then the more craft-y palate kicks in, and the modern touch is jarring, like blue neon lights installed under said Rolls Royce
Pint poured at T Mobile Park in Seattle. Pours copper with a creamy white head. Smells a little like apples. Tastes a little watery with a slight hop and malt taste. It�s okay
Draft at Owl �n Thistle. Slightly hazy amber. More wheaty character than hoppy. Just okay.
Appearance: hazy amber; no head Taste: similar to anti-hero 6/19/19 - Mod Pizza (Space Needle) ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A Seattle staple. A beer that surprised me how much I enjoyed coming back to drinking it again, after diving deeper on my craft beer journey. Balanced hops and malt, light bitterness, and drinkable year-round.
Van tap in Seattle. Drogig, hoptonen, bitters, kruidig. (9-2016).---------.
From a 12 oz. bottle. Pours a copper with an ecru head. Grasst aroma. Flavor is mild bitter. Ho Hum.

Tap at Takamiya. Nose of light caramel and gentle grassy hops. Copper/amber color. Thin malt, and some fuzzy fruitiness, and perhaps a bit of honey. Thin body. Pleasant, and bit tangy, and unexceptional.
Draft from Nine-O bar in Bellevue. Golden orange, solid head, light lace. Pale malt, herbal hops, and banana. Okay taste. Average mouthfeel. Eh...
Tap at the Seattle airport. Slightly murky orange pour with a white head. Citrus, hint of pine. Not great, but certainly serviceable.

Madrona Red--2003 12 oz. Bottle. 5.50% ABV? (4.25 / 5.0) Amber Ale. Slightly hazy dark amber color. Light lacy head. Earthy floral malty hop front. Crisp dry sweet toasted tasty caramel fruit earthy malty biscuit body. Tart clean balanced dry citrus hop end. Nice Amber / Red. Sampled 11/26/2003.

Bottle pours a red-amber witha modest off wihite head. Nice full malt aroma and some hops that are a bit floral. Nice balance of rich sweet malts and not too bitter hops. Full feel on the palate. Nice.
Ruby red color, sticky head. Nose of fresh herbal hops, sweet & sticky with tons of hops. Tastes of sweet caramel & toffee. Finishes very nice. Damn nice beer.

Red. Who�d thought? Creamy head left quickly turning into a spotty head an lacing. Caramel with a touch of roast and bitter hops with some citrus. The roast comes through more and the bitterness is stronger. Some caramel and bitter orange as well. Musky malt finish with touches of bitterness. Average.

The Bear Creek Red is unusual in the sense that it is more of a malt heavy Red - especially considering the Reds typical of the Northwest area. A good layer of caramel is lying under everything, with little wisps of hops now and then. Very palatable, but not the most flavorful beer in the world.
(draft) Clear amber body with beige head. Aroma is medium sweet, floral, orange, light spice. Taste is sweet, floral, orange. Medium body.

Amber with a slight cloud to it. Super caramelly aroma, (butterscotch cookies) with hints of apple and "flowers". Toasted malt on the begining of hte taste lightening up to the moderate bitter finish. A good brew for you Fat Tire drinking friends and you.
Washington Brewfest /03 Sparkling reddish amber, beige head. Malt nose.Full bodied malt flavor akin to a light scotch.I like this one

Draught at Wig Wam last night so they must be brewing it again. A very pleasant orange with a white head. Fresh, juicy citrus notes throughout. A mild toasted malt backbone carries it just enough but the player on the scene is the citrus. Finish is full of that juicy citrus and get a tad sweet. Very enjoyable DIPA.

Apparently available again. On tap, pours a clear honey color with a one finger eggshell head and good lacing. Aroma is light sweet hoppy citrus fruit. Flavor is similar, mild bitterness. A very well done brew.

modest 2 finger head that dies back leaving spotty sticky lacing.. Brew is hazy orange copper. Aroma is pithy citrus hops.. smells juicy... not much malt to speak of... some sweetness for sure but is blown out of the water by the hops. Not as bitter as some more well known ideas... but Holy Hoppy from early to late palate.. there is plenty of sweetness... but again.. it is all the hops from front to back. Body is on the thicker side for the style... oily and viscous... somehow it remains balanced for a PNW DIPA.
22oz bottle 8/8/15 (Pear Delicatessen)-Pours an orangish amber with a decent head. Aroma of hops and malt. Taste of the same. This medium bodied brew wasn�t good but wasn�t bad.
Bomber. Pours a golden orange with an off white head and aroma of hops and citrus. Taste is bitter, with hops, citrus, grapefruit, and pine notes into the dry, bitter finish.

With Z , pours a semi clear light rusted orange Amber color with a beige head. Nose is sweet citrus with some trailing bitterness. Taste is pleasant sweet citrus with softer pine and resin. Finishes on the sweet citrus notes with a hoppy dry finish . Ok ! Quaff Score 6 / 10

Bottle from Happy�s Market, Ellensburg, WA; no ABV on bottle Hazy amber color, medium sized head. A good American Barley Wine, as it�s well malty, noticeable from the moment you pour; sweet, rich, with nice hopping, lowering bitterness, but still good fruits and hop resins. Very good, but probably not fresh.
Bottle - Sweet earthy hops and caramel. Dirty gold with a decent off white head. Sweet caramel and bitter hops with a long sweet bitter finish. Not bad.

22 oz bottle @ Hale�s. Pours cloudy dark orange with thin white head. Aroma is thin sugary sweet malt and muted citrus hops. Taste is similar: thin malt is quickly overwhelmed by heavy sugary sweetness which pushes through the hops on the finish. Some nice big flavors in the hops - pine, orange, and grass - but again they�re really obscured by the lingering sweetness of the malt. Not that bad, really, but... odd beer.

Serving: from tap at Smarty Pants. Aroma: moderate, piney hoppy aroma. Appearance: small, creamy, off-white, initial head with fair lacing and fully diminishing longevity. Cloudy, medium-amber body. Taste: heavily bitter initial flavor, and heavily sour grapefruit-like finish with long duration. Palate: medium-to-heavy bodied with dry texture and soft carbonation. Overall: huge taste but too heavy-handed for me.

(Draft: Celtic Bayou in Redmond, WA) More hoppy than the blonde ale, but the sweet, grainy flavor shows just as much presence, and this pilsner isn�t nearly as clean as I was expecting. Sweet and grainy aroma lacks the hop character of a good pilsner. The body is light-to-medium, but a bit heavier than most pilsners. Clear, golden color, with a whitish head that settles to a broken layer, but leaves a fairly large swatch of lace on the glass. Serviceable for a blonde ale, but not a good example of the pilsner style.

This was a really weak attempt at a pilsner. Way over hopped with some citrusy/floral hops, nothing subtle about, just in your face hops and bitterness. To bold of a beer that really missed the idea of the great delicateness of the pilsner style.
Golden blond with a nice layer of smooth cream. Crisp, clean, hop ping in the nose with some German hop flavor--of which I am not an aficianado. An easy drinking summer brew that failed to win me.
Cloudy gold(chill haze?) Crisp hop nose. Good crisp hop profile with a decent finish

Caramelly medium brown colour. Woody, leafy, chocolatey notes in the slightly toffeeish aroma. Slightly toffeeish flavour with a little hint of nuttiness and a respectable amount of chewy, earthy malt. Some dark fruits in the finish.
Dark brown colour with tan head. Strong malt nose with alcohol undertones. Mild malt taste with alcohol finish.

Bottle pours dark copper, hues of plum, medium foamy sandy colored head, spotty lacing, with very light carbonation. � Malty nose, sweet, with a very soft biscuit and alcohol note. � Peaty, hints of licorice, and light dark pitted fruit on the tongue. � Medium to full bodied, with a fairly thick and somewhat viscous mouthfeel. Sweet malty finish, lingering spices. � Slightly medicinal as well but its very subtle. � Otherwise this was a fairly decent offering. � I�d probably have it again.
Perfect scotch appearance, but with a head. Easy malt aroma, with a fair malt flavor. A dank, musky maltness detracts overall from the experience.
Light brown, tan head.Antiseptic nose.Light malt flavor with mild alcohol heat. Not much here
Relatively bland as are most Mexican lagers, but this had considerably more body.

Serving: from tap at Snipes Mountain Microbrewery and Restaurant Aroma: none detected. Appearance: average-sized, creamy, off-white, initial head with good lacing and mostly diminishing longevity. Clear, dark-amber body. Taste: moderate caramel malt, lightly sweet initial flavor and finish with average duration. Palate: medium body with oily texture and soft carbonation. Overall: very good. Unique taste.

Not sure if this is the right beer. On tap as a special bitter at the brewpub. Pours a nice hazy dark gold color with a thin white head. Aroma is a little malt but has a nice citrus hop kick. Flavor is pleasantly bitter with a nice malt balance. Good beer.
Bronze color with decent head. Don�t detect the subtle flavors advertised for the beer in the brewery. A mid-range, but unspectacular IPA/APA straddler that they cal an ESB.

From a bomber. Pours a cloudy orange-brown with a big robust head. The very nice aroma is dominated by soft fruit (pear and mild grapefruit) and brown sugar malts. The flavor The flavor is rich and malty, but not overly so, and the fruity hops (hinting at times at an almost barleywine complexity) come in to balance the whole thing out in a very nice way. The beer is not too sweet, not to bitter, with a gentle chalky aftertaste that I find quite pleasant. The mouthfeel seems spot-on for the style. I like this beer, and it could easily become a session regular for me, especially if available in 12oz form. I can understand why this one is getting more low threes than high threes, but it�s hard for me to understand the really low ratings that it is receiving. Perhaps the quality has improved this year? I don�t know.
Mahogany with an off-white head. No lacing. Bitter and roasty aromas with hints of caramel. Toasted malt flavors with bitter hops. Slightly fruity. Standard ESB.
Hazy reddish orange. Medium head. Light sweet aroma. Very solid beer....Very balanced with good presence by both hops and malt. Bitter to begin, but mellows quickly. Very nice drinking beer.

This is just a really basic esb, it is quite easy to drink and is not overly tasty as it is not really bad either. Somewhere inbetween, with some caramel maltiness, earthy bitter hops, creamy on the palate, with a harsh dry finish.

28-Dec-05 (22 oz bottle: Obtained in trade with Larry Pitonka, thanks Andr�!) I�m very happy to have a fresh bottle because boy, that first bottle was a total disaster. Popping the cap, there was no "Michael Bay" explosion, and it didn�t foam up when pouring the beer. And no soapiness or overripe apples in the flavor. No, instead, this is a healthy beer, and very tasty indeed. Up front, there�s lots of toast, mildly roasty and lightly sweet maltiness and a touch of caramel, with a moderately bitter and slightly citrusy hoppiness kicking in the midpoint that easily balances the ample malt and finishes with dominance. The beer is good out of the fridge, but is still very flavorful and enjoyable at room temperature as well. There is also a slight chalkiness to the flavor and mouthfeel. Body is medium, but shows no signs of thinning in the finish. Carbonation is solid but gentle on the palate. The nose is lightly malty, hoppy and somewhat dusty, but doesn�t impress as much as the flavor. Fairly hazy amber body is crowned by an inch of very bubbly, off-white head. Overall, with the assertive malt character and snappy hop bite, it�s a west coast ESB through and through. Definitely worth of the effort to get a second bottle.18-Oct-05 (22 oz bottle: $3.29 at John�s Marketplace in Portland, OR) We have two problems with this bottle of beer. First is the insane amount of carbonation. This beer is so overcarbonated, I scoop all the light-tan head out of my pint glass, and the head builds right back up again. It�s like the magician pulling the handkerchief out of his pocket. And then my taking a small sip of the beer results in an explosion inside my mouth. The second problem is the intense soapiness of the aroma. This is about as strong a soapiness as I can remember in any beer, and it�s almost unbearable. Fortunately, the flavor isn�t as bad, perhaps because the malt flavor of this beer is strong enough to overcome the soapiness to some degree. Nevertheless, this really isn�t drinkable, and I�ll have to obtain a new bottle if at all possible. (2, 2, 4, 2, 7 = 1.7)

Bottle: Copper amber, moderate to large off-white head, foamy, fairly nice lacing, a few strong streams of carbonation. � Slight grainy aroma, a bit sweet perhaps, with a touch of diaceytl. � Malty start, earthy, somewhat grainy, but fortunately not as buttery as the nose hinted. � This one is fairly robust for an ESB. � Minor apple skin and hop bitterness at the finish. � Body is quite full, mouthfeel is moderate tho. � Lingering metallics and/or strong earthy notes after the finish. � Could stand to have a cleaner finish. � Overall, not too shabby.
Dirty copper color, white head. Touches of caramel and malt. Pretty straight foward midle ofthe road ESB.

A true rare find in the states. Bronze with and interesting, hard to place aroma. Banana esters becoming undeniably relevant in aroma and to a lesser extent--in flavor. Barrel malt taste with a rather sour finish. A decent try.
On tap at The Flying Pig, Everett WA. Pale yellow and thin. Lemony with no other outstanding flavour.
Golden colour. Aroma is lightly bready, lightly cidery. Slightly buttery character, with hints of white bread. A shade light for its own good.
Medium gold colour with a nice white head. Aroma is light hops with some maltiness. Slightly sweet taste with some hops for a delicate balance.

2004 draught @ Redbones. Light tangerine juice-like appearance, yellowish and lightly hazed with a small white head, though a bit too pale for the style. Aroma of saaz hops, not overly so, with some pils malt dryness and a bit of graininess. Begins with a crisp and interesting bite to it, with notes of yeast, almonds and honey, but the body dies off immediately afterwards. Wateriness to the extreme, low flavor through the middle and only a short, grain and alcohol sort of finish. The sour/sweet skunkiness is present, a strange stale/sharp alcohol tone, and though it begins to-style, it quickly becomes rather nostalgic of a crappy adjunt lager, as Bill says. Medium-light body.
Hazy banana liquer look. A fairly standard helles, albeit fresher. It still has a rather dank, lightly annoying, offkey corn syrupy sweetness quality--though subdued. Not a favorite style of mine.
Wow, how could I find such a well brewed dunkelweizen in the south west? The characterizing banana flavors are there carried up by a strong body and crispy hoppy flavors. Cheers!
From the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 13/10/2007 Hop and spice aromas. Bronze mid brown coloured and slightly hazy in appearance with a fruity banana flavoured finish.

On tap at the brewery. Very hazy hazelnut brown color with lots of caramel and malt aroma. Small amounts of banana/clove. Very smooth and easy to drink. Complemented very nicely with the wheat. Easy drinking, perhaps my favorite at this brewery.
On tap at the brewery. Dark red- brown pour with minimal foamy tan head. A bit of roasty malt and caramel in the aroma and flavor. Watery, thin palate. Some light hops on the finish. Good.
Arizona strong Beer Fest Brown with small head. Aroma and flavor are sweet fruits, caramel and light roast with a bit of a watery body. Lightly bitter coffee finish. Not bad.

Sampler, Aroma was of roasted malts and toffee. Dark body to the beer. Roasted coffee flavor with some hop bite that made this one somwhat uninique I thought. Will have to go back and get a full glass
Medium brown hue with a strong alcohol-mediciney aroma. Super sugary, but thin. This is more like a bad stab at a Belgian dubbel than a dunkles.

The almost perfect dark beer. Very nutty taste, smooth finish, not very bitter. Strong aroma, but not offensive. You can definately taste the hops and the yeast. The extra roast just adds to the flavor, making this one of the best beers I've had in a long time! If you ever come to prescott, Arizona, you gotta try this beer!

On tap at Rockfish Grill and Anacortes Brewery. Copper color, almost no head, aroma of light sweet malt; doesn�t really invite me much. Flavor is moderately sweet, with ripe fruit notes, and a slight medicinal quality. Seems rough around the edges, and this is the second lager I�ve had from the brewer that seems not quite finished. Finishes sweet and a little medicinal.

Whooahh...way too much caramel in the malt, it just brings the rest of the beer out of focus. Just too unbalanced, I think I taste a touch of espresso in the backlground (?) which is strange, but then again I feel like I've been drinking straight malt extract, so my taste buds may be a bit confused.

Lovely maroon amber color with a nice head. Decent malt aroma, however; like the other WA doppelbocks experienced to this point, it was dissapointing for the style. No distinguishing features--the malt is detectable, but not delicious and at some points, rather bland. Ok.

Canned, 355ml from Honest Brew of Crystal Palace, London. Clouded gold with short white head. There was a mixed start to this, boiled cabbage was the first impression but this was followed with a sweetish, if slightly tinny, maltiness. There was a hint of mustiness from an aggressive carbonation. Possibly the saver for me was the Saaz hop hit, lime and lemon notes. Just okay really.
Can, Brewklopedia, Leicester. Hazy yellow gold with a white head. Toasted grain with corn. Hints of lemon with funky mushroom. Traces of tinned pineapple syrup. Some cabbage. Herbal.
Hazy yellow lots of cream. Aroma strong straw grain. Tastes spelt, lemon, wheat. Buttery dry crisp.
Can. Light straw color. Thin white head. Taste is light bitter, light sweet. Medium body. Aroma and flavour is malt, spices, banana, fruit, honey.

12 oz can, gifted by lutton, and paired with football. Definitely an 11 am, a lot of football games to watch kind of beer. A light golden pour with tons of carb, rocky head. A clean, slightly floral, inviting grain aroma. Flavor is crisp, cool, simple to drink. Some fruitiness hiding in there. Refreshing. A nicely put together kolsch, with lots of right going for it. UPDATE: Draft pint at Toronado for Pint Night. Kegged today. Awesome! This beer deserves more credit. Delicious, and exceptional for the style. Drink fresh.

Can bonused to me by luttonm - thanks! Keeping me company tonight while I grade (ugh). Clear gold pour. Aroma is combo of honey, biscuit, corn, and a hint of apple. Moderately sweet, minimal bitterness. Goes down easy, light body. Carbonation is a tad on the soft side. Overall: I know it�s getting on to fall, but this�d do just fine on those last few days that are still clinging to summer.
Can from Beers of Europe. Pours clear golden orange with a short-lived thin white head. Aromas of tinned green beans, light sugar. Taste is cereal grains, faint grassy astringency. Thin finish.
Can from Cotteridge Wines; clear yellow pour with a bubbly off white head, aroma has citrus and some grain, taste has grainy malts, vegetable stock and some lemon, hint of peach, not a good combo.

Rating #1994 2015.09.27 #CraftTakesSeattle Day 4, Beer 96 � Draught at taproom/brewpub. Pale straw coloured pour, bubbly white head, no lacing. Aroma is clean, lots of grassy, earthy notes. Medium carbonation, light body - nice clean mouthfeel - nothing astringent - and a vaguely present earthy bitterness that rounds this out well.
Can in Seattle. Thin foam, pale clear yellow. Eggy, sweet aroma, lots of tea-like malts. Pale, chunky malts, not crisp at all. Warm, creamy body. Not great.

Schwarzbier Lager--2004 12 oz. Bottle. 5.75% ABV. 25 IBU�s? (3.25 / 5.0) Black Lager. Mild lace head. Light sediment. Hazy ugly brown red color. Fruity ester mild hop front. Sweet fruity mild toasted toffee caramel Porter Ale ester body. Tart citrus mild hop end. Disappointing. Poor Labeling. Sampled 3/6/2005.

(12 oz bottle: Bottleworks in Seattle, WA) This is a pretty old bottle I presume, and the beer has almost assuredly taken on characteristics that weren�t there originally, most notably, the fairly potent sourness. But I have to say, the sourness is actually quite nice. Rather than tasting like a schwarzbier, this is starting to remind me of some of the Flemish sour brown ales I�ve had in the past. Flavors include: tangy and acidic sourness, tart cherry, somewhat dark malt base with a hint of sweetness, and some wood and earth from the aging. The nose is sour, somewhat cherry-like, and slightly earthy. Medium bodied, nicely carbonated, and the sourness is very refreshing on the palate. The color is a medium-dark ruddy brown, but most certainly not black or even close. Half an inch of light tan head gradually settles to a wide ring. Though probably not intended, the onset of the sourness in this beer has been an interesting and thoroughly enjoyable development.

Bottle: Great aromas of pitted fruit like prunes and raisins which deceive your taste buds as they are blown away by the ultra tangy, sour hops. This is reminiscent of Worcestershire sauce (credit to Indiana_Red�s wife Melissa for this original identification). The color is dark brown, uhh, I mean schwarz and is accompanied by a frothy, light brown head. The carbonation levels are high which make the tang even more apparent. Good one, grows on you after you get used to the hops. Thanks Indiana_Red for sharing.
Clean black colour. Thin rocky head that fades quickly. Mild malt nose. Flat malty taste that lingers.

Hazy brick. Lacing, soapy bubbled foam with scattered islands of cream. Clean, but slightly metallic aroma with a slippery fruitiness and airy roast twinge. Earthy malt, sulfur accents with phenols and cocoa hints. Fairly loose carbonation but solid bodied. Acidity greets the palate, swirled with an unwavering mixture of phenols and roast astringency. Rich chocolate frosting, earthy roast, and squeaky clean lagery notes lurk beneath. Slightly gritty with cane sugar hints, but continually clean with husky malt layers that impart more fluffy girth to the body. Finishes clean with a dry, spicy bite of chalky malts and earthy hops. With the exception of the phenols and sourness, this is very well structured, highly drinkable, hoppy example of the style. Most likely an outdated bottle, but there�s no date stamp to be found.

Bottle Pours a very dark brown with a huge fluffy pale tan head that slowly receded. Very nice lacing. Aromas are a yummy carmel, dark malt and sweet brown sugar. Flavors are a sour woody carmel taste. Also of rasons and other dark pittededs. That sour taste puts me off a bit but it�s not bad. Feel is thick and smooth with a soft carbonation.

GABF 2004: RIch dark copper brown with a thin off-white head. Smooth, subtle dark malty aroma. Dry roasty malty body has a touch of caramel sweetness and lager yeast. Very smooth and balanced, this would make a good session beer. A nice rendition of the style.
Black, black, black! This beer tastes very "black." Extremely bitter but not really hop bitter, just bitter. A little like 1554. Good example of the style.
Nice and smooth, malty mouthfeel. Sweet, subtle dark malts. Needs to be a little more smokey in my opinion. Still a good beer of course!

Bottle pours dark ruby, almost black, with garnet highlights, medium frothy tannish colored head, sticky lacing, with soft carbonation. � Dark semi-sweet chocolate, burnt malts, and slight butter on the nose. � Forwardly malty, heavily roasted, with the aformentioned butter notes. � Great body with an exceptional creamy mouthfeel. � Finishes slightly buttery sweet, rich, creamy, with heavily roasted malts. � Not a session beer IMHO, a bit too sweet, but tasty nonetheless.

column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: From 2010 file notes. 6 pack from Valley Wine Company in Davis, CA. Orangey wheat beer. Not to my taste.

column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: Bert Grant�s Mandarin Hefeweizen--2003 12 oz. Bottle. 4.20% ABV. 20 IBU�s. (3.0 / 5.0) Mild lace head. Creamy clouded lemon orange color. Mandarin orange scented mild hop wheat spice front. Thin mild wheat body dominated by mellow smooth orange flavor. Mild citrus hop wheat end. Sampled 9/21/2003.

column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: One of my favorite summertime beers of all time. Orange tint and mandarin orange flavor. I was sad to see this one go. 4.8 Rated 7/4/04

column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: Had this beer on 8/11/2004. Aroma is not that impressive, with only a faint citrus scent. Color is a hazy bright gold with very good carbonation and a thin little head. Taste is light and clean. Starting with a light body it goes down with a fizzy feel. Finish comes in with a very light malt flavor backed by a faint citrus taste and ends with a little bitter bite. Overall it�s just not a Hefey. It is a refreshing summer brew but it lacks flavor, there is almost no mandarin and none of that rich sweet, yeasty flavor in a good Hefey.

column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: 12 oz. bottle via trade with IrishBoy - Pours a hazy golden color with a 3/4 finger thick white head. Very light spotty lacing. Aroma is light wheat malt and citrus. Flavor is lightly sweetened malt with a tad bit of orange. Light body. A decent beer. Thanks Richard.

column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: Date: 01/01/2004 Mode: Bottle Source: Beverage Resort hazy dark yellow, whispy fine white head, light sweet orange aroma, light malt flavor with lots of orange sweetness like an oranqe soda, touch of bitterness in the finish -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 06/01/2005 orange dries out after a while loosing some of the sweetness but keeping the orange flavor, an improvment, but still weird Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: it was�nt a bad beer. description says it all. orangey and not overbearing. sweetish i used to get it cheap from the defunct shop rite in leonia nj. they had some great micro brews. the beer had moderate carbonation and really was not too wheaty in consistancy.

column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: I wish I knew where I could buy around town. I havn�t been able to find it anywhere.

column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: Bottle from Country Club Liquors; Nose of wheat and oranges; yellow-orange with a small yellowish head; flavor of whaet and light oranges, but no sweetness. Might have been really flavorful if it wasn�t an old bottle I found in the back of my beerstores fridge. Night light fuit taste even if some of the esters have disappeared.

column4: Yakima Brewing And Malting Co./Bert Grant's Real Ales
column5: Gold bodied with a short-lived head. The aroma is sweet Mandarin oranges and garden flowers. The oranges become almost syrupy sweet in the flavor, although the wheat finally shows up in the background.

Tap. Pours clear black, small creamy beige head, dissipates slowly, good lacing. Aroma is pretty much straight roasty with a side of ashtray. Flavor is light sweet, light bitter, roasty, coffee grounds. Medium body, soft mouthfeel. Pleasant.
Draft at GABF. Pours dark brown with off white head. Nose and taste of toasted chocolate. Not much else. Dry finish. Lighter medium.

Looks nice, black w/beige head. Nice lacing. Smells a touch of roast and chocolate. Tate, licorice right up front. Then beer runs very thin, almost watery and ends with a big ash flavor. Not my favorite. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On nitro at the brewery. Large roasted malt notes throughout. Dark black stable tan head. Caramel and a slight sour note. Nice little beer.

On tap at Hopper�s pouring up deep dark mahogany with lasting tight tan head. The aroma offers up spicy anise and black licorice slowly giving way to some dark roasted maltiness. The taste is largely dark roasted malts moving into brief moments of sweet fruity esters and then thin layers of spicy black strap molasses and dark roasted coffee.
Draft at brewpub. Pours black. Not much on the nose. A bit of licorice on the tongue. Thin mouthfeel. A bit meh!

on tap at Hoppers..appeared a dark bottle brown with creamy thick tan head. nose is nice a roasty. tastes sweet, roasty, choco, and light coffee coming through at the end. good beer, and you can grab a growler to go.

on tap 7/23/10. porter colored mahogany brown with a tan nitro head which lasts the duration. pleasant aroma of dry roast, smoke, dust, black raisins and a nutty/chocolatey/coffee thing. the flavor is the same with a bittered finish and lingering rubbery aftertaste. watery nitro body and dead mouth feel. i�m sure this would be greatly improved with good �ol co2... 6/3/6/2/12/2.9
On tap at Hoppers Appearance: Black with a nice off-white nitro head and good lacing Aroma: Roasted malts and coffee Taste: Silky mouthfeel. Roasted malts, chocolate and coffee A nice stout.

On tap @ Hoppers. Pours a clear dark brown color with a creamy tan head that lasts and leaves drippy lacing. Aroma and flavor are a bit too light for the style, but include dark roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and light nutty hops. Almost creamy on the palate, but just a bit too thin to pull it off. Nothing bad or off in the brew, just not quite enough of what is there.

column1: Tenaya Creek Hauling Oats Oatmeal Stout
column5: Pours black in color with off-white head. Malty sweet aroma. Notes: on tap at the taproom

column1: Tenaya Creek Hauling Oats Oatmeal Stout
column5: Pint at Giordano's Pizza, on the strip. Pours black, with a small, bubbly, grey head. The aroma is mild coffee, walnuts, brown sugar, earth, and pine sawdust. Sweet and malty, with a strange, acrid, bitter finish. Light to medium body, with a watery, malty mouthfeel. This is an easy and tasty beer, but the aftertaste is kinda off.

column1: Tenaya Creek Hauling Oats Oatmeal Stout
column5: From a can. Pours dark cola brown with a creamy beige head. Tastes like ashy wood, burnt toast, and dark chocolate malt. Light body and medium carbonation. Smells like ashy wood, burnt toast, dark chocolate malt, and a hint of dried fruits.

column1: Tenaya Creek Hauling Oats Oatmeal Stout
column5: Can. Pours deep, dark brown. Aroma and flavor are rich chocolate, toasted and caramel malts, some roast, and some dark fruit; somewhat thin and ashy. Medium body

column1: Tenaya Creek Hauling Oats Oatmeal Stout
column5: Can at home. Pours black with a medium, creamy and bubbly beige head, long retention with light lacing. Moderate roast and chocolate malt, lightly bitter with prunes, dates, oats, light earthy and woody hops and bitterness with a sweet finish. Full body and medium carbonation.

column1: Tenaya Creek Hauling Oats Oatmeal Stout
column5: Can. Pours a dark brown color with a thick tan head. Aroma is mild, sweet cocoa and roasted malts. Sweet and roasty taste. Mild cocoa and roast with a little sweetness.

column1: Tenaya Creek Hauling Oats Oatmeal Stout
column5: 650 ml bottle. Pours black with moderate tan head of big bubbles. Aromas of nutty chocolate, ashtray, and roasted malts. Flavors of dark chocolate powser, dry roasted malts, and acidic black coffee

column1: Tenaya Creek Hauling Oats Oatmeal Stout
column5: From a bottle. Medium bodied with a thin head, dark chocolate bitterness with no acrid flavours, good stuff.

column1: Tenaya Creek Hauling Oats Oatmeal Stout
column5: Shared 22 oz. bottle. Dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of dark malts and chocolate. Taste is dark malts, chocolate, roasty. Some burnt elements. Overly acidic. Okay.

column1: Tenaya Creek Hauling Oats Oatmeal Stout
column5: Great name for an oatmeal stout. Taster at the source. Pours nearly black with s persistent beige head. Aroma is dark chocolate, overextracted coffee roast. Flavor is dark chocolate, mild overextracted coffee roast. A bit thin for the style.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Nutty, bread crust, a little roasted malt, with some caramel sweetness. Mild bitterness.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On tap at Desert Edge Appearance: Dark brown with a big beige head and good lacing Aroma: Toasted malts and nutty Taste: Toasted malts, nutty and coffee Easy drinking. At first sip I thought it was similar it tastes like a dark iced tea, nice.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On draft at the pub. This is a great brown ale. Very drinkable. Nice roast, chocolate, hint of coffee, fruity, and malty. Really nice beer.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On draft at Trolley Square brewery - Pours a fairly clear chestnut brown color with smallish light tan head. Aroma is slightly roasty, with notes of dark chocolate, toasted hazelnut, vanilla bean, and oak. Really a nice aroma. Flavor is malty, with a touch of roastyness, wet oak. Finish is just on the sweet side of balanced. This is a fairly nice beer overall. Not amazing, but a flavorful session ale that I could easily have a few pints of and not tire. Possibly the best Desert Edge brew I�ve had.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On a pull tap in the brewery in SLC. Listed as Cask Nut Brown, they said there was no added carbonation, and that is was casked. A really nice rasberry aroma, the body was ultra-thin, but the head was great. The taste was kinda a let down, smooth, nutty and some hops, fruit. Overall, better than expected.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: NABA Brew Fest 03: Very subtle with a light malt body with an underbalanced absence of hops. There was a very poor palate, mouth feel to this one, makes me want to drink something else.
Draft at Taphouse. Pale, clear golden, cap if creamy white head. Aroma is sweet and grainy. Taste brings more if the grains, clean, not vegetal at all. Pure lager without any down side.

From Dec 2006 Poured from 12oz bottle a clear yellow gold with a small head of foam that quickly dissipated. Some lacing on the side of the glass is noted. The smell is grainy with some sweet malt mixed in there. The taste has a good balance between the sweet malt and bitterness from the hops.The finish is crisp and clean. Quite quaffable. Everything is done on the light side with this lager but it *is* only 4%abv so the taste for what it is is quite pleasing. I'd drink this again, no problem. Bottom line: A nice light, refreshing American Lager that makes for a uncomplicated seesion beer.
There�s too little of everything in this beer: hops, malts, particularly taste. Still, it quenches the thirst and has a nice label.
"super light pour, almost like a wit. pretty weak all around. a hint of grassy hops but moreso, this is just a non-offensive macro in a micro bottle. "
Gift from St Regis in Deer Valley. Pours a clear straw color with white head. Nose of grass and malt. Taste of bready malt, touch of lemon. Average lager. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a medium amber color. Aromas of caramel malt, hops, and a touch of citrus. Caramel sweetness in the taste with a good bitterness of hops.

On tap at the Sockeye brewpub pouring copper with off white head and some sheet lacing. The aroma is sweetness and citrus then moving into some nuttiness. Interesting aromatic combination. Enjoyable flavor with the same sweetness running into orange zest like citrus as noted in the nose. The citrus bitterness grows and seems to pick up some resiny pine by midway. Mild roasted malt join the hop resin to create a modestly dry finish.

On tap at Sockeye Boise. pours out a clear crisp amberish gold topped with a small off white cream head. Aroma was of a nice hop combo, floral, pine, and some citrus. Taste was plenty of grapefruit peel bitter hops along with a malt to help round it out.
on tap-pours a light tan head that laces and amber color. Aroma is pine, some light/medium malt. Taste is sweet light/medium malt, pine/herbal hops bite through drying finish.

On Tap: the brewer called this an english pale ale, I would tend to agree. Pours a nice golden color with a small head, aroma is sweet and bitter. Taste is sweet from malt, some bitterness, light citrus tones, and a bit of fruitiness. Not as intense as a esb. Very pleasant.

On Tap at the bew pub Light golden amber with small white head and traces of thin lacing. Mild sweet malts and faint citrusy hops in the aroma. Flavor was easyon the hops and mild fairly sweet malt profile. Strange feel, dry and a bit bitter.

Somewhat aromatic with flowers, citrus, and earthy hops, hints of toast and malt; well balanced and tasty bitter that has a long finish, pleasant medicianl hints, and a musty dryness over a decent malt base; good

Pours orange-gold with a creamy head and sheets of lacing. Aromas of lemon and grapefruit with floral hops, candy and sweet malts. Again sweet malts visit us along with caramel, floral, citrus and bitter hops that blend very well. Nicy hoppy palate and a dry, bitter finish. Well made bitter.

ReRate on-tap at Sockeye: Hazy bronze color with a nice thick white head. The aroma is spicy with herbal hops and a sweet malt body. The flavor is also moderately hoppy with a good blend of hops similar to their IPA but a little less balanced and a little more toned down. Finishes slightly astringent, not too bad.

NABA Beer Fest 03: Poured yellow and clear with little head, aroma is artificial fruit, slight malt. A good semisweet flavor with decent amounts of hops to counter balance. Drinks smooth and overall very good for a fruit beer, these are usual too sweet or unbalanced for me.

column1: Merchant Ale House Strawberry Blonde Ale
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: strawberry infusion in a not so well made base lager. on tap at the source. beats dirty water.light pink.

column1: Merchant Ale House Strawberry Blonde Ale
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: looks a solid golden in color, has a clear strawberry aroma, tastes strongly of strawberry as well, has a creamy feel to it which complements the strawberry very well, very delicious and refreshing

column1: Merchant Ale House Strawberry Blonde Ale
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Pours gold with little head. Smells and tastes of sherbet, add to the taste a strawberry sourness. A bit of carbonation on the tongue.

column1: Merchant Ale House Strawberry Blonde Ale
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: This beer smelt great, it had an amazingly good smell of strawberrys and the beer tasted strong of strawberrys, one of the best fruit beers I have tasted.

column1: Merchant Ale House Strawberry Blonde Ale
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: [1538-20080719] Tap. Aroma is a dead ringer for Strawberry Shortcake, the toy not the food. Clear, light yellow brown body with a small long-lasting creamy white head. Flavour is watered-down strawberry cream. Light body. Really odd but light and refreshing. (@ Merchant Ale House; St. Catherines, ON)

column1: Merchant Ale House Strawberry Blonde Ale
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: 2008-07-19. Yellow body with a small white head. Big strawberry aroma up front is awesome but takes a turn for the artificial and candylike upon further inspection. Flavour is similar and it reminds me a specific strawberries and cream hard candy. Underlying beer is light, with just a touch of bitterness. Average palate is fairly effervescent, smooth. Actually hit the spot after a day of wine sampling, but I personally can�t imagine having more than one. I am probably over rating it, but so be it. Worth trying though if you are into fruit flavoured wheat beers. Draft at the brewpub

column1: Merchant Ale House Strawberry Blonde Ale
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Tapped an off yellow with a foamy white cap. Nose of strawberry and malts with hay and paper. Tastes pretty sweet, of fake strawberry and sugary malts with marsh mellow. Very sweet and spritzy finish. This reminds me of the malt based coolers available at the beer store. Tough to choke down half a glass of this. Ohh my.

column1: Merchant Ale House Strawberry Blonde Ale
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: A hazy blonde with a thin cremay white head. Aroma of artificial strawberries and diacetyl, In mouth, waaca!!!!! A rather chemical fruit spritzer with light strawberries. Awful. On tap at brewery, July 28 2007.

column1: Merchant Ale House Strawberry Blonde Ale
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Same as the blonde, medium yellow, decent sized white head. Mild artificial strawberry aroma. Taste is just plain awful - the artificial fruit is disgusting and it does not mix with the otherwise decent blonde ale. Horrible, the worst beer I have ever had from these guys (and I like their stuff).

column1: Merchant Ale House Strawberry Blonde Ale
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: (Draught) Golden body with a quick dissipating, white head. Fake strawberry aroma with slight citrus. Tart with somewhat berry flavour? Fake, dry finish.
Aroma of dark fruits, prunes and some alcohol, quite nice. Muddy red/brownish colored body, with a small head. Lots of alcohol in the flavor and a nice fruityness. Quite decent.
Redish amber with small head. Fruity aroma with nots of sweetness. Soft feel. Sweet with fruity bitter aftertaste.
Cloudy golden-brown color. A lot of malt aroma; alcohol; light yeast; a touch of Acacia honey. Very sweet, maybe too much, light hop.
An unclear amber beer with a brown head. The aroma is sweet with strong notes of alchol and lesser of caramel. The flavor is very sweet with notes of yeast, spices, and alcohol.
Bottle. Hazy amber colour with a big baige head. Sweet fruity aroma and a sweet fruity light sour alcoholic taste. Medium to full body and a sweet light alcoholic finish.

red-amber colour, very foamy head, nice lace, strong nutty aroma, notes of vinegar and alcohol, earthy, very very sweet, full-bodied, long sugary finish with the expected warming alcohol touch - thanks to fiulijn for this rare beer

Huge bodied dark beer. I was expecting syrupyness, but it was suprisingly light. The first beer I�ve had over 12% which wasn�t some kind of supercharged lager, and I found this excellent. Really put the wine in Barley wine.
Apple aroma. Cloudy, orange/brown color, beige head, good lace. Sweet, very fruity, apple, orange, full. Suprisingly well hidden alcohol and easy drinkable.

2005-04-01, 8-4-8-4-16=40 Cloudy dark amber color; huge head. Quite sweet aroma, malty, alcoholic, light vegetables and very light mint; then it develops the hop aroma. Sirupy, malty; really sweet. Would be great with some more bitterness. A real Barley Wine. 2004-05-06, 8-5-8-4-17=42 Hazy dark amber color; fine perlage; huge thick head, persistent, magnificent. Strong (sweet) malt aroma, Barley Wine like; palm sugar; very light yeast and fruitness. Malt syrup, correct bitterness. Very sweet, which also helps hiding very well the alcohol. Far from being complex, but really enjoyable for a late evening. I like it!

Cloudy orange brown color, medium head. Aroma is sweet candy sugar, apricot, raisin. Taste is very sweet, like sugarwater, some caramel malty notes, bit alcohol. Alcohol is quite well masked actually, but the beer is a bit unbalanced. Sweet and alcoholic palate.
Ein WASSER Debakel!!! Nicht der Rede wert. Getrunken in N�rnberg. Fassware. 0,3l
From a 33 cl bottle purchased at a rest stop on the Autobahn. Poured a clear gold with an off white head. Bread aroma. Flavors of toast. Crisp and slightly bitter finish.
Bottle from Biershop Bayern. Clear yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, hay, light corn and light hoppy. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Dry and light bitter finish. 280117

500ml bottle. Barely clear golden colour with average, thick, frothy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, snow-white head. Fresh hoppy aroma has grassy notes, a touch of lemon and yellow stone fruit, supporting pale malty background. Taste is grassy hoppy, a touch of yellow stone fruit, minimally sweet pale malty basis, a cautious grainy touch. Nicely hopped Pilsener.
Ins Glas ergie�t sich ein goldgelbes Pils mit sch�ner Schaumkrone. Geruch herb, grasig, leicht getreidig. Geschmack startet bitter hopfig, grasig.

500 ml flip-top bottle in Garmisch, Germany. Pours a pale gold color with soft white head. Aroma is malty and sweet for a Pils. Taste is sweet, corny and smooth. Palate is too smooth for a Pils. Typical southern Pils, should have been a Helles.

33cl bottle at the Krone in Greding, Bavaria. Having spent some weeks in Germany this year it came as a pleasant surprise to find a Pilsener that is both interstingly and adequately hopped, holding its bitterness to the end.

0,5l. Golden yellow pale clear white rocky head, some lacing. Aromas dough, sweet malts, grains. Palate sweet caramel, cardboard, smooth carbonation slick mouth feel. After taste sweet wit hodd dry , very weak hints of hops in the finish. Unbalanced and way too sweet on the malts.

Stringent herb-bitterer Antrunk, in dem leckere Getreidenoten vorhanden sind. Die Verkn�pfung von Herbe und Bitterkeit �berzeugt durch seine Intensit�t weiter ohne aufdringlich zu sein, auch der Hopfen wird von Zeit zu Zeit durchgelassen, er zeigt sich aber nicht �berm��ig. Erfrischend, zum Ende wird das Bier bitterer, was der S�ffigkeit aber nicht schadet. Leicht grasig. Gelungenes und ansprechend bitteres Pils, das den Hopfen nicht vermissen l�sst. 7/11/10/11/10/11

Bottle 330ml. @ home. Clear medium yellow color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, toasted, hay, light moderate hoppy, grass, hoppy. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20101004]
*Old rating, best before 27.10.05. Malzig-neutrales, leicht frisches Bier. Malzig-s��lich, aber irgendwie unrund.

Die Schaumkrone h�lt nicht gut, sie f�llt schnell grobporig ineinander. Geruch milchig. Geschmacklich milchig-metallig, das wars dann auch schon fast, nur im Nachgeschmack dazu leicht bitter. Fazit: Muss nicht sein, auch notfalls kaum trinkbar. Test vom 25.5.2010, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 8,4,5,4,9,4 - 4,80
Bottle @ Bamberg. Poured into ceramig mug. Golden with a large white head and lacings. Fresh nose og hay and grain. Herbal and perfumey. Smooth and dry. Decent.

Swing-top bottle (Labeled Christoph�s Classic Premium Pilsener at 4.9%). Strong sweet barley/hay aroma. Hazy medium yellow color with small head. Sweet barley/hay wort flavor with lightly bitter grass finish. Okay but seems to not have finished fermenting.

It�s golden with a creamy, white head. The aroma is mild with notes of malt, bread and light flower. The flavour has a light sweetness and notes of malt, bread, light flower, straw and the finish is dry � it�s well composed, refreshing and nice.

Bottle 50cl. w. swing top. Clear light to medium yellow orange color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, hay, toasted, cabbage water notes, cardboard notes. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20091002]

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Pours an almost clear pale yellow with a solid and lacing white head. Malty aroma with a hint of flowery hops. Light body, sweet malts and a discreet whiff of metal. Subdued bitterness. 021009

Light yellow colored with little white head. Slightly hopped aroma with somehow cardboardy note, rather thin aroma. Thin to medium bodied. Flavor is more dominated by hops and lemon, aftertaste dries still. Well, not very crispy one.
Bottle, 4.9%. Aroma seems a bit sweet for a pils. The same goes for the flavour. Low to medium bitterness and low carbonation.

(swing top bottle) Hazy, yellow colour with a blonde foamy head. Slightly dusty, sweetish, buttery malty aroma with a shy herbal blend. Initially sweet malty, later very slim and flat, slightly herbal hoppy, light-bitter finish.

Hazy coppery golden/light amber and a decent eggshell coloured cap and rounded lacing. Nose is Syrupy, dandy and passable faint floral. Initial taste is clinks of upfront bitterness, goes a bit tea like before a surge of cloying clementine biterness. Decent enough cooling moderate carbonation and a bit, as said before, annoyingly cloying. Finishes with a brassy citrus bitterness, not a good combo, before a long wooden bitter linger. Hrm. Cask, Boggart Microbar, Arndale Market, Manchester
Cask (Head of Steam, London) Rather dull blond ale. Hoppy, but thin, even unbalanced.
an amber coloured ale, with a sweet fruit maly nose, and a bitter fruity malt flavour.
Cask Handpump at the Mill Hotel, Chester 28/06/2001 Mid brown coloured with some bitterness and pale malt. Dry hoppy finish.
Cask at Head of Steam, Euston Light brown colour, good mix of hops and malt, I normally like everything from this brewery and this was no exception. Definitely a brewer to look out for.

Cute wooden pump clip. Copper colour. Sweet, bready, undeveloped malt nose. The palate is also malty, but dryer with a touch of bitterness developing later on. However, the sweetness returns and lingers on the finish. All seems a bit unbalanced. Not bad, but not really my favoured style of bitter - I prefer something crisper with more bitter grip. I wouldn�t have recognised this beer from the brewer�s description. Cask (handpump), Head of Steam, Euston, London NW1 (with Spiesy).
[Cask conditioned at The Head Of Steam] Golden coloured. Sweet and fruity. It tastes like very mature pears. Very strange and rather unbalanced, but still tasty.

Cask Conditioned, at the Wenlock Arms, London. Golden honey colour, slightly hazey, with just a fine white head. Jammy, honied aroma, discernable from some distance. Butterscotch flavour (pointed out by Steve) Good biiter-sweet finish. Interesting and original drop this.

Cask Conditioned at The White Lion, Fewcott. Golden Amber in colour with a chunky white head. A deeper sweet malt base than expected which is followed by a tangy flowery hoppy bitter flavour. A pleasant session bitter, though the sweetness does linger.

Gold pour with a tight white head and lace. Aroma is wheat malt and light honey along with some floral notes. Flavor is sweet honey start, flat wheat malt, and a light floral bitter finish. Medium bodied but slightly fizzy. easy drinker, flavor and bitter make it a solid wheat beer
Draft at the brewery. Clear body, small white head. Aroma of not much at all, the flavor is a bit sour and tart but Slightly off. Nothing special.

Bottle from the brewery. Pours a crystal clear light golden color with a decent sized bubbly white head that slowly dissipates. Aromas of sweet honey with a light spice with almost a lime mint kind of thing happening? The flavor is pretty good actually, there�s an awesome raw grainy cereal type flavor in there that I really dig. Sweet sugary honey like maltiness with some spicy wheat and yeast flavors to counter. Medium body with a moderate level of carbonation. Nice brew, I�m glad I picked this up because I almost passed based on style. I hope the rest of those propeller beers I brought back surprise me as well.
Jaune avec une petite mousse blanche. L�ar�me du malt et un peu de miel. Pas mal ordinaire.
This light refreshing ale is made with water, malted grain, hops, and yeast, with wildflower and fruit blossom honey from Nova Scotia�s Annapolis Valle

341ml bottle pours a slightly hazy golden color with a finger of white head that leaves very little lacing behind. Aromas are floral with some grass and light fruits. Taste is malty sweet with some hoppy bitterness. A really well done wheat ale that is much better than I can describe.

The pour is a light yellowish body with a finger of foam off white head. Sweet nose with no honey aroma, buy floral, grassy notes and a light wheat malt. A bit of a hop in the taste, but mostly a lightly sweet, lightly malted beer with notes of floral, grassy hops and wheat.

Single bottle purchased from Zyn Liqour in Calgary, AB on 11/05/2011. Colour: Light and slightly clouded with medium head. Nose: Sweet white wonderbread (not quite a honey scent), sprite, a spot of oak. Taste: Medium-light sweet, light bitter, medium-light sour. The wheat is soft and the honey even softer. A touch of wood but not much else. A pop gun beer.

Originally rated November 2005. Pours a pale golden-yellow colour with a white fizzy head that does not last long. Very sweet nose with the real scent of honey and wheat. Thin mouthfeel. The taste is slightly bitter with that malt and honey mixed quite well. Not much in the aftertaste, just a tad of the honey. Nicely brewed light refreshing beer that smells and tastes what the the name describes.

Pours with a slight haze, is a highly carbonated brew and has yellow to light light amber colour. Aromas are cereal/grain like, some sweet notes as well. The beer is somewhat sweet, light bodied, fast and not as bad as some other honey wheats that i�ve had. It has a metallic taste in it that i don�t enjoy however, shows some bitterness as well.
Bottle from beers of Europe. Hazy amber colour with a white head. Aroma and taste are yeasty and lightly spiced. Medium body.
F�a�ka z nemecka. V��a trosku zelezita. Farba tmav�ia medova. Chu� pr�jemn� sladova.
Light brown in color. Aroma is a bit stale. Taste is a little sweet with a slight bitter finish. OK beer.

As Bayreuther Original Landbier Zwick'l. Bottled 0,50L. Dark orange color, unclear and bubbly aspcet with moderate white head of medium duration. Fresh corn and wheat aroma, notes of malt, grassy, fruity herb. Moderate watery and malty palate, watery texture, soft carbonation, pale grains and corn palate, moderate sweet hearb final.
Bottle in Grafenw�hr. Tastes like dried fruits, toffee malt, and earth. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like earth, toffee malt, and dried fruits.
Clear yellow gold. A little too much generic sweetness for me to really like this. A touch of spicy/floral hopping, but just too meh. Crisp and clean if a little heavy.

resin, floral, grass, spruce, citrus, herbs, light sweetness, medium sweetness, heavy cloying sweetness, lightly bitter, medium bitterness, very bitter, lightly sour, medium sourness, heavily sour, light body, medium body, full body,
Bottle. Pours clear yellow with a white head. Dusty, paper, grains. Taste is light a bit watery, quite alot of paper, light caramel note-
Pisane z pamieci: ladna piana jasnozlote klarowne. Aromat i smak niczym nie odpycha. Jest goryczka. Srednio wysycone. Poprawne piwko
Der Antrunk ist grasig frisch, der K�rper hat getreidige Noten unterstrichen von einer leichten Malzs�sse. Im Abgang die Pilstypische Hopfenbittere. Durchschnitts-Industriepils.

Baden Baden 25/10 2016. 50 cl from tap on Italian restaurant. Pours clear golden yellow with small white head. Lacing on the side of the glass. Aroma is lightly fruity with a bitter touch. Medium carbonation and watery palate. Flavor is medium sweet followed by pronounced bitterness. The aftertaste is bitter and lingers on for a decent time. Good for lunch. Solid pilsner without Boeing extraordinary.

Bottle. Light golden, small and mostly diminishing head. Moderate, malty and lightly sweetish aroma, light herbal hoppyness. Body is light to medium, malty and lightly sweetish flavor, light herbal hoppyness. Finish is short to average, malty and dryish - lightly sweetish, light metal and herbal hoppyness. Pils with notes of sharp metal. Nothing special.
50cl bottle. Pours clear golden colour with a mid-sized good lasting white head, high carbonation. Taste of spicy hops and grainy malt. Taste of grainy malt, hay, mild spicy hops, average Pilsener.
50 cl bottle. Pale golden colour with medium head.Grass and hay aroma and taste. Very mil with a short dry bitter finish. Medium carbo and light body

On tap at Green Sheep Budapest. Nice lacing yella pils. Corn flakes nice smooth and sweet fresh bread taste, very very light bitterness. Not yer mamas czech style pils. Very enjoyable German style pils!
Botella de @Vivalabirra, Oviedo. 17/11/19 Color amarillo dorado corona de espuma blanca aromas cereal notas levadura, sabor cereal, maltosa cuerpo ligero.
Nice mild taste with a bit of bitter at the end. Probably more bitter than other Bayern beer I tasted, but still pleasant and easy to enjoy.
Fresh aromas and nice golden color. Clean malty taste, very little hoppy bitterness. Nice aftertaste that I can�t really describe.
Best lager I have tasted in a very long time. Some special spice or development of the beer - I do not know what- made it sooo good.
Bottle. Pours clear dark amber with fluffy head. Aroma is sweet caramel, toffee. Flavour is caramel, toasted malt. Good.

Pours clear dark brown with a small offwhite head. Aromas of dark malts, caramel, dusty notes, bready. Taste has dark malts, light bitterness, caramel, bready, chocolatey finish, dark fruits and esters.
Keg @ Pure, Birmingham. Pours hazy brown. Grainy malt aroma with some cocoa. Decent smooth dunkel taste, vaguely sweet with some good toasted malts.
Tapped. Dark brown color with impressive white foam. Malted aroma with decent amount of caramel notes. Rather medium body with caramel and some roasty beans, quite drinkable.

At Buskers pub in Rome-Italy, on tap. Pours a dark amber almost chestnut skin, medium beige head which lowers leaving drafts. Nose: smoked sensation, hidden toffee, metallic hint far away. Mouth: malty with a sweet accent and an overall mild (tea-like) bitterness cleaning the palate. A very adventurous dunkel. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Hazy medium brown color, tan head. Aroma of dusty cocoa and caramel. Taste has lightly roasted malts, subtle toast.
Keg@purity bar, birmingham. Black beer with small head. Aroma is bready and lightly roasted malts. Taste is brown bread, caramel and roast malts. Slightly fizzy on the palate. Good.
Bottle@Guren. dark brown reddish. 3 finger foam. Low carbonation. Maltyness rules. Smooth butterscotch make it to the sweet side, no bitterness. Classic Muncher dunkel. Very drinkable.
Super Bier! Schmeckt wie ein Altbier, das gef�llt mir, sch�ne Malznoten und ein angenehmes Hopfenaroma. Das Bier kann man sehr gut trinken!
Light black beer with sweet vanilla and a few light malts. Nothing great. A little oily and synthetic.

13/I/13 - 33cl bottle from Erasmus Hotel, back in the days when it was still a beery place @ Klaas� place - BB: VI/2000 - bottled: VI/98 (2013-20) Huge thanks to Klaas for sharing the bottle! Clear orange beer, irregular unstable yellowish head, bit adhesive, some sediment floating around in the glass. Still an amazing head after almost 15 years! Aroma: sweet and sugary, honey, dry sherry, orange peel, candied orange peel, marzipan, spices, madeira. MF: ok carbon, medium to full body. Taste: bit sourish, orange peel, sugary touch, little vinegar, sour apples, pretty fruity. Aftertaste: honey, little bitter, citric acidity, orange peel, alcohol noticeable. It is very clear from this beer that Kris uses a cooling ship to cool the wort. After all those years the wild yeast and bacteria make the beer more sour than at first, which makes the beer preserve better. Very nice beer if you like both sours and aged beers!

At the Hotel Erasmus in Bruges. Pours a nice Medium golden orangish color. Minimal fizzy white head, lasted maybe a minute or two. Aromas of light spices, a touch of brown sugar, and something whiskey like. Flavor is lightly sweet and hints of spiciness.

Sehr s�er Geruch, etwas getreidig, leicht bitter. Kr�ftiger Geschmack, etwas bitter und herb, sehr fruchtig und hefig, pr�gnant holzig-trocken. Weiter sehr fruchtig und eigen, gut! Im Abgang deutlich hefig-getreidig und s��lich , die Fruchtigkeit birgt hier eine deutliche Alkoholnote. Aromatisch hopfig-malzig, cremig. Test vom 12.3.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 10,12,12,13,13,12 - 12,00
Bottle at Brasserie Erasmus.�Clear amber/brown - white head. Caramel. Sweetness. Vineous. Light oxidation. Light berries. Honey notes. Peppery. Fruity. Nutty. A bit old - but still nice.

De dolle 21. 33cl bottle consumed at hotel Erasmus, Brugge, Belgium.... Pours a mostly transparent golden orange brown with a thin layer if offwhite head... Rich sherry aroma with figs, honey, and dark Belgian sugars. Aged for sure with mild oxidation. Sweet all around... Flavors are on par with the difference being a faint to mild citric fruit tartness towards the backend. Carbonation is light and body hasn�t thinned too much from the aging process. A well aged Belgian strong ale which has de eloped some nice aged characteristics. 8/4/8/4/15

Bottle at Hotel Erasmus, Brugge 02.10.10 Hazy amber appearance with a slim white head. The aroma is quite weird but likeable, I get mouldering fruit, you know like orange with a bit of white mould on em� in the fruit basket, Loz get�s gravy granules, so an interesting combination. Flavour lean�s more towards the fruit element rather than the gravy side but its a bit sour, the alcohol showing towards the end. It�s fine but not as great as I was hoping, maybe it�s on the downward spiral, btw the beer menu said 1989 but the bottle said 1998. A8 A4 T6 P3 Ov14 3.5

Thanks to DeDolleWaitor. Vintage 1998. Pours amber with a white head. Aroma is caramel, vineous, fruity, raisin and plum. Light oxidized. Flavour is caramel, vineous, sour raisin. Still nice after 11 years.

Bottle 33cl. @ home. [ Vintage ]. Clear medium orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, oxidide, vintage malt, fruity. Flavor is light heavy sweet, light acidic and moderate bitter with a long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20090710]

Bottle, 33cl. Vintage 1998. Served by DeDolleWaitor. Pours a clear golden beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is vineous, raisin and fruit. The flavor is likewise vineous with some acidity. The palate is sweet. Overall a good beer, maybe a little oxidized.

My # 3400th rating. Shit. Thanks Rene for trading this. 1998 vintage. Pours clear amber with a small creamy white head. Nose is deep. Vinous, matured, dusty, oxidized, yeasty. But it also has a very fruity touch to it. Sherry, vinous and fruity. No doubt it is past its prime but its also obvious that this once was a world class beer. Just grateful for trying this. Thanks.

Dark opaque brown with a small beige head. The aroma was a nice combination of espresso, chocolate, hops bitterness, and smokiness. The flavor was pretty much just espresso with a hops bitter aftertaste. Too much carbonation for this brew...very crisp feeling (maybe why this is a summer stout.)
[Kran b.d., zakupione w Browarze] Barwa jasno z�ota, nieklarowne. Piana bardzo niska. Aromat i smak g��wnie s�odowy, w tle chmielowa goryczka. Nasycenie niskie, goryczka niska.
White small head . Decent aroma, sweet with touch of Lublin hops. Light with interesting wheat flavour and yeast a bit like wheat lager. Interesting cross over.

Full Sail Brewing Company--Hangtime Ale--Adventure Series--2003--12 oz. Bottle Release. 5.00% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) Wheat Ale--Clear thin bright golden color. Light lacy head. Floral pilsner spicy Saaz hop front. Tangy crisp pilsner body with tangy wheat citrus mild sweet caramel body. Clean wheat spice mild hop end. Wheat Pils. Sampled 7/8/2003.

There is really not too much too this beer. It is very simple, has a wheaty cereal malt background and not a lot of yeastiness here, has a little bit of fruit, but not picking up anything other than a small amount of floral hops.

Seems like Full Sail may be moving a little towards more non-descript beers. This is still a nice brew. Citrus aroma, with a nice hop finish. Golden yellow coloring, with a medium head. Flavor is slightly hoppy, mostly balanced with malts. Mouthfeel is nice, not watery, but not overly thick. Another winner from Full Sail, but not they�re best offering.
BOTTLE...clear gold but no head. dull light tast. I dont like wheat beers, but this aint to bad...but I would not buy it again..

Bottle: best heffe i ever had, then again it didn't taste at all like a heffe. Clean in appearance and taste. No cumbersome bananna, clove, lemon, bubblegum get your girlfriend drunk heffe bullshit. Ideal summer ale.

bottle-I had very low expectations going into this brew, but i seemed to think it was better than the ratings give it. Its downfall was teh filtered appearance(BORING!)-lots of carbonation-big bubbles. flavor was very sweet, tasted like a lemon poppyseed muffin. smelled like grass, lemon and spicy hops. good flavor, but ratings are not very good due to the appearance. good summer quafer though on a hot New Mexico day!
Good wheat aroma. This is a no frills beer with wheat flavor throughout. A good example true to style.
I can't complain about this beer. Another excellent, well- rounded ale. Good medium body, nice balance of sweetness and bitterness. Oh, how I love Full Sail.

nearly clear golden color with a small but consistent and lasting head. light clean whispy nose, light in body and beggining with a clean but lightly sweet malt but comes later with a mellow yet full boquet of hops

The beer pours a pellucid golden amber color, the head minimal; frothy in texture and it vanishes quite quickly leaving a thin sheet of lace to cover the glass. Nose is citrus crisp, clean and fresh, somewhat sweet as is the start that is also thickly malt; top is skinny in its feel to the palate. Finish is sprightly acidic and the hops pleasant enough in their spicy presence, dry lingering aftertaste, and a nice drinkable beer, not great, but drinkable nonetheless.

Draft: Poured a light golden color ale with a medium size foamy head. Aroma of citrusy hops notes with light cereal notes. Taste is a mix of light cereal notes with some floral citrusy hops notes and light bitter notes are also noticeable. Body is about average with good carbonation. Refreshing and enjoyable without being entirely focus on hops.

A hazed golden ale with a thin off white head. In aroma, nice biscuit malt with grassy floral hops, light citrus pulp, OK. In mouth, a nice crisp biscuit malt with grassy floral hops, citrus pulp, very nice and smooth. On tap at Clybourn location.
flavor and aroma is very thin. has a dirty sock flavor with a weird sweet finish. would not call this one an IPA. technically itt is an english IPA. purs copper with a thin white head.

Pours bright orange with a bubbly, foamy white head. Aroma is floral, nectar, resin, citrus, and bread malts. Flavor is floral and earthy, bread malts, nut, and hints of grapefruit. Has a thin body. Dry. Not bad, lots of complexity.
Had it on tap at Goose Island. Excellent clear amber color with s nice sized head. Smooth IPA taste with slight notes of caramel.
On tap at Goose Island Clybourn. Poured clear amber gold with off white head. Aroma balances malt husk bitter resin. Light carb med bod. Taste light bittersweet grassy hop.

2/8/16 Chicago (Goose Island Brew Pub $4 16 draft pour into Nonic glass). Golden Brown pour, medium carbonation. light bubbly thin head. Bread yeast aroma and hoppy bread taste.Dry crisp taste, medium carbonation and texture. Overall OK offering, would have liked a little stronger or with a more bitter hops taste.
Not sure aabout this one. Listed as a scottish ale. IT isn�t super hoppy. A bit earthy, lots of almost savory malt delivery.
Poured from draft at goose island brewery. Orange and white head. Clear. Not too scotchy. Carmel and hoppy notes. Smooth for the style
Found this one hard to rate because while it was good, it fell short in a lot of areas. A little mild and thin.
