Tap at Franconian Beer Festival 2019. Cloudy orange-gold with a thick head. Nose is wheat malt, clove, orange, melon. Sweet, lots of stone fruits in the flavor, also melon and hints of tropical fruit, peaches. Hugely fruity and flavorful.
Milk oatmeal nose, Cloudy white yellow cloudy. Medium body, chewy, light spice, light mealy, dry, good balance, pleasant.
Cloudy yellow. Aroma is unripe banana artificial banana some yeast. Very green and minerally. Taste is dandelion. Some yeast profile with sour and sweet grass. Minerally. Ok.
Tap. Hazy golden color with white head. Aroma is fresh yeast, bananas, dough. Taste is the same. Silky mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Fine!
bottle bb 13/6/17 golden cloudy thin head cereal bit ester butter pear apple low carbonation oro torbida non molta schiuma poco persistente cereale leggero esteri diacetile pera mela poco gassata

500ml Bottle - Hazy golden in colour. Grain, lemon and some floral notes in the aroma. Ripe bananas, lemon, toffee and some slightly metallic notes in the taste. Not as clean as many beers of this type from Franconia but drinkable.

Draft @ Fr�nkisches Bierfest, N�rnberg. Pours a hazy orange color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity wheat malty banana aroma. Fruity wheat malty banana flavor. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy banana finish.

Appearance: Cloudy golden color with a big white head that leaves a fine lacing. Aroma: Mild wheat, some banana and fruity. Palate: Medium body. Slightly sweet and a moderate bitterness. Average carbonation. Taste: Light banana, mild citric, some wheat and yeast. Overall impression: A little bit to moderate hefe weisse. Easy drinkable. Felt a bit thin. Personal stats: Bottle from a trade with Grima
Bottle looks simple, but okay. Beer in the glass light yellow, nice head. Starts mild, quite moldy, modest yeasty, not too dry. A bit moldy-grasy. Finish drier, still dominated by malty notes. Okay.
Bottle: Hazy, yellow to light orange color, creamy white head. Aroma of wheat, notes of yeast, oranges, cloves. flavor is also wheaty, spicy (cloves), light fruity. Quite common brew.
Tap. Hazy dark brown color with beige head. Aroma is earthy, red berries, caramel, chocolate, rustic, syrup. Taste is berries, caramel, syrup, leather, a bit sweet. Oily mouthfeel. Quite nice!
Tap at Franconian Beer Festival 2019. Nose is fruity, estery chocolate with toffee. Medium sweetness, chocolate, raisins. Smooth, lightish, bit of citrus hop. Nice.
Tap at Fr�nkisches Bierfest. Hazy orange brown, golden foam. Nice toffee roast, medium a bit foamy body, praline chocolate, good orange peel hop kick to finish. full flavored but fresh and moreish.

Das Bockbier der Brauerei Fischer in Greuth, Mittelfranken. 0,5L B�gelflasche mit fr�nkischem Etikett halt! Dunkles Braun mit Rotstich, cremige verhaltene Schaumdecke. Leicht rezenter Antrunk, r�stige Malznoten treten zuerst in den Vordergrund, ehe die dunklen eingelegten Lik�rfr�chte durchdringen. Die S�sse wird von einer leichten S�ure ausgeglichen. Leichte Alknoten sind sp�rbar, aber nicht aufdringlich, sie vermitteln das Gef�hl als wenn ein Schuss Rum oder Lik�r mit im Bier w�ren. Leichte Hopfenbittere im Abgang. Kein Alltagsbock, aber ein richtig gutes Winterbier, sch�n w�rmend!
Unclear mahogany with a large off white head. Aroma had roasted malt, caramel and chocolate. Flavor had diacety and roasted malt. Finished buttery.

Bottle @ Fr�nkisches Bierfest, N�rnberg. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma with weak hints of dark fruit. Fruity malty caramel and dark fruit flavor. Has a fruity malty caramel finish.

Bottled, from Landbierparadies. Deep copper colour, rich creamy head - looks delicious! Caramelly nose with some chocolate. Mid sweet with soft mouthfeel and medium-full body. Creamy with caramel and cocoa powder. Low bitterness. Despite its depth and mellowness, this beer does not really turn me on - it is too sweet and caramelly.
*Old rating, best before 30/06/09. Sch�n trocken-w�rziges Bier. Nette R�stmalzaromen, ein Hauch von Karamell, leicht alkoholisch, w�rzig, nett aber nicht zu tief.
Bottle at Hopfen & Malz. Nutty brown with a tan head. Aroma is buttery. Flavour is roast malt, fruity, light carbonation, no real alco in the taste.

500 mL bottle from Bieropholie, shared with Mike, served quite cool in a tulip glass. Clear mahogany with no head. Smells really vinous, tart fruitiness, sine melanoidin, sherry, something is wrong here. Medium body, almost still. Quite oxidized, slightly fruity and tasty, vinous, bad; off-dry with some bitterness and a very oxidized, unpleasant finish. Suspect packaging failure.

05/04 On tap at restaurant Pilka, Cakovec (former brewpub). It had murky dark brown reddish body with medium half white, half ocher head. Aroma is faint, roasted sugar and caramel, with some faint hopiness mixing with sourness from being not pasteurized. Flavor was bitter, sour and sweetish, roasted sugar dominated, with lot of coffee and slight acidity well incorporating into the whole thing. Typical Schwarzbier, but lacks some body, although not as much as the Pilsener. Finish is long, bitterish and really nice. So, liked it, would be even better with more body, but fine...

1l fliptop bottle courtesy of heavy, who brought it from �akovec (a huge thanks for lugging it around!) Poured a murky red-brown body with a huge fluffy off-white spongey head that went away at a medium pace. The nose is predominantly caramel malt with some dusty yeastiness... a bit staleish but ok. The taste is ok, but not en par with the best in the country. Smooth mouthfeel, caramel, malt, some chewy and slightly acidulous hoppy bitterness somewhat "tainted" by roast in the background. Long, low, bitterish roasty aftertaste. All in all, it�s kinda pleasant, drinkable, but just too ordinary. Too light for its own good, lacking body. Has the same "faults" as the pale but they dectract from this one far more than they do for that one.
Sampled draught at Pilka, Cakovec, Croatia. -deep dark coloured, little pale-brown head, unpleasant smell, roasted coffee aroma, not so good yeasty finish

05/04 On tap at restaurant Pilka, Cakovec (former brewpub). This is mixed dark and pale beer, had slightly murky brown amber body with bigger ebony head. Aroma similar to their dark beer, roasted caramel with faint hopiness. Unpasteurized sourness if, of course, felt. Well balanced aroma, maybe even better than of its parts, but the flavor is not, as it is much lighter, like pale beer, but with most characteristics inherited from dark one, dominated by bittersweet roasted sugar. Pretty short, but pleasant finish. As Doggythedog said, the sum happened to be lesser than the parts.

Courtesy of heavy, thanks! As it happens so often with these, the sum is lesser than the parts. Nice dark amber colour, medium sized off white head that went away fast. Yeasty/malty nose. Watery, notes of caramel, some bread, a bit acidulous, with notes of lemony hopiness and a low roastiness. Oddly, seems less bitter than the Svijetlo and the Tamno and I like it less than them. It�s nice enough but I wonder if it should even be in the database.
Sampled draught at Pilka, Cakovec, Croatia. -little head, coca-cola coloured, strong caramel taste, not so drinkable

Deep dark beer with no head. Not carbonated yet (fresh out of the tank). A bit of sulfur in aroma, but nice smoked peat comes out. It comes out well in mouth, like a smoed porter, with powdery chocolate and nice body. Enjoyed with OKBeer . On tap March 2005.
Very dark brown. Very woody, smokey (cedar?) aroma. Flavour is smokey with light chocolate and toast notes. Slight nuttiness.

Black with a thin tan coloured head. Smoky, roasted, nutty aroma. Flavours of smoke, peat, expresso, and butterscotch finishing with a pleasant smoky bitterness. Medium bodied, thick mouthfeel for a lager. They also have a Blackhook Porter, made with similar ingredients. I was told the lager is made in the summer because they go through more beer, and can make the lager more quickly.

Bottle from Terre de Boissons Calais and drunk at home. Very dark red dark brown colour lasting tan head. Milk chocolate aroma with some dark fruits too. OK carbonation. I thought that this was quite malty easy drinking interesting beer and it hides the ABV very well. Yes tasty indeed. Just a little bit of paper somewhere, but otherwise fine.

Out of the three separate bargain basement beers purchased.. this was by far the most palatable. Spot on to style. Malt centric and not too sweet. Finish is smooth and rounded. I actually was a bit disappointed that the bottle was empty after the long encounter with a particularly stubborn table top jigsaw resurrection,

Kolor br?zowo rubinowy, zm?tniony. Piana be?owa, wysoka, d?ugotrwa?a nie zmniejsza swojego rozmiaru. Na szkle pozostawia grube w?sy. Aromat przynosi delikatn? palono??, s?odowo?? z ciemnymi owocami i odrobin? karmelu. Smak: ponownie, ciemne, sma?one owoce, przypominaj?ce nieco przypalon? marmolad?, karmel i s?odowo??. Na finiszu niezbyt intensywna, przpalona goryczka. Wysycenie ?rednie, pasuje. Idealnie schowany alkohol, powoduje, ?e piwo pije si? lekko.

The weakest beer I think I've ever tasted. Yes the alcohol content is high but it had no flavor, aroma, head, or even color to it. Not bad for finishing out a night of drinking I guess. This is some pretty foul stuff.

(500 ml can). Light golden colour, decent head. Fruity and yeasty aroma, aggressive carbonation, light bodied (no surprise!), moderate to low bitterness. Not too bad for an industrial pilsener, but not a great beer.
On draft at the brewery restaurant. Pours a cloudy light brown with an off white head. Not much in the atoms department. Feint cardboard flavors. Not too tasty.

Bottle. Brought back from the brewery by my wife. Dark cola colored pour. Short tan head. Nose is cola, sweet malt, watery caramel and faint wheat. Taste is a different story altogether. Normally, I�d think an infected beer would smell infected, but this doesn�t. However, the sour cherry and sour wheat flavors don�t really belong in a dunkelweizen. Some lemon as well. Yeast notes and faint malt. Body is light-medium with a soft, dense foam carbonation. Ends with more sour fruit notes, sour wheat, light malt and light caramel.

With great trepidation after reading all the warnings, I'm putting in a new beer. I found it in a liter flip-cap bottle at the bottom of the take-out beer cooler at the brewery. The spelling of "Wiezen," although incorrect, is what is on the bottle. I opened it up, and a frothy head of foam sprang up, and just kept coming and coming. Filled up two glasses with the foam alone. After this I was able to pour one I could actually drink. Hazy medium brown color appropriate for a the style. Huge head that lasted throughout the beer. Taste was surprisingly light, malty, but a bit thin in the middle. A bit of hops, and very faint bananas in the finish. I would have hoped for a bigger German yeast influence. Better overall than the hefe, but still not all that great a beer.
Bottle from Wegmans. Amber clear with thin head. Funky grain aroma. Mod carb. Pretty light with mild hopping - more like a characterful lager imho. Not great

Gezapft am Flughafen Newark Tr�bes Gold-Gelb, kein Schaum Kaum Aroma, man riecht etwas Hopfen, Zitrone, Sahnebonbon. Geschmack: auch relativ geschmacklos. Getreide/Brot im Hintergrund und Gaumen. Hopfen. Leicht cremig. Etwas Bitter. Erfrischend aber harmlos und uninteressant

7/28/18 - New York, NY - Brooklyn - on tap at Ox Market Tavern. Hazy light orange pour, frothy snow white head. Aroma is grainy, hints of white grape juice. Smooth flavor, a hint of honey sweetness, pear-like fruitiness. Crisp, refreshing mouthfeel. Good summer beer.

12 ounce bottle. Hazy honey gold pour with a medium-sized rocky white head. Mild lemony malt nose, with hints of light grain and yeast. Light grainy malt flavor upfront. Thin bodied and bready. Light fruity hops in finish. Lean and light, as a summer ale is supposed to be. Nothing more.

From bottle to glass at Tribe Road Kitchen in Hamilton, Bermuda. With 45 minutes of free time during an overnight business trip, I happened upon a great lunch spot with a small, but eclectic bottle collection and chose one I had not had. This was light, crisp and refreshing in the heat. Bready malt was the main character of the flavor, with lemon on the aroma.

Pours from bottle a slightly clouded yellow-gold that clears steadily, with one-finger white head that leaves some lacing and skim. Light, uncomplicated aroma of biscuit and grass, tempted to say �smells like beer.� Palate adds gentle lemongrass, bread, hint of corn, mineral. Manages to provide a creamy mouthfeel despite fairly light body. Finish is crisp and clean. The simple approach works well for a summer beer. This is one of the better thirst-quenchers that I�ve had lately.
This is a very light beer. Not much aroma. I would like to compare this to a coors light beer. Yuk
A pretty standard blonde ale. One of riverhorse�s better beers. Easy drinking, perfect for the summer sitting on the porch watching the sun set.
Cloudy pale with River horse standard selection of hops. An easy summer sipper for hops lovers.
This beer doesn�t do anything in spectacular fashion, but it�s light, it�s easy on the eyes, and it sits well on the tongue. You can do a lot worse than this beer as summer ales go.
500ml can from Tasty Life Songbai, Xiaimen. Pours golden yellow with a dissipating head. Aroma of malt with a hint of lemon. Sweet finish.
50cl. can. Pale yellow lager. Pretty refreshing and easy drinking another mass Lager. Ok

The aroma is grass, some corn sweetness. The apperance is straw yellow, white head, true to its style. The flavor is grassy, sweet, corn, low signature of malts or hops. The finish is a sweet syrupy corn like residue. Not good. I guess it�s ok for the odious pale lager style.

Pour is a bright yellow with a average white head. Aroma is faint grains and not much else. Flavor is a very weak and very bland. Some sweetness but no hops or malts are present. Still its not skunky and i�ll give it that.

Pours a hazy straw color with 1/2" of white foam and briefly fizzy carbonation. No head retention, no lacing. Mild skunkiness and some citrus in the aroma. Odd, the flavor is nothing like the aroma - no skunk at all, no citrus, little hoppiness. Instead, it has an initial and very brief wheat tang. Then its gone. Completely. This is replaced by a sweetness, tasting a little of honey and a lot of amber candi sugar. It is quite sweet, but shy of being cloying. A small hop presence makes itself known in the finish. Almost medium body, and surprisingly on the flat side.

(Can 50 cl) Clear, pale, pilsener golden with a small, white head. Aroma of brewing cereal (rice) and malt. Medium-bodied, lightly tart notes from the brewing cereal - and then really nothing much more. Overly carbonated. 161106
Pale golden coloured. Light aroma. Mild and fairly clean flavour. Refreshing and quite good.

A light yellow beer with a bubbly white head. The aroma contains notes of straw and brewing cereal. The flavor is sweet yet sourness from the use of brewing cereal lingers in the background, leading to a very dry end with a strong note of hay combined with a slight bitterness. My guess was that there was corn in this beer, but the label tells me, that the brewing cereal used is rice.
A cold icebeer should be very delcate but this one was NOT special. It had a strange taste.
Light Cloudy Yellow/Gold Coloring. Sweet Malt, Some Candy Sugar Notes and a Bitter Ending. Little to Love on This Brew.
A light yellow beer with a small white head. The aroma is very grassy and sweet with notes of glue. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of glue and citrus before a dry hoppy end sets in.
Bottle Citric and slightly grassy, but otherwise neutral nose. Pale straw coloring, no head. Citrus flavors, generally low bitterness. Watery and boring.

Bottled: Golden coloured. Ligth unclear. Has a small white head. Is malty and fruity in the aroma. Some vague spicy notes. Fruit and malt is dominant in the flavour as well. A little bland. Is more sweet than bitter in the end. Very light to drink, but quite boring. Theres much better examples of the style out there.

Pale orange/ginger colour. A predominantly hoppy, citric beer. Grapefruit aroma. Lemon and grapefruit flavours. Crisp, clean finish - not too sharp. A touch of pale, dry malt appears towards the end. A bit one-dimensional, but an excellent quaffing beer. Tastes a bit like a pilsner. 500ml bottle (bottle conditioned) from Beer Seller, Lincoln. No BBE date.
Cloudy yellow hue with a white thin head. Orange and yeasty nose. Quite highly hopped taste with an under lying yeast taste.
Sampled at Stockholm Beer Festival 2003. Light and somewhat hazy. Not much of an aroma. Rather lively at first, then smooth. It tastes "old", museum-ish, like old logs(?).
Cask conditioned at Stockholm Beer Festival. Pale golden. Slightly earthy nose. Herbal flavour, earthy and dry mouthfeel.
Golden, not very clear. Aroma is hoppy and alittle fruity. Some elder in the flavor. Not much bitterness.
Bottled. Pale golden. Saffron aroma. Sulphury and fruity. Sweet, yet crisp with hard mouthfeel. Light bodied with low bitterness.
sharp hoppy aroma, pale golden hue with minimal head, highly hopped with a crisp refreshing palate, low carbonation, not complex but still pretty good
cask leggero ambrato discreto malto leggero cereale nota tostatst buona nota fruttata amaro medio

14/3/2019. Cask at the Leicester Beer Festival 2019. Pours clear dark amber with a small bubbly off-white head. Aroma of toffee, sweet malt, fruit and grain. Medium plus sweetness, light bitterness. Moderate body, oily texture, soft carbonation.
A chestnut coloured real ale. A typical British real ale and a fairly good pint, nice if you want something that isn't overpowering in flavour.
Cask at The Blue Anchor. Clear chestnut colour with white head. Heavy malt aroma. Notes of malt red wine wheat yeast

Bottle from Hogs Back Brewery shop. Sour (and sweet) fruit and berries aroma. Dark amber. Weak off-white head. Tart. Matches the aroma. Light bodied. Shorter finish than perhaps couod be expected. I like.
Cask @ Star Inn, Vogue Cornwall, dark brown white headwith a malty and slight caramel taste, and a malty aftertaste nice beer.

Cask at The Blue Anchor. It pours deep brown with a thick beige head. The nose is fresh brown bread, earthy, wood, leather, dried fruits, fruit cake and leaves. The taste is smooth, wood, earth, Jamaican gingerbread cake, dried fruits, damp leaves and cherry with a dry, woody finish. Medium + body and fine, foamy carbonation. Nice depth of flavour and good balance. A tasty old ale.

Cask at In De Wildeman. Pours clear brown with a thin off white head. Aroma of fudge, caramel, sweet malt and some overripe dark fruit. Flavour is moderate sweet and light moderate bitter. Over light bodied with flat carbonation.
Poured a bright reddish amber with no head. Aroma of dark fruit and caramel malt. Medium body, flavour is fruity berries and caramel malt, fairly bitter.

On cask @ In de Wildeman. The aroma has toffee, caramel, nuts, some flowery hop tones. Clear, brown coloured beer with no head. The taste is light-moderate sweet, light bitter, has toffee, caramel. No carbonation. Light-medium bodied.
Tap at the Franconian Beer Festival 2019. Orange-brown with a mediuam head. Nose of chocolate, cocoa cola, light spicy hops. Flavor is mostly chocolate, some orange. Decent.

Color naranja muy oscuro, tirando a marr�n. Tres dedos de espuma con excelente. Aroma a Malta, caramelo, az�car quemado y un punto de pasa o moscatel. Gusto exagerado a malta, cereal en grano, galleta mar�a, ligera mantequilla, ligero amargor al final del trago. Cuerpo acuoso. Muy equilibrada, malta por un tubo y no peca de dulce.
lossti von bssti undarus woderzi van perzi con oranginas destis westis con perri

500ml Bottle - Copper with some orangey tinges and a foamy head. Malty aroma with wort, raisins and caramel. Malty and sweet taste with raisins, nuts and toffee standing out. A bit too sweet but still drinkable.

Ordentliche Schaumentwicklung mit durchschnittlicher Rezenz. Farblich rotbraun und leicht opal. Riecht w�rzig, leicht malzig, nussig, minimal s��. Geschmacklich viel Karamell, malzig, wenig r�stig, nussig, s��lich. Erinnert eher an Rot- oder Braunbier. Trotzdem gut.

Bottle. Chestnut color with fluffy off-white head. Aroma is burnt sugar, grains, chocolatem Taste is the same, charr and burnt sugar again, roast. Oily mouthfeel with natural carbonation. Characterful, but not quite my type of character.

On tap at Drummer Gasthaus, 7.10.17. Clear brown with a small beige head. Sweet and nutty aroma with a little bit of caramel. Sweetish taste, then a little dry, slightly bitter and nutty, a little bit of prune. Medium body, sleek texture, slightly oily, soft fizz, sweetish and nutty finish. Nice and good for its style, but nothing special.

Many thanks for this beer to kevnic2008. Bugelflasche. Ladna sredniej wielkosci jakosciowa i bardzo trwala piana, barwa klarowna o czerwonym zabarwieniu. Smak gryzacy, wytrawny, nieco drewne nuty, karmel, slodowosc srednia, dosc fajnie chmielnie. Porzadna robota.
Bottle from Landbierparadies24! Pours ruby red with a longlasting off-white head. Aroma of roasted malts and nuts. Taste has lots of hazelnut, slight roasted malts and some sweet caramel.

Draft at the brewery. Clear chestnut brown body with a tan colored head of little retention. Malt is expressed as tootsie roll / caramel chocolate candy with notes of cola and raisin. Strong diacetyl butter taint in the nose with seemingly no hop expression. Light bodied, lightly sweet with low bitterness. It�s under-carbonated but nicely silky / soft in the mouth, but like the nose there�s little authentic malt expression to be found, something like caramel-chews and chocolate cake frosting.
Unlike Baltika�s, this is not bottle-conditioned. Cloudy and very pale. Flavour is quite watery, with a hint of phenols and spice. Bland, with some vegetal notes.
Tasts not very special but is good drinkable................................
Bottled. Cloudy mustard yellow. Vague malt aroma. Some fatty vanilla and an undistinct mellow maltiness. Clean finish. Acceptable, but not very interesting.
Bottle from Cafe Kisimul, Barra. Pours hazy amber. Nose of caramel, grass, moss, hint of fruit. Smooth, balanced.
Very plain nothing tasty at all. Low carbonation, watery, no head. Sweet, no hop or malt taste.

* Bottle. Pours amber, cloudy, with a white head. * Aroma sour malts & fruity hops of apricot & citrus. * Palate is light body, very low carbonation, very fine bubbles, felt watery. * Taste is tart & quite sour, orange, mango, slightly dry, then earthy malts. * Finish is malty, sour, moist, then drying. * Overall very low carbonation, watery, sour, earthy finish.
Bottle at home. Pours clear amber, nose is vegetive, ash, toffee, taste is watery, thin, toffee, sweetcorn.
500ml bottle from Aldi. Pours with a head. Aromas of butter, light malt. Taste is more of the same, faint citrus too. Watery, dull finish.

Bottled, 500ml from Aldi in Ludlow, Shrops. Burnished gold with no head. There is a fusty nose to this on opening and the character does transfer into the beer, quite flat and watery as well, some wet cardboard CO2 notes. Really quite poor, but I was running out of options in the town.
2*500ml bottles from the real ale festival at Aldi. Insipid and watery beer. Very little carbonation, no head. Really very bad. May have been a bad batch.

Bottle from the Scottish Real Ale shop. Appearance - hazy golden with very little head. Nose - lemon zest and astringent malt. Taste - more of the same. Palate - medium bodied with a creamy yet slightly sour middle section and an astringent finish. Overall - the sourness is a concern. Wouldn�t return for a second.
Bottle from Aldi. Poured flat, little aoma, taste is orange and a hin of spice, with little aftertaste. Disappointing
malty/woody nose, coffee, malty, nutty, almondy flavours are present, very full smooth body, dark copper hue with a wonderful head, quality bottle conditioned offering

(Hand Pump) Deep ruby red, vanilla aroma. The appearance was sublime, crystal clear and sparkling. A good drinking beer, although the palate was very hard to define. Blackcurrant with a bitter finish? no not quite. All in all a good beer.
Gravity Cask, Catford Beer Festival. Dark red. Oaty, barley aroma. Nice condition. Dark flavours, some blackcurrant. Very tasty. Good balance of sweet and bitter. Dry finish.

Cask - The Playhouse, Norwich. Amber in appearance with a small off-white head. Plenty of fruit qualities in both aroma and flavour with a caramel backbone. Average mouthfeel. Not one I�d buy again given another choice, but not terrible.
Handpulled cask at the Kings Arms, Norwich. Copper with a thin off white head. Quite fruity with caramel and grassy hops. I didnt like it too much but it wasnt the freshest of pints.
Bottled. Clear amber colour, absolutely no head or retention of any form. Bitter, beer sodden carpet aroma. Bitter, sloppy flavour. Damp, mildew flavour that lingers painfully.
Gravity Cask, Catford Beer Festival. Tindall is a Norfolk micro that opened up in 1998. Pleasantly fruity beer with a nice touch of hops. Finishes well.
Very dark and bitter but balanced by a lighter palate for such a dark roast. Good for someone who only drinks dark beer to have on a warm evening. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cask half at the Volunteers Arms, GBBF. Pours clear dark brown with a beige head. Aroma of chocolate with vanilla. Similar taste. Mild bitter finish. Was on the bar when this won Champion Beer of Britain and it�s still great.

Cask (Kingston Arms, Cambridge). Clear dark chestnut brown color. Medium size, tan head, stays. Looks nice. Roast, touch of caramel, berries in aroma. Roast, caramel, woody, fruity in taste. Mild and mellow mouthfeel. Very nice balance and super drinkability. Prime example how mild should be! Excellent brew.

Did this beer win the Best British Beer award? That's what I overheard when attending the Chelmsford Winter Beer Fest 2018, so I had to try a pint. Was a really nice balanced mild, with a good head and a nice rounded sweet malty body. I was impressed enough to have a few.

Cask at GBBF 2017, Olympia, London, Aug 2017 and at Twickenham BF 2007 - Reddish brown in colour. Good foamy tan head. Malty; roasty malts, dark chocolate, coffee. Fruity; berry fruits. Hoppy; slight hop bitterness. Bittersweet roast chocolate malty and fruity. Bitter malty finish. Lots of flavour for low ABV. Liked this. Nice Mild. (2017-08)
Cask at Wenlock Arms, Hoxton, London. Clear brownish red. Caramelly, nutty and slightly roasted malt aroma. Semi dry, low to medium bitterness.
Cask at The Great British Beer Festival 2017, Kensington Olympia. Sweet and malty, with dark bread notes.
Nice tasting session mild. If I see it on tap I will always have a pint!
Cask. Coca Cola brown appearance, hardly any head. Aroma- malty caramel, dark malts. Taste- treacly, biscuity malt, hints of chocolate. Good.

Dark ruby color with a fine tan head. Ok intensity in the aroma. Medium light body and a soft carbonation level. A bit to sweet texture. Sherry-ish, fruity and toffee in the flavor. [Handpull at Orange Tree in Chelsford, England] Brewery #1611
Bottle. Black. Lightly roasted malty porter, sourish taste, thin body. Added port not self evident. Soft bittersweet, rather dry, finish. OK. (2008)
9th July 2008. BBE of Nov 2006! Quite a soft porter. The port doesn�t really present itself other than possibly being responsible for the pronounced fruity tone. Not too dry.

[500ml bottle from The Real Ale Shop, Priory Farm, Wrentham, Suffolk] Pours deep crimson/black, with no head at all. Big lumps of sediment at bottom. Initially tastes weak and watery before a slight chocolate flavour comes through, followed by a big wallop of damsons and sloes. The sourness of the damsons dominates unpleasantly mid-drink before the intense dryness of the sloes comes through. The aftertaste develops through burnt woody notes into a slightly smokey dryness. In fact dryness in the dominant characteristic. Despite this, I�d agree with others who have said that this should posssibly be classified as a mild rather than a porter. However, despite being quite an interesting and unusual mild I wouldn�t number it amongst my favourites. Still a decent beer though - give it a go if you fancy something different.
Bottle. Black beer with a lightly roasted and coffee aroma, and a quite tart and vinegar flavour. Overall a weird but OK porter.
Gravity cask @ Reading Beer Festival 2006. Almost vinous dark berries. Light roast lavours. Thin and dry - could do with a bit more oomph.
Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Reading BF. A black beer with a fruity smoky roasty aroma. The taste has some nice sour roasty notes. Decent if a little thin.
Cask Conditioned at Reading BF 2006. Black with a tan head. Thin roasted malt, a touch harsh with some balanced sweetness.
Cask @ Reading 06: Black with a fluffy tan head. Simple oat-like bready notes. Mild chocolate malt. Not bad.
Cask gravity Reading BF 06. Black beer with disappearing beige head. Bit of a thin porter, I certainly didn�t get any port out of it. Some nice tarryness, just not very much else
Gravity at Reading beer festival 2006. Good depth of flavour: oil, breakfast cereal. Some choc. Nice.

column1: Hal and Mals Half Moon Light
column5: Rich, malty lage aroma with earthy notes. Clear American Standard yellow color with tall head. Acidic, well-hopped. Tangy finish, but it loses CO2 and was a little watery.

column1: Hal and Mals Half Moon Light
column5: Sorry, but this was really shitty. The color was a deep yellow, unlike most light beers, but they somehow managed to take out ALL of the flavor!!!! I actually found one with less taste than michelob ultra!

Date: 03/22/2005 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub hazy yellow, headless, sweet malt aroma, creamy body, light and flavorless, touch of bitterness in the finish, Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 2/10; Flavor: 2/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 5/20 Rating: 1.7/5.0 Score: */4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
Boring. There�s no flavor at all. I couldn�t really find hops or malt. There�s a slightly hazy yellow body and it was served with no head. It�s not bad, it�s just not really there.
Light, earthy and slightly floral aroma. Deep amber gold with webby head. Citrus and floral notes and an almost golden ale mouthfeel. Tart and fruity finish which I found a little too acidic.

Date: 03/22/2005 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub hazy amber, scant head around the edges of the glass, light sweet malt flavor, light bitterness in the finish, not much character Aroma: 2/10; Appearance: 2/10; Flavor: 2/10; Palate: 2/10; Overall: 5/20 Rating: 1.1/5.0 Score: */4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
There�s a little bit of malt character, but the flavor is short and small. Clearer than the other beers as well. It has a light brown body and was served with no head.
very little aroma; dark brown color; probably the best of their beers I've tried
I enjoyed this one with good friends and decent music at Hal and Mal's. I was delighted to pay only 2.50 for a beer that far outperforms budcoorsmiller and many other mass produced beers.
Bottled, Thanks Per. Hazy,orangish brown color, no head at all. Aroma and flavor are very carmelly with notes of noble hops. Some honey flavor. Buttery mouthfeel. Dry hoppy finish. Interesting beer.

Bottled. Despite the fact that this is the pale version it is cloudy ornage-brown and has a balsamic toffee aroma. It is sweet, mild and softly malty with mild honeyish finish. Where most Russian beers are unrefined and sluggish this is a subtle, complex beer.

Bottled. Like the pale Admiral the label states 6.8%, but their website says 6.2%. Regardless, it pours mahogany coloured and has a pleasant, roasty, lighty chocolatey aroma. It is dryish, mild and lightly fruity with a velvetty, woody finish.

dirty dark-amber colour, absolutely no foam, bready and unfermented malt in the nose, low carbonation, some acidity, dry aftertaste of unfermented malt - tastes like a failed homebrew, it's just totally awful. I think Per has tried to infect me with this one :-)
Bottled. Orange-brown and cloudy with rich head. Acidic toffee nose. Light bodied, sweet and mild with low bitterness.

Cask version served at Great Taste of the Midwest. Very nice hoppy aroma. Some off notes from molasses. Beautiful color. Murky reddish yellow in color. Head mostly dissipating. Cask smooth. Very good flavor.
A perfectly acceptable IPA, but not a memorable one, at least not on a first sampling.
Had this one on tap during a SNOBS tour of the new production brewery. It poured a nice copper color, good hop balance, I think it�s a good rendition of an Alt.

on tap @ Brew Kettle, looks amber fore taste is some hop taste, which follows with a mish mash of malts, then boring... just very bland finish to me perhaps that is to style though? Either way was pleasurable to drink.

Poured from the tap, color is a muddy amber-brown with a medium light tan head and minimal lacing. Soft chocolate aroma that�s nutty with a hefty roasted sweetness. Medium bodied with a surprisingly assertive bitterness. Very well balanced, rich and creamy. Outstanding flavor, lots of depth. Creamy malts with hints of toasted bread, nuts, burnt chocolate, and caramel. Slightly grassy with plenty of fresh noble hops. Great rendition of a hard to find style.
On tap at the Brew Kettle. A deep brown color with a thin off-white head. Nice hoppy aroma, earthy with a caramel malty sweetness. Similar flavor, good mouthfeel and a dry bitter finish. A nice alt.

On tap from Brew Kettle. Copper in color, served in a nice mug! (I know, not a big deal, but I think it was my first beer out of a mug!) Hah...Smell of hops and carmel. Taste of hops, caramel, malts and nuts...This one had a slightly hoppy, bitter finish which I didnt entirely care for, but still a very decent beer.
On tap @ Brew Kettle: Copper color with an off white head. Aroma, grassy hops, some bready yeast notes. Flavor, soft carbonation, bready, caramel, a light herbal bitterness. Very pleasant beer.

Draft at the brewpub. Aroma: Lots of German malt, toasted nuts, and a nice earthy hop note. Very light grape aroma. Appearance: Coppery red in color and fairly clear. Off-white head was full and creamy with good retention. Nice lacing. Flavor: Nice maltiness upfront with some light caramel and toasted nuts. Some spicy/earthy hops into the finish. Bitterness was just enough. Good clean finish. Palate: Medium bodied. Moderate carbonation. Overall: Good, easy to drink beer.

Bomber Bottle, in .25 l straight-sided glass. My sample is just labeled "Brew Kettle German Style Alt (old) Beer," which the bartender said shouldn�t be rated because it was not being commercially served. But this bottle, from the cooler of the BOP section, has the ol� gov�t warning on its label, and other non-Ringneck stuff has rated pretty well, here, so I�ll assume this is the same recipe, except this one may be extract-based. Deep coppery pour with a frothy, persistent eggshell head. A Munich/Vienna malt nose that does taste a little like extract and steeped grains. Smell is bit hard for me with a swollen nose right now, but I can get pleasant hint of a little hops and a very slight smokiness, perhaps a bit nutty, too. I agree that it�s a very clean beer. I had thought I shouldn�t hold on to this much longer because it might not have been filtered, conditioned or pasteurized, but it had held up very well. Ultimately, the taste is a little on the light side for what should be a hoppy German style, but there is nothing displeasing about it.
Pours a medium reddish brown with a good, airy head. The aroma is lightly hoppy with a solid caramel maltiness. The flavor is malty with only a little hops.

This bottled brew poured a large sized head of fine to medium sized ling lasting off-white colored bubbles that left behind a fair lacing. The body was transparent softly carbonated and caramel brown in color. It had a mild caramel malt aroma. The mouth feel was tingly and somewhat smooth with a caramel malt flavor in the finish. The flavor contained notes of caramel and malt.
In the bottle in my microbeer of the month club. On the thin and unimpressive side. Hops seemed non-existent. Their pilsner was much better, even though I'm not much of a pils fan.

On tap at Nashville Airport - Medium brown, clear, light to medium body. Virtually no head but did produce some lacing. Aroma hints of hazelnut, molasses, strong coffee, and smoke. Moderately sweet and acidic, major coffee taste with maple and buttery hints. Oily texture, soft carbonation, dry finish with a nutty and mildly hoppy twang on the aftertaste. Overall a little too thin and a little too one-diminsional.
1/2 pint (3.9%) by hand-pump on 23 Mar 2019: grassy, grain, malty aroma, pale golden thin white head, very sparse lacing , cereal, grassy malty flavour, creamy, bittersweet finish.
Sample at the three hulats Jdw. Medium creamy white head. Clear golden pour. Light bitterness.

Seriously the nicest tasting and smelling blonde bitter ever. You can tell that quality ingredients are used in making Daleside Blonde and that no expense is spared in the quantity either. This really is a yard stick for other brewers as it's flavours compliment each other. It's light, pleasant and not heavy to drink at all.

Cask at ORB, Darlington. Pale yellow gold blonde colour, white foam head leaving lacing and tropical fruity & citrus hoppy aroma. Taste is pale malt, biscuit, nutty with floral citrus hop and light bitter. Smooth mouthfeel, light bodied, soft carbonation, semi-dry finish. Quite drinkable.
On tap at the Dog & Bone, Lincoln. Golden colour with a thick white head. Taste is sweet malty and a touch of citrus. Light bitter finish.
Cask, Seabirds, Flamborough, North Humberside. From 2008 Notes. Pours light amber smallish head. Medium bodied. Caramel sweetness. Enjoyable

Cask at Cuthbert Brodrick, JDW, Leeds. Pours clear pale gold, thick foamy white head. Aromas of light lemon, light caramel. Taste is more of the same. Light trailing bitterness. Bit watery. OK session beer.
Cask the tap room batley. Aroma is citrus. Golden colour ok white head. Taste is sweet malts light citrus some hops light bitterness. Medium body. Ok session ale.

Gravity dispense at the Happy Man Spring BF, 14/03/14. Clear golden with a moderate off white covering. Nose is orange sherbet, bread dough, straw, lemon rind. Taste comprises caramel notes, toasty, citric sherbetdom, melon, light bread. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, semi drying close. Ok GB.
Cask at The Coach and Horses, Harrogate, September 2013. Clear gold with white head. Malt. caramel candy and scone aroma, faint bitterness in the mouth. Buttery aftertaste, medium body.
at GABBF 2012. OK aroma, tart. Little nutty, little bready. Orangy gold color, no head or lace. Bitter flavor. Lite body, smooth mouthfeel, bitter finish, solid pale ale, easy to drink,
Draft at GABBF. Hazy golden color. Plain bitter aroma and flavor. Easily drinkable.

Kodiak Island Brewing Company--Liquid Sunshine. 5.00% ABV--35 IBU�s. Growler and on tap @ Kodiak Inn Chartroom Lounge. Mild lace head. Slightly hazy bright rich golden color. Mild floral hop front. Crisp mild sweet fruit mellow ester clean butterscotch Golden Ale body. Clean mild earthy tangy hop citrus end. Refreshing tasty brew. (3.5 / 5.0) Sampled 6/10/2005.
On tap @ Cafe Amsterdam, Anchorage. Typical California Common with just a bit more hop flavor. Light roasty flavor balanced well with the hops. My wife really liked this beer.

Draft@ Cafe Amsterdam ANC. Hazy light amber color with a fleeting white head. Subtle aromas of sweet bread malts with light floral hops. Medium body. Nice flavor is light sweetbread pale malts with a touch of floral hops. No off flavors, very easy drinking Pale Ale here.

Handbottled. A slightly hazy amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of caramel as well as light citrusy hoppy notes. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of straw, caramel, and citrus.

Handbottled from tap. Clear amber coloured with a small white head. Fruity aroma of caramel, berries and hops. Fruity flavour of caramel, berries and hops with notes of grass and yeast. Dry hoppy finish.

From PET bottle. Pours almost fully clear golden orange with a small almost white head. Light citrusy hops aroma. Flavour is mild sweet, slight grassy and mild citrusy in hops profile. Mild bitterness towards a light finish. Mild spiced and bitter hoppy finish.
Had it at Kodiak while stationed there. The best one to my taste of the beers brewed by Kodiak Island Brewery. Sweet and lemon taste.

Sampled at the �08 GABBF. Golden color with very little of an off white head. Wet cereal grain nose . This beer has a simple sweetness to it with some lemon citrus and a light bready foundation. Not very interesting, but would be a nice dinner beer with lighter fare.

Kodiak Island Brewing Company--North Pacific Ale. 4.50% ABV--30 IBU�s. Rich lacy head. Clear dark amber color. Malty earthy mild toasted floral hop front. Crisp toasted mild sweet biscuit caramel toffee earthy Scottish ESB body. Clean mild tangy hop spice end. Smooth tasty brew. Organic. (4.0 / 5.0) Sampled on Draft @ Kodiak Inn ChartRoom Lounge 5/8/2005. Kodiak Island Brewing Company--North Pacific Ale. 4.50% ABV--20 IBU�s. Growler from Brewery shipped via Coastal to Seattle. Mild lacy head. Hazy bright light amber gold color. Slightly fruit mild hop front. Smooth malty fruit ester caramel body with hint of Scottish peat. Clean citrusy fruit mild hop end. OK, but did not hold up in shipping. (3.25 / 5.0) Sampled 6/11/2005.

Plastic container. A hazy amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of caramel and nice spicy hops. The flavor is sweet and very malty combined with hops and a light roasted edge, leading to a dry and slightly roasted finish. The body is a bit thin.

Handbottled from tap. Cloudy golden coloured with a fast disappearing white head. Fruity aroma of caramel, hops and pine needles. Fruity flavour of caramel, hops and pine needles with notes of berries. Dry hoppy finish.

1 gallon plastic container. Pours cloudy orange with a shortlived and little head. Aroma is lovely peachy and sweet fruity. Mild caramel malt accent. Nice caramel malty and sweet flavoured with a solid hoppy peachy flavour. Smooth and hoppy finish with a decent bitterness to break the sweetness and fruity flavours.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Country Ale
column5: Bottle 50cl. Foggy bronze colour. Big and stable ivory head. The aroma is modest. Vague caramel, esters and hops. Medium to full body. Creamy texture. The taste is medium dry. Caramel, nuts, floral hops. Light bitterness. Decent.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Country Ale
column5: Honey, cardboard, toffee malt, and straw aroma. Dark amber with moderate head. Moderately sweet toffee malt and moderately bitter herbal hay flavor. Nice body. Good - wish I could have had a fresher bottle though.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Country Ale
column5: Bottle - heavy carbonation, light brown with small head. Fairly strong hoppy aroma. Ting on tongue and in mouth. Strong tasting, full bodied, bitter finish - strong aftertaste.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Country Ale
column5: Amber haze colour with creamy white head. Visualy medium carbonation. Aroma without notice of an alcohol:you can detect fruity-floral notes with sweetness of malts. Taste is the same, finish slightly dry. Malt sweetness is medium, also hop bitterness. Proper beer for its style.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Country Ale
column5: The body has a deep amber color with a burnt orange to reddish highlight. It has tons of visible carbonation rushing up to its thick and creamy head. The tightly packed off white head leaves lots of cool lace patterns and rings on the glass. It�s malty and sweet with notes of caramel and toffee. Underneath the maltiness is a mild dried leafy/herbal and slightly mineral like hop presence. Meeting on the tongue are wonderful malty bready notes with hints of bready yeast, caramel and toffee with mellow fruitiness. Light leafy and herbal hops add a pleasant balance of mild bitterness to the finish. Its mouth feel is a solid medium to full and smooth as silk with mellow carbonation.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Country Ale
column5: # 3444 ersma: dorothy, die nette dame auf dem etikett, zieht sich f�r jede sorte was andersfarbiges an. das ist witzig. braun-kupferfarben mit mittelviel schaum. der geruch ist malzig-s��lich mit karamellnote. der antrunk ist ale-ig, s��lich mit viel karamell, aber auch leicht fruchtige und bittere anfl�ge. die mitte wird herber und bitterer, auch hier karamell, dazu etwas herbe kr�uter. der abgang ist bitterer, s��liche aromen mehr im hintergrund, deutlich herber. die flasche ist ansehnlich. fazit: solide. gut trinkbar. 10,10,9,10,13,10 - 10,00

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Country Ale
column5: light sweet alcoholic aroma,amber, hazy, off white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, oily feel, soft carbonation, light sweet dry finish.may be too old.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Country Ale
column5: Light amber and hazy. Has an off-white head, lasting. Aroma is heavy sweet, some odd fruity notes too. Perhaps light hops. Flavor is heavy sweet, light bitter finish. Creamy texture.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Country Ale
column5: Barely any aroma. If anything, a slightly TCP tinged malty character. Looks good though, dark brown / reddish with a good amount of bubbles rising for the style. Thick, sweet, caramel deep malt flavour balances well with the bitterness from the hops. Can taste the alcohol, good full body, almost oily. A great standard beer.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Country Ale
column5: 500 ml bottle at home. Stood for two days and poured carefully into a pint shaker, but still more cloudy than expected. Hazy brown, with minimal head. Caramel malt aroma with a splash of Cointreau. This is repeated in the flavour, along with dried fruit and nuts. Deceptively thin mouthfeel for the ABV, but as a number of raters point out, this hides its alcohol well, and drinks more like a premium bitter, particularly as there is a hop astringency to the finish.

Tap at town hall 7 corners. Hazy light orange with small white head. Typical hefe nose of banana, citrus, etc. Sweet citrus, banana, tart and yeast taste. Crisp, medium body. Decent, typical for the style.

5 oz. pour, on tap at Town Hall Station. Consumed on 6-24-17. Cloudy, bright orange-golden. Small amount of off-white head. Pleasant, fresh, yeasty, bubblegum aroma. Not the most complex smell but a nice one. Nice, sharp flavor. On the dry side but with a softly bubblegum finish. A touch of lemon. Light to medium body. Frothy in the palate. Good liveliness. An above average hefeweizen. 7.4.7.3.14=>3.5

Draught at the brewery. Pours cloudy orange with a medium, creamy white head, medium retention. Aroma is moderate banana esters, clove phenols and grainy wheat malt. Flavor is moderate clove phenols, light citrus, banana esters, spicy hops and light bitterness, grainy wheat malt with a dry finish. Medium body and moderate carbonation.

Hazy yellow pour at the brewery with a thick white head and some white lacing. Nice slightly spicy / banana / clove nose. Refreshing, yeasty, slight cracker going on in there and just a hint of acid mixed in with the the banana phenolics.

Keg @ Town Hall. Hazy gold with a tight creamy white head. Classic nose. Plenty of banana and clove. Bubblegum sweetness. Bread. Taste is crisp. Bright. Mashed banana and sugared cereal. Some pear juice. Spritzy finish. Light and active on the palate. Decent.
On tap at the brewery. Light. Citrus. Wheat. Crisp. Refreshing. Yeast. Bright.

Sampled from the tap at the brewpub. Pours a cloudy yellow with a touch of orange and a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a good amount of clove with some sweet wheat and a bit of bread. Flavor has a nice combination of wheat and clove with a nice light earthiness.
Tap - small foamy head, very hazy orange-yellow color, pretty big shot of typical hefe banana and clove aroma and flavor, sweet wheat backbone, good hefe overall ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours cloudy bright yellow with a nice white head. Aroma of banana big time. Taste is a lot of banana and medium thick body. A little one dimensional but decent. Just missing that real German full yeast flavor. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at the brewpub. I came in from walking around so I wanted something refreshing. This really hit the spot. A well-made, classic style hefe with iconic yeast. Slightly more bready than a true German hefe, but still worthy. Served in a standard pint glass though.

Appearance: a clear, coppery reddish hue, with a solid white head, soft and creamy. Aroma: clean to the point of empty, but not without it's good points, still fresh and zesty. On the palate: a neat little blitz of hops storms a quick buzz, but fades soon thereafter. Body is light/medium. Tasty fruitiness (cherries, grapes) pervades the flavor profile, and remains throughout consumption of this very satisfying, and flavorful ale. After the pint was drained, I had one on cask, and it was creamier, lighter, smoother, utterly delicious.

Clear copper body with small off-white head. Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, orange, roasty. Taste is mildly sweet, roasted/smokey, with mild bitterness in the aftertaste. Crisp medium body, freshness is noticeable. High carbonation, some acidity.

From old tasting notes. Translucent, deep orange brown color. Huge creamy tan head. Faint toasted malt nose with notes of pine needles. Sweet roasted malt flavor is lightly carbonated. Pleasant hop finish. Nice Belgian lace.
12oz bottle (Old Notes)-Pours a reddish brown with a decent sized head. Aroma of malt, caramel, and slight toffee. Taste of the same. This light to medium bodied brew is pretty bad.
I drank this for years before the craft beer revolution. The label and clear brown color were much more inviting than Bud. Very bland by current craft beer standards.
Pours a weak head with an aroma that smells slightly of malt vinagar. Flavors of molasses, malt, and carbonation. I wasnt to impressed with this. It reminds me of a simple home brew.

From a twist-off green 12 oz. bottle, no freshness date, sampled in a pint glass. Poured a clear reddish hued toffee brown with a small tan head that quickly settled into a fine sudsy lacing. Aromas of prune juice, milk chocolate and caramel, hints of toasted grains. Steady carbonation, more light bodied than medium, smooth and easy drinkability, the tastes can be a bit thin and watery, but overall, and for the cheap price, not the bad, passable, thin chocolate and caramel malts, some sugary maltiness too, the prune juice flavor is more restrained than in the smell, a light toasted graininess emerges in the end, touches of soft hop spiciness in the finish also. For the price, a nice beer for the budget minded, often in the singles rack at the liquor stores in my area.
Chicago trip. Tuesday 12:15. Bottle at Old Chicago by O�Hare. Dark copper. Doppelbock prune aroma. Flavour of raisins, chocolate and prune.

After trying the skunky Augsburger Golden I was a little leary to try this one, but I�ll try anything once. Pours a clear dark brown brew with a fast dissolving off white head. Very little lacing if any. Aroma of roasted nuts, medium malt, caramel, and a touch of toffee. Taste is highly carbonated, nutty, and some corn. Finish is watery with a hint of bitter aftertaste. Though it comes in a green bottle, at least this one was not skunky as the Augsburger Golden. The Augsburger from Huber was better.
A light dunkel. Light roasted aroma and flavor of lightly roasted barley, butter, and nuts. Thin. Not bad for the dollar I paid for it.
Pourts a nice dark brown. Aromas of toffee/caramel malt. Nice soft malty flavor with hints of hops.

In the bottle at the Huber Haus Mug Club wildcat tasting. Dark brown in color with a slightly of-white head. Even though it is in a green bottle, it had not skunked. Mild caramel aroma and an acceptable amount of malt flavor and body for a $4.99 six pack. Minimal hop bitterness.

Unique and unexpected aroma of tart black cherry, pineapple sweetness, plum, fresh earth, and does indeed have a bit of a smoky, spicy, meaty quality, along with some roasty malt and fudgy chocolate. Opaque, thick-looking murky black color, lightly coating the glass, with an uneven, subsiding head. Flavor begins with a grainy, roasty coffeeish maltiness, shortly becoming tangy, tart and fruity with notes of prune, cherry and licorice, finishing with a blend of pineapple and grapefruit juice, wood, vinegar, spices, pepper, doughy yeast and faint brown sugar. Dry, grainy palate, full-bodied and lightly warming. Quite challenging and hard to rate. Comes in a ludicrously huge 22 oz. bottle; certainly seems a natural candidate for a 7-10 oz. 'nip' bottle. Only really approachable at 60 F+. Thanks to Kinz for the opportunity to sample this esoteric and exceedingly rare Imperial. I'm also not sure if it's truly enjoyable, but it is kind of fascinating in a strange way. Seems to be perhaps an attempt at an A. Le Coq-style Imperial Stout?

My pleasure to add another beer to the bin. Found this Legend product lurking amongst their standard brewery offerings at the corner wine and beer store. Pours a pitch black. Light barely penetrates around the edges. Rapidly diminishing medium brown head, but leaves a ring around the edge of the glass. Smells like a steak that has been marinating in worcestishire (sp?) and onions. Sort of weird. The flavor is of grilled steak with some A1 sauce splashed over it. I'm not certain if I like this or not. The whopping 11% is pretty cleverly hidden behind the malt attack. Finishes sort of sweet and sour. To the brewer's credit, they were clearly trying to make something different, and they succeeded. I've never tasted anything quite like this before. There are definitely hops there, but I can't figure out what the heck they are. I pretty much try anything my local breweries put out, and I commend the effort at expirementation, but I'm not quite completely on board with this brew. Though I am definitely "feeling" this one.
Slightly dryish, with a perfumey accent. Limpid blonde colour. Drinkable, as adjunct-laden ales go, but not recommended.

Quite surprising for me. I thought it would be bad but it is decent and mid range. However there is a SPIDER FLOATING IN MY BEER AND I JUST OPENED IT!!!!!!!!!!!! IF IT WASNT FOR THIS SITE I WOULD HAVE DRANK IT!!!!!! Bob and Doug anyone at least it wasn't a mouse!!!!!!!!!! Okay its okay except for the spider... it was a little one though. Nice pillowy white head that is really large. Somewhat sweet malty, grainy aroma.... Malty sweet head. And slight bitters.. PS I didn't rate the spider... however maybe it's like tequila??? hmmmm Since then I've opened another bottle and it had a hair in it... root and all.... ughghgh... I'm writing a letter to Molson!
Gravity @ Hants Bowman, Dundridge (21/07/05). Malty nose with no suggestion of hops. Off-dry with hop flavours and little maltiness in the taste. Strange but not bad.

Regulation amber colour. Dry, vaguely malty, a touch of earthy hop. Rather thin. A run of the mill session bitter. Nothing wrong with it, but not much to comment on or enthuse about. Cask (gravity dispense), Battersea Beer Festival, February 2005.
Cask at Battersea Beer Festival 2005 (Thursday). Amber and hazy. Fruity aroma with a bit of sulphur. Dry, fruity and a little sweet and some hop bitterness. Gritty.

Cask Conditioned, at the Wenlock Arms, with SilkTork This beer made it clear to me that a mans liver should not be wasted on crap beer. When there�s lots to sample, then there is much work to be done. Despite the advice of SilkTork, I heroically pushed on with the sampling of all beer by the pint. Trouble was that this beer was very ordinary. So ordinary that I laboured through it for what seemed and eternity, whilst SilkTork was splitting his sides at my dispare. We had a blinder that night at the Wenlock (see the last beer of the night - Mahrs Br�u by SilkTork). Lots and lots of nothing in a glass. Also sampled cask fresh at the Black Jug Horsham. Bright amber coloured body, sudsy grey head. Strong session bitter, lip smacking and generous. Wonderful bitter indeed, pulled on especially for my thirsty lips. Scored 3.3

June, 2003: Wenlock Arms. Beer has a ripe banana aroma with the banana continuing into the flavour. That�s the best that can be said for this watery session bitter - thin body, light hops and a banana skin waved in the general direction of the liquid to provide some kind of taste. Spiesy, the poor bastard, drank a whole pint of this. [1.8] Jan, 2005: Black Jug, Horsham. This is the dry hopped Black Jug version. Chocolate and coffee notes in a gulpable session bitter. Body is quite light, bordering on lean, but flavours are inviting. Acidic aroma. While at the bar a customer asked for a sample, saying he�d heard it was a bad beer. After the sample he ordered a different beer. Clearly a beer with some character! [2.7]
Sain sen kollegalta syntym�p�iv�ni. Maukas, kevyt mutta ei mit��n erikoista

On tap at J. J. Bitting. Pours a murky browned light amber with a thin white head. Sweet malt, caramelized bananas, yeast and wheat. Nice amount of wheat and banana flavors coming through. Toast and caramelized banana again. Sweet and wheat filled, musk and toast. Not my favorite style, but this is well executed. Another big beer (at 7.4%) where the alcohol is hidden nicely.
Draft. Pours cloudy dark amber. Nose and taste of banana, chocolate, dark wheat malt and spicy wheat. Medium body.
Draft. Pours deep amber with an off white head. Nice fruity yeasty aroma with sweet caramel malty notes. The flavor is toasty, sweet, and wheaty, some fruity yeasty notes. Nice.
Nice Dunkelweizen with a strong wheat flavour and aroma. The chocolate is much less pronounced but gives it good character. I didn�t taste or smell any hops. Nice palate.

Sampler at the brewpub. Cloudy brown color with aromas of spiced dark quickbread with some banana yeast. A little touch of stale butter (diacetyl?) as well which eventually dissipated. Off-sweet dark malty flavor with some overripe bananas, fruit, spices and a mild roasty bitterness on the finish.

on tap-pours a creamy light brown head, clings to glass with cloudy reddish-brown color. Aroma is dark malt, sweet, bubblegum. Taste is dark malt, sweet, bubblegum, chocolate, wheat. Medium body, good carbonation.
On tap at the Brew Pub. Poured a dark brown color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of light chocolate and lightly fruity. Fruity tasting. Very light lacing left on the glass.

Thin dense creamy head of very fine bubbles. Muddy dark brown in color. Interesting aroma with roasted grains, a bit of banana and . Little tart flavor with plenty of body. Little chalky with a nice roastyness and a bit of chocolate. FInish is nice and creamy with a bit of bitterness and a nice lingering roasty flavor. I liked this one a lot as a whole.
Dark brown topped with a slight off white head. Strong banana in nose. Rather tart with a slight hoppy finish. Sligtly above average Dunkleweizen.

Bottle. Clear golden color with white head. Aroma is earthy, herbal, a bit caramel malts, some barn. Taste is earthy, rustic, caramel, grains, a bit cooked stuff. Mineraly mouthfeel, quite chewy, a bit chalky, sparkly carbonation. Rough, but actually quite tasty
Bottle.amber, big bottle, fairly rural, grain, barn, light farty, herbal bitterhops. Medium body, chewy mellow. nice.

Low Carbonated Beer pours into the Glass. The foam stability is medium and the body amber. The Aroma is malty, flowery, a bit hoppy. The taste is malty, darkmalty, a bit bitter, fruity, a bit fermented darkfruits. Rather of the kind which they call "ungespundetes" in Frankonia when its abut lower/natural Carbonation. The low carbonation, supports the balance of the beer and makes it a great easy drinkable one with always a intense and cofortable taste.
Leicht tr�bes goldgelbes Pils mit einer ordentlichen wei�en Schaumkrone. Geruch floral hopfig, grasig. Geschmack sehr hopfig, grasig, floral, nett!
Pours a golden color with minimal head. Simple hay aroma, lightly grassy flavours with not much else going on.

(bottle) Clear, golden colour with a blond medium-sized foamy head. Citric and herbal hoppy aroma with mildly bready cara-malt. Bitter-sweet flavour, light to medium bodied with a soft carbonation. Present cara-malty body with fruity and herbal hops; medium-dry bitter-sweet and elegantly hoppy finish. Recommended. 10.VIII.12
It�s golden with a creamy, white head and the aroma has notes of malt and straw. The flavor has a light sweetness and notes of malt, straw, a little bread and flower, and the finish is slightly dry.
Bottle. Clear golden with medium off-white head. Flavour is malt, butter, spices, hops and a little citrus-

Bottle 500ml. @ HenrikSoegaard Sommerhus Tasting - Handrup Strand. Clear medium yellow colour with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, butter, light hoppy, perfume. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110626]
Bottle. Pours a light yellow with a small white head. Aroma with notes grain, malt and hops. Palate is quite watery and finish is bitter, but short.
Bottle. Clear yellow colour with small creamy white mostly diminishing head. Hoppy aroma. Sweet bitter flavor.
Bottle. Frothy white fair mostly deminishing head. yellow colour. Light bitter flavor. Average light bitter finish. oily palate.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are malt, butter, grass and hops.
Bottle split with Caesar and Dutchdrebus. Clear golden color, white head. Smell and taste malts, nicely bitter, malty bitter, easy drinkable. Pleasant. 7-4-7-4-14

Bottle. Unclear pale yellow color with white head. Aroma is cooked veggies, lots of it, some pale malts. Taste is cooked veggies, some grassy hops, crackery malts. Oily mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Not impressive.
Bottle.dms grass and hay nose. Golden, off-white cream. Medium body, chewy. Mellow light grain, alright grassy hop counterpoint, no offflavor on the palate.

column1: Limonaderie du Ventoux Biere au Petit Epeautre
column5: Bottle. Cloudy dirty pale colour. Faint aroma of orange vomit. Thin watery beer with a dirty dish-water flavour. Some hints of orange peel. Not very good. The brewery is actually a lemonade maker who is branching out into beer production to make ends meet. There is an encouraging growth of traditional breweries in the south of France, but this one just doesn't cut the mustard. We popped in to visit, but the brewer was too busy bottling lemonade to sell us any of his beers. His stuff is, however, available in the major supermarkets in the area.

column1: Limonaderie du Ventoux Biere au Petit Epeautre
column5: Medium hazy gold-yellow with medium shortish lasting off white head. Light yeasty and spicey grassy aroma. V low carbonation with medium soft to watery body. Mild hops and some faint wheat beer character even though the label says barley is the only grain. An interesting traditional local brew. Probably quite refreshing after you cycle to the brewery or sitting in a nearby cafe watching the Tour de France go by.

This is not what I was expecting, the name eludes to mud. I bought this beer because of the Bottle (awsome package) and I was expecting somthing more like a gueinness, or may be that it would seperate in the glass.

Sample at the brewpub. Another mild...hmm, is this going to be the one? Darkish amber, a bit cloudy, delicious very sweet caramel-vanilla nose; oaky flavors, bit on the thin side and papery towards the end. Nope, wasn�t the one.
Had on Cask. Brown Coloring. Good Head. Malt. Bitter. Looks like it could be good...but comes out thin
Cask. Very nice brown color medium head. Aroma has slight malt overtones to it. Taste is malty and a little tart on the end. For a beer so thin, the malt profile is incredible.

On Cask: Solid brown with highlights of dark maple syrup, a one finger high head of creamy, liquid oatmeal-looking head of creamy color sits atop, lacing in thick patches, quite a good looking brown. Smell is mild, roasty, clean, lightly tangy and a bit faint. Taste is mild tangy roastyness of malts, a bit of grains and a nice twingy-like bitterness into the finish. Feel is light to medium bodied with a touch of grainyness throughtout, a tad to thin and watery in the overall feel. This brown looked amazing, but came up a little short in every other aspect. Their Chalk Board states "...as rich and dark as the river itself" I don't know if thats a good thing, cuz just a few days ago they found a dead body just down by the sewer treatment plant, it was in the Pioneer Press. So I told em they may want to rethink the slogan for that one.
(cask) Clear copper with medium beige head. Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, toasty. Taste is sweet, caramel, finishing with a lightly bitter floral. Quite pleasant.

Pours a hazy light amber, with maybe a quarter inch of white head. Nearly all of the foam dissipates quickly, what remains leaves isolated traces of lace. Very light scent of wheat and lemon. Lightly sweet maltiness followed by a faint grassy/lemon taste. Thin body, very light carbonation. Refreshing but fades a bit too quickly.

Im not a big Hefeweizen fan, but i tried a sample of this at GW. Not sure if this is the exact one as no one has rated it in two years! They said it was there Hefe beer, but i dont see it listed on their website either, but oh well. To sweet for my liking. To banana-ey smelling, and i hate bananers!
Festival tap: Grayish yellow with nice estery nose. Banana nose comes through in the taste, Thick bodied, spices all over. Long estery finish.

Sample at the brewpub. Rather pale, cloudy but not opaque, no head. Bananas and a bit of caramel in the nose. Creamy body, very full, spicy pie flavors: banana, caramel, allspice, cinnamon, vanilla; quite rich. Nice.
Cloudy...light Amber Coloring. Big Head. I thought a very good Hefe.. Yeast, wheat..fruity...very nice and sweet

Cloudy golden color with a monster head. Wheat with some yeast in the nose. The wheat hits your tongue like a ton of bricks. The yeast manages to dissipate before it makes much impact on the taste. Citrusy notes as well (lemon) as well as some hay. Quite a nice Hefe.

Color is a soild lighter gold, pretty hazy, with a whiteish head about a finger high and leaves spotty lace. Smell is light of wheat and yeastyness, quite fresh, some lemony spritzyness but faint. Taste is more of the same, wheat, oats, light yeastyness, lemony cirus, pretty short lived comparativily speaking. Feel is right on but a watery lateness shows through with a touch of soury bitterness. Not bad, good for a summer evening or afternoon lunch, such as I did, to sit back on the patio and enjoy.

Cloudy golden with small white head. Aroma is intense banana, some wheat and a hint of clove. Taste is not as sweet as expected, wheat/banana. Finishes with a lemon sourness. Nice light body and acidity.
Date: November 5, 2011 Mode: Draft Source: Great Waters Brownish amber pour malty/caramel aroma and taste.
Tap at Great Waters in St. Paul, MN. Dark brown pour with a small white head. Caramel scotch aroma. Medium palate. Caramel and vanilla taste. Pretty good.

Mild aroma with dry malt. Great appearance, light red and a thick, long lasting head. Very mild flavor, dry malt and some taste of barley and grain. Bitter overall. This is a rare style so I am not sure what to expect.

Dark Red/Brown Coloring with Light Tan Head. Smokey Aroma. Thin Mouthfeel...Starts Malty and End with a Dry Hop Aftertaste with Light Whisky Notes Popping up Along the Way. Pretty Neutral for a Scottish Ale.
In the cask at the Brewpub. Amber pour with a yellow head. Mouthfeel of high alcohol. No flavor kick. A rather bland beer. Finishes with a nice malty mouth coating and a bitter twang.

Called "SCOTCH ALE" when I was there, but was definitely (abv and body-color/density) a scottish. Cloudy coffee brown. Head stays on (but thin) through a few sips. Light clover-hop effect in aroma and flavor (inseparable). Finish a touch bitter and syrupy. Some nuttiness present. Greasy flat sticky mouthfeel that needs more time to mellow the amber malts with the hops and scottish yeast--reminds me of a homebrewed Scottish 80/- I opened ahead of its ready date. I couldn�t finish this one, though I tried. On cask.

Cask-conditioned: Well.....beyond its lovely sheeting cascade and cloudy, pale brown color this was a big disappointment. Along with its awesome cascade of fast, light yellowy sheets flying up the sides of the glass like the locusts of the apocolypse, the head got to about two fingers high, is white and lumpy with divets and some unclinging lace sheets that faded fairly fast. Smell, well there wasn't much there at all, a big swirl and a big wiff produced a barely noticable sweet malt. Taste is very mild at best, with a very watery sweet malt and mild hop thats a bit bitter sweet. Feel is light and watery clean and a bit gritty and slightly sweetish but mild and played out, one nice highlight was a slight smokey sense that showed up very late in the finish. This was not all that enjoyable, needs alot help for a Scottish ale.

(cask) Hazy dark copper with small tan head. Aroma is moderately sweet (molasses), caramel, light roasty, hint of smoky. Taste is mild caramel up front, the caramel get stronger as it finishes complemented by light peat. Nice medium body.
Smells of molasses and sweet malt, with substantial carbonation raising a white head. Tastes sweet, with hardly any hop presence in aroma. Very slight bitterness. Not terrible, not great.
On tap at the Holborn Whippet, 3/10/2012. Amber with a decent, off-white head. Sweet, fruity beer with a caramel edge and gentle finish. Fine.

Draught at Anno 1900 in L�neburg. Red-amber with a clingy white head and malty caramel and a touch of peachy banana on the nose. Full malty body with hints of nut brittle, then banana and a gentle hop bitterness in the finish.
Pours copper with a white head. Aroma is malt, fruity notes and light yeast. Flavour is malt, pine, grass and fruity notes.

Orange, hazy color. Big white creamy head. Plenty of lacing. Nice malty aroma with some mellow hints of banana. Tastes the same with a nice crisp bitterness. A little sweet. Not too bad for a steam beer.

Draught @ Dronning Louise, Torvet 19, Esbjerg, 6700 Denmark. Clear medium to light amber colour with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, toffee. Flavour is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration, caramel, fruity malt, toffee - banana notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20120216]
Tap @ St. Clements. Clear amber with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, caramel and a little toffee. Flavour is malt, caramel, medium sweet, little toffee and a little bitter.
Amber with a lasting off-white head. Malty aroma of caramel, with herbal hops and a touch of fruit. Sweet fruity, almost winegum-like flavour with caramel notes.
On tap. Clear amber with a small off-white head. Sweetish malty and somewhat caramellish aroma. Medium body, malt and toffee but hardly any hops. However clean and well made. 170212

Tap @ Dronning Louise, Esbjerg. Pours clear amber with a small, creamy, white head. Aroma has caramel, sweet malts, light grass. Highish carbonation, fine dry and living mouthfeel. Flavour has caramel, sweetness, light honey. The sweetness is kinda sugary, but a firm but mild grassy bitterness. Simple but elegant.
Golden color with small white head. A typical light beer light in the hops and in taste. Alittle fruity taste comes through but not much.

Cask @ Moan & Dove, Amherst MA. Pours a ruddy brown colour. Small tan ead. Nutty lightly floral nose. Very drinkable, nice malt backbone, light to medium bodied, finishes partially sour, not terribly impressive. My first cask BBC.
330ml bottle from Sainsburys. Gold with a moderate white head; deep earthy hop aroma; sweet and rich malty flavours; slightly spicy finish.
Pours a glowing copper coloured beer with a good head. Wonderfully full flavoured. Slight carbonation. Complex spicy beer. Nice.

330ml bottle. Pours orange with lively carbonation and no head. Looks a bit like a fizzy drink! Aroma is light and standard lager fare. The taste is malty with a good hop balance coming through in the long finish. Feels quite heavy for a beer of this strength. Good overall.

Bottle 330ml bottle, from Sainsburys. Poured a real dark bronze colour. The aroma is light, but not that malty for an Oktoberfest, style beer. The flavour is hoppy The beer has a nice fresh bittersweet finish.

[i]Bottle, 12-07-07 thanks to Glen for this. [/i] Amber in colour, bit malty and some sweetness but quite flavoursome with a nice hoppy note, served at room temperature as well which seems to bring out a few more flavours, quite nice really.

Aroma is lager malts a bit grainy, some german veriety of hop giving grassy notes. Taste is quite full on, the grainy lager malts are all over you, however there are some hops in here which balance it reasonably.

Not bad as far as it goes. The strong malt is good with a lingering bitter finish. Unfortunately, after this it has a lingering cloying quality that takes away from the beer over all. As far as Meantime goes I�d stick with their IPA or chocolate stout.

Bottled, filtered, 600ml. Gold amber colour with white head. Malty, sweetish beer with a thicker mouthfeel than expected. Toffee caramel note in the background with a biscuity malt. Some lemon, citrus on the finish. Nice easy drinking beer.

Draught (under the Meantime banner) at Brew Wharf at London Bridge (London), a clear golden copper with no head. A clean sweet fruity aroma, slightly vinuous. Carbonated mouthfeel, very sweet, stewed fruit flavour and a dry finish.
Clear chestnut with no head, the aroma is sweet and malty and a lightly hoppy flavour. Nice enough, easily downed.
Cloudy yellow, thin white head. No noticeable aroma.Flavor is light malt, light hops, with a lingering finish

Clear dark brown body with some red light. Candy sugar and leaf-like aroma, lots of lacing on the glass.... with a big ass hop bite. Of course, Tugboat hops the hell out of everything, and sometimes it�s a nice touch, something different than the same old vienna you might see. The malts flavors are sweet and roasty, the body is smooth and theres a touch of sweet strawberries in the finish... bread, berries and peaches are formed from the hops used in this one. Pretty good.
Dark amber with a white head. Aroma is biscuity with some sweetness and earthiness. Flavor is strong malt sweetness and bottom-fermented characteristics. Medium light body and very dry finish.
(RBSG04) Clear amber body with beige head. Aroma is medium sweet, caramel, some earthy. Taste is medium sweet, earthy, caramel, light herbal. Light-medium body. Not to style.

Light hazy gold with some sticky head & light lacing. The aroma is malty with some wheat & banana, very citrusy with hops and some belgian qualities. The flavor is tangy with bitter and sourness. Finishes tangy, weird finish. Not too bad though.

Pours an amber color with a nice fluffy white head. The Vienna is just like TB�s summer ale, sharing a fruity, sourness, grapefruity thing that is overwhelming in my opinion. This brew had a bit more bitterness than the summer ale, but not all that great.
An all around even beer. Defined hop presence with a spiciness- not sure if from the hops or not. Still Tug, still good. Moderate body.

On tap @ Bosco�s in Little Rock. A true black lager with a nice white head and great lacing. Roasted malts dominate the aroma with slightly sweet molasses and bready notes. Taste is rich., smooth and creamy with a great roasted maltiness, a slight hops bitter and even a slight coffee flavor. Very nice black lager.

On tap in Nashville - Opaque black with a small off-white head. Good lacing. Medium-bodied. Major characteristic on the nose is very smokey and roasted malt. Hints of pumpernickel, dark chocolate, mild coffee, spruce, and tawny port. Very complex and if the aroma was a little stronger, would have given it a 10. Good hoppy twang balanced the heavy malt sweetness, slightly vinous and smokey on the palate. Oily and lively mouthfeel. Dry and crisp finish. A rare excellent American version of this style.
This poured a cloudy yellow color with a moderate head. The aroma contains citrus and coriander. The flavor is citrus, cloves, and biscuit. Overall a very nice witbier!

Draft sample at brewpub. Poured hazy golden to yellow color with an average creamy white head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate yeasty sweet citrus aroma. Medium body with a light sticky texture and soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a medium sweet spicy finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met.

Appearance: Pours a lightly hazy, golden-yellow body with a thin, white head. Smell: Delicate wheat nose, very lightly tangy, precedes fruity, slightly sour scents. Particularly distinct are the orange peel and spice notes. Taste: Soft wheat and light pale maltiness with a pinch of table sugar. White peach fruitiness seasoned with coriander. Bitterish Cura�ao orange peel taste. Slight perceived sourness. Light, though balancing bitterness. Drying, lightly crisp finish with a lasting spice note. Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Ample medium-high carbonation. Drinkability: A good, enjoyable witbier to gulp down on the 5 Seasons outside patio on a sultry summer night.

Hazy and cloudy in the pour, with a small dollop of white head. Nice spicy aroma, that really lingers right on into the flavor, which brings forth clove and coriander, with some banana notes on the tail, slightly astringent alcohol bite in the finish that I was not expecting, but overall nicely balanced. A great patio beer for spring
Pours a slightly hazy pale yellow color with a white head. Aroma is wheat, coriander, and some orange peel. Flavor is pilsner malt, wheat, coriander, coriander, and a light bitter finish.
on tap. Slight haze. Mostly clear golden yellow. Thin fizzy white head. Heavy aroma of orange zest, bananans. Flavors of malted wheat and zest. Very light body left nothing in the finish.

Color is a somewhat cloudy amber gold with a thick but not persistent head. Aroma is strong, very wheaty and malty, with strong lemon hints. Flavor is rich, wheaty-malty, with some hop edge to it. Refreshing, smooth, this is a great beer for late summer and early fall.
