column5: Date: 03/22/2005 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub dark ruby, thin tan head, sweet butterscotch aroma, starts off with some malt flavor but drops off to nothing, eventually the flavor reappears but is not an improvement, too much bitterness in the finish Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 2/10; Palate: 2/10; Overall: 5/20 Rating: 1.6/5.0 Score: */4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

column1: Hal and Mals Mundts Scottish Ale
column5: Dark mahogany body, but served with no head. Malty aroma with dark chocolate and roast. Diacetyl? The beer starts good with dark malt flavors, slight smoke, but then the flavor falls off to a buttery mess at the end. It has potential though.

column1: Hal and Mals Mundts Scottish Ale
column5: My favorite brew from this pub. Nice, sweet cocoa and smokey aroma. Dark whiskey colored, caramel head. Prevalent smoked peat flavor, lightly sweet with very light hopping. Light bodied, session-style mouth with lightly tart smokey finish. In the spirit of Belhaven Scottish. Quite good.

column1: John Harvards Manchester Black Widow Lager
column5: 11th October 2008. GABF. Clear brown beer. Toasy malt, lagerish. Was hoping for something crisper and darker.

column1: John Harvards Manchester Black Widow Lager
column5: Creamy tan head with red-black body. Aroma is moderately sweet, chocolate, caramel, some anise, light earthy. Taste is moderately sweet, earthy, caramel, some anise, light chocolate. Light-medium body, light stickiness.

column1: John Harvards Manchester Black Widow Lager
column5: Pours dark brown with a thin off white head. Smells of sweet malt, touches of caramel and lots of earthiness. Tastes of spice and sweet malt.

column1: John Harvards Manchester Black Widow Lager
column5: Pint at manchester, CT location. Chocolate DMS lagery aroma. Dark, mildly transparent mahogany color with a light tan head. Start is chocolate malts with roasted malts in the middle. A weird mustiness lingers in the finish. Tones of licorice are also present.

column1: John Harvards Manchester Black Widow Lager
column5: Very tasty looking. Dark ruby red through light, with a light fluff of off white head riding atop. Aroma is malty, with good roastiness, mild hopping and that lagery aroma. Flavor is rich and roasty, with a hint of plum, perhaps. Hops are present only at the very end, lending a light sharpness to the finish. Balance is great, body is fairly light. Carbonation is definitely in full effect, yo. Lots of burps.

Cask at the Lord Moon Of The Mall in London. Weakened bronze. No head. Nose is mildly hopped with some ice tea notes, and some sweetened malts. Some nice wafts of fruit as well. Taste is very fruity with more sweetener coming through. Hop charcter is apparent as well. Moderate palate. Smooth in parts. Finish was more of the fruit taste.
Cask-conditioned @ JDW, Soton. Hops and caramel aroma. Thin with bitter taste and a touch of rustiness. Not too good and not very summery either.

Now under the Camerons badge. Pale amber colour. Clean and crisp, with a bit of dry malt, but a rather watery body. Not bad, but not exciting. Cask (handpump), Lord Moon of the Mall (JDW), Whitehall, London SW1.

Cask Fresh @ JDW's Sir Julian Huxley, Surrey. Pale rusty bronze colour. Aroma is wooly and musty. Pale malt, slightly sweet but not clingy or sticky. Thin to medium body. Fruit in the middle to finish - thin, slightly citric, quite refreshing. Slightly citric hops playing along on top becoming more assertive and more earthy in the finish. A pleasant, refreshing, decent quality and quite tingly stimulating ale. Nice.

Cask Conditioned. Pale yellow beer with thin head. Thin aroma with light malty lager flavour. One of the many attempts to move lager drinkers to beer, but ultimately highlighting the differences not making similarities would be better.

2/9/19. On tap at the downtown brewpub. Crystal clear light copper pour with a small off-white head that fades to a ring. Light malty aroma, caramel, a touch of fruitiness. Light flavor, dough, biscuit, a touch of caramel, a hint of hoppiness. Not bad.

Spelled as Drop Anchor Steem at the brewery booth and on draught during Great Taste of Midwest 2009 in Madison, Wisconsin. Pours a semi-clear brownish amber colored brew with a fast dissolving off-white head. Aroma of roasted caramel malt, some bread crust, a hint of yeast and citrus. Taste is medium bodied, with flavors of roasted caramel malt, some bread dough and a touch of citrus. Finish is a little gritty with a toasted malt aftertaste that slowly disappears. More of a brown/amber ale than a California common but still enjoyable.
A light malty aroma on this brown pour. Somewhat nutty aroma. A crisp, clean body tasting mainly of bread but with a little yeast and hops.

Draft at the brewpub. Poured a clear copper color. Head was white, thin, and left a bit of lace behind. Not much aroma other than a whiff of graham cracker and light citrusy hops. Dry and crisp on the tongue. Flavor was as bland as the aroma. There was some toasted bread, nuts, and nonspecific subdued fruits. Pretty typical example of a marginal (at best) style.

12 ounce pour at downtown location This looked to be a good starter to the evening. It also turned out to be my only one as I got stuck driving but the Black Watch Scotch Ale should be on tap for at least a little bit longer in cask form. If not, there�s always something in the cellar. I wanted to give this a shot since the other alternative I was aware of was to try Anchor Steam. I�ve got nothing against Anchor but when I can support the local guys I go for it. Aroma / Appearance - The caramel body had a short half finger head that soon faded away to a slick oily covering. Caramels, cherries and wheat dominate the nose with a hint of citrus on the background. Flavor / Palate - Toasted rye bread, apple butter and malts form an interesting but relatively simple complexion. It doesn�t change much as it warms. It is a great session beer for those times when you don�t want the relative complexity of a porter or stout. On the whole I wouldn�t mind having a growler of this to open a tasting with; it wakes up the palate enough to get things going without leaving more than a dry slightly bitter finish.

Pint at the downtown location. Poured a clear medium amber with a very nice initial cap of white head. Aroma was soft and pleasant with lightly toasted caramel and wisps of floral notes. The flavor followed suit, with soft caramel at the core and mild floral bitterness and lemon zest gracing the edges. Crisp and refreshing on the palate. Nice non-offensive, highly-sessionable brew.
(Tap) Pours a copper color with an average head. Decent lacing. Some citrus, with a long and dry aftertaste. Not particularly complex. Otherwise, it�s pretty good.

Glad to see they brought this back after a long hiatus....but why in midwinter? A light, clear, amber brew with a short but pervasive head with some leggy lace. Clean tasting and crisp, light body with a fair amount of bitterness. Dry. Not a lot of depth or character, but very easy drinking.
Dark amber color with a thin head. Mild hops aroma. Kind of a dusty taste, yet slightly sweet. A little lemon, perhaps? A pinch o� malt. Oddly tasty.
Not a copy of Anchor, which is a plus. Maltier, fresher. Fruity and refreshing.

Un-Muzzling Olde Muzzlehatch Ratings, #81. 12 ounce draught at the downtown Madison location, August 2008. Light very clear copper-pink with just a touch of creamy foam which diminishes to a thin ring...fresh sweet cherry nose with perhaps a hint of clove, and also just a bit of pale malt sweetness, cookie crumbs sprinkled in cherry juice...sweet cherry juice flavor, very clean and fresh, quite light, the fruit flavor continuing to the finish...a bit of tartness towards the finish, but probably not enough for those who can�t stand sweet fruity beers and demand that cherry be accompanied by the "sour/wild" "sour brown" or "lambic-fruit" appellations. To me it was pretty quaffable, never sticky or cloying, and it�s appropriate enough that this marks my 500th Wisconsin beer rating, given that Great Dane was probably the first brewpub in the state I ever visited, around 20 years ago, and that if pressed I�d name New Glarus� own cherry beer, Belgian Red, as my favorite beer. Here�s to fruit beers and the Badger state!

On tap at the downtown brewpub 8/8/08: Pours a transparent deep copper with a touch of ruby hues and a thin-lacing white head. Aroma of lightly sweet toasty pale malt and fruity cherries. Starts with a mild slightly grainy sweetness and decent semi-tart cherry balance. Pretty drinkable, but not that exceptional.
(Draught) Pours a clear amber body with a small off-white (somewhat pinkish) head. Aroma of canned cherries, candish sugar, and almonds. Flavor of metallic and cherries with a watery mouthfeel.

Name: Cherry Ale Date: 08/08/2008 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: hazy amber, wispy off white head, Aroma: light caramel malt aroma, Flavor: sweet malt flavor, nice cherry character, cherry tartness provides a good contrast to the sweetness, good blend of the sweet and tart cherry, Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

Draft at the brewpub (downtown location). Poured a clear amber color with an off white head. The aroma was of subdued cherry and light toffee. Light body. Tasted of tart flesh fruit with a hint of malty toffee. So so.

On tap at Great Dane - Downtown. Poured medium amber with a short cap of off-white head. The aroma picked up sweet dusty cherry skins over a paler malt base.. warmth brought out some cherry skin tartness.. OK. The flavor showcased pale malts and tart cherries with some sweetness as well from cherry meat.. light grassy bitterness surrounded and paired well with the cherry skins.. grainy finish. Drier on the palate and light-bodied.. some interesting elements, but it really fell off on the finish.. just OK.
Pours a semi hazey reddish colour with a thin off white head. Aroma is very pleasent, ripe tart cherry, cherry pie and danishes. Flavors are tart, satisfying with flavors of red licorice.

Tasted on tap at the downtown Madison location. This fruit beer pours a deep reddish color. Small sized pinkish foamy head. Aroma is cherry and tart, some malts. A medium bodied fruit beer. The malts are fruity and sweet. Hops are floral and earthy. There is a lot of both sweet, tart and sour cheery flavor in this beer. The fruit flavors are more tart and sour than sweet, yet they balance out just a bit to the sour side. There is also a nice malt backbone behind the fruit. Lively carbonated. This version of this beer is very good. An excellent example of just what a fruit beer could be. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly tart.
Clear ruby with off-white/pink cover. The aroma is cherry pie, almondm and caramel. The flavor is cherry, mildly tart and lemon. The mouthfeel is fizzy and light.

Small light pink head with a reddish-brown body. Very dry, tart, lots of cherry flavor and aroma. Difficult to drink a lot of as it really is over-the-top cherry flavor and quite acidic, but refreshing nonetheless. A bit too sweet.

Hops in the aroma. Little hazy, golden color, small white head, good lace. Flat, malty, smoked, light sweet, light bitter. Long lasting finish, smoked of course but more bitter and dry. Better than their lager but still not a very good example of the Bamberg smoked beers.

Gold color with a touch of copper, a bit hazy. Hardly any head. Fishy (!) aroma, like fresh herring. Malty flavor, a bit smoky with some apple. Fair deal of hopbitterness. A bit thin on the tongue, but a lovely beer. Has nothing to do with a pilsener, but still heartily recommended.
Light hoppy and light smoked aroma. Hazy, light amber color, small white head. Strongly smoked flavor, light sweet malts, medium body. Long lasting smokey finish.

Orange amber color, cloudy. Absolutely no head and not carbonated. Smokey aroma with apple. Slight smoky flavor with lots of apple fruitiness. Hints of oak. Thin, almost watery. Still beer that has something of a lambic but with less body and less intense complexity. Off course lacks the sourness of a lambic, but has some Bamberg smokiness. Certainly worth a try!
Dark brown color. Cloudy, no head. Slight caramel and apple aroma. Just a bit of apple sourness, coffee and caramel. Almost no carbonation.

column1: Dark Horse 3 Guy Off the Scale Old Ale
column5: 12oz bottle pours out a hazy cola color with a ring of a head. Nose is pit fruit toffee caramel sweetness cherry some chocolate and nutty notes. Taste is more of the sweetness cherry caramel pit fruit and even molasses. Very easy to enjoy even if it is 15%.

column1: Dark Horse 3 Guy Off the Scale Old Ale
column5: Pour is dark copper with red notes and a thin light tan head. Nose is strong caramel, brown sugar, notes of apple skin and a hint of darker malt. Taste is more malt forward, a little bit more depth. Some apple skin sweetness with a hint of heat in the finish. Medium body with strong carbonation and a prickly feel.

column1: Dark Horse 3 Guy Off the Scale Old Ale
column5: Bottle (12 oz). 2011 vintage or older (?). Shared by JulienHuxley, thanks! Split 3-ways. Appearance: Hazy dark amber with a small beige head and little lacing. Aroma: Surprisingly not too boozy for the abv. Toffee, moderate fruitiness, raisins, tobacco, sherry, candi sugar and herbal notes. Taste: Moderately sweet. Medium boozyness (really not that much for a 15% abv beer). Toffee, raisins, tobacco, sherry, candi sugar, herbal notes and light bitterness. Palate: Full bodied. Moderate carbonation. Oily moutheel. Warming and fruity finish. Overall: Not too boozy for the the abv. Decent BW. Tasty, but still not my cup of tea. Nice fruitiness.

column1: Dark Horse 3 Guy Off the Scale Old Ale
column5: Bottle, shared with Tom. Hazy amber copper pour with ring of white foam. Aroma of boozy cherries, fruity, brandy. Taste is boozy, cherries, sweet caramel malty notes. Palate is full bodied, light carbonation.

column1: Dark Horse 3 Guy Off the Scale Old Ale
column5: 2008 bottle thanks to northernbrews for sharing. Clear copper-red pour with some minor bubbles. Aromas are raisins, caramel, red fruit, toffee candy, and cocoa. Tastes like apples, toffee, raisins, chocolate, and burnt sugar. Great mouthfeel, especially for a 6 year beer. Smooth and just a little syrupy. Abv is very well hidden. Love this. Please brew this again Dark Horse.

column1: Dark Horse 3 Guy Off the Scale Old Ale
column5: Bottle: 2008 release. Thanks, Jeff. Syrupy looking, burnt caramel color. No head, just a few stray bubbles that rise to the top. Aroma is a good, balanced mix of caramel, toffee, apple, raisin, honey, graham cracker, sherry, & a little bit of cocoa powder. Not overpowering in any aspect, & the alcohol is very mild considering it�s 15% ABV. Nice, sweet caramel candy flavor; notes of toffee, apple, raisin, red grape, prune, toasted malts, sherry alcohol - warming but not overpowering, & nowhere near 15% ABV. Sweet, very slight oxidation, but it actually adds a layer of complexity rather than being hindering at this point. Oily, slick mouth feel. A very nice barley wine.

column1: Dark Horse 3 Guy Off the Scale Old Ale
column5: Tasted on 6/1/14 from a capped 12oz bottle obtained in a trade quite some time ago, this bottle has quite a bit of age on it. Pours a nearly opaque, dark, fiery auburn with a thin tan head that disappears fairly quickly. The nose is dominated by caramel, toffee, just a hint of nutty sherry oxidation coming through, raisin, date, and bit of a brighter cherry fruit note with some alcoholic heat. The flavor is all of those same characteristics with some added toasted chocolate bitterness. Everything is extremely well-integrated and balanced. The body is very full with light carbonation and a long lightly bitter caramel, toffee, and somewhat nutty sherry finish. Even with a lot of age, this is an excellent barley wine.

column1: Dark Horse 3 Guy Off the Scale Old Ale
column5: poured from a 12 ounce bottle, not sure of the vintage. Aroma: raisins and cherries were apparent whilst I poured the beer into the glass, sweet fruity alcohol, nutty, slight oxidized notes/ sherry Appearance: slightly cloudy amber with a small halo of bubbles Taste: raisins, cherries, sherry, burnt sugars, leathery Palate: medium/medium light bodied, surprising how light the body is with such a big beer, it never feels thin or watery Overall: This is an amazing Barley Wine, warming, easy to drink(this would be dangerous if I had more then one bottle), a treat for sure

column1: Dark Horse 3 Guy Off the Scale Old Ale
column5: Mahogany pour, small head. Nose is caramel, brown sugar, dark fruits, apple skin. Lots of warm dark fruits on the mouth, caramelized sugar, touch of green apple skin. Some lingering bitterness. Nice sift feel. Good stuff.

column1: Dark Horse 3 Guy Off the Scale Old Ale
column5: Waxed bottle to sniffer (2008 vintage; shared by alexsdad06). Looks good; a cloudy brown with light beige lacing. Smells solid; sweet and malty with notes of dark fruit, caramel, and a touch of butter. Tastes like it smells, sans the butter, with a nice, smooth mouthfeel (especially for 15%!). Good beer.

Tasted this in the Saltcot, Saltcoats (JDW) in May 2003. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear pale russet in colour with a thin white head. Floral hops in the short nose. Thin weak mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malt gives a poor digestive malt base with slight redcurrant fruit. Floral hops in the short bitter aftertaste leaves some astringency. Finish is poor and runs out of legs. Has a slightly sweet malty edge but nothing more. An ok session bitter.

1. Cask Stillage at the Community Centre, Frodsham 25/05/2002 Amber mid brown coloured and slightly bitter. Some sweetness in a smooth dry malt finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich 27/05/2002 Mid brown coloured and malty. Slightly dry bitter finish.

(Bottle 50 cl) Dark amber without much head. Lightly smoked character with a discreet sweetnes and a subdued bitterness. Somewhat nutty notes, very drinkable and pleasant although not with the greatest personality. 090303

[Cask at Volunteers Arms, GBBF 2004] A brown beer with a small beige head. The aroma is light - what is there is of sweet caramel. The flavor is roasted with loads of chocolate, leading to a nice dry bitter end, but the body is a little thin. A very refreshing beer.
[Cask conditioned] Brown coloured. Malty and fruity aroma. Quite roasty and malty flavour.
Lift it and cry to the eagles that come down from the cargs with meat in their claws for two peaple. This is a decent drop to spill. A brown ale is my thinking.
Very dark bitter with a strong head and a roasted aroma. The flavour is dry with a slightly burn't feel. Overall a pleasant dark bitter.
A lovely brown nutty malt flavour,good hops,a very tasty bitter,a nice session.

Nicely bottled. It doesn't indicate that this is bottle conditioned, but it behaves and tastes as if it is. A wondeful chocolate and coffee aroma with a touch of musty oak and a slap of leather. Very drinkable with a restrained but tasty balance of dark malts and tree bark hops. A classic bitter using classic English hops to good effect. Long dusty finish. Good 'un!
Frothy head, amber color. Slight hoparoma. Hopbitter flavor with butterscotch. Just a hint of blackcurrant.

Draught from brewpub in Breck. Piss light yellow/golden beer with small white head. Aroma is caramel and sweet citrus and spice. The flavor brewing cereal, bland and thin. Generally lightly sweet and not really any balance at the end. I wouldn�t expect Breckenridge to have an offering like this.

On tap @ Breckenridge in Breckenridge poured a clear pale yellow with a lasting white head. Aromas of straw, light fruittiness and a hint of honey. Palate was light bodied and smooth. Flavors of straw, light citrus and a hint of yeast with a smooth malty finish. By the way this is a bloinde ale not a lager!

Draft at the brewpub. A very light golden beer with a thin white head. The aroma is sweet with light notes of citrus - too light for my liking. The flavor is sweet with an artificial sweetness note as well as a note of brewing cereal, and the body is thin.
tap. light golden pour with clarity. thin soapy head. light sweet lemon aroma. grainy with sour fresh lemon. The lemon is a bit piercing and the beer is thin. otherwise it goes down easy.

Draft at the brewpub. Poured a clear pale gold color. Head was bubbly and white. There was only a whiff of grain and caramel. Dry on the tongue with a touch of citrus up front that gives way to a light grainy finish. Very light body. It is what it is.

Clear yellow. It has an unusual aroma, not too nice for me, or I would guess, a Bud drinker. Some crispness and lightness, but an off flavor was present, or maybe just a flavor which is unique in this type of beer. Some spiciness, overall not too good.
Really light colored, no real head retention. Fair amount of carbonation. They must have been sick of having people asking for Coors Light, so instead of carrying it, they brewed their own.

On tap at the Denver location, slight amber-red hue, with an off-white head, light sour fruity raspberry nose, with a faint fieldberry accent, hint of tartness in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a yeasty, acidic, sweet and sour raspberry character, with a wheaty, raw toastiness, light tart wildberry accent, leading towards a grainy malty, mild raspberry sourness finish.
tap. golden pour no head. wheat and raspberry aroma. more wheat than raspberry. not too bad.

Draught. Body is hazy medium yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), lightly to moderately yeasty (dough, mold), with a note of raspberry. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter, yeasty. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Pretty run-of-the-mill.
Straw colored, lots of carbonation. Fuzzy mouthfeel. The aroma was of raspberry, but I don't think there was enough of it. The girl I was with at the brewery seemed to enjoy it, however.
Nice and hoppy. Some metallic off-flavors, but weren't bad. Hazy Amber color. Fairly refreshing after a morning of summer skiing at Arapahoe Basin.
[Cask at GBBF 2005] A red-brown beer with no head. The aroma is malty with a roasty character. The flavor is of roasted malt with a light hint of suphur. The mouthfeel is flat.
Cask conditioned, GBBF 2005: Black no head. Coffee aroma. Malty and sweet flavour. Finish is sweet and creamy. Slightly roasted.

1. Cask Handpump at the Court House Station (JDW), Barnsley 17/08/2002 Black slightly strong in alcohol and rich on the palate with some roast flavour in the finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Fat Cat, Sheffield 23/08/2003 Dark red with some sour fruit flavour. Bitter slight roast finish. 3. Cask Handpump at the Anvil, Wigan 05/03/2005 Dark with some alcohol taste. Slightly bitter caramel finish.

Cask (gravity dispense) at GBBF 2005. Can�t believe I�d not rated a Broadstone beer before. Darkish brown colour. Mainly chocolate accented and, as suggested, with touches of licorice. But it lacked the sour edge that I might expect from a porter. Either the recipe has changed, or the bottled version is different or (most likely in my view) those who noted excessive sourness in the bottle have got beer from a bad batch. I found this perfectly pleasant but a bit short of clout.

Nutty, chocolate aroma is fairly sweet. Clear, dark chestnut brown with low off-white head. Fairly roasty flavour has some chocolate and nutty character. Medium-light body with somewhat low carbonation. Cask at GBBF 2005.
[Cask conditioned] Very dark brown coloured. Very malty and roasty. Very nice.

Why do so many bottle conditioned beers have a nasty bitter aftertaste? This initially tasted like a sour bottle of vinegar. After a while it did start to resemble something drinkable..It might have come from a bad batch but has nobody ever heard of quality control ? In its cask form no doubt this is a pleasant beer,but in a bottle, no thanks.

Very dark brown with a beige head. Aromas are are sour berries and chocolate - a bit of a mess and not typical of the style. Flavours are fruity and sour and lacking the chcolate and licourice promised on the label. To be fair hints of chocolate do poke through the nastiness. Perhaps this is a badly bottled beer that is decent from the cask. Its as if the wrong yeast has been used in the bottle conditioning. Messy.

Draught at the Swan in the Rushes, Loughborough. Very dark red/black coloured, with average, foamy, tan coloured, long lasting head. Fruity, sourish aroma. Roasted-malt flavour, with a nice sour finish . Smooth and full bodied. Very nice and very drinkable.

(Cask conditioned) Very dark, deep red/amber color with small, big-bubbled head. Dry, sour wineous cherry aroma. Roasted-malty, sour flavor. Quite original and very sour for a porter. I'll be sure to remember this one.
a little on the lighter side for the style. brewer says full bodied..not quite, but ok. a nice touch of smoke and malt balance are the only things that make this average."

Draft. A chestnut colored beer with a lazing brown head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel as well as a lighter note of nuts. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, and nuts as well as a light note of alcohol.
Sample at the brewpub on 8/7/10. Pours a clear dark red with a medium tan nitro head. Faint nose of malt and a bit of peat. Malty aroma with some peaty smokiness and a bit of hop in the finish.
On tap. Clear reddish brown with an off-white head. Aroma of nuts and a little dried fruit. Medium body, some roasted malt and nuts with a whiff of smoke. Fairly hoppy finish. 130709

From tap at the brewpub. Pours clear and deep amber golden with a small tan head. Aroma is light smoked and roasted malt. Mild caramelish and subdued smoked flavoured. Medium dry. Roasted caramelish flavoured finish.

Date: July 06, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear dark red, fine grey head, drippy lace Aroma: sweet dark caramel aroma, touch of smokey earthyness Flavor: sweet malt flavor, dark caramel sweetness, light smokeyness, touch of that darned astrengency Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 9/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Drinkability: 5/10 Score: *4

~Pours a rich amber color with small creamy of white head. ~Scent is choclaty and nutty. Some smoked malts as well. Real mellow scent. ~Taste is a realy mild smoky sweet. Some chocolate notes here as well. ~Smooth feel, slightly bitter finish. ~This is my second bottle. The first was obviously infected. Very bad like raw veggies. Completly ruined this beer. ~Luckily my second was not infected. I think this is my first Scotch Ale, as I have never had a beer that taste like this. Very easy drinking with good flavor.
Draft from Beerfest at Sudwerk in Davis, CA. This one seemed oddly brewed, but it had a superbly malty backbone. Smokey and caramelly!

Draft at the Beer Fest in Davis, CA. I was very impressed with this beer. Poured a brown color with a thin head. Sweet malty flavor with a hint of carmel flavor. Not a full-bodied as other scotch ales I�ve tried, but very good.

Draft at Brew It Up! Small light brown head that was mostly lasting with a fair amount of lacing, trnsparent, no visible carbonation, and a brown-orange hue. Nose was roasty malt and a hint of smokiness. Ditto for the flavor. Smooth mouthfeel and medium body. A quaffable brew; however, there are much better to be had of this style.
Bottle from Landbierparadies - clear golden color, white creamy head. taste is grainy, spicy, malty. very sweet. okay.
500ml Bottle - Golden with a white head. Lemon, tea, lime and grass in the aroma. Hoppy and tangy taste with lemon, tea, aniseed and grass. Refreshing, crisp and enjoyable.
Pours a clear golden body with a medium white head. Aroma of grain, grass. Flavor of grain, grass, and earthiness with a crisp clean finish.

Bottle bought @ Landbierparadies. Pours tiny hazy deep golden with a rather small frothy offwhite head that leaves some sparse trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is slightly malty, slightly herbal, tiny fruity and tiny floral with dark bread, biscuits, caramel, dried mango and apricots, hay, minerals and lemon peal. Taste is sweet, bitter, slightly malty, slightly herbal and tiny fruity. Mouthfeel is crisp, round and medium bodied. Finish is sweet and bitter with dark bread, caramel, toffee, canned papaya, hay, minerals and lemon peal. Interesting fruitiness. Bit sweet perhaps.

Bottled, from Landbierparadies. Clear golden, mid sized firm head. Distinct grassy spicy nose. Really dry with light body and crisp, rounded mouthfeel. Crisp bready malt, lots of grassy, spicy hops, notes of roses. Really bitter finish. A dry, hoppy pilsnerish helles.

Bottle 500ml. @ home on the terrace. [ As Beck Br�u Hell ]. Clear medium yellow color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, pale malt, moderate hoppy, grass. Flavour is moderate sweet and moderate to light light heavy bitter with a long duration, sharp, grass, dry, silage notes. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20140606]

500ml bottle. Aroma is light spicy and honey. Hints of hops. Appearance is light cloudy yellow with a small white head. Taste is light light sweet and very light bitter. Leaves a light dry mouth feel. A very fresh and interesting beer.
Draft. Pours gold with a white head. Clean grainy base, with very light flowery notes and a relatively clean finish. Not bad.
oro scarico buona schiuma piuttosto persitenten naso cerreale leggero maltato un tocco erbaceoo buona maltatursinixisle chiusura secca discreto amaro non molto aromatico
on tap. bella hell con un delicato profumo di malto. in bocca ha un ottimo equilibrio tra malti e luppoli un corpo fantastico. beverina ed equilibrata
Pours a light golden color. Clean pale malt, little floralness snd a whisper of citrus.
Fonefan 310814. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is wort, citrus, malt. Flavour is wort, citrus, malt, grain. Boring beer.

Bottle 500ml. @ after Tasting at The Danish Ratebeer Summer Gathering 2014, TSODRBSG14. [ As Beck Br�u Leichte ]. Clear light medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is light moderate malty, grain, pale malt, grass. Flavour is moderate sweet with a average duration, grain, pale malt, grass notes, buttery notes. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20140831]
50 cl bottle. Pours pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma is grainy and light cornish. Flat cornish. Dry straw finish.
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Medium head with medium duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are malt, grain, bread and water. Above average carbonation.
Bottle 500ml @ fonefan Pours clear pale yellow with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt, wort and grain. Taste is light sweet and light bitter. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.

Bottle. A dense, finger-thick white head forms over a clear, pale golden body. The aroma is very weak,with some grainy notes and a little fruityness. It�s medium bodied and dry, with a nice co2 level. Weak flavor too, some pale malts in the back, and a touch of fruityness, grass and some pine cones up front. Low on bitterness. Short finish. Easy drinkable, but dead boring. 140831
Bottle, 2.4%.Clear pale yellow with small white head. Aroma is malt, little grainy and a little cardboard. Flavour is malt, grainy, little cardboard, little sweet, thin, watery and a little bitter.
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Clear yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, light malty and bready. Flavor is medium sweet. Sweet finish. Watery. 310814
Bottled@Akkurat. Pale golden colour, small white head. Aroma is grains, bready malts, mild cardboard as well as some hayish notes. Flavour is bready malts, herbs, grains and some earth.
Cloudy amber color with a big head. Fairly weak and watery with little aftertaste turning into a garbage aftertaste finish. I truly do not get the bitter style.
On draft, not nitro, it poured a clear golden color, it has a simple clean taste, nothing special
(Nitro): Real English feel. Spicy, malty, yeasty aroma. Sweet biscuity malt with a light herbal touch. Plenty of fruitiness. Nice session ale.

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: Adventures with Tim outside of KBC beers. Yup, we were in Grand Marais, supposed to go to some gun show. He got all sorts of screwed up and found out the show was in the Soo. We found ourselves here and well, we both sat down at the bar and right onto broken seats the both of us. Yup, we fell right onto the floor, and probably looked liked idiots, but hey, the establishment should�ve had the seats fixed. So, well....okay, well we probably looked as funny as the brewer who brewed this beer as it wasn�t that good.

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: On tap @ the brewery 6/1/07. Dark complexion with very little head. Slightly malty aroma. Taste is overly sweet malts with some light nut flavors also. I didn�t enjoy this beer enough to get more than one, and unfortunately this was the only beer they had on tap at the time to try.

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: An even deep mahogay, edged in off-white. No aroma. All flavor and sugars is dominated by an artificial and weak cheap maple syrup taste. No malt character, no hops. Just maple syrup and water. Ick. Palate has no balance, therefore. One of the worse browns of all time.

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: Sweet....dark brown....had this a few days ago...like dit alot.....very malty with a almond tate...lame review i know

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: Solid dark brown in color much like weak-looking coffee, no real head was produced but very nice off-white stringy lace all over the glass. Smell is faint and delicate with roasted malt, nuts, hazelnuts, with a very minimum citrus hop tingle. Solid tasting brown though, very subtle, nice roasted malt character with a slight note of hazelnut and a small hop note in bitterness in the finish thats all very smooth, slightly warming, and drinkable. Feel is medium and a bit gritty/grainy near the finish. Not a bad brown at all, could use a boost though.

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: Reviewed from notes. The appearance was a pale orange to copper color with a quarter finger�s worth of white foamy head that fell off fairly quick. No lace. The aroma had some caramel/toffee malts up front with a little bit of toast, grassy hops and some light earthiness. The flavor was mostly sweet through all of the previously mentioned aromas. Aftertaste was between the malts and toast, very little hop presence. Malty finish. The feel was about light bodied, perhaps just a touch above. Good sessionability about it. Mild carbonation. Overall, decent as a food beer but not a true to style ESB.

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: tap at the brewpub - Pours hazy orange with a small, lingering white head. There�s a mild toasted caramel malt aroma. The flavor is mostly sweet malt with some quite mild hops bitterness mainly in the finish that serves to keep the malt under control. It�s light bodied and overall a decent beer, but that�s about it.

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: Amber brew with a thin head, served in a pub style pint glass. Great aroma of sweet malt and rich, complex hops. Flavor is excellent blend of a slightly sweet maltiness offset by a strong but restraint citrus and piney hops finish. This is excellent and to my thinking more traditional than their Sandstone Pale Ale. These days I�m more interested in brews that explore and elaborate on tradition, rather than trying to emulate it. But that�s no detraction form this � it is a fine ale, quite excellent, and highly recommended.

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: On tap at the brewery. Hazy coppery body, thin tight off-white head. Light bready, sweet body with citrusy and piney hops providing nice balance. Refreshing and quaffable.

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: An even tawny mahogany pour with a fringed edging of gold and a white rim of head. Distant hops and malt aroma. A somehwat off toasted oat sugars, with a rough woody grain and oaky presentation. Some buttery Cascade touches in there...maybe some diacetyl? It�s okay. Palate carries some decent balance, which is pleasent. Certainly the most drinkable and nicely sessionable of their beers.

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: I thought this was too hoppy for a ESB, but still pretty good. I had this last week and only gotten to reviewing right now. Terrible rating I know.

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: Bottle. Dark hazy amber with a medium tan head. Gusher. Touch of caramel and hops in the aroma. Fairly typical ESB profile, nice bitterness and a tiny hint of astringcency in the dry finish. Decent palate? Bit of a funky tang lingering in background making only slight appearances. Average but pleasant. Thanks DuctTape.

column4: Lake Superior Brewing at the Dunes Saloon
column5: Color is a nice golden light amber with a copper tone. Very thin head but has light off-white stringy lace that sticks well. Smell is a nice floral citrusy aroma, very pronounced, a bit crisp and very fresh with a nice caramel backing, quite a decent wiffer. Taste is mellowing smooth of citrusy hops with a very nice little hop twinge that dances on the tongue a bit and goes down smooth with a slight lingering bitterness thats not overpowering in the least. Caramel malt backing that keeps it balanced is a bit noticeable. Solid medium body, pretty full and a nice bittering dryness in the finish. This is pretty good stuff, an American take on the English style ESB thats not to hoppy or piney.

Very pale yellow body topped by a medium thick white head. Sour malty aroma with a touch of sweetness and a little hoppiness. Slightly sweet yet bitter flavor with hoppy notes and a touch of sourness. Light bodied and fizzy.
A light bodied, middle-of-the-road amber ale. Plenty of hops, but nothing special.

Copper body topped by a medium thick head with decent lace. Grainy malt aroma with light hoppy notes and atouch of sourness. Slightly sweet and bitter hoppy flavor with a good malt balance. Light to medium bodied, smooth and slightly dry.

column1: Big House Legs Diamond Pale Ale
column5: Deep Golden body with amber accents topped by a medium thick head with decent lace. Sweet and fruity hop aroma with slight malty notes. Sweet and fruity hop flavor with a touch of maltinessand a bitter hoppy finish. Medium bodied, relatively smooth and slightly dry.
(Draught) Pours opaque with a yellowish, creamy head. Nose is very faint. Flavour is overly molasses with a thin soy hint. Average.
Pours with a dark reddish brown body topped by a medium thick head with some lace. Sweet chocolate malt aroma and flavor with a slight bitterness. Medium to full bodied and smooth.

Cask, Crown & Thistle, Gravesend. Part of the wicked women series. Fruit aroma. Very sweet with full mouthfeel, sharp citric hops on top. Citric finish very strong, finishing long. An intense brew in good condition.
Cask Handpump at the Fat Cat, Sheffield 22/12/2002 Mid brown colour with sme fruit flavour and a slight roast finish.
Cask Conditioned at The Black Prince, Woodstock. Dark brown beer with little head. Little condition to this thin, slightly sour mild. Boiled cabbage with a plummy background.

Cask, Crown & Thistle, Gravesend. Good fresh condition. Thinish dark mild appearance. Seaweed and Twiglets aroma. Refreshing with a nutty, oaked wine quality. Some roasted barley in the finish. Leaves a licorice taste on the lips. Decent.

column4: White Shield Brewery / Museum Brewery (Molson Coors)
column5: One of the Bill Tidy series of beers. Cask, Crown & Thistle, Gravesend. Standard bitter, nicely balanced. Nothing outstanding.

Cask-conditioned at the Bag O�Nails, Bristol 20/5/08. Deep amber coloured with a slight white head. A fairly standard bitter, with some fruit and caramel in the aroma, followed by a sweetish flavour with some marmalade, earthy hops and a short bitter finish. Good.
Cask Handpump at the George & Dragon, Great Budworth 25/05/2004 Amber golden coloured fruity bitter, smooth on the palate. Slightly bitter dry creamy finish.

Hand pulled at the Anchor, Birmingham, during their Archers weekend. Orange bitter, with a nice roughly fluffed head. Good citric bitterness - full flavoured and quenching, with a nice length finish. Hoppy, prickly fruit mouthfeel. Strong and nice - a notch above the crowd and easily the best Archers beer of the night.

Cask Conditioned, at the Wenlock Arms, London. Amber with a speckled beige head. Deep hoppy aroma. Smooth malts settling into deep green, sour, hops finish. [This beer was just called Maypole, and at 4.5%, served in May, but looks similar enough].
Cask, Dog & Bone, Gillingham. Huge floral citric aroma. Bold citric rush in the flavour with a juicy orange base. Good, clean and refreshing. Damn fine ale.

Cask at the Ship in Itchenor. A typical English bitter with well balanced bitter hops and plenty of malt. There was lots of flavour for such a low abv and drinkability was turned up to 11. It helped that it was perfectly kept and we had just finished a 2 mile family walk. A great pint.

A surprisingly clean tasting, satisfying, old-fashioned bitter. Light chestnut coloured, nicely balanced hop and malt flavouring and not too strong. Well-kept at the Royal Oak, Hooksway, near Chichester.
500ml bottle from Aldi (Oct 2016) - Dark amber body. Nose has citrus, sweetness. Taste a bit dull. Average beer.
Bottle from Aldi, Keighley. Darker clear copper with a small head. Mildly grainy malty bitter with a sessionable texture and taste with a gentle sweetness.

Bottle shared. Poured a medium amber with a frothy white head and lots of bubbles. The aroma is sweet malt, nutty hop bitter. The flavour is moderate bitter light sweet with a crisp light woody hop, light sweet toffee, biscuit dough palate. Medium bodied with average carbonation.
Bottle. Bronze with a small head. Slightly malty with a bitter finish. Typical CAMRA bottled beer. Average to say the least.
Old rating, bottle. Nice round bitter. Refreshing with caramelly hints, easy to drink with hints of grain. Nice and round, easy to drink with nice fresh hops in the aftertaste.
Butelka 500ml. Bursztynowy klarowny kolor. Piana mala biala lekko kremowa. Aromat i smak orzechow .ciastek.karmelu.chmielu. ciekawa goryczka na finiszu. Niezle MarcinG

Bottle from Aldi. I rather enjoyed this. It is an unashamed traditional Bitter. Nice bright ginger colouring, with brusque salty arome. Taste of bitter, British hops. Some small pith, but mainly crusty seashell sour malt quench. Spot. Hit. Yep.
Just what a great beer should be. Delightful. I don�t see not marking high when something deserves it. They�ve done a fine job.
On tap-thin offwhite-copper. A-soft caramel. T-caramel-lt/med malt, some floral/fruit hops.

Poured a semi clear copper colour with a medium sized white head. Plenty of carbonation, aroma was pleasent- floral, earthy and hints of caramel. Taste was pleasent also, slightly bitter, acidic with noticeably hop finish.
On tap at Wilmarths Deepwater Grille. Slightly bitter nose. Dry bitter body with faint floral hop. Light brown color. Water taste.

Third stop during May �07 brewpub tour, brought us to the South Shore Brewery in Ashland, WI. Pours a clear reddish amber brew with an average off-white head that dissolves to a fine film. Fair lacing. Aroma has scents of medium barley malt, some flowery hops, and a touch of maplewood. Taste is smooth, creamy and light flavor that is listed in aroma. Finish is a little flat with a touch of bitter hops. Some flowery herbs in the aftertaste.

Had this at Old Hayward Brewpub in Hayward wisconsin. Bo the brewmaster was bartending - Old Hayward handles a lot of production for South Shore brewery and I really enjoy their products on tap. This ESB poured a nice mid-grade amber with light with head. Aroma is of hops and malt with some floral accents and a bit of pine present. I would say more towards a medium bodied, but not quite a full medium. Good flavor that finishes clean.

Great glowing amber copper toned hue with a pencil width high head of off-white ivory foam and leaves small stitching of lace all around the glass. Smell is faint of floral hops and malt a bit estery and woody, but very hard to get any good aroma from this. Taste is lightly hopped and piney bittered, pretty easy to handle and dries with a nice hop twinge that mellows quickly. Medium bodied but getting light with nice drying in the finish. Pretty solid but could offer more spunk and lasting flavors for an EPA.
Aroma: caramel, pine, citrus Appearance: dark golden with a white head Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness, Palate: medium body, creamy, average carbonation, bitter finish Tasty
355ml bottle. Its a gusher, and it fucking sucks, tons of autolyzed yeast character, dirt, not oxidized. Fucking shitty.
Bottle from Perfect Pour. Clear amber body with medium head. Lots of soapy foam. Nose is hops, spices, floral. Taste is hops, caramel, spice. Really nice and enjoyable.
bottle shared with rusty at club wakonda., orange pour with white head, aroma is fruit, taste is malty hoppy slight orange, and grapefut, not bad
On tap - light red - has a bit of an apple aroma and a whiskey and apple taste. Some pineapple and citrus as well. Medium body and light resin.

Bottle, thanks sevenhokie! Caramel and bready malt aroma with light notes of floral and citrus hops. Pours cloudy copper colored with a thick tan head with excellent retention and good lacing. Starts with sweet caramel and bready malt flavors. Finishes smooth with light floral hop bitterness and some citrus hop. Good, but not a lot of hop flavor to truly call it an IPA.
Bottle. Hazy dark golden full off white head. Aroma of citrus and floral. Medium-high sweet taste. Finishes with just a light hop bitterness and feels refreshing. Decent double ipa overall.

Bottle from exchange. Pours a clear orange with a white head. Aromas of candied orange peel, caramel, some pine. Taste is more bitterness than I like but not as over the top as I thought. Slightly melony. Medium body.
Drink this beer with a fork. Nice thick brew. Enjoyed from glass bottle while hanging Christmas lights. After a few, be careful on the ladder. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap. Pours clear orange, minimal head or lacing. Aroma is perfume, a bit medicinal, candy? Odd. Flavor is really sweet, tangerine perhaps, lots of backing perfume, medium bitter. Medium body, flat as a board. Sticky sweet. Ewww.

Vom Fa� in der Brauereigastst�tte in Trabelsdorf. - Goldgelb, klar. - In der Nase leicht s��liches helles Malz und milde aber elegante Hopfennoten: Zitronen�l und Gras. - Antrunk keksartig hellmalzig und zart s��, was nach dem kernigen Kellerbier beinahe entt�uscht. Sehr aromatischer Hopfen: Zitronen�l, leichte grasige Sch�rfe, Ankl�nge an K�mmel. L�ngerer hopfenaromatischer Abgang, in dem zitronige Aromen dominieren. - Elegant gehopftes, sehr sch�nes Pilsener, das aber f�r meine Begriffe nicht mit dem famosen Kellerbier mithalten kann.
Ins Glas ergie�t sich ein klares goldgelbes Bier mit sch�ner Schaumkrone. Geruch hopfig, getreidig, grasig. Geschmack hopfig, grasig, lang anhaltende Bitterkeit.
50 cl bottle from Bierzwerg. Clear golden, white head. Grainy aroma, hay notes, butter. Flavor has grain, grassy hops, some buttery notes as well. Bitter, dry finish.
Bottled. Pours clear pale golden in color with a whitish head. Hay, fruity notes and malty notes in aroma. Quite bitter in taste, light notes of hay as well.
Clear pale yellow colour. Very small white head. The flavour has a clean bitterness, hint of fine aroma hops.
Oro schiuma media discreta persistenza leggero maltato cereale leggero luppolato erbaceo amaro medio non molto secca

(bottle) pours a clear golden-yellow colour with a frothy white head. faint aroma of floral hops and grain, slightly husky, with notes of lavender and marzipan. flavour is dried fruit, muesli and candy floss, slightly sweet, with a hint of caramel and butter. medium-bodied with average carbonation.

Draught at Akkurat Stockholm. fine and lasting white head.clear yellow color. Fune flowery hop aroma. Nice crips and fresh bitternes with small maltiness. A perfect sparkling palet. Big drinkabillity:

500ml bottle. Clear dark yellow to orange golden colour with nice frothy lasting white head. Hoppy aroma, hay and grass, malty addendum. Taste is a bit flat and monotonous, no hop detected. The only highlight is a slightly sweet, carbonation lined caramel and bread flashing right before the finish that is more a fade out than anything lasting.
German pils just don�t really interest me. Poured a clear gold with a thin white head. Slightly herbal in the aroma, some hops too. Flavour has some grass, malts hints of citrus hoppiness.

column1: Jasper Ridge Red Earth Pale Ale
column5: Draft at brewpub. Copper color. Crisp, fresh taste; nice malts and slight hops on palate.

column1: Jasper Ridge Red Earth Pale Ale
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Pours a nice dark amber with a thin off white head. Sweet citrus aroma with some piney hops. Soft citrus taste with a hoppy bitter finish. Dry texture with average carbonation. Needs more flavor to stand out from the pack.

column1: Jasper Ridge Red Earth Pale Ale
column5: On draught at the brewpub in Ishpeming, Northern Michigan. Pours a clear golden amber colored brew with a thin off-white head that slowly dissipates and leaves behind some excellent lacing. Aroma is fruity, some caramel malt, flowery hops and some earthy herbs. Taste is medium bodied with flavors of caramel malt, a touch of apple skin, grassy and floral hops and a touch of spice. Finish is mildly bitter with some grapefruit zest and grassy hop aftertaste.

column1: Jasper Ridge Red Earth Pale Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Faint hop aroma. I can tell there�s something there, but it doesn�t really show. Pours a clearish amber-gold, with an off-white head above. Flavor is dirty and bitter. Ugh. What�s in here? Pennies, socks and iron ore? Messy, this is all over the road. A typical, darker pale ale base is here, but it�s tainted with some off-earth character and a bad, bad bitterness. This is the kind of hoppy beer that turns people off of good beer. For that, I loathe this example. Learn how to get some flavor out of hops and don�t just make something bitter.

column1: Jasper Ridge Red Earth Pale Ale
column5: On tap at the restaurant/brewpub. Translucent orange-brown body, medium buff head. Medicinal hops aroma, herbal, perfumey, and earthy. Malts are dry. Body is also dominated by perfumey, medicinal hops (I can�t think of the hops variety, but it�s a distinctive one). Toasty, slightly caramely malt backs the hops profile. Strays from the typical pine and grapefruit pale ale hops theme. OK.

column1: Jasper Ridge Red Earth Pale Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub, Ishpeming MI. This and the stout were the pick of the beers here for me. Attractive bright ginger colour with a lasting white head. Nice condition - lively without being too fizzy. Plenty of grapefruit hop character in the aroma and flavour. Dry, bitter mouthfeel. Very refreshing. Nothing particularly out of the ordinary, and maybe a little one-dimensional, but a very good example of the style. This was the beer I returned to for a pint after finishing the sampler.

column1: Jasper Ridge Red Earth Pale Ale
column5: just got a growler of this.poured copper with a small of white head. aroma, malty caramel, wit a touch of honey. flavor dry hops with a little toasty, some malts and just a hint of the honey and caramel as it leaves the tongue. nice and smooth mouth feel leaving the mouth dry and for me looking for water. but a good beer will enjoy drinking this growler.

column1: Jasper Ridge Red Earth Pale Ale
column5: Copper Color with Off white Head. Malty Aroma and Taste...Nice Dry Hop Overtones...Finishing with a Dry Aftertaste. Nice Decent Pale Ale.

column1: Jasper Ridge Red Earth Pale Ale
column5: Pours a lightly hazed deep gold. It has a thin cap of white foam and decent lacing. Mildly hoppy aroma. Hoppy and bitter, but not much other character. Pine hops. Light body. Good carbonation. Lingering pine hop aftertaste. Worth trying for sure, but not exceptional.

column1: Jasper Ridge Red Earth Pale Ale
column5: Festival tap: Amber brown with a nice toasted malt nose. Flavor is toasty as well with a nice bitterness at the finish, medium bodied and light on malt flavor.

Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a hazy burnt brown color with a one finger white foamy head that dissipated within about a minute. Light lacing stuck around but slid after a while. The smell had a decent nutty/roasty caramel/toffee, earthy and slightly toasty. The taste was mainly the same. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. There�s a nutty aftertaste with a dry caramel finish. Overall, I say this was a pretty good brown ale.
Draft at brewpub. Dark brown roasty malt. Astringent vinegar aftertaste . . . something wrong with this one.

Draft at brewpub. Very dark brown pour with a thin off white head. Sweet brown sugar aroma with a hint of roastiness. Initial sweet nutty flavor turns to a tart, apple vinegar finish. A solid brown ale.

On draught at the brewpub in Ishpeming, Northern Michigan. Pours a clear dark copper colored brew with a creamy off-white head that quickly dissipates and leaves some spotty lacing. Aroma of roasted dark malt, a touch of toffee, caramel and a touch of apple vinegar. Taste is medium bodied, with flavors of roasted malt, some dried nuts, a touch of vinegar and tart corn. Finish has a slight metallic texture with mostly roasted dark malt and a touch of grassy bitterness.

from the growler. poured a nice mahogany, with a big tan head. aroma, caramel, nutty, toffee, brown sugar, grapes. flavor the same as the aroma , got some hops, and malts when it warmed and some sourness, good beer

Jasper Brown Ale, on tap at the restaurant/brewpub. Deep orange-brown body, thin buff head. Cerealy, acidic, toasty nose. Very light, watery body, with toast and earthy hops, also perhaps a touch of red grape. Earthy bitter finish. Crisply carbonated. I preferred my cudighi sandwich.

On tap at the brewpub, Ishpeming MI. Murky red/brown colour. Thin beige head. Soft caramel and toffee aroma with, unfortunately, some diacetyl. The same sweet shop cocktail of toffee, caramel and butterscotch on the palate. There are some sharp notes too, turning sour on the finish, which didn�t really fit with the other attributes of the beer. Plenty of people appreciate these caramel malty brown ales. Unfortunately, I don�t. Especially with the sour elements in the mix.

Color is very nice for a brown, its dark brown of deep, darl, varnished oak with dark amber highlights. Thin off-white head of tight foam, creamy, small lacy patches linger then fade. Smell faintly of dark wheat, roasted malts and a great nutty backing, hazel and chestnut I believe.Taste is complex and in subtle layers, all smooth and soild of roasted malts and mixed nuts and has a very slight dark fruit, bananaish note, and a hop twingy bittering late, very interesting. Nice late dryness follows, mellowing out even more so then at first. One soild brown ale with a medium body and light grainyness thats pretty drinkable. It could use a bit more boldness, but is relaxing and good none the less. I enjoyed it. Solid offering.

column1: Jasper Ridge Mather Black Cherry Wheat
column5: Color is a unique orangey-brownish, much like weak maple syrup. No head or lace on this one. Smell is mostly tart cherries and very fresh and softly deep cherry sense filling the nose, very nice. Taste is tart, sharp but dulled of dark cherry with a light wheat backing. Levels off quickly leaving it a bit empty in the end. Feel is pretty light and getting close to medium, watered down. Its an OK cherry beer, made with real black cherries and it shows, but is lacking in body and length of character. Still would make for a good summer heat beat beer.
Draft at the brewpub. Paired nicely with a fish n chips meal. Aroma: roasted malt, coffee, hint of chocolate. Smooth and creamy palate.

On nitro draught at the brewpub in Ishpeming, Northern Michigan. Pours an opaque dark brown colored brew with a creamy beige head that stays with the beers throughout. Aroma of is very faint with some toasted dark malt, vanilla and a touch of coffee. Taste is medium bodied, creamy texture from the nitro charge with a very faint flavor of toasted dark malt and some light chocolate. Finish is light a touch of vanilla then a clean cut aftertaste with no flavor.

2008 MiBGF: Opaque with an excellent creamy beige head and very good lace. The aroma has notes of grassy hops, roasted and chocolate malt, walnut, raisins and some coffee. The taste is lactic and fruity with a nutty and chocolate background, rather simple and straight forward palate. The mouth feel is smooth and soft. Starts nice but in the end is just an okay beer.

On tap at the brewpub. Noses in light coffee and coconut liqueur. Pours a deep black-mahogany, with a really intense mocha head, staying. This is really sweet, but surprisingly complex tasting. I hate the sweetness, but love the blend of nuts, caramelized sugars, vanilla, bourbon, and roast that comes through. For that is complex. And actually, some of the Guinness-like thinness helps fight off the hazelnut-syrup sweetness. In the end, I�m a little confused by this beer. The sweetness hurts, but the malt character isn�t bad. If this was an Imperial, people would be drooling all over it, but the watery lack of carbonation hurts a little.

On tap at the restaurant/brewpub. Deep opaque brown body, tan nitro head. Light chocolate aroma with moderate sweetness, backed by roast. Strong chocolate body with a fairly strong caramely characteristic, light sweetness. Subdued bitter finish. Smooth but something seems to be missing. Perhaps a bit too much caramel confuses the palate.

On tap at the brewpub, Ishpeming MI. This and the Red Earth Pale Ale were the pick of the beers here for me. Good dark brown/red, almost black, appearance with a persistent mushroom coloured head. Roasty aroma, with plenty of mocha notes. More coffee comes through on the palate. Smooth mouthfeel, but a little residual sweetness lowers the score a notch for me. A decent, tasty stout nonetheless. Perhaps it just shone in comparison with the preponderance of light beers - a Kolsch, 2 Wheats and 2 Fruit Wheats - in an 8 beer sampler .
Black Color with Dark Tan Head. Very Similiar Overall to Guinness or like Varieties. Overall a Bit Sweeter and More Roasts...Nice Overall Stout.

Sampled this beer at the Great Taste of the Midwest in Madison WI. Even though my scores on this are accurate and well researched, Da Man wants me to say more about the beer, so I will. Bla, a somewhat crappy stout. Not impressed at all.

from a growler--seems a little flat, perhaps because of the growler. smells smoky and roasty with some dark chocolate in there somewhere. taste is very roasted and earthy, plenty of woody coffee in there too. finishes slightly bitter, but aside from being a little thin this is a good stout.

Color is a solid black with slivers of dark ruby highlights. Small but foamy creamed head thats light brownish creamy colored, leaves no lace though, what a shame. Smell is coffeeish and lightly earthy like wet soil, dark mustyness with darl roasted malts lingering and a note of chocolate malt. Gets a dark cherry note upon bigger wiffs way in the back. Taste is light and subtle with dark roasted malts, earthy with coffee, nuts, and chocolate notes changing the tune as it goes. Has a very nice woodsy like drying in the finish, a bit burnt-like. Its a bit empty at the start then layers begin to mingle. Feel is a lighter body style smooth and barely creamy, could be heavier, good drinkable light stout.
Excellent Belgian blonde. Sweetish with warm brandy-like alcohol notes. Full malty mouthfeel.
Fles 33cl thuis. Weinig spannend, wat zoetig en commercieel. Toch ook wat bitterig. (10-2010).

Sampled from the tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear light gold with a white head that dissipates slowly to the edges. Aroma has earthy wheat with straw and a bit of sweetness. Flavor has earthy wheat throughout with a hint of sweetness.
Keg at the brewpub. Slightly hazy golden, thin creamy white head, decent retention. Aroma of faint biscuity wheat. Taste is doughy wheat. Medium bodied, dry.
Draft. Lemon in taster glass. Smells like lemon. Flavor is dry and wheat easy going. Roope

On draught at the brewpub in Ishpeming, Northern Michigan. Pours a cloudy golden pale colored brew with a fast dissolving white head that leaves behind some minimal lacing. Aroma of golden grain malt with wheat, a touch of citrus and a touch of lemon. Taste is light bodied, crisp, with some golden grain malt and a touch of citrus. Finish is semi-dry, crisp with a clean cut aftertaste with very little bitterness.

On tap at the brewpub. Hazy yellow body, lacking the brownish tones the blueberry and raspberry extracts give to the fruit versions. Light tangy nose with wet hay (and semi-dirty socks) and light fermented fruits. Spicy, bready body, ester-forward but light, crisply carbonated. Subtle fruity sweetness. Mundane.

On tap at the brewpub, Ishpeming MI. Straw colour with a very slight haze. Incomplete white head. Not much in the way of aroma. Subtle citrus flavour (it was served with a slice of lemon although at least that was just on the side of the glass not floating in the beer). Clean and refreshing mouthfeel. Not a great style but this is a decent enough example. Not much else to say.
Hazy Yellow Color with White Head. Heavy Mouthfeel. Alot of Lemon/Citrus Notes. Overall with a Light Dry Wheat Aftertaste. Nice Lawnmower Brew.
Festival tap: Candy-like sweetness, like a sweet tart. Thin bodied, just too dominated by the sweetness. Some lemon and cherry.

Color is somewhat pale light yellow and diluted with a thin foamy head, leaves no lace. Smell is very faint of musty dust with a lemon and sweet honey note. Taste is very wheatly sweet and lemony, vey mellow and easy. Leaves lots of lemon-like tartness and is a bit watery. Feel is light bodied for sure, watered down. Its their top seller, and I see why, its a lighter fare which compares to most macro lights.
Pale Pale Gold Color with No Head. Sweet Lightly Grained Malt. Dry Malty Aftertaste. Slightly Better Then Drinking Michelob. Subtle To No Malt Aftertaste.

The server said that this was a "Canadian Style Lager," but if that�s true, its better than anything by Molson and Company. Poured a clear golden yellow, with just a thin trace of pure white head. Pretty light on the aroma. Good hoppiness up front, like a good Eastern European lager, but it didn�t stick around very long. Decent mouthfeel, good carbonation. A bit of lemon in the aftertaste. Very clean, very smooth beer. Refreshing and well made. Not really my style of brew, but nicely drinkable. Goes good with pizza.

Appearance: clear, bright golden color, short, swiftly diminishing white head. Aroma: clean, and simple. Taste: excellent texture, delightful tang, dominant sweetness. Some hops up on top, fading back quick, and tasty malt. Persistent honey/citrus taste, long lasting finish. Really flavorful lager, I could down this by the bucketful if that were possible.

Appearance of a solid pilsner with a pale light yellow, glowing; atop sits a small white head of very airy froth, light spotty lacing. Soft on the nose with a crisp sweetness from malt and a light honey-like note. Taste is excellent, perfectly light textured smoothness and medium bodied. Flavors on this are quite nice and subtle in its layers. Starts with a favorable light bite of hop thats just right and flows into a nice sweet tartness, very smooth with a hint of sugared honey in there. Perfectly balanced, subtle and pleasing beyond belief. One very amazing pilsner and so drinkable its not even funny.
Pale yellow color with no head or aroma. Just a bit of a grain, like standing outside a grain elevator. Plain, borring, sad...

Being an amature rock hound I loved the idea behind this old world process of throwing in warm granite stone boulders to kick in the carmelization. If you lick, thats right, lick, rocks like I do while trying to bring out colors of agates and minerals in rocks and stones, this beer is a fine pleasure for the palate. This beer has a solid pilsner look about it, golding yellow, sparkly and glowing, some carbonation bubbles flowing. Received with a finger high head of tight white frothy foam, leaves small spotty lace and a good retention ring on top the whole glass through. Smell is incredible for this ale, it smells like granite, I swear it does, really. Highly sweet light citrus and clean hoppy freshness, sharp and cutting of minerals, salt, and very strikingly so. Very unique and distinct, wow. Taste continues into the realm of uniqueness again, highly sweet of grapefruit rinds and yeasty grained. Textured and flavored much like the granite stones themselves, and I tell you this in the high regards of confidence that is what I'm tasting in this beer... Granite rocks! Which in by itself is like a mix of light ocean sea salt and white pepper, very mineral-like or perhaps like a vitamin supplement, but not mediciny in the least, quite distinct. Hops all over the place finding home in every crevice of your mouth, but nothing over the top at all, balanced well with a very nice malt backing. Making this one uniquely textured and flavorful beer, leaves your tongue in a bump tingly mood. Quite full as well, and smoothing out a bit for a great finish. Amazing little beer.

Tap. Pours cloudy golden, medium creamy white head, good lacing. Aroma is pretty solid wheat, lemon, banana. Flavor is classic lemony, banana, clove, bubble gum. Light sweet, minimal bitterness. Light body.

Aroma: Lots of banana and clove aromas, with hints citrus. Appearance: Cloudy yellow with a rich white head. Taste: Medium sweetness straight through. Palate: Medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, long soft finish. Overall: A nicely developed hefe, but nothing mind blowing or standout.

On draft at brewpub This was by far the best release at the brewpub. As a general rule it seems that if you stick to the German styles here then you might come out with something that is more than a forgettable pour. I�ll certainly keep that in mind next time I visit. Aroma / Appearance - The cloudy yellowish base looks almost like diluted fresh squeezed orange juice with a clean white styrofoam cap. Vanilla, ripe bananas, orange peels and dough push this to the bready side of the style without a doubt. Flavor / Palate - An easy drinker fills the mouth with its fluid presence. Lemons, bananas, and orange pulp enrich the profile and move it from run of the mill to above average. Vanilla custard and honey bookend a well balanced spectrum. I am glad I ordered the 20 ounce pour of this rather than any of the other current drafts.

Sample at the brewpub. This beer pours a murky orange-yellow color with a thin white head that burns away to a film relatively fast. Stringy lacing on the glass. Aroma of bubblegum and wheat. Light, clean body with flavors of banana, bubblegum and cloves. The finish is wheaty with a sweet banana aftertaste. Slightly above average Hefe overall.
yellowish hazy with large white head. mostly orange to the nose. slight bitterness before well balanced orange and clove notes before a nice body. overall a good brew

Growler courtesy of Bill Metzger. Nice hefe. Aromas of banana, clovey. Supposedly modeled after Weinhenstephaner. Not as good but better than large majority of American attempts Ive come across. Well balanced & quite good

Name: Subchaser Hefe-Weizen Date: 07/23/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub opaque yellow, creamy white head, solid lace, sweet banana aroma balanced by light clove, creamy body, banana flavor with a tempered sweetness, nice clove balance, the banana and clove continue to take turns at trying to dominate, eventually the clove wins in the finish Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.2/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **/4
On tap @ Rocky River: Pours a cloudy gold with a white head. Aroma, lemons, wheat and some yeasty notes. Flavor, lemon, tart, wheat and some bready notes. Very generic hefe.

Pours yellow big yellow head. Loved how they said they use weihenstephan yeast I love that yeast. The aroma is banana all the way. The flavor is much the same banana, cloves, some lemon and hallerataus, it tasted exactly like a hefe I made, good beer.

Hazy, pale and lemon-tinted caramel orange in color with a persistent white snowcap for the head. Sugary bananas are aromatically represented with a buttercream base and milky vanilla characteristics. Sweet cream sings with vanilla wafers, and a slight waft of cotton rides its coattails. Creaminess drops for the lemon banana chiffon flavor to come full circle. The vanilla�s there, in a wafer crust sort of way, getting soggy as the banana persists upon it. Gentle carbonation lacks the effervescence, but the pastry portrayal fills in for her flavor. The otherwise medium body kilters toward yogurt intuitions, encouraging vanilla, lemons and bananas with a subtle breezy bitterness in the end.

(Cask at Akkurat, Stockholm) Pale golden colour with frothy white head. Fruity nose with citrus, lemon, apricots and floral hops. Fruity taste with notes of citrus, lemon peel and grassy, slightly earthy, hops in the finish. Easy to drink, very sessionable.

(Cask at Oliver Twist, Stockholm, Sweden) Shady straw yellow color, creamy white head. Mellow hoppy herbal and apricot scent. Very nice bitter citrus and floral hoppy taste. Medium mouthfeel, nice high bitterenss.

Not the most aromatic golden ale. A clear and pale one covered by almost no head. Soft bready malts with the characteristic grainy bottom that are complemented by limey and bright, but light hops. Swift sweeping bitterness follows. The ensemble is quite clean, but never takes a single risk and remains deceptively thin-bodied.

Sampled cask conditioned at Akkurat, Stockholm, Sweden. This pale golden, crystal clear ale must surely be named after the famous Australian Ratebeerian. It has an orangey nose, is sweet, fruity and well rounded with soft mouthfeel and notes of vanilla and strawberries. It's an easy drinking ale, well suited for summer weather and has average bitterness and a fair amount of character.
On tap at The Baltic Fleet, Liverpool. Pale and light hazy colour with a white head. Floral hoppy nose. Hoppy and a bit grassy flavour.
Cask Stillage at the Community Centre, Frodsham 24/05/2003 Amber coloured with some alcohol present. Slightly bitter full malt finish.

Cask Conditioned at The Baltic Fleet, Liverpool. A pale golden amber beer with a whispy light head. A spicy zingy floral flavour opens up the palate for a heavier floral flavour. Not high on bitterness but a peachy sweet aftertaste lingers on.
Draft at brewery. Hazy golden hue with medium white head. Medium aroma of citrus and malt. Medium body. Refreshing flavor with a very short sweet finish.
Cloudy yellow with a lacy white head. Big clove and fruit. Bananas and orange. The flavor is crisp but has an odd bitterness in the finish. Not bad though.

Standard hazy orange pour. Fizzy white head. Big nose with lost of orange and corriander. Pleasing tart malt flavors compliment the smooth orange notes. Finishes with the dry corriander. My favorite Wit.

For some reason, the brewpub featured both a Hefe and this Wit at the same time - provided for some interesting comparisons. This wit lacked aroma and could've used a good deal more orange peel. Palate started off prickly and sharp; thinner bodied. Finish was very herbal with a slight tang.
on tap at rocky river brewing comppany. pours a hazy orange/gold. fresh. hops, citrus.

Lakewood, Oh. - on tap at the Beer Engine. Murky, dark orange colored pour, soft, pillowy white head. leaves good lace. Pleasant floral aroma, light spruce in the back end. Juicy, solid citrus flavor with some minty notes and a faint back end of sweet maple syrup. Clean, even, thickish mouthfeel. Overall, a very decent, solid midwest IPA.

On tap at the Beer Engine. Pours a lightly hazy golden amber with a medium creamy/bubbly off white head that left some lacing. Aroma was a bunch of fresh American hops, lots of citrus notes, light pine, floral, some toasted malt and caramel. Flavor was pretty much the same with some grassy notes, again a bunch of fresh hop flavor and a nice malt backbone. Hop bitterness there, but not overpowering as a good American Pale Ale should be.

On tap at RRBC. Draft lloked fantastic. A hazy gold, and a beautiful creamy head that laces the glass the whole way down. The aroma has a hint of citrusness, The malt flavor comes through with some breadiness followed by a soft sort of bitterness that continues into the finish. This was a decent brew. I was pleased with this as I have not been wild about previous offerings from RRBC.

On tap at a tasting this evening. Pours a orange color with off white head. Had a nice pine smell to it in the background. Only problem was the soap smell upfront. I kept thinking maybe this was a very well washed glass. Then I knew that wasn�t the case when I had a second pour. Mouthfeel was medium. Had a great flavor of pine and malt sweetness. Has a nice flavor overall, but I just can�t get that soap smell out of it.

Cloudy, faded orange color w/o much head. Lots of pine aromas, but there was also a wierd, kinda off thing going on too that I couldn�t really put a name on. Maybe soap? Anyway, it tasted better than it smelled, with flavors of pine tree and mild malts. Pretty full bodied and oily. Finished with more piney hops. Not the best version of this beer, according to the brewer. Problems with water pressure and the chiller gave him problems throughout the brewing process of this one, so I�ll re rate it next time it�s on.

Great citrus/hop aroma. Looks very nice and deep golden - I haven't often seen an unfiltered pale ale. Listed at 60 IBU, this started with some sharp citrus notes, and as it warmed the hops became fuller and thicker (not quite sticky). Smooth but not thick. This was my favorite of the evening (6/25/03)

Cask @ Baltic Fleet, Liverpool. Very dark with a small off-white head. Has a good roasted malt nose with a very drinkable texture that does not feel its strength. There�s a small sweetness within its taste, but there�s still some roasted malt in here too, with the smokiness evident in both aroma and taste, but more pronounced in the latter aspect, as well as lingering a while in the palate. The smokiness provides a ham flavour.

Bottled. Black colour with a mediumsized brown creamy head. Aroma is roasted malts, some ashes, a bit toffee, nuts and smoked wet wood. Flavour is caramel, toffee, some roast and ashes as well as some mild chocolate and old black coffee. Lovely.
Draught at the brewpub. Light sweet with a roast and very light smoke. Creamy vanilla base and light sweet finish.

Cask, gravity NWAF, Manchester in company of Dad, Pauline and Baz 20.01.12 Pours dark brown with a creamy film of bubbles. The smokiness is quite light but noticeable. Tangy and fruity with a nod too smokiness in mouth, some roastiness, little coffee. A6 A4 T6 P3 Ov13 3.2
Gift from Sj. This is a really good Porter. Brown pour with thin beige head. Aroma of roast, caramel buttery malt. Flavor is sweet caramel, smoke, roast and butter. I really liked this.
bottle at home ... black ... barest lacing ... light smoke .... blackcurrant fruit nose ... light over fizzy ... dark roast ... light fruits ... chocolate cherry dark malts ... pretty reasonable

Cask at NWAF, 2011. Black with a beige head. Dark roast coffee aromas with a bit of smoke and dark chocolate. Smoky, woody flavours with coffee and chocolate. Easy going brew, quite smooth. Dry, malty finish. Not bad.

Cask handpull at The Baltic Fleet, Liverpool. Wow, I am so surprised that I haven�t rated this before. More porter than smoke. But good chewy malts and subtle smoke aroma and flavour. Quite a lot of choc on aroma. Would have stayed for a second pint but the pissed up Liverpool fan sat opposite was starting to scare me. And this was just after midday when the match was starting at 4pm. Jesus.

Bottle. Pours a black color with a small longlasting off-white head. Has a roasted malt smooth smoky aroma. Sweetish roasted malty smoky flavor with some hints of chocolate. Has a sweetish roasted malty finish.
Bottle from GBBF 09. Black with a beige, rocky head. Sweet smoked caramel aroma. Salty smoked flavours, moderately sweet. Interesting.

Cask, Nottingham �10. Lightly hazy amber with a thin foam. Aromas are biscuit and nutty malts with raisins. Brown sugar with hints of marzipan. Flavours are crystallised autumn fruit with caramel and peppery spices. OK.

Cask@Nottingham Beer Festival 2010. Bronze beer with a strongish head. The aroma is fairly bitter and the flavour is mildly toffee with a watery bitter finish. Overall a nice mildly toffee and bitter beer.
Cask/gravity at Peterborough BF 2008. Citrus & malt on nose, full bodied, with dates & dried fruit on the palate and then a long bitter-grapefruit finish.
Cask (handpump) Fellows Morton Clayton, Nottingham. Solid bronze body, plenty of fruit to get your teeth into, a sweet surge balanced out with a lingering bitter finish.

Bottle conditioned. Amber/bronze colour, good fluffy white head, plenty of lace, moderate condition. Fruity malt and yeast in the nose, quite sweet in the mouth but with a good hop bitterness developing that becomes very dry in the finish. Hints of yeastiness linger.

i had this because it was the only Milly's beer they had on tap that i hadn't tried before. the bartender asked me if i wanted it with strawberry or lemon in it. i said strawbeery because it sounded kinda neat. i got this peach-colored liquid in a pint glass that reminded me of amaretto and orange juice. i'm not a fan of wheat beers at all and the only thing keeping this rating up as high as i rated it was the strawberry. Milly's makes some kick-ass beers, but this is definately the worst by far.

Eh, what can i say. This was someone else's beer that i tried, it had a shot of strawberry in it. It had a stange peachy color because of the berry shot and the aroma turned me off, almost medicinal. The flavor wasn't much better. Cough medicines taste better to me. I'm not a fan of wheat beer and this one was made worse by the berry. Wouldn't reccommend it to anyone.

I saw a pint from across the bar and realized that Milly's had a new beer. A summer wheat. Unfortunately an American wheat beer, of which I've never had a good one.
