This one has berries in it which gave it a sour off-tone at the end. Besides that and the perfect cloudy golden-orange color, it was like many other wheat beers that would have been better with a good German hefe yeast strain.

Die spritzige Weisse kommt frisch, mild, fruchtig und hefig daher. W�rzig im Mittelteil und im Abgang. Insgesamt s�ffig, aber nur durchschnittlich. Schmeckt witziger Weise �hnlich, wie das zuvor getestete Bier: Weiherer Weisse, hat auch den gleichen Kronkorken.
500ml bottle at Landgasthof Trabelsdorf. Aroma is light algae, light yeast. Appearance is cloudy orange with a fine white foam. Taste is light sour. Light dry, light carbonation. Proper.
Pours hazy yellow with a creamy fluffy white head and lacings. Very yeasty and sweet. Banana and wheat.
Tr�bes goldgelbes Bier mit sch�ner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, fruchtig. Geschmack hefig, fruchtig nach Banane, leicht w�rzig.

500 ml bottle. S. BB 24/03/13. From bierzwerg.de. Cloudy golden colour with small to average sized off-white head. Wheat, bread, mild yeast and mild sourness in aroma. Flavour is mildly tart with some fruitiness, bready wheat and some mild yeast. Lemony tartness.
Bottle from Bierzwerg. Aroma is yeasty. Flavour is sweet, lemon, yeast. Refreshing, but nothing extra.

Dark yellow colored with medium sized yellow head. Hazy appearance. Rich grainy-wheaty aroma with sweet banana, strong yeast here as well. Thin to medium bodied. Flavor is also strongly yeasty with overly sweet banana. Too sweet. Maybe little bit too old.

500ml bottle. Hazy dark golden to copper colour with good lasting frothy white head. Fresh and slightly spicy lemon aroma. Perfect fizzy carbonation. Taste has a fresh lemon note, well balanced wheat malt that becomes almost creamy in the finish. Good!

Bottle rated in Nov 2011. Head is mostly lasting. Body is dark yellow. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (bread), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of banana taffy and Circus Peanuts candy. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter, slightly unclean. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Really weird, artificial smelling rendition. Not enjoyable.
bottle from Bierzwerg. Cloudy yellow, large whiet head, very creamy. Full-bodied, yeasty, shy fruity hints.

Flasche 0,5l: Kastanienbraun, dunkles Kupfer, glasklar, kr�ftiger stabiler mittelporiger Schaum; frische + fruchtige Nase, kr�ftige malzige S��e, Malz, Malzzucker, dunkles Karamell, Hopfennoten, dunkle/eingelegte Fr�chte, leichte R�staromen, etwas Kaffee; frischer + fruchtiger K�rper, leichte malzige S��e, leicht w�rzig, R�stmalz, etwas Malzzucker, dunkles Karamell, cremig, kr�ftige Kohlens�ure, Hopfennoten, leichte fruchtige S�ure, R�staromen, Kaffee, N�sse; angenehmer malzig-trockener Nachgang

Etwas geringere Schaumentwicklung mit durchschnittlich feiner Konsistenz. Farblich dunkelbraun mit leichtem Orangestich, klar. Riecht malzig, leicht r�stig, w�rzig, kernig-nussig. Geschmacklich unglaublich weich, malzig, etwas r�stig, recht nussig. Sehr gutes Dunkelbier.
Bottle from Landbierparadies. Clear red/brown colour, beige foam. Nose of caramel, red fruit, chocolate. Light sweet, bready, decent hoppy. Good Dunkel
clear dark brown color, off-white head. taste is coffee, nuts, caramell. very dark and intende Dunkel. bit too much actually. not very quaffable. interesting, though. I'm a bit undecided here

Bottle from Landbierparadies24.de Pours dark hazelnut with a solid off-white head. Aroma has nuts, roasted malts and sweet chocolate. Taste is malty, slight roasty and chocolatey-sweet with some slight coffee. Earthy-malty finish!

Many thanks for this beer to kevnic2008. Piwo nie ma prawie wogole piany. To co sie tworzy podczas nalewania nie oblepia nic szkla. Barwa czerwona klarowna, Zapach mielonych orzechow laskowych. W smaku syrop klonowy, pierniki torunskie w czekoladzie i przede wszystkim drazniaca kiepska i zimna kawa. lekka i z rozpuszczalnej wersji. Caly czas towarzyszyl mi taki posmak, przypominalo takze cukierki kawowe copico. za slodkie i zbyt kawowe.
500ml Bottle - Dark brown in colour. Malty aroma with caramel, grain and raisins. Fruity and malty taste with nuts, caramel, raisins and biscuity malt.

Multiple fresh bottles over the years in Bambergerland: Rusty chestnut. Tight pearly foam. Clean malt aromatics of nuts, cocoa, tilled earth, honeyed biscuits and toasted bread. Hops contribute a hint of licorice beneath. Delicate pinpricks of carbonation. Firm body. Artfully layered breadcrust, plum skin and a dusting of cocoa merges with a scratch of earthy, anise-tinged bitterness. Strikingly succulent hoppiness steps up to match the fat but clean malt core. Polished malt continually reveals its many dimensions, with a pils-derived vanilla cookie crispness smattered with tiramisu and creamed java notes. Discernible unripe-plum acidity boosts drinkability yet does slightly inhibit development as it displaces some of the powdery textures. Assertively hoppy and licoricey finish is charged with a staunch mineralic snap which paves the way for complex malt notes of cookie, hazelnut, creamed java and toffee. An enjoyably clean and harmonious Franconian dunkel.

50 cl bottle while getting some sun near the river. Strong coffee and roasted malts aroma. Dark . Medium off-white head. Long lasting retention. Nuts and roasted malt. Medium sweetness.Average carbonation.
Rating from 2005. Sehr sch�nes Bier. Malzig s�ffig mit feinen R�stmalz- und Schokoladenankl�ngen. Mild-herb und angenehm r�stmalzig im Nachgeschmack, dabei nicht zu s��. --> 13

1. Cask Handpump at the Brewery, Liverpool 18/06/2001 Light and hoppy. Sharp caramel flavoured finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Brewery, Liverpool 22/11/2001 Straw golden coloured and pale. Some sour fruit flavour. Slightly bitter hop finish.
Csak Conditioned? at The Brewery, Liverpool. A pale yellow insipid colour with virtually no head. This is a hin tasteless attempt at a lager ale. Totally a waste of time.
Cask. A hazy golden beer with a thin white head. The aroma has notes of malt and citrusy hops. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, lemon, and hops, leading to a lightly bitter finish.

Cask. Golden colour, not much head. Aroma is fruity hops, some mild bready notes, mild wood as well as some vanilla and earth. Flavour is hops, fruits, some cereals, mild caramel malts as well as some slight wooden notes.
Cask (Giddy Bridge JDW, Southampton) - Golden in colour. Fruity, malty and slightly musty aroma. Malty and fruity taste with some faint hoppy notes.
Cask Handpump at the Punchbowl JDW, York 20/02/2008 Fruity hop aroma. Clear golden coloured hoppy and very fruity. Sweet on the palate with a crisp and slightly bitter malt finish.

Cask at the Devonshire Arms, Burton. Gold with a ring of white head; buttery and slightly citrus, with some trpoical fruits, orange and lychee; a warming a bitter finish. Interesting, but somehow this fails to deliver.
A Mes rate: cask at the Market Porter. Gold with a thin white rim. Very "green" with slight malt and hops but generally on the bland side. Wheaty finish. Nothing special.
Cask handpull at County Hotel, Ashford. Gold, thin beige head. Some butter toffee. Lots of peppery hop on end. Good condition. Hops are excellent, bit of diacetyl I suppose.
Cask Conditioned, at the Crosse Keys, London. Pale golden colour. Cider/apple aroma, Waldorf Salad (BeerLimey).
Cask: Pale golden appearance. Sweet pearish aroma, moderate spice, dry, pretty low on flavor. Started out interesting but left pretty disappointing.

Mid gold colour. No discernible aroma (too cold from Wetherspoons as usual). Some dry malt and balancing hop bitterness in the flavours. Medium body. Clean finish. Decent, but not hugely thrilling. Cask (handpump), Lord Moon of the Mall (JDW), Whitehall, London SW1.

First tasted this in Gabriels, Paisley in May 2002. Cask, handpump dispense. Crystal clear pale straw in colour with a thin white head. Strong lemon peel on the nose and thin but refreshing mouthfeel. Good lacing throughout. Pale malts give a juicy tart note of grapefruit and lemon zest. Floral dusty hop resins give a good aftertaste. Citric notes in the dry finish. Typical summer session golden ale.
Cask in the market porter. Alround rating: Pale sweet malts, grassy hop, earthy minerally either from the yeast or hop, but its not very bitter.

Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Citric aroma. Sour grapefruit taste, with just a little sweetness and a mid bitter finish. Pretty ordinary golden, though perhaps it has a bit more flavour than most.

Hand pulled at the Wellington, Birmingham. Beautifully silk, oiley fresh lime, hop start. Not too sharp, more of a fruit-gum sweetness. Goes a bit malty on the finish, a bit weetabix, but generally this doesn�t spoil things. Beautiful fresh Golden.

(Hand pulled)Yet another pale straw coloured brew from this Shefford brewery. Loose white head, freshly mown hay in the aroma. Fruity and hoppy taste, with a dry bitter finish. A good pint, shame it's seasonal.

From old tasting notes. Cloudy golden color. Huge whipped cream white head. Tart, fruity malt nose is sharp and ascerbic. Bittersweet fruity malt flavor that becomes sharp and potent. Lots of flavor, lots of body, lots of oomph! Long malty finish.

Date: 09/08/1996 Mode: Bottle Source: Chevy Chase, DC clear yellow, big frothy head, crisp hop aroma, lots of carbonation, heavy malt flavor with well balanced hops, sweet malty finish -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 07/05/1997 Score: ii to ii+ Words: Total Beverage Words: DC hazy golden, rich malt aroma with strong floral hop aroma, rich malt flavor leading into hop bitterness and finishing with a clean warmth Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.1/5.0 Score: **+/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Pours with a frothy white head. Honey colored and murky. Aroma is bready(yeasty) with caramel and brown sugar. I don�t pick up much of the hops or spices that the previous rater mentions. Flavor is sweet almost syrupy. Some alcohol does show up on the finish to moderate the sweetness.

hazy amber bronze, big off white head that held up well and left a sheet of dense lace. yeast, citrus and coriander spiced aroma. palate is thin but pleasantly carbonated so as to be refeshing. sweet start followed by a tangy tart middle , finish is full of hops and a lingering dry alcohol note.

Swing top from Aldi, 01/01/19. Good fragrant lager to KO the NY. Pillowed gold. Aroma of mown grass, lemon, shrub sap. Hints of macaroon and almond behind crackers, curd, grass and honey touches. Clean malts lingering with vanilla, clean grassy hops. Fast and enjoyable without deep analysis. Good lager.

Cask conditioned handpump Becketts Bank Leeds 14/07/14. A golden coloured beer with a whitish head and lace. A nice fruity beer. Peachy notes are good. malt balances nicely making it an easy drinking tasty beer with a good body. Liked it.
Cask @ The King�s Arms in Salford. Mild fruit hop and taste but very pleasant in this respect. Deep amber with a v small head.

First tasted this at Gabriels, Paisley in July 1999. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear amber red in colour with a thin white head. sweet smell of damp raisins in the short aroma. Thin but creamy mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malts give a moist maltloaf base with raisins, sultanas and dates. Slight prickle of dusty hops gives a short bitter aftertaste. Finish is sweet and malty with strong biscuity overtones present in the mouth. An ok session bitter.

Cask@Market Porter, Borough. Reddish amber colour, creamy mediumsized white head. Aroma is sweet fruity hops along with nectar and wood. Flavour is nectar, wood and a lot of fruits in a nice balance. Aftertaste is fruity nectar and the mouth leaves really dry afterwards.
Copper with a small white head. Fruity aroma, blackberry and other berries. Fruity dry flavour, refreshing, and just a perfectly made bitter. I love the berry aroma.

Cask, Market Porter. Copper, thin white head. Nose is hoppy fresh citrus, touch of spice and butter. Mouth is slightly brackish bitterness. One-dimensional. Palate is slightly fruity, slightly dry. Alright.
Cask@MarketPorter. Sweet caramel malts aroma with herbal hops. Amber color, off-white head, good lace. Fruity, caramel, malts, light hoppy, little sticky.

1. Cask Handpump at Wilkie�s Tavern, Warrington 03/06/2002 Amber golden coloured creamy and slightly citrus flavour. Dry hop finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Crown Inn, Stockport 25/07/2009 Hoppy aroma. Golden coloured hoppy and fruity pear flavour with a little dryness and bitterness in a crisp malt finish.

Pale amber brew with the usual Phoenix rich fruitiness in aroma and flavour. Lots of full maltiness and flowery, sappy, orangey hops then a sweet yet dry and bitter finish. (cask @ Queen�s Arms, Cheetham)

Mid amber colour. Faint aroma. No complexity in the flavours, but clean, crisp and a touch citric, with some malt in the background. A little sweet and soft on the finish. Respectable stuff. Cask (handpump), Lord Moon of the Mall (JDW), Whitehall, London SW1.

Cask at CBC, Covent Garden on 24th August 2019. Clear amber with shallow film and partial lacing. Spicy, malty quasi-savoury aroma. Fruity in-mouth with berries. Hazelnut nuttiness. A nutty and fruity finish. Smooth mouthfeel and a light to medium body. Pleasant.
Cask @ Head Of Steam, Leeds. Clear golden with a creamy head. Clean hoppy, there's sugars prominent in its nose.

Cask-conditioned at the Room & Gaskill, York 24/6/2019. Golden in colour, with a tight, white, head. Tangerine and gooseberry fruits, a flinty edge, touch of resin, biscuity malts and a dryish finish. Very good.
Cask at The Falcon in Clapham Junction. Bright golden colour, well-hopped, a touch of resin, refreshing. Lovely golden ale.
Tried at the Three Stags, Bennington. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is slightly citrus. Taste light sweet. Light body.

Cask at Rose and Thistle, Frimley. Soft floral aroma. Clear gold. Thin creamy white head. Sweet with a light bitter edge. Citrus. Malts. Medium bodied. Slick. Soft carbonation. Abrupt finish. Pleasant - low key taste but complimented by the palate. Sessionable.

Cask (4.3%), 1/2 pint, hand-pulled at Haymarket Bar, Edinburgh on 23 Jun 2017, floral, pale malty aroma, pale golden with a thin white head and good film of lacing, floral, pale malty flavour with a bit of resin, creamy.

Cask in The King & Co in Clapham. Clear pale yellow, with a white head. Nose is a bit of sulphur �Burton snatch�, grain, cereal, light citrous hop. Taste is very light body with a light grainy hoppy character.
Blue bell in York, not overly hoppy for an APA. Very golden. Very nice. A good spa but not super flavoursome
Cask west riding dewsbury. Golden thin head lacing. Aroma is slight citrus hops. Taste is decent sweet biscuit malts zesty citrus decent hop bitterness. Medium body. Ok golden.
I really don�t know what to make of it. On of those spur of the moment beers. A bit of a potent flavour. I would say a cacao or a clove nose. Not that great, but I�ve had worse.

Well. I�m not a fan of hemp beer. I think it is an abomination of the true nature of beer. Mill Street does everything well though, including brrewing this hemp beer. It was a decent hemp (for hemp beer).

As far as I know, this is only available on tap at the Distillery area where the brewery is located. It�s alright as an opportunity for Mill Street to expand their repertoire, but it�s not my favourite. Kind of nutty and earthy, with a nice dark colour that belies its relatively mild taste. Alright as a genre exercise, but they�d be better off sticking to their other beers.

On tap at Pure Spirits across from the brewery in Toronto. Dark brown, smallish head; light, toasty caramel nose; bitter herbs and dried fruit on the tongue, a bit of cola character...thin, very dry finish; pretty dull I thought.

Again, just catching up my ratings here. I tried this at the outdoor jazz festival last year in the distillery district and it was my favourite beer of the night, which surprised me because the few hemp ales I have had so far in my life have been gimmicky and not very good. This one poured a deep brown with a floral nose of some sort (I could say hemp, but I was probably just looking for it). The word earthy has been used in previous ratings and that is fair � there really isn�t any hop bite here, but there is a very drinkable medium bodied ale. I found it well balanced which surprised me. Very good, I wonder if it has changed at all in the past year.
clear brown, off white head. sweetr malt and whole wheat toast aroma. flavour follows with the toastiness and finishes dry and earthy. not bad.

Clear brown w/ ruby hue. Beige head. Mild toasty aroma of honey & hemp. Light, carbonated feel. Slightly nutty, lightly toasted flavour w/ mineral & honey notes. Rounds off w/ some earthiness & a light spiciness.

Toasty aroma with some metallic hop notes, soap, crackers. Chestnut brown colour with no head. Light to medium body. Carbonation is low but insistent. Palate is woody, toasty with some light chocolate notes that contribute to an overall earthiness. Sweetish, crackerlike, slightly nutty, slightly oily finish.

I was at Pure Spirits, the pretentious restaurant and bar across from the Mill Street brewery, and I ordered a pint of their Tankhouse Pale Ale. I received something that looked like the Pale Ale, and smelled sort of like the Pale Ale, but it definately didn't taste like the Pale Ale. It wasn't bad by any means, it just didn't have the same hop bite, but instead had a more prominent sweet and earthy flavour, with subdued hops in the dry finish. Before I had a chance to question my server about it, I overheard another waitress listing the beers for someone, and a new Hemp beer was mentioned. I ran into one of the Mill Street guys outside after lunch, and he confirmed that what I had sounded like the Hemp beer. So that's what I'm guessing I had. Either that, or the Tankhouse Pale Ale was REALLY off that day...
Slight malt nose, amber with a small head. Sour/sweet flavour, more like caraway seeds. Really full bodied, dry after taste. Quite good!

column1: Golden Valley Muddy Valley Oatmeal Stout
column5: Draft pour pint at Golden Valley, presented on nitro. Near black pour, thick cream. Drinks like chocolate milk. Smooth, creamy and delicious. Very interesting cocoa, toffee like aroma. Roasted malt, battling a subtle sweetness. Very tasty stout here.

column1: Golden Valley Muddy Valley Oatmeal Stout
column5: Keg @ Golden Valley. Deep brown pour with a tight, creamy tan head. Nose is fairly mild-mannered. A bit of chocolate, little else. Smooth and supple body with a bit of earthy roast malt. Fine carbonation. OK.

column1: Golden Valley Muddy Valley Oatmeal Stout
column5: On tap at golden Valley brewing. Pours out black topped with a creamy tan head. Nose is sold roast some light ash notes and a little rolled oats. Taste is more of the nice roast malt light chocolate and some more of the oats.

column1: Golden Valley Muddy Valley Oatmeal Stout
column5: On tap at Golden Valley, pours black with a small tan head. Aroma is robust, with notes of dry cocoa, oats, and toasted bread. Flavour is similar, with low residual sweetness - oats, cocoa, and roasted malt. Thick palate without much sweetness at all. Well-constructed and enjoyable. Good.

column1: Golden Valley Muddy Valley Oatmeal Stout
column5: Draft - Oats, cocoa and some chocolate notes. Jet brown with a decent brown head. Toasty notes, some dark fruit and a rich body. A bit boring, but OK.

column1: Golden Valley Muddy Valley Oatmeal Stout
column5: Nice toasty beer with a creamy silky texture that was enjoyable off the nitro pour.

column1: Golden Valley Muddy Valley Oatmeal Stout
column5: Keg at the brewpub in Beaverton, 11/11/14. Light black with a decent tan covering. Nose is light roast, chocolate, toffee, spice. Taste comprises light coffee, richer chocolate notes, dark malt, subtle roasting and charr. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. Ok stout, becomes a little sweeter in the close.

column1: Golden Valley Muddy Valley Oatmeal Stout
column5: Tap. Very dark pour. Oatmeal, dried fruits, chocolate, malt. Medium to full body with a lot of flavors. Almost creamy finish. Nice

column1: Golden Valley Muddy Valley Oatmeal Stout
column5: On tap in Beaverton. Pours a murky brown color with a medium tan head. A big fruity and roasted malt nose. Dark fruits, plum, some sweet white chocolate and cocoa. Roasted throughout. Good.

column1: Golden Valley Muddy Valley Oatmeal Stout
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a black body with a finger-width, dense and very creamy, chocolate milk colored head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing throughout. Aroma is sweet and rich, milky and dark chocolates with a bit of a malted milk ball essence. A moderate amount of creamy roasts, a bit of a lactose sweetness, and touches of licorice. Flavor is similar. Creamy roasts and a nice mix of dark and milky chocolates that seem a bit accentuated by some lactose additions. A light ashy note, touches of licorice, smooth oats, and a light earthy bitterness as this finishes creamy and dry before leaving lengthy a aftertaste. Medium, smooth body and a soft, creamy, light carbonation. Overall, a pretty solid sweet stout. Rich, creamy, and roasty with a very soft, pleasant body. Nice beer.

From old tasting notes. Bright gold color with a brief white head. Fruity malt nose with a hint of floral hops. Pleasant hops upfront. Subtle light malty notes as well. Softly carbonated. Spicy hop finish is pleasant and dry.
12oz bottle (Old Notes)-Pours clear light golden. Aroma of skunk. Taste of corn, grains, and sweetness. This light bodied brew was not as bad as I thought it would be. Actually, quite tasty.
Liked the dark Augsburger better, but drank this off and on for years. More hop bite than Bud, but not a great beer by current craft beer standards.
This pours a bright golden colour, with a small white head. Has a very malted mouthfeel and a slightly spiced hop finish. mid palate, the taste resembles a candycane with a touch of mintiness.

Pkbites on the first page of the ratings says it all, so I won�t repeat what he said. What I will say is Augsburger was arguably the best lager in the USA, bar none. I recall my Dad drinking it in the 60s from quart bottles, and I loved it through the 80s in the green 6-packs. As the last regional to hold the Augsburger contract, I do not understand how Huber can�t make their Berghoff Lager taste like this! No excuse. RIP Augsburger; we loved ya! UPDATE: just went to the Monroe, Wisconsin website for the people that apparently bought out Huber. The music is the same as the Pabst website. Sadly, all my questions have been answered.

12oz bottle. Golden with large quickly fading bubbly head. Semi-skunky aroma with a touch of bread & fruit. Astringent & thin, but does give way to some mild hops & fruitiness but dryness prevails. Nothing special here.
medium body beer by my standards. Enjoed on several NWAs flight mid 2006. Has a good flavour for a lager, not overly bitter or watery.

From a 12-oz bottle, picked up from Pick & Save in Marshfield, WI, pours a light golden honey yellow with a thin fast dissolving head. Lots of carbonation. Aroma is immediate skonk maybe a little citrus but even more SKONK! The skunkiness may indicate the green bottle does not block the sunlight. Taste is very highly carbonated, grainy and sour. Finish is gritty and sour. This may have been a bad bottle but I remember the Augsburger from Huber was much better. Interesting history trail of this brew... 1951 to 1961 - Monarch Brewing Co, - Chicago; 1961 to 1972 - Potosi Brewing Co, - Potosi, WI; 1973 - 1989 Huber Brewing Co, - Monroe, WI; 1989 - 1997 Stroh Brewing Co, - Detroit, MI; 1997 - 2002 (limbo); 2002 - present Stevens Point Brewery, Stevens Point, WI

From a twist off 12 oz. bottle with no freshness date. Poured a clear lager golden with a small foamy white head. Grainy and grassy aromas with a light spicy and a subtle fruitiness. Even, steady carbonation and a softly crisp, smooth light bodied mouthfeel. Grainy tasting with a very light caramel, a little lemon-like fruitiness, a soft spiciness, the hops are way in the background, and a sort of dry hayish, sweet malty finish. Passable drinkability, but I wasn�t too impressed with this lager, glad I only purchased this as a single.
orange/ligtbrown color, thin lasting head, nice one with plesant grainy parts and hops,... a little less bottom and balance.
Fruity sweet aroma. Slightly acidic, with an alcoholic cringe. Finsih is wet. Has a weird wine-like floral quality.

Keg @ Golden Valley. Hazy gold with. Small head. Nose has some pine and cantaloupe meat. Light caramel. Flavor is lightly bitter. Sweet grain. More pine and some grass on the finish. Soft body, a touch soupy and unstructured. Ho-hum.

On tap at golden Valley brewing. Pours out a golden topped with a white head. Nose is a nice pine some floral hops and a little sweet caramel malt. Taste is more of the pine floral hop combo and a biscuit malt.

On tap at the Golden Valley Pub in Beaverton, OR. Yellow orange pour with a thick white head. Aroma and taste of muted citrus fruits with pine. A bit bitter, no real sweetness. Thin, but maybe I�m confusing the mouthfeel with the flavor. This is no better than average and not my beer.

On tap at Golden Valley, pours a hazy pale golden blonde with a small white head. Aroma brings out piney hops and just enough biscuity malt to back. Flavour is very clean, with piney hops, some fruity and floral notes, and just enough biscuity malt backbone. Clean and hoppy, with excessive drinkability.
Draft - Sweet grapefruit and pine. Clear gold and a decent white head. Bright grapefruit notes and a nice pithy bitter finish. Solid.

Keg at the Beaverton brewpub, 11/11/14. Lightly hazed golden orange with a moderate off white head. Nose is caramel malt forward, candied fruit peel, light tropicana, sweet tunes. Taste comprises caramel malt, light orange, straw. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. Medicore IPA, just about ticks the style boxes, pretty dull.
Tap. Light clear copper pour. Caramel, pine, floral. Slightly bitter light to medium body. Good effort

On tap in Beaverton. Pours a clear copper color with a large white head. A nice nose of caramel and pine. The flavor is a clear easygoing light IPA with low bitterness, dry, caramel, pine and light lemon. Enjoyable.
Bomber. Weak. Not sure how they call this an IPA. Cheap...you get what you pay for here. I�d rather spend another $.60 and get a hop stoopid or something with flavor.
On tap at the brewpub. A mild India Pale Ale. Not much of a bitter finish. Average at best.

Sampled at GTMW �11. Goddamn, why aren�t there more of these? Or why don�t they get the attention they deserve? It�s a full-flavored lager with plenty of grassy, classy, spicy hop character. Aroma was like sticking my nose in the foil bag from the homebrew shop. Moderately bitter in the flavor... gives you a little slap but sets no limits on your gullet. Also, bitchin� name.

On tap @ Delafield. Clear golden yellow with a pure white head. Aroma of bready malt, hay, citrus and fresh cut grass. Flavor is a great balance of bready/toasty pils malt and bitter citrus hops. Light body with active carbonation and a very smooth, clean, refreshing finish. I really like this beer, kind of a hybrid of the style but it works so well and is extremely drinkable.

Pale gold. Tangy noble/citrus hopping and light sweet malts. Pale lager malts followed by even, refreshing citrus hopping. Crisp, lightly acidic, light on the palate. Easy to drink. An overall success for the style.

Decent pils with a light color but with some nice hop character. The light sweet bready malt hid well in the background allowing for the low hop character to stick out a little. Well blended brew but could have gone for a more fresh hop character. Did not seem to be dry hopped.

My first one at the brewery in Delafield. Poured a clear golden with a medium sized white head. One thing that stood out which I later discussed with the brewer, was that it was noticeably hoppy for a pils- which I enjoyed of course. It just made it an interesting twist on an otherwise boring style (in my opinion). Some soft grapefruit and ginger notes underlying the beer. Aroma was classic grain, but again hops on the nose. Nice beer!

Sampled during Great Taste of Midwest 2009 in Madison, Wisconsin. Pours a clear golden yellow brew with a short lived off-white head. Aroma of grassy hops and golden grain malt with a hint of corn. Taste is medium bodied, with flavors of grassy hops and a touch of honey and golden grain malt. Finish has a sharp bitterness then a crisp aftertaste.
Sampler; Yellow body with white head. Corn aroma and flavor gives you the bitter beer face. Typical pils.

Pint at the brewpub. Big fluffy snow-white head with good retention topping a light clear gold body...fresh, mild grassy nose with light hints of acerbic hops...sweet, malty, bready initial flavor profile, reminds me of Portugese sweet bread...dries and thins out quite a bit late with a smattering of iron.

Completely transparent yellow-gold in color with some renegade bubbles rising to the top, where a dusty white head and similar wrung hold dominion. Bright aroma with sugary lemon wafers, expensive dish detergent, and lollypops. An over-arching theme of cleanliness, brightness and sweetness. Interesting garden variety flavor. Initially thin and then an herbal character is divulged. Malt profile is generally shunned while much attention was devoted to the hop bitterness. Tingly, musky, dry and clean. Quite possibly a contract brew for Stetson Cologne.

Clear gold color with a medium head. Interesting aroma that reminded me of honey. Dusty hops flavor with a light malt base. Wow... simple, yet tasty. One of the best made pilseners by a brew pub, hands down!
Sample at brewery. Brown with creamy head. Smells sweet and fruity with a background of chocolate. Flavor not as robust as aroma. Creamy.

It�s baaaack! ESB on tap. Pours clear Amber, large creamy beige head, great residual and lacing. Aroma is a bit dusty, biscuit, hints of grass and pine. Flavors is light sweet, light plus bitter, perhaps a bit bocky, if that is a word. Lingering bitterness. Medium light body.
Clear reddish brown pour with a thin white head. Aroma is biscuit, malty honey floral. Almost no hop nose at all not bitter. Overly sweet. Not bad but wonky for an ESB.
Clear amber body with a small white head. Dry malty aroma with a bit of floral hops. Dry caramel flavor with some light malt and a bit of floral hops on the end.
pretty nice, but their beers are quite similar, just a little more malt, light cola color, a little head, some butter notes and grapes
Honey aroma, volatile. Crystal clear copper, medium yellow head, good lacing. Maraschino cherry flavor.Vanilla present. Alcohol apparent. Grassy finish. Decent.

Deep amber, almost brown beer. Thin white head and lacing that quickly recedes. Strong green apple scent. Also some caramel and lager malt scent. Very sweet, malty taste with a sour, overripe fruit edge. Caramel and toffee malts, apples, pears, and overripe plums. Good and interesting beer.

Pours a clear reddish-orange color with a slightly fluffy medium sized white head. Aroma is notes of citrus and hops, with a nice roasted malt aroma. Flavor is a light malted roast flavor. A relatively solid ESB.
Pours orange/amber with a white head. Smells of citrus and rosey. tastes metallic and soapy with some earthy undertones.

(Sample Date: 3/14/2009 Source:Legend Brewery) Pint at the Brewery. Chocolate roast aroma with some earthy hops. Clear dark amber brown. Chocolate and roast with a bit of roast astringency and dark fruit notes. Earthy spicy hop flavor. Medium body and mouthfeel. Dry bitter finish that is slightly oak and wine.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecer�a Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Deep golden color. Sweet malty nose with oranges, toffee and brandy through out. Fully body with fairly yeasty mouth, a lot more bubblegum and cloves become apparent. Good, but not great.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecer�a Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Notes from the file last updated in 2010. Pours light gold. Aroma is kandi. Flavor is spice and kandi. And malt.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecer�a Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: 22oz bottle old rating -Pours a murky goldenish amber with a white head. Aroma of yeast, spice, and sugar. Taste of the same with the alcohol coming throught just a bit. This full bodied brew is a well done brew.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecer�a Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: MacTarnahan�s Brewing Company--Portland Brewing Company--Gran Luxe Tripel Ale--Limited Release 2003 22 oz. Bottle. 9.30% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) Belgian Ale--Trippel. Big thin head. Clear bright golden color. Sweet floral Belgian wheat coriander spice front. Sweet crisp body is hot with rich mellow Belgian banana flavor. No sediment yeast notes. Hot spicy clean end. Sampled 7/10/2003.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecer�a Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Very vinous. Like chardonnay with Westmalle yeast. Delicious but very unbeer like. Belgian wine.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecer�a Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Pour is a dark orange with a small white head. Aroma is some spice and fruityness along with some sugar. Flavor is a bit off with some candi sugar again and a spice but finishes with a stoung bitterness that leaves a sourness on the tounge. Maybe a bad bottle but this is not an above par triple. Alcohol is not a problem.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecer�a Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Thanks to Tom at Pyramid for breaking this one out. From a 22-oz. bottle--Poured a golden-straw-copper clear body with a small, rocky head. Yeasty, musty nose. Vinous, cidery flavor. Hints of apples, pears, and white wine. This beer survived four years at room temperature quite well. I would like to try another. Alcohol well hidden. Carbonation retained nicely. Quite good.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecer�a Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: (Bottle) Pours a lightly cloudy orange body with a small off-white head. Aroma of horse blanket, mustiness, and fruitiness. Flavor of cherries, berries, caramel and grapefruit with a bit of a bite in the finish.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecer�a Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: At first all I got for the nose was a snootful of soapy yeat, but as the head broke up, which it did rapidly, there was some sweet malt, cherries, and berries. Nice hazy amber body. The flavor is a fruity sweet malt, a touch of banana now added, and just a hint of its hefty abv. It has a sweet fruity finish with a low alcohol burn. Not bad. Binny�s Beverage Depot, Glen Ellyn, IL

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecer�a Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Not too much apparent in smell or appearence, the 9.3% isn�t really noticeable either. Pretty smooth, but also not that flavorful. I think this is a 2003 bottle. While not at the top of the tripel style, it�s pretty good.
Cask @ Horse & Trumpet, Leeds. Slightly hazed amber with a creamy head. Has a stewed fruity nose, with a less stated taste that includes some grain that�s flavoursome.
Cask. Frothy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Oily palate.
Mahogany colour with a creamy white head. Rich winter fruit, malt aroma. Rich fruit malt flavour. Strong tasting beer of malt and burnt toast.

Cask conditioned at The Woolpack, Banbury. Chestnut colour with white head. A sweet, malty, fruity bitter, quite autumnal in character, with a forest fruits type flavour. Quite a thick mouthfeel, but short on the finish.
Draught (Live and Let Live, Cambridge) Rusty orange, no head. Pleasnat, light hoppy aroma, some citrus - orange. Full malty, bitter taste, some nuttiness. A little citrus zing too.
Cask (handpump) at Babington Arms (JDW) Derby. Gob-smackingly lovely. Beatiful deep brown with a ruddy tinge, creamy head, chewy fruits in there, tingly feel to the finish. A well-appointed bitter.
A nice bitter. Aroma and flavour are a bit charred. Raisins aswell at the start, but its not sweet, dry citric spicy hops in the finish, quite a bitter finish.

Cask Conditioned, at the Wenlock Arms, Dark burgundy colour, very rustic looking, static but persistent white head, with a slight reddish tinge. It had an almost smoked aroma to go with its looks. Strong bitter but flavoured with cinnamon or spice. It certainly had the strength to compete at the end of the night. 6of7.

This beer is a load of shitte. I tasted corn in my beer, which I wouldn�t expect with a bitter. This really disappointed me and made me feel ripped off. I tasted some of the hops after word, but I was already too upset. dont buy it

Cask Conditioned, at the Wenlock Arms. But wait there�s more!! I ran out of space and was writing between other rates. This little treasure nearly escaped my eye. Golden with a proud irresistible white head. Big hoppy floral aroma. Good body and structure. A chewable beer. 8 of 7.

Cask handpull, �All creatures Great and Small festival�, The Merchant Inn, Drugby. Dull watery suck of lemon barley sweet with peach and elderflower hints. Dusty amber with a slim white lid. Slight vinegar on the nose. Grassy, sweet and dull.
A Mes rate: Cask at Chelmsford Beer Festival. Bland malty bitter with some slight hops to detect giving it some refreshing citric notes but it�s just not enough to save it. Like a watery iced tea.
Cask Handpump at the Queens Arms, Manchester 18/11/2001 Amber mid brown coloured and bitter. Roast malt and hop finish.

Striaght from the Cask at the Erewash Beer fest in Sandiacre on Sat 20th Nov 2005. Light brown on colour. Not as exciting as Phoenix beers usually are but still a good solid bitter. 2nd try At The Pilgrim in Liverpool Dec 4th 2004, much the same impression. Kinda fruity too...

Phoenix is one of my favourite breweries, but this was one of their more mundane efforts. It�s a pale copper coloured, malt accented, basic session bitter. Clean and dry, but not packed with flavour. Perfectly acceptable, but nothing there to really tickle the taste buds. Cask (handpump), Head of Steam, Euston, London.

Hand pulled at the Anchor, Birmingham (during their Phoenix weekend). Pale brown beer, which looks thin from the word go. Chubby, sweet rounded vague flavour. Slight bitter finish, and very slight overall. Like a less impressive brother of Oal Oak.

Cask Conditioned, at the Wenlock Arms. Definitely punching above its weight. Golden colour, no head. Slipped down very smoothly. FYI � Phoenix Micro Brewery was established in 1982 as Oak Brewery in Ellesmere Port. It moved in 1991 to Heywood, Rochdale and changed its name in 1996. It now supplies over 150 free trade outlets and has a very large programme of seasonal beers.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Summertime Ale
column5: Cask conditioned at The Old Bullring Tavern, Ludlow, Shrops. Hazed gold with white head. Malty, fusty grainy beer, tartish and really not in great order but very expensive in this pub!

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Summertime Ale
column5: Cask Handpump at the George & Dragon, Great Budworth 14/07/2003 Golden coloured with some wheat and hop aromas. Lasting bitter malt finish.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Summertime Ale
column5: Cask@Chelmsford BF. Quite corny, but oddly as a slight burnt malt flavour comes through, didn�t really sit well with me to be honest, corn on the cob.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Summertime Ale
column5: Beer #22 at Chelmsford Beer Festival, with Duff. I have to echo some of the other comments here about it not being a typical summer ale. Not that crisp and I detected distinct smoky notes in the aroma and a sort of burnt corn on the cob taste. Weird, but intriguing. Cask (gravity dispense).

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Summertime Ale
column5: Gravity at Olde Dolphin Inn Beer Festival, Derby. Strange - a faint whiff of chocolate? Really rather malty, not particularly crisp or refreshing, not what I�d expected.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Summertime Ale
column5: Cask Conditioned, White Horse Hedgerley, Bucks. Gravity dispense, poured by me. Started off ok, but has some weird roasty/caramel aftertaste that isn�t at home in a summer ale.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Summertime Ale
column5: Cask Conditioned, at the Wenlock Arms. Bright golden colour, shiny white head. A little short on flavour, especially given the quality of their bottled beers. I must say that I was excited to see it on but disappoint at the result. For better or worse everyone�s doing a summer ale this year.
Cask@black country arms, Walsall. Golden beer with small head. Aroma of malts and light honey. Taste is honey, malts and herb. Ok.
Cask gravity at Smugglers Alehouse New Romney. As Hunny Bunny 4.2% abv. clear gold lasting white head. honey no doubt almost soapy. OK condition. some lemon flavour. not for me.

500ml bottle from Beers of Europe, shared with Ashton McCobb. Pours hazy gold with a thick white head. Aromas of light sweet malt, faint honey. Taste is light sweet, hint of ginger. Light sweet finish. Yeasty.

Bottle thanks to allmyvinyl. Appearance - golden with a proportionate head. Quite a few "flavour chunks" suspended in there. Nose - pine or faint mountain herb. Taste - sour lemon and herbs. Palate - light bodied with a creamy yet tangy texture and a long dry finish. Overall - a bit on the dry side to be balanced.
Pint from the three horse shoes. Pale straw colour, white head. Faint hop and sweet aroma. Taste only has a faint honey hint. Better than expected.
A yellow golden colour and a small head, with a bitter taste to it. A nice floral aroma. A good finish to it would be a nice session beer.

500ml bottle. Golden yellow colour, foam white head that diminishes and aroma is malty & fruity. Taste is malt with honey-ish notes, some earthy yeast and a tangy hop bitterness. Light bodied, well carbonated, dry finish. OK.

Cask. Golden, small white head goes away quickly. Biscuit nose, some hops. Taste is biscuit, light hops, some sugar, but I didn�t get any honey. Really watery. Very bland but I do think this would be a great starting point for someone starting on craft beer.

Bottle 500ml. Clear light yellow colour with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, fully lasting, white head. Aroma is light moderate malty, flowery honey, citrus - lime, flowers. Flavour is moderate sweet and light acidic with a average to long duration, lemon, sour. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20111211]
A - floral with no honey? A - light with thin head T - little front with a lot of end bitter P - thin O - ehhh...
Very tasty being a lower alcohol beer. Nice crisp bitterness and well rounded malt flavor.

(Bottle) Pours llight yellow. Malty aroma with some funky, light floral, grassy and herb-ish hops. Tiny hints of buttery popcorn and fruits. Malty, medium sweet flavour with hoppy tones. Light bitter and a bit dry. Small body.

330 ml bottle from a local grocery store (Hemk�p). Light clear yellow color. Small white head, not lasting.Mix of malty and fruity scent.A bit metallic taste. Faint malty and hoppy taste as well.Fairly high bitterness, especially for a low alcohol beer. Quite a good lager beer, when you�re able to purchase it in your convinient store on the corner it�s even better.

Bottled. Yellowish golden colour, mediumsized white foamish bubbly head, a little lace. Cooked vegetables as well as skunked hops in aroma. Cooked vegetables, malts and quite strongly hopped finish. Not much aftertaste in this one. Watery and quite standard "bulk" stuff.
Bottled (BB 09/2006) Pale yellow, decent white head, lace. Sticky hoppy aroma. Hoppy but watery. Dry, slightly woody aftertaste.

(Can 50 cl) Comes as "DAB Mellen�l" at 4,5% ABV. An unspectacular pilsener golden beer with a decent head and a marked bitter finish. Comes is a rather corny yellow can with a smiling sun and a red bikini top.... 280802

Bottle. The colour is pale yellow with a tint of gold. The foam is two finger thick, white and quite firm. The smell is dry and bitter with lots of hops and a touch of dough. The carbonation is fresh and full of medium sized bubbles. Nice! The taste is well balanced with an integrated lovely dry bitterness and some malt with a touch of marzipan. The body is kind of weak with no traces of any sweetness or bread-notes. The aftertaste is gentle (and quite short) with a growing touch of malt and some sweetness. A very drinkable Dortmunder for barbeques and hot summer nights!
Yello beer. White head. A thin beer with not much aftertaste. Some taste from hops.
Yellow, carbonated, white head. Sugary aroma with some hop notes. Hoppy but thin flavor.
[3.5% ABV brewed for the Swedish market] A crisp and clean Pilsener. Nice bitterness despite of the low alcohol content.
Mild malt nose. Clear amber, headless. Honey, pecan, grass. Medium body, easy carbonation.

Draft at the brewpub. Bottom line comments: nothing really "wrong" with this one, but nothing great either. Golden beer, moderate hop. Not sure I�d align this with the "bitter" family in good ol� England, but it�s a drinkable quaff. (#6618, 5/17/2017)

Draft sample at the source. The beer is a clear yellow with a white head. The aroma has grainy bitterness and aome corn. Medium sweetness and odd corny notes. Lighter medium body and medium carbonation.

4oz on tap at the brewpub. CLear orange color. Thin white head, leaving good thicker lace. Medium to bigger body. Smooth, kind of soft lighter carbonation. Light dry finish. White bread, dough, mild caramel. Mild spicy hop. Moderate sweet taste, light bitter. An alright ESB.
Draft at the source. Crystal clear golden color. Subtle straw aroma. Taste is peppery biscuit.

Pours mostly clear and light amber. Nose is biscuit, crackers, And flowery hops with some light caramels. Flavor is English cracker malts with some toasted biscuits, flowery hops and some clean caramels. I just don�t really care for the English malt a lot of the time.
Clear amber color with ivory head. Mild spicy hop, pale malt aromas. medium body, average carbonation. Earthy aged hop flavors with dry pale malts--decent
Tap. Nice amber color. Good Head. Taste was slightly hoppy, not sweet but somewhat tasty. Aroma was a bread, slightly citrus.
Draft sample at brewpub on July 14, 2012. Medium amber hue, moderate malty nose, suitably firm ESB flavor that�s not the best of the style but far from the worst. Decent.
Draft, sampler: pours amber colored with a light off white head. Citrus aroma and a flavor that states malty and then hits you with its bitterness.
Cask Handpump at the Maltings, York 16/04/2011 Floral hop aroma. Golden coloured fruity hoppy and floral with a hint of dryness in a malt finish. A little thin on the palate.

Cask handpull, The Maltings, York, 18/04/11. Pure gold with a lace ruff. Bright floral and grassy hop, lime and biscuit aroma. Good tangy floral hop, rich tea biscuit, nettles and tangerine, balance. Squeaky clean, perfumed and soapy with generous finishing bitterness. Good- if a bit wishy-washy after a sip of Aardvark.

Amber-copper body with a low, white head. Lighter smell of hoppy fruits. Perfumed fruity taste with mild bitter endnotes. A bit thin and watered. Half, hand pulled cask at The North Bar in Leeds, 11.07.2010.

[Pint, North Bar - Leeds, 31/12/09] Clean pale appearance. Aroma of subtle grass and fruit. Slightly fruity taste. A pleasant but unadventurous ale. Just too laid back on all fronts. Probably more suited to a hot summer�s day.

Cask at the Maltings, York under the name �Silver Creek,� although the abv and style are the same - I am tempted to place the rating here until further notice, considering there is no mention of �Silver Creek� on the Rooster�s website. Orange bordering on copper with a thin film of dense white foam. Aroma is slightly indistinct, with slight grass, caramel, and dusty hops. Taste is upfront orange and lemon, with a malt presence dominated by caramel and butterscotch. Moderate to high bitterness, with a slight sour acidity in the finish. More lively in the carbonation than some.

cask at Maltings York: dissapointed in this one after having the tennesse stud as my last memory of outlaw brew. beer has a slightly astringent aroma with some berry fruitiness. The flavors were slightly asidic and became more developed as you drank. Quite a delicate bitterness and malt backround. good but not spectacular.
Handpulled at the Flowerpot, Derby. Still billed as an Outlaw brew. Well fruited and hoppish, slight astringent citrics, pale and tempting.

Cask Conditioned, at the Wenlock Arms, London. Pale golden colour with a ring of white. Fruity with soft malts. Apparently experimental and definitely still sold under the Outlaw Co. brand on this occassion. Not bad, the beer is well proportioned, just moderate everything. I would have called it and English Pale Ale, as there is nothing wheat about it.
Pale straw in colour. Flavours are light caramel with an IPA like chewiness. Traces of sulphur and salt. An addictive beer.

Cask Conditioned at The Dispensary, Liverpool. Pale Yellow beer with thin short head. A sharp tasting wheat beer with fragrant fruity notes. It has moved out of the Outlaw experimental stage. One of the tastier wheat beers and deserves to be a success.
Cask Conditioned at Blind Jacks, Knaresborough. Pale yellow in colour, this has a thin flavour of apricot character. No real bitterness or lasting aftertaste.

Draft at Brew Kettle Tap Lockout. Poured clear dark brown color with an average frothy off-white head that was mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate toasted chocolate nutty malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium toasted sweet flavor with a medium toasted sweet finish of moderate duration. The beer also went well with my spicy hot dog.

Sample at the Brew Kettle on 3/24/12. Clear reddish brown color with a medium tan head. Malty nose with grassy hop notes and some nuttiness. Caramel malt flavor with nuts and a bit of roast in the finish.

Bomber as extra in trade. Dark brown with red tint and large, billowing, tan head. Aroma is sweeter chocolate, nuttiness, a little dough and some fruit. Flavor is sweeter red and purple fruit, a little nuttiness, some caramel, chocolate, cocoa powder, a little mettalic, nice. Medium to full, creamy body with active carbonation. Tasty nuttiness with heavy chocolate, pretty great for a brown ale.

On tap at the Brew Kettle. Poured clear medium amber with a short cap of off-white head. The aroma picked up toasty caramel and nutty notes with rising chocolate as it warmed up.. quite sweet. The flavor had caramel and chocolate at the base with earthy and cocoa bitterness surrounding.. if you wait for it, a sizeable dose of pine bitterness emerges at the back and works very well. High carbonation on the palate with a sweet base and decent balance against the bitterness on the sides.. OK flow.. crisp, refreshing finish.

Bottle via homebrew swap. Thanks! Body is ruby ruby, tan head with minimal lacing. Nose is roasty brown malt, some caramelized sugar, light plastic. Flavor is nutty brown malt, dry toffee, more of that plastic. Some coffee comes through in the end along with balancing hops & some rich fruits.

Thanks to Crizay! Nutty, roasted malts in the aroma, with hints of coffee and vanilla. Pours medium to dark brown with a thin white head. Very good flavor, alittle nutty with some chocolate notes, with some caramel in the background.

22 oz bomber. Pours a dark semi clear amber with a medium sized frosty beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, cola and nuts. Taste of roasted malts, nuts, caramel/toffee with a faint chocolate presence. Not bad.

10/30/2007: Chestnut Brown Ale pous a dark brown color, is clear, and has a lasting dense and foamy head. The aroma and flavor are actually pretty rich with chocolate, caraelized sugar, and slightly roasted malt and nut flavors. The overall level of sweetness is just right for my taste as far as Brown Ales go. This beer has a medium to medium-full body and is pretty smooth and creamy on the palate. This is one of those nice, easy to drink beers that one could enjoy pint after pint of... 16 oz draught at The Brew Kettle in Strongsville, Ohio. Rating #14 for this beer.

Bomber courtesy of crizay. Pours brown with a thin white head. Smells of spice, caramel, roses, some chocolate. Tastes of chocolate, some earthy hints, tea, touches of underlying bitterness. Mouthfeel is a bit watery. Finish is semi-sweet.

Draft @ brewkettle: Murky brown color with a light tan head. Aroma, roasty notes with some caramel and molassas. Flavor, chestnuts, toasty, brown sugar, and roasty malts. Really quite nice, I would almost call it a porter for how malty it is. Really was my favorite beer of theirs that I had.

On tap @ Brew Kettle: Pours a clear amber with an off white head. Aroma, caramel, a light citrus hop to it, nutty, and some grassy hints. Flavor, caramel, a bit bready, grassy and spicy hops, a nice lively carbonation, with some pleasant bitterness on the finish.

Sample at the brewpub. Dark maple to light chestnut color, translucent, with a bit of creamy lasting ring...lightly toasty, malty nose that grows deeper and sweeter as it warsm...woody maltiness in the body, hint of lactic character, dried herbs...toasty dryness completes it.

Hazy reddish copper w/ finger of white foam. Sweet, toasty aroma of caramel, toffee & herbal, earthy hops. LIght, moderately resiny feel. Flavour is sweet & malty w/ some toasty notes & a mildly earthy hop finish.

Nice copper body with a good glow. The head is definitely on the thin size but has good color and density. The aroma is intensely malty. Hard woods, toffee and an interesting scuppernong (wild grape native to the Southeastern US) fruitiness that I�ve picked up in a couple of other beers. A nice bit of fresh hops are floating around in the aroma as well. The flavor isn�t quite as good as the aroma, but it�s quite quaffable. The medium bitter finish is neither short nor long.

On tap @ Brew Kettle: More of an Am. Amber than Alt,IMHO. Medium amber w/ a lasting white head. Compared to the Copperhead Red, this beer has a little more herbal hop aroma, malt is lightly toasty with a moderate caramel. Fruitiness is a little green apple. Flavor is medium toasted malt, light fruitiness, earthy hop, well balanced but lightly, ever so lightly to caramel malt flavor. Not terribly complex for amber style as it should not be, but highly drinkable. Finish is lightly earthy hop flavored as is aftertaste. Lighter body, maybe a little too light, smooth but dry m/f, medium carbonation. Good session beer due to lower abv, this one was 4.2, but not terribly complex. Given the 4.2 ABV, it might not be. I bought a growler of this based on drinkability as a session beer for New Year�s Eve, not because it was a great beer. But it does have a lot of flavor for a lighter beer, I�ll give it that.

Slight malt aroma, but overall very little scent. Nice orange-brown color. A little sweet, malty flavor. Slightly salty aftertaste which I did not like. Very smooth. Not a bad Alt, but not a Long Trail.
The menu said Amber, but their description refers to it as an Alt. I thought it was more of an alt. Smooth, thick and sweet - full of caramel. A medium hop presence. Great lacing.

Bottle: Chocolate milk brown head lasts on a dark brown body. Roasty aroma predominates, but doesn�t overpower. Chocolate and caramel underly roasty coffee. Sugary sweetness and a very light fruitiness. Well balanced and roasty with a sugary sweetness. Very light chocolate and alcohol flavor. Caramel sandwiched between. Fruitiness seems low, but gets accented by the sugary sweetness. Finish is sweet and roasty. Body is lighter and has higher carbonation. M/f is smooth and lightly dry in the finish. Not a bad stout! A little thin on depth, but still fairly flavorful.
Thick sweet and smooth. The sweetness was not overwhelming though - there was a good amount of roast and hop in this, adding some coffee flavors and a dry-er ending. Very tasty.

22 ounce bottle. Pours a lightly hazy golden/orange with small floaties and a medium foamy white head. Aroma of lemon, sweet cereal grains, floral, some hops and honey. Flavor of honey, malt sweet, citrus, wheat and cheerios.
Bottled as Brew Kettle Honey Wheat. Pours a clear gold with a large foamy head. The aroma is definitely wheaty and there�s a nice honey note throughout. Light flavor. Refreshing.

Bottle: Light amber w/ a short lived white head. Sweet honey in the immediate nose, then hints of wheat as it warms and nuttiness. Seems to be also a little floral character, but not necessarily from the hops. Well balanced, wheat malt flavor and honey, clean! There�s a lightly tart finish that is sort of refreshing and a bitterness in the aftertaste. Lighter mouthfeel, but one drawback, it�s lightly astringent. Highly carbonated. Good lawnmower beer, not highly flavored, but better than macro alternatives!

This draft brew on tap at the Kettle poured a small sized head of finely sized mostly lasting off white colored bubbles that left behind a fair lacing. The body was a transparent uncarbonated light brown color. The aroma was a mild honey wheat one and the mouth feel was smooth initially with a wheat malt bite in the finish. It did have a nice smooth honey wheat flavor that was not overdone on the honey which was sweet and smooth.

On tap at The Brew Kettle. Small sized white head and fine-small sized bubbles that mostly diminished. Transparent and an orange-golden hue. Malty, hoppy and sweet aroma. Sweet and malty flavor. Smooth palate and fair lacing.

The palate of this one started off prickly and overly bubbly - it thinned out along the way. Clear and golden with decent lacing. A tangy ale with medium thick honey running through it. Finished with a sweet lingering honey. Refreshing.

column1: The Brew Kettle Copperhead Red Ale
column5: Bomber at Darkness Day 2012. Amber pour with a small head. Very malty, thinner palate. Not bad but not great.

column1: The Brew Kettle Copperhead Red Ale
column5: Pours a nice coppery color with a very light tan head. It�s sweet and malty in both aroma and flavor. Mediocre, but not bad by any stretch.

column1: The Brew Kettle Copperhead Red Ale
column5: From the 4/2012 3R6P tasting. +++ Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured an orange-caramel color with a small soapy white head that left a touch of lacing. The aroma was crystal malt and vague fruity hops. The flavor was caramel, grapefruit, pine, crystal malt and a hint of orange. The finish was medium length caramel, crystal malt and vague fruit. Medium body. Uninspired.

column1: The Brew Kettle Copperhead Red Ale
column5: From a bomber. A lttle darker than a pale lager. Smell is sweet bready yeast. Taste follows the aroma, quite malty. Though quite malty, with a little caroub, not really over the hedge. A little difficult on a long swig. A little medicine builds during the session. Finish is same. $4.99 for this bomber.

column1: The Brew Kettle Copperhead Red Ale
column5: 22 ounce bottle. Served in a Sam Adams Boston Lager glass, the beer pours a clear amber color with about a half inch off-white head that went away quickly. There�s a good amount of lacing left on the glass. The beer smells like toffee, toasted and bready malt, and some light fruitiness. The taste is similar to the aroma, but there�s also a bit of caramel flavor noticeable too. Mouthfeel/body is medium, it�s a bit slick and creamy and has moderate carbonation. It�s also smooth and goes down easy. I think it�s a decent enough beer overall. If I remember correctly this was just $3.99 a bottle at my local Giant Eagle, so at that price I�d buy it again.

column1: The Brew Kettle Copperhead Red Ale
column5: 22 ounce bottle, no freshness date. Pours crystal clear golden orange color with a nice 2 finger off white head with very good retention that reduces to a fairly thick lacing cap. A fair amount of lacing clings to the glass. Aromas of caramel, toasted malt, bread, and light citrus notes with some light spiciness. Some pretty faint aromas that have some good balance. They get a bit stronger as the beer warms. Taste of caramel, bread, toasted malt, light citrus, and spiciness. Fair amount of bitterness on the finish; with linger notes of caramel, bread, citrus, and spiciness on the finish. Medium carbonation and a light-medium body; with a slightly creamy mouthfeel. Great drinkability as expected for 5%; with no alcohol noticed in the taste or finish. Nice balance of flavor and bitterness. Overall this is a pretty nice amber ale that is easy to drink and quite enjoyable.

column1: The Brew Kettle Copperhead Red Ale
column5: Bomber from Whole Foods Market Columbus/Dublin, OH. Pours a clear amber color with a medium sized fizzy brown head that fades quickly. Aroma of leafy hops and toffeeish malts. The taste is toffee malts, toasted malts, spicy hops. Medium-full bodied. Well balanced. Another nice one from Brew Kettle.

column1: The Brew Kettle Copperhead Red Ale
column5: Pours amber with a slight khaki head. A hint of malt on the nose. Moderate carbonation smooth balanced taste but not particularly complex. Clean finisher. Meh!

column1: The Brew Kettle Copperhead Red Ale
column5: 22 oz bottle. Poured an amber color with little head at all. Not much aroma if any. Taste was just an average beer. I was a little disappointed in this offering from TBK because most of their other stuff is really really good. Only good thing was is that the 22oz bottle was only 3.99!!

column1: The Brew Kettle Copperhead Red Ale
column5: not much aroma, light malt floral rose smell with little head. rich amber color. Tastes strongly of rose with caramel malt flavors on the back of the tongue and light bitter hoppiness with no aftertaste. Don�t drink this one really cold, its much more flavorful just slightly chilled.

This was a guest tap at the BrewKettle in Strongsville. This was a thick ale with a lot of sweetness - I don't think I've ever eaten juniper berries, but under the sweetness there was a medicinal taste. Finished dry, but the sweet flavors stayed too long.

On tap @ Spandauer Havelfest 2019. Purple/dark red body with a tall, creamy lasting pink head. Mineral aroma. Taste is cherry syrup, sweet, sugar. Fake, chemical. Fruity finish. Medium body, soft carbonation, oily/sticky texture

column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Dark brown with quickly diminishing head. Decent lacing though. Roasted malt aroma and flavor. Medium body. Nice to try.

thanks to Owen for the beer. Bottle dated 2004. Yikes Pours dark brown nearly black. Great carbonation for the age. Long lasting light brown head. Lots of spotty lacing. Nose is very oxidised. Dry cardboard, tree roots, licorice, and some char and ash. Quite pleasant for the age and has held up reasonably. Taste is wet cardboard, burnt licorice root, and roast malts. Not a bad for the amount of oxidation but a shadow of what is was.
Dark brown coloured. Head is light brown and mostly lasting. Aroma is burnt, roasted, laqurice, dark bread. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter. Medium to full body. Oily texture. Soft carbonation.
Can. Dark brown colour with a medium off white head. Aroma and taste of roasted malts and chocolate. Watery mouthfeel.
Can. Nice creamy head with good duration. Color is close to black. Aroma and taste are molasses, chocolate, caramel and malt.

Can. Thanks to my brother for bringing this from Sri Lanka. Creamy lightbrown good mostly lasting head. Moderate malty and hopy aroma. Roast and especially chocolate notes. Moderate sweet and bitter flavor. Week ocolate notes. Moderate light bitter finish. Oily palate. Not a good stout but not terrible either.

Smells and tastes like roasted malts with no hint of hops. This beer has a smooth taste and mouthfeel, but if carbonation had a specific taste, this beer has it. It is very carbonated, but not in a sense that it is brimming with bubbles...more like a sensation on your tongue. All in all, a good stout.
Black and fizzy with small head that does not last. Roasted malt aromas, but high carbonation tickles the nose (not good). Very thin palate. Much too watery for a stout.

Bottled, at Paddy�s Brewpub, Flemington, Australia. Dark brown with a slightly reddish hue. Not looking like the classic stout or foreign stout for that matter but still decent. If not for the appearance I noted that it was very similar to the Srilanken Lion Stout, just thinner. The gathering: duff, eczematic, Linc, motelpogo, Spiesy, Sully.
Not too bad, but pretty thin and diluted for a stout. fairly tasty and easy to drink though. Sweet caramel and light roasted flavours, pretty flat however.
17th beer of the night? Sheesh I did get there late! Horribly sweet aroma, tastes like any other weak sweet stout, short lived roasty flavour, touch of charcoal with lingering sweetness.

Cask, at Newark Beer Festival, May 2004. Notes recovered from a recently unearthed old notebook. Rocket fuel is certainly an apt name. Very volatile, spirity, lighter fluid aroma. Nearly black. Flavour is like a mixture of liquidised Pontefract Cakes (licorice) and Gees Linctus cough mixture and rubbing alcohol. And the texture is pretty much how I�d guess that mix would end up too - thick and syrupy sweet. Really difficult to know what to make of this. Leave it in the barrel to settle down for another year and you might have something a bit more developed and harmonious. As it is, its all over the place. A couple of extra points on the overall score for potential.
Cask Stillage at the Victoria Leisure Centre, Nottingham 16/10/2003 Dark and quite sweet with plenty of alcohol. Slightly chocolaty flavour to the lasting finish.

Brown and orange with no head. Aromas are sweet and sour with musty yeast. Not off - just not that nice. Flavours are yeasty with sweet caramel. Thick and sickly on the palate. Has a bit of the kit homebrew barley wine I once made. Stronger is not always better - this is a bit of a mess. Surprisingly, alcohol is not the evident in the taste. Have a Bonce Blower instead if strong beers are your thing.

Dark coughing syrup, flows in the same way; not a bubble gets a chance. Bit of tar, and a full ashtray after a very long disco night - as well as the first morning coffee in a big hospital make out the nose. When I was young, we used liquorice sweet " drop " to make "coffee" with. If I had had a press with some Archimedes screw, I might have obtained this - without the alcohol, of course, but it has no more flavour. Well, OK, the finish is somewhat vinous. With tobacco ash. Syrupy MF. No, make that just plain syrup. They tried something. It failed. Is Boggart Hole Clough still operational, S.T.? Barley Wine?

this is certainly one to flush out your organs. forget about nitrogen car kits, stick a pint of this in your tank and it�ll be goodbye today...see you next millenium. i think most people buy this for the novelty. beers of this strength cannot be taken seriously. dark, sweet and sickly. one of those you close a day at the festival with and to keep the fire burning till you get home. i really find it hard to rate this beer in figures. i gave it 6 but i dont regret having it, just wouldnt have it again, ive done my time.

Cask Conditioned at The Ship & Mitre, Liverpool. This is now the strongest beer I have ever knowingly had, though the 20 yr old Hardy's may have been above it. It is as black as the night with a red hint, no particular head. Imagine the Jollop the Doctor gave you as a kid to get rid of a particularly heavy cough and this is what you have but with an extra alcohol through the nose blast. Linctus and Bluebird Treacle toffee converge in a heady mix. Not for the faint hearted, but I've not had a cough since!!

Flasche 0,33l: Golden, glasklar, stabiler mittelporiger Schaum; frische + leicht fruchtige Nase, dezente Zitrusnoten, Hopfennoten, Getreide, Malz, leichte fruchtige S�ure, Brotteig, fruchtig-s�uerliche Bitterkeit; frischer + leicht fruchtiger K�rper, trockene W�rze, leichte Hopfennoten, unreife Fr�chte, Malz, gr�nes Getreide, cremig, kr�ftige Kohlens�ure, leichte trockene Zitrusnoten; angenehmer fruchtig-trockener Nachgang

33cl MHD03/2018 from the local Denn's. - Kurz: sawtooth unpolished Biobrot malts overshadow faint hedgerow-herbal hops in this typically Bio-uncouth lager trying to go undercover as a Pils. Boiled cereals in the nose ruin the fun from the onset. Had a fresh Tegernseer Helles before this and the lemonade hops were so much more fragrant yet subtle for a less hoppy style.

0.33 l bottle from �denn�s Biomarkt� (Gevelsberg), best before August 2017. Clear, golden yellow with a medium large, frothy, almost stable, white head. Sweetish, moderately grassy-spicy aroma of grains, straw and slightest hints of citrus. Slightly sweetish, moderately bitter, quite grassy-spicy and minimally fruity taste of grains, straw, some honey and hints of citrus, followed by a short, moderately bitter, grassy-spicy and quite dry finish. Medium body, slightly effervescent mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Nice!
Goldgelb schaum ok, Geruch malzig getreidig leichter Hopfen etwas s�uerlich, im Geschmack ebenfalls eher malzig getreidog mit herb saurem Abgang

Bottle from ErlangerNick, thanks my friend, drunk at home. Clear gold colour lasting white head. Lovely lager aroma, I mean I haven�t smelt that in a while. Lager yeast and malt aroma. Fairly light in the mouth then a fairly aggressive hop finish. I thought this was pretty good. Some bitter finish. Rather a decent pils.

Bottle: Golden, clear, small white foamy layer; mild strawy-malty nose; mild - as well - bitter-sweet flavour, light bodied, at least soft; shorter and slightly drier herbal-malty, but thinnish finish. A very inoffensive brew...

Bottle. Clear golden color eutg white head. Aroma is grainy, cardboard, grassy-earthy hops. Taste is earthy and floral, malty, some cardboard, but overall on the interesting side. Medium carbonation. Quite malt-forward, but the hops are there as well. Okay overall.
Bottle. Golden, white head. Fresh grassy hop nose, light sulphuric and metallic. Medium light chewy body, some fruity malt, a hint cattiness, grassy and perfumed hop finish.

0,33l Flasche. Dunkelgelbes klares Pils mit cremigem Schaum. Es riecht nach Honig, Getreide und Stroh. Geschmacklich recht flach. Wenig Hopfen. Undifferenziert herb. W�sserig im Mittelteil. Metallisch im Abgang. Das Bier tut nicht weh, Ist aber ein schwaches Pils.

330ml bottle. Minimally cloudy, amber colour with small to average, frothy, fairly lasting, minimally lacing, white head. Herbal-spicy, grassy hoppy aroma, cautious, minimally strawy, grainy background. Taste is grassy hoppy, herbal-spicy hints of hay. Nice.

column4: Unicer Bebidas (SBG Super Bock Group - Carlsberg)
column5: Drunk on Beer Time in Albufeira from bottle, black beer with nice short cappuccino head, nice, smell is bread, taste is also bread, roasty malts, not bitter, not sweet, no coffee, short finish, light creamy texture, soft carbonation, medium body, good but not special, Earlier Rating: 10/8/2019 Total Score: 3.2 Drunk on Beer Time in Albufeira from bottle, black beer with nice short cappuccino head, nice, smell is bread, taste is also bread, roasty malts, not bitter, not sweet, no coffee, short finish, light creamy texture, soft carbonation, medium body, good but not special,

column4: Unicer Bebidas (SBG Super Bock Group - Carlsberg)
column5: Bottle of 25cl, in a Tulip glass; from the fridge. An OK Tier stout. Not the best, not the worst either.

column4: Unicer Bebidas (SBG Super Bock Group - Carlsberg)
column5: Having one at the Villa in Luxembourg-Beggen. Very dark with a frothy but fast dissipating beige head. Smell of rum and cream. Slight bitterness in taste but rather watery. Therefore refreshing. Low carbonation.
Goudblond bier, koolzuur verdwijnt wat snel. Geur mout, bloemen, grassen. Smaak mout, alpenweide, vanille. Aangenaam mondgevoel, wat zoet. Nasmaak, mout, kruiden, lichte hop bitter. Aangenaam drinken
Bottle @ home. Clear golden color, medium to full sized white head. Smell and taste malts, hayish, decently bitter. Easy to drink, pleasant. 7-4-7-4-16.
bottle bb 23/4/19 oro carico limpida buona schiuma piuttosto persistente naso decisa maltatura note leggermente caramellate Amaro delicato una leggera nota Metallica
Bottle from Bierspezi Hamburg - clear golden color, white head. simple m�rzen, quite bitter! not an easy drink.
Tap at Kelkje during BrettFest. Clear golden with white head. Sweet malts, wheat, barley, milk of the beechwood, light caramel, leather. Moderate sweet and bitter. Medium body and soft carbonation.

6 3 6 3 12 Draft at Kelkje, Amsterdam. Near clear golden orange with an off white head. Aroma of bread, dough, malt, light fruit and grain. Flavour is above light sweet and bitter. Above light bodied with moderate carbonation.

resin, floral, grass, spruce, citrus, herbs, caramel, roasty, amber, orange, red, brown, cloudy, sparkling, minimal head, white foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, lightly sour,
Fles 50cl thuis als Zimbus Drachenblut. Zoetig, vol, droppig, caramel, gebrande mout. (10-2014).

Draft @ In De Wildeman. Crystal clear light amber (or deep golden) color. Dense white head. Aroma's of malt, hay/grain, light sweet, light butter. Flavor is grainish, light sweet. Light bodied. Hint of bitterness in the finish. Clean German M�rzen.
Kastanienfarben, klar mit sehr feiner Blume. Malziger Antrunk, sch�n w�rzig, Alkoholnoten kommen auch durch! Feingehopft im Abgang. Kr�ftiges M�rzenbier.

Bottle. Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma of fruity almost minty alike - children vitamin pils, some butterscotch alike nose, leafy hop profile. Taste is grains, fruity and leafy hops, rather sweet, a whiff of spice and deep butterscotch. Quite sweet with a little bitternes.

("St. Geogen Br�u Helles") Klares goldenes Bier mit wenig Schaum. Duft flach nach Getreide. Geschmack schwach metallisch, etwas w�ssrig, leichte Bitterkeit. Vollbierans�tze im Aroma vorhanden, setzen sich aber nicht durch.
Tap at the brewpub. Pours hazy gold with a white head. Aromas of clove and banana. Medium body/strong carbonation. Flavor is bready/clove/banana. Really quie flavorful in the style.

draft at the brewpub - Pours a hazy straw color with virtually no head. It has a rich, yeasty, banana aroma. The taste is sweet and wheaty with substantial banana and spice notes. I enjoyed this hefeweizen.

Draft at brewpub. Dirty/murky/muddy yellow colored body with a fine white head. Far too yeast heavy (and don�t tell me that�s how hefeweizen is supposed to be) - low carbonation and soft texture. Creamed bananas and creamed wheat with some light lemon citrus. Bland.

Tap at brewpub. Pours cloudy but with a brownish mustard-yellow tint. Aroma is a perfect hefe: bubblegum, banana, and clove. This is how a hefe should smell. Flavor is soured banana with weak clove. Spreading mouthfeel. For such a good smell, this beer disappoints after that.
had at the brewery on a recent visit to estes park. fairly typical hefe with maybe a little sweeter twist. made a nice session beer during the summer trip.

Draught sample at the brewery. The beeer was a hazy, light-medium gold color without any head. The aroma was malty with light notes of toasted grain; Hoppy with light notes of herb. floral, moderate note of lemon; Yeasty with a trace of dough; Moderate miscellaneous notes of banana and clove. The flavor was moderately-to-heavily sweet, lightly-to-moderately acidic with an average-sized, husky, trace-sour finish. The body was light-to-medium, the texture was watery and the carbonation was lively.

Head is fully diminishing. Body is hazy light to medium yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (bread), with notes of bubble gum and banana. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic. Medium body, watery/syrupy texture, soft/lively carbonation.
I am not a fan of wheat beers, but this was probably not a good one to judge the genre. Aroma was pleasing, but taste was sweet and not enough hops to cover the wheat. Not a great aftertaste as well.
Tap. Pours hazy yellow with a thin white head. Sweet wheat aroma. Banana and clove flavor with a dry wheat body. Fizzy and light bodied refreshing palate.

On tap @the brewery. Hazy yellow with a white head . Aromas of wheat, yeast and just a hint of banana and spice. Flavor was wheat and yeast with a little banana and clove hiding in the background. Not a very good hefe-wiezen.
Pale golden yellow, large white head. Grassy aroma with hints like club soda. Light watery body like unfermented wort. I wont have this again.
Cask Handpump at the Smithfield Hotel, Manchester 22/06/2003 Golden colour and very fruity with some alcohol and sourness. Lasting malt hop finish.

Cask, Wetherspoon's Watch House, Lewisham. Good condition. A dirty gold colour. Sweetish with some soft but tangy hops; quite earthy but with citric tones. Malt becomes cloying in the finish. Some honey flavours up front - but on the whole quite muddy. Not great.

I remember the name being 'Swift Hound'not 'Swift Hand', but my writing isn't so clear anyway, so i guess this is the beer. Sweet toffe-ish start, thin to medium bodied, with some bitter hop in the finish, uncomplicated, but enjoyable. Had this one on cask aswell.

Cask Conditioned, at the Wenlock Arms. Dave says to me so �so what nest then?�. I say �I�ve had everything on mate�. He says �wait just a ??? minute, I�ll be right back�. Down the cellar stairs the saint goes, to return with tomorrow�s spoils. The man is a saint. It was lovely and golden, just settling down pale ale. Fresh, crisp, pale looking. Fruity but nicely so. This was turning out to be a very civilised afternoon at the Wenlock�.

column1: Walking Man Homo Erectus Imperial IPA
column5: Pours a cloudy amber with a small tanish head and little to no lacing. Smell is of caramel, fruit, a touch of citrus, and hops. Taste is chewy, fruity, caramel, a good amount of bitterness, and malt back. Ends thick and a little strong.

column1: Walking Man Homo Erectus Imperial IPA
column5: Draught @ the brewery. Pours a clear brownish colour with a white head. Nose is malty sweet and pleasant pine notes. Flavour is a quite sweet caramel malty upfront that lends way to mild hop character that develops further toward the end. Classic older style DIPA.

column1: Walking Man Homo Erectus Imperial IPA
column5: Draft - Sticky lupulin and caramel notes. Very sweet and caramel forward. Copper gold with a decent beige head. Sweet, sticky and oily caramel with hops and a bit of a dry finish. Very old school caramel forward.

column1: Walking Man Homo Erectus Imperial IPA
column5: Cloudy amber full tan head. Nice sweetish hop/malt initial taste. Long evolving long lasting but finish a bit bitter on the edge of the tongue. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
