column1: Walking Man Homo Erectus Imperial IPA
column5: Total home run for Walking Man. Never before had a high ABV double/imperial IPA that was so well balanced and drinkable. No alcohol burn, no throat scraping hoppiness - just great flavor and mouthfeel - blissful EXPERIENCE! Thanks Stevenson WA for creating this.

column1: Walking Man Homo Erectus Imperial IPA
column5: Bottle at home. Pours cloudy amber with a large, frothy off-white head, long retention with excellent lacing. Aroma is heavy citrus, pine and resin hops with medium caramel and doughy malt and light pear esters. Flavor is heavy citrus, pine and resin hops and moderate bitterness, sweet caramel and doughy malt with a dry finish. Full body and moderate carbonation.

column1: Walking Man Homo Erectus Imperial IPA
column5: Rating #1957 2015.09.26 #CraftTakesSeattle Day 3, Beer 57 Clear golden pour with a bubbly white foam, spotty lacing. Nose is tangerine, pineapple, essentially the tropics in a blender. Mouthfeel crisp, mild alcohol warmth, low-medium carbonation. Taste is sweet tropical notes with the spicy tang and hoppy bite. Wicked.

column1: Walking Man Homo Erectus Imperial IPA
column5: On tap at ABV Pub in Hillsboro, OR. Hazy orange/copper pour with a small white head. Fruity aroma. Flavors of orange and mango and other citrus. A nicely malty and sweet IPA with lots of hops and flavor. Medium full mouthfeel.

column1: Walking Man Homo Erectus Imperial IPA
column5: Bottle: Poured a copper with off white head. Aroma is malty. Taste is malty with some hops. Gets some bonus for the labeling on this one, but not much else here.

column1: Walking Man Homo Erectus Imperial IPA
column5: Bottle from Belmont Station, Portland Hazy amber color with medium head. The strong malty character of this beer and medium sweetness level, although both lovely, label this as an old school IIPA; the hops are strong, more resiny than else, a bit orangey too; the malts also have a mild biscuity note. The caramel still dominates the final. The alcohol is well conceived. Excellent powerful beer, I wouldn�t drink more than a glass of it per session though.

Not bad for a dark wheat beer. Murky medium to dark brown appearance with a hint of red. Light malty and wheaty flavors, little bit of sweet and tart fruit. Growing on me with each sample of the six-pack, but not really something I would rush to get again. Decent beer though...worth the try.

Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a small head. Aroma of caramel, bit of citrus and grain. Taste of chocolate, mild malt sweetness and grain. Some bitterness and fairly clean finish. Moderate body, bit of a malty character. Not bad.

Nice taste, nothing special about it, Tastes like a generic version of a dunkel. Very drinkable. Has nice color, slight chocolate and sweetness taste, very small head. I really liked this beer, but I've had better dunkels..

Can from Main Market Co-op. Deep rick brown color with thick, fluffy beige head. Aroma is light roast and nutty character. Tadte is spot on, roasty, grainy and thick. Never thought I'd see a top notch dunkelweizen from the States. This is it.
Deep brown with a dickhead. Sweet malt, Caramell, very light wheat spice, a bit of earth, some chocolate in the background. Medium bodied. A sweet slightly bitter finish. Solid.
Can from Total Wine, Gainesville, VA. Pours clear brown with an inch of beige head. Aroma is very light: roasted malts and that�s about it. Flavor is nutty coffee, browning leaves, toast. Not bad.
Draft pours brown with a off white head. Aroma of grains, chocolate and caramel. Taste is malty.

Can. It pours a dark brown/cola color with a light tan head. The aroma is roasty with some notes of cocoa, plum and raisin. Maybe a hint of coffee, but I think it�s mostly the roasted malt. The flavor is fruity with more plum and raisin. Mild notes of cocoa and roasted malt in the background. The roasted malt comes through stronger in the finish with a hint of ashy bitterness. The body is light, but there�s some oily slickness on the palate that adds some depth to the strong flavors. It has a raisin bread-like malty backbone. A little sweet in the finish, but overall a pretty enjoyable take on the style.

12 oz can into a sampler glass, dark brown with short tan head. Hint of malt in the aroma, light body, little in the way of carbonation. Chocolate and toasted malt flavor, not much banana or clove noted. Mild malt finish with slight bitterness. Now I want to try a beer actually faithful to this style and compare.

12oz bottle (courtesy of Headbanger) poured into a Weizen Glass at 39�. Color is a deep dark brown with mellow carbonation and a small off white head. Aroma is roasted malt with a hint of smoke. Body is a lighter medium with a smooth mouth feel. Flavor is roasted malt, a hint of dark chocolate and a little hop spice. After taste is clean with some bitterness coming in. Overall it�s a nice flavorful brew.
330ml bottle in 2013. Hazy orange with a white head. Aroma of raspberry sweets, sweet fruit and acidic notes. Light and crisp. Raspberry flavour seems a bit fake.
Hazy/turbid orange/brown beer with a slight/medium off-white/beige head. Medium aroma; taste starts medium sweet and ends slightly bitter and dry. Malts, orange, raspberry, tart and hops. 7/4/7/3

Bottle. 33cl sample. The aroma has raspberries, wheats, hint of slight lactic sourness. Bit hazy, orange coloured beer with a thin head. The taste is light sourish, bit tart, has more sourish tones towards the finish. Initially more lactic, bit more citric in the end. Raspberries and wheat dominate the flavour. Fresh beer. Decent.
Bottle @ home. Clear orange amber color, medium sized off-white head. Smell and taste are quite nice, clearly raspberry, only a little bit sweet and a light tart note. Quite ok.
Bottle @ BBQ. Hazy amber colour with a small white head. Smells fruity, raspberry, strawberry. Tastes strawberry, cherry, fruity, sweet. Medium body, nice carbo.
#2055 Bottle. Hazy pink to amber, medium off-white head. Aroma of raspberries, touch of malts. Taste is lightly sweet, a bit tart. Raspberries, wheat, yeasty finish. Medium body and carbonation. OK
Bottle 0.33l. Cloudy, amber colored. AROMA- raspberries, touch of dumpling. FLAVOR- pleasantly lightly sour, not dry, raspberries, touch of dumpling dough. Medium bodied. Pleasant one.

33cl bottle. Appearance: A deep orange body, with a tall and thick off-white head. Aroma:wheat,raspberries, berries marmalade. Taste: Rapsberries and wheat sourness a bit artificial, some marmelade and light malts sweetness. Thin body. Ok carbonation. Not fully convincing.

Bottle. Color: Orange red, off-white head. Taste: Like a normal wheat beer with too little raspberry syrup. And so you get a moderate beer that is not a wheat beer and no fruit beer either. Thin body, average carbonation. Watery. Mwaah...
A hazy red colour with a pinkish head. Quite a tart taste with a good raspberry flavour and some hop taste. Not bad.
Pours an amber colour. Taste is medium. Quite an alright cider considering it's industrially made
This stuff is quality in a bottle likes! Bottle looks great and makes for a romantic evening wi yer burd!
75cl bottle. A clear yellow colour, no head. Aroma of sweet fruity apples, mild sourish apples and sulfur. Taste of sweet riped apples, grapes, minimal sulfur, medium carbonation.
Danke an danlo. S��licher, dumpf apfeliger Antrunk. Apfelig-holzig, breiter im Geschmack werdend. Geringe Herbe, vollmundig, roter Apfel. Hohe S�ffigkeit, langer Abgang. Gef�llt. 8/8/9/8/7/8
750ml bottle. Pours gold with high carbonation. Aroma is cheap woody apple juice and vanilla. Taste has sweet apple juice throughout. Some vanilla. Cheap apple juice aftertaste. Pretty basic.

750 ml green screwcap bottle, as Merrydown Original Vintage Apple Cider - Medium Cider, from British Corner Shop. ABV is 7.5%.Pale golden colour, moderate white head that actually lasts a while. Aroma of apples and sulphites. Medium sweet and medium sour flavour of apples and sulphites. Not bad, not great.

750ml bottle from Ken Warne, Darlington. Golden colour, white foam head that quickly dissipates away and aroma of fruity apple, musty. Taste is sweet fruity, ripe apple, with sulphury hints, sugary and an astringent note. Slightly syrupy mouthfeel, medium bodied, spritzy carbonation, sweetish finish. Kind of OK.

Many thanks to beerhunter111 for sharing. Smooth mild beginning. Easy to drink, fruity with a nice carbonation. Fruity with tannins in the back, nice balanced with a subtle but nice sweetness in the end with fresh apples.
750 ml bottle @home,bb 05/2019. Pale straw,clear. Aroma of fermenting apples,alcohol and cooked mushrooms. Taste is weird as well - alcohol heavy mix of apples and mushrooms. No.
75cl bottle. Light golden color, some white bubbles. Aroma has sweet notes and some apples. Balanced apple body, sweet notes and hint of tartness.

3/7/08 on draught at the brewpub. Aroma is solid roast malt forward with no hop flora; very porterlike. Appearance is clear amber-brown with a medium maintained tan head. Flavor is malt dominant as well, with sweetness, sourness and roast all even and masking low bittering with no flora. Mouthfeel is medium/high bodied with a good amount of creaminess, medium carb feel and sweet finish. Overall, good for not being to style, although the sweetness can get to you after a while.

On Tap at the BrewPub. Nice chestnut brown with a small light tan head. Some wispy lacing and a soft woody light roast aroma. Fairly light and thin and a bit of that slightly sour light porter twinge. Dare i say it?.... "Quafable" !
Tap: Dark brown with a nice tanhead. Sweet malts with nice roasted, nutty flavors. A bit of a tangy aftertaste. Pretty good all-around brown ale.

Draft @ Brewpub: Pours am immensely dark brown with a smaller beige head. Aroma of roast, malt, and floral hops. Flavor is initially solid with roasty notes, malt, nuts, and a bit of hops before weakening out in the finish. Finish is a bit flat with some light bitters. Most likely just what the brewer was looking to achieve; drinkable by most patrons. Still, better than a lot of browns.
On tap at Sockeye Brewing Boise, ID Pours out a dark brown topped with a light tan head. A nice aroma of light hops and nut. Tast of light hops and some malt. Pretty good brown ale.

It's like a big bear man! Not bad, kind of off kilter, there was smoething missing but I cannot put my finger on it. Had a slightly sweet malty, carob, ladyfinger, cookie like taste to it. No head, nice lacing, nutty and dark, with a nice bittersweet aftertaste. Better than most that I have had in hits category.

A very brown bear color, dark brown in the middle with tan edges. Excellent lacing without head. Floral hop aroma, citrus, nuts and malt, almost like a Scottish ale. Non bitter malty and nutty flavor. Almost like a newcastle clone but fresh. Smooth, not dry or bitter, nicely carbonated. Overall a very fresh brown ale with great complexities.

Shared with Strykzone of Facebook Chat. From a 12 oz can pours a copper gold with a white head. Nose of perfume and corn. Light to medium body with a soft smooth mouthfeel. The flavor is simple and brings some light fruit. This is not a complicated beer but drinks nicely and is a step up from most blonds

12 oz. can from hayduke that we had together via facebook chat. Golden with a nearly white head. Aroma is pleasant enough. Sweet corn and sugary notes. Flavor is also sweet with something like cereal and grass. With warming it became somewhat drier. Pleasant.
Nitro pour, clear pale gold body. No hops and a very white bread but not husky. Could be a pinch less sweet but I like it.

On nitro tap at Sockeye Pub & Grill, pours a clear blonde with a small white head. Aroma and flavour brings out sweet cereal malts and biscuity notes. Sweet and restrained but boring as hell. It�s a cream ale after all.
Really smooth body, kind of a hazy cream yellow, buttery light flavors, almost wheaty too, sweet malts balance well
Perfect cream ale. Hazy golden body with long lasting creamy head. Velvety mouthfeel, slightly sweet aroma and taste. One of their better brews.

Tap at brewery - Not sure what to think about this one. Perfumy hop nose, with hints of citrus fruits. Simple maltiness, with a creamy mouthfeel, light bitterness in the finish. Not sure where they were going with this one, it kind of misses the mark.

Sockeye Brewers Whim Cream Ale 8 3 13 4 7 35 3/7/08 on draught at the brewpub. Aroma is faintly hop dominant, but light in all aromas. Appearance is clear yellow gold with a well maintained white head. Flavor is low on sweetness with faint corny malt, although it uses no corn and slightly more dominant noble hop bittering. Mouthfeel is light with medium creaminess and very low carb feel. Overall, simple and easy drinking.
On tap at brewpub pours out a clear straw topped with a cream white head. Nice and sweet. Also pretty thick very nice.

Draft: Re-rate. Color was this pure blonde/golden color with a thick white head that lasts and lasts. Taste is a medium intensity with fruit tones, sweet malt, and very light hop bitters. Very creamy texture coats the mouth well. Better the second time around.

This brew was just reintroduced at the Claybourn brewpub last Thursday. Poured into an Imperial pint glass from the cask. 4.5 A: Suprisingly clear deep amber color. Thick, super creamy head. 3.0 S: Bready, but not much else going on. Not really any yeast character. 3.5 T: Low hop profile. Bready, but overall very neutral. 4.0 M: Very light body, but silky smooth. This would have been a 5 if the body was a bit thicker. 3.5 D: Some good aspects and some bad make this an average, drinkable brew. Serving type: cask Reviewed on: 06-28-2009 04:06:41
On tap at GI Clybourn 7/20/09. Pours amber-brown with light white head. Caramel and pine hops. Bitter up front, then a funky sweetness, then a bitter finish.
On tap at the GI Clybourn brewpub. Poured a deep red, with minimal aroma. Primarily hoppy taste. Reminded me of a less-strong IPA. I enjoyed it as an after-dinner drink.
On tap at Goose Island Wrigleyville. Deep rich red color, with small off-white head. Aroma of roasted malt, mild citrus hops. Taste is nutty, toasty caramel malt. Crisp medium mouthfeel.

On tap at Goose Island Clybourn. Pours amber with a white head. Aroma is of grass, malt, light hops, and caramel. Taste is of grassy hops, grain, and pine. Has a bready malt backbone that evens the beer out. Lingering taste of caramel. Mouthfeel is light and heavily carbonated. Crisp and easy drinking, but nothing amazing.

Draft at Clybourn. Poured a slightly hazy dark orange color with an off white head. Smelled of flowery/citrusy hops and a bit of graham cracker. Light to medium bodied and on the dry side. I tasted caramel, citrus fruits, and toasted bread. Decent enough.

draft at brewpub- quite tasty- Irish ale? That�s weird, because it�s touted as a hoppy amber, and tastes fairly piney and citrusy. Nice dry hoppyness to the brew. A patron at the bar tipped me off to a nice little drink- a pint of the ipa topped with the celebration. Good beer.
Draught at the pub. Cascade and centennial aroma, mild flavor of hops medium bodied. Very drinkabe with a dry finish. Big lacing thin off white head. Dry toasty malt body.

draft at GI cly....pours a medium slightly hazy caramel brown with a thin wispy white head.... decent intermingling of caramel malt and grassy ops. more of that crystal malt than hops...similar to the nose, a favorable balance of malt and a moderate degree of grassy bitterness in the finish.

on tap at GI LPB. pours hazy amber with white head. nose has some nice hop notes of citrus and melon, some biscuity malt coming through too. flavor is citrusy with toasted malts. chewy, and the crystal malt used becomes cloying. pretty hopped up but not something i could drink more than a half pint of.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On draft at the brewery. Creamy dense white head. Soft caramel, malty sweet, low hop character, light fruitiness.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On tap at Red Rock, pours a clear bronze with a medium white head. Aroma and flavour brings out strange herbal notes and bready notes. Not authentic at all. Seems a bit off.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a bright orange with a bit of red with a thick beige head. The aroma is light malts. The taste was mostly a smooth creamy malt with some light hops and a small bitterness. Pretty nice. I enjoyed this one.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Mahogany with a small head and good lacing. Wet malt aromas. Soapy hops and roasted malts. Bitter flavors of caramel and roast. Tail is so so.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: NABA �05: Amber color, light hops, stark astringency and watery, albeit a little malty, body.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column5: Dark red beer with a still white head. It gives a sharp aroma with the promised sharp-sweet flavors forthcoming ... caramel, mostly, but ending with a bitter hoppiness.

22oz bomber-An amber body with a decent head and an aroma of nothing but maybe a little malt. Taste of the same. I was expecting more from the pretty cool label but I gues you can�t judge a beer from its label.

Had this beer on 9/29/1998. Color is hazy and gold, with good carbonation and very low head. Aroma is light with a hint of malt, but has a bit of a wine like smell to it. Taste is flat and empty. It starts with a light body that goes down easy, because there�s not much there. The finish has a slight bitterness but not much and no hop flavor at all, there is also no hop aroma. This may be the worst Pale Ale I have had, the body lacks malt flavor or any flavor at all, there is no hop flavor, bitterness, or aroma.

Fort Collins Brew Fest 2004 - This was probably my favorite beer of the fest. Copper/amber colored. Agressively hopped with a strong citrus zing - mostly grapefruit. I�d easilly classify this as an IPA.
Fort Collins Brew Fest 2003: Had a fair amount of carbonation. Wasn't very hazy for an unfiltered wheat beer. A little disappointing. Also, fairly dark for a wheat beer. Refreshing and above average.
Draught: I'm partial to brown ales, and this one was pretty decent. not too heavy, I was drinking this on a hot day and it was not overbearing.
Fort Collins Brew Fest 2003: Your run of the mill brown ale. A bit nutty. Not too bad, as far as heavy body is concerned, when drinking on a hot summer day.
A - Wheat and grass A - Light gold and hazy T - A little sweet and bitter M - Thin and mid carbonation
Clear, light yellow. Close to no aroma. Sour, corn flavor. Starchy, abrasive flavor. Yuck.
Fort Collins Brew Fest 2003: Fairly hoppy, Pacific Northwest variety, I would assume. This is a run of the mill brewery, not bad, above average.

(bottle) clear deep amber colour with a small off-white head. aroma of caramelized malts and bran flakes, with some notes of herbal hops, beef jerky and black tea. flavour is mostly roasted grain and earth, with a light touch of salted popcorn and booze in the light roasted-bitter finish. medium- to heavy-bodied with soft carbnoation.
Clear mahagoni. Aroma is slight almond, caramel, grapes, toffee, malt. Taste is shallow nutpeel with quite some bitter molasses. Not that balanced. A bit harsh while swallowing. Ok.

resin, floral, grass, spruce, citrus, herbs, caramel, bread, hay, cereal, pale, golden, amber, orange, red, brown, clear, hazy, rocky head, frothy, minimal head, white foam, light sweetness, medium sweetness, heavy cloying sweetness, lightly bitter, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium sourness,
Bottle, as "Bock". Red amber, low eggshell head. Light roasted, roux nose, some oxidation. Medium body, low carbonation, light stickiness . Some singed cardboard, nuts, roast, oxidized Dunkel finish.

Bottle, as "Bockbier", 6.5%. Clear amber color with white head. Aroma is apple phenols, bready, caramel, raisins, a bit oxidized. Taste is raisins, oxidized, malty, sticky. Low carbonation. Not too great.

(bottle) Clear, deep golden colour to copper with a medium-sized and off-white foamy head. Bready malty aroma with notes of caramel, subtle fruity accents and a whiff of herbal hops. Moderately sweet and slightly bitter flavour, medium to light bodied with a soft carbonation. Bready malt character with caramel and herbal hoppy accents, leading into a moderately dry and mildly herbal hoppy finish with notes of caramel in the aftertaste. Decent. 24.VII.16
bottle, d�ky pane doktore! Golden with a small white head. Smooth and velvety from the start. Full-bodied malty flavours dominate, not too sweet, with some resiny-grassy hops.

Bottle: Clear, copper coloured, quickly collapsing small off-white head; sweetish grainy-dusty nose, herbal hops are very well hidden; mild to moderate sweet-bitter flavour, pretty light bodied for a beer of 6.5%, not so soft; slightly lingering grainy and herbal-hoppy finish. Disappointing...
50 cl bottle @ home while cooking Francesinhas. Light copper colour. Medium head. Good lacing. Average retention. Bread, alcohol, malt aroma. Medium sweet. Balanced. Ok

Eher der waldig, erdige Vertreter einer sonst meist s��lich, hellen Biersorte. Kupferfarbend und mit einer netten kleinen Blume ausstattet kommt es daher. Riecht dominant getreidig & ganz hinten ein wenig nach Hopfen. Der Trunk w�rzig, dezent s�� & fein bitter. Das etwas andere Maibock. 0,5/ca.1Euro aus einem Getr�nkemarkt in Forchheim.
Hop malt aroma. Clear amber colour with poor head and no lacing. Bitter malt hop flavour. Flat palate.

W�ssrig frischer Antrunk, minimal w�rzig was aber schnell versiegt. Im Mittelteil eigentlich nur w�ssrig, h�chstens eine leichte Herbe ist hintergr�ndig erkennbar. Eine sp�rbare Tiefphase - auch wenn es noch keinen Hochpunkt gab. Im Abgang herber, leicht bitter, immerhin leicht w�rzig. Das Bier schmeckt nicht besser als ich es erwartet habe... Test vom 27.9.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 5,5,8,4,4,4 - 4,85

79c 660ml bottle. Decent foresty aroma with soap, spruce, grain and grassy hutch notes, marzipan dabs. Actually want to drink this. Again that licked stamp staleness, conifer, fizz turning to sog, occasional metal, but grass and reasonable pilsy bite. Not terrible.

Bottled. A rather cheap lager, but there is nothing bad about it. This is stuff that Carlsberg would try to pass off as premium in Norway.. A store clerk in Parma tried to make me buy a better beer instead! Watery, but with a decent malt/hops balance.

Bottled. 4,7% version (prodotta ed imbottigliata da Castello di Udine s.p.a. - San Giorgio di Nogaro UD - ITA). Light and evanescent foam. Yellow pale color, shiny and barely bubbly. Light scent, watery and malty rumors. Acceptable taste; refreshing and with a good bitter. In short not of special.
Canned(330ml). -such a bad beer even for Italia, pale yellow with no head, watery and metallic

Bottled, Filtered, 500ml. Aged almost 3 yrs. Orange amber colour with bubbly white head. Rounded and smooth with a sweet toffee caramel taste and a touch of ripe banana. Pleasant flavour though the body is somewhat sluggish. Little hop character, certainly not an IPA, but a reasonable beer all the same.
Very little head and a nice hoppy finnish.Not what I would really call an IPA more like a bitter.Pleasant but easily forgotten.
Light amber color, almost no head. Aroma has hops, caramel and just a hint of citrus and pear. Hopbitter flavor, metallic and butterscotch. Hopbitter, buttery finish with walnut.
Quite flat dark ale with a mainly alcohol aroma and a deeply hopped flavour with hints of caramel. A very plain English hopped ale. Too strong tasting for the style of drink.
Brewed to celebrate 140 years of the Co-op. Is problably better than my rating but its just so dull. A bit sweet and not much bitterness. So, so.

column1: Sly Fox Robbie Summer Scottish Ale
column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Had this last year. An above average scottish ale, with a good malt presence and a crsip malty finish.

column1: Sly Fox Robbie Summer Scottish Ale
column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Not the best scotch beer Sly Fox has done but was pretty drinkable, lighter color than most scotches I've had, looked more like a pale ale, nice thick bubbly white head, very well balanced, medium in body, fair amount of hops in the flavors & finish, a decent scotch ale

column1: Sly Fox Robbie Summer Scottish Ale
column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: I enjoyed this scottish ale. The word "summer" may be deceiving in the title there's nothing light about it. Malt character mixes well with high alcohol content.

column1: Sly Fox Robbie Summer Scottish Ale
column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draft at the Grey Lodge in Philly. Copper colored beer. Had a hint of malty taste.
Draft pours deep brown with a tan head. Aroma of caramel and chocolate. Taste is toffee, chocolate and coffee.

Draft sampler, 4 Aug 07. Nice homey brown color. Large coffee smell, could almost pass for a stout. Brown and caramel malt taste, with a prominent English hop palate (but now I read on their webisite that this uses Polish hops). Very pleasing and mellow.

Nice dark, not quite black color with pleasant smoke aroma. Flavor is primarily smoke with coffee notes. Not particularly complex, with somewhat weak flavors. Drank later in the evening after a Fuller�s London Porter, which is superior.

tap at the brewpub-pours almost black with a nice soapy kacki head. nose is roasted and deep dark chocolate. very aromatic for this style. really smells bold for a low abv beer. flavors are robust-roasted chocolate and light smoke. body is medium with a little more than usual carbonation. That didn�t detract from this experience. long roasted finish that lasted long into the walk back to the car! This was the only beer i had a pint of. nice!
Brewpub visit 11/04 ... Black with a thin tan head. Smoky, smoky, smoky! Heavy roast character, yet not too heavy.
Not a lot of head, but good lacing and nice color! Combination of chocolate/Coffee flavors in a not-too-sweet combination.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: 650ml bottle [ '13]. Hazy, reddish amber colour with slightly late awakening, small, thick, creamy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, beige head. Slightly sugary malty and fruity aroma, notes of caramel and dreid fruit, raisin, some marzipan, a touch of toffee and apricot. Taste is moderately sweet malty, minimally sugary, bitter hoppy counterweight, fruity hints of dried fruit, apricot, raisin, soem caramel, toffee, marzipan, a minimally dry, papery touch. Nice.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Bomber from Albertsons. 2012 vintage. Aging had not gone well. Flat, mahogany pour, no head. Sweet, caramel aroma, a little off. Taste follows, going further downhill, medicinal, sweet, leathery, tobacco, dry. Sharp tang with no alcohol warmth. 2013 vintage comes in much better. Sweet, malty and strong. Heavy weight, warming.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Medium big and medium lasting off white head. Opaque amber color. Tired malty aroma and some madrification. Sweet caramell and firm bitterness. A small body for a Barley wine.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: 27.12.2017, 0,65l bottle (2013 vintage) @ home: Soft gusher. Big bubbly-creamy longlasting head. Aroma is slightly sweet sour-ish mineraly, weeds, grass, fruit stones, dried fruits, oak, minerals, dusty cellar, harsh citrus peel, bark, old dusty hops. Taste is slightly dry mineraly, weeds, minerals, grass, bark, fruit stones, harsh citrus peel, dusty cellar, dried fruits, alcohol, old dusty hops, hay. Medium bitterness, slightly dry and harsh mineraly mouthfeel. Fair enough, too old I guess...

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Like Barley Wines. This is a very good one. Lies heavy. Foggy appearance. Few small bubbles that are slow to rise because of thickness of brew. Light Carmel color nice Carmel-porter mix of taste. Last sooo long on the tongue and in the mouth. Only need to drink every ounce in a while. Smooth and high alcohol. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Sweet barleywine. Could use some hop flavour. On tap at the Griffon Gastropub, Transit. A sipper that needs much food accompaniment.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: 0.65l waxed bottle. Quite a cloudy looking one this. Really cloudy, deep orange or even amber in color. A good looking off-white head - really good for the genre. Like the aroma. Loaded with red berries. Red currant and lingonberries. Toffee sweetness, lots of malty caramel. Malt drops and red apple sweetness. Smells really nice and inviting. Tastes nice also, but it�s surprisingly thin analyst light bodied for a 10 percenter. Lots of red berries here, toffee and red apples. Shocking lightdrinkable. Almost a little refreshing. Little alco warmth in the aftertaste. 14.04.2017

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Sample from 2012 bottle during Blarney Wine Festival 2017 on 03/18/2017. The beer is a hazy dark copper-amber color with a medium thin light beige head that burns away steadily to a film. Stringy lacing. Aroma of malt, wood and citrus. Full-bodied with flavors of caramel malt, oak, ripe fruit and a bit of grapefruity hops. The finish is boozy with a citrus and malt aftertaste. Above average overall.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: 2013 vintage, poured into snifter from bottle. Pours an orange-gold color, somewhat hazy, almost no head whatsoever. Some caramel and pine/citrus hop notes on nose, taste is a bit more bitter with less citrus, a touch syrupy on tongue.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Bottle, 2013 vintage (from Boxbeers). Pours amber with whiteish head. Aroma is sweet, caramelly, mashy, fruity. Flavor is sweet and bitter, caramel, fruits, malt, mash, citrus. Finish is sweet and bitter with some alcohol. Overall: good, but bit neutered (it is Widmer Brother�s beer) and underfermented.

From May 2007 Compliments of jwc215. Thanks again, Joe! This pours from 12oz bottle a slightly hazy orange with a nice healthy head of foam that shrinks to a fine layer and it has some lacing. The smell is a nice mix of hoppy bitterness and some bready and sweet malt notes. The taste on first sip has some sweet malt and some bready notes that is followed by a hop oil flavour and a bit of citrus and just a tiny bit of grass. Interesting. Swishing the beer in my mouth, the hop oil is the most noticeable flavour that I can detect, followed by the bread, and I'm finding it quite pleasing. Further sips in and I'm noticing that the finish has a lemony taste to it and that's something that I thinks detracts from my overall enjoyment of this Pale Ale. Lose that and I'd give it higher marks. Bottom line: A good Pale Ale that could be better if...see my remarks. ;^) I'd still say try it.

Now called "Stegamier Pale Ale." Bottle - from sampler pack. Colror is straw to orange and fairly clear. Malt and hop aroma with a hint of metal. Pretty good - both hoppy and malty but not the best hop flavor.

12 oz bottle from a coworker. Pours a thin rusty orange with large clinging bubbles and a fizzy off white head. Aroma is harsh fruit notes, peach and apricot, rust, wet bread. The body is overly fizzy and thin to the point where I thought I was drinking seltzer. Flavors of bread crust, rotting fruit and cdopper. Blah.

Pours a tranlucent copper amber with an average foamy off white head that left some lacing. Aroma of floral hops, sweet orange light pine and some caramel. Flavor of pine, decent malt balance. I was pleasantly surprised by this one.it was a decent hoppy session pale ale.

Twist off bottle. Golden pour into Sam Adams lager glass. Faint aroma of grass and caramel. Taste surprisingly estery (banana comes to mind) with a dry grassy finish. Decent flavor to this pale ale that is an increasingly varied style.
Clear amber of color with a beige head. An aroma of malt bisquit and hops. A flavor of malt, hops, citrus and grass, a nice bitter finish.

Appearance: Pours a clear, orange-amber body with a half inch of evanescing, whitish foam. Smell: Sweetish nose of grains and light caramel marked with some spicy, citrusy hop notes. Taste: Blend of dry caramel and toffee with a flavor of steeped, soaked grains. Citrusy, lightly spicy hops provide a medium amount of balancing bitterness. Then, it�s back to the toffee-esque malt, though the flavor and body starts to recede at this point, but in no way does it approach being watery. Short, dry finish. Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Drinkability: A generally okay, comfortably average pale ale. Sure, you could do worse, but you could also do far, far better in terms of pale ales.

Date: May 23, 2009 Mode: Bottle Source: Ticker Tasting Appearance: hazzy copper, fine off white head Aroma: lightly sweet crystal malt aroma, lots of earthy and floral hops Flavor: sweet malt flavor, lots of earthy hops come in strong and fast to dry out the sweetness, light long bitter finish Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.8/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: *4

i enjoyed the beer like quality with the pleasant addition of some fruit punch like flavors that were light and complemented the real beer character of years ago. light floral hop almost artificial with equally light malt it is balanced. light abv yet golden in color and nicely drinkable. a brewer who has the experience and know how to impress in todays market while sticking to affordability. i applaud that sense and this brew!
Bottle. Pours a pale gold body with a white head. Mild grainy malts, crackers, some light floral bitterness. Dry and a bit like wheat. not so good.
On tap at Redwood. Poured a yellow color with a small sized head. Yeah a light beer - generic smelling/tasting, it is what it is.
Draft - Light malty sweetness. Pale gold with a decent white head. Sweet, light and some grains.

Draft sample. Poured clear pale color with a medium frothy white head that was mostly lasting with fair lacing. Moderate sweet aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met.

Nice clear golden color. Small head that quickly goes to lace. Aroma of fruit hop hint of citrus. Flavor is about the same with a bit of malt thrown in. Not a lot of fullness to this brew, but then it is a light beer. One of the better light brew beers you will find.

(Tap @ Redwood Lodge, Flint, MI): Very pale, almost clear, color, small bubbles, white head. Malty aroma, weakish. Malty, sweet taste, fizzy, good nutty taste. Refreshing. Sweet almost sugary aftertaste.

Sample at the brewpub: Clear golden color with a thin white head and spotty lacing. Light floral hops aroma. Light-bodied and effervescent with a nicely floral hops flavor, along with a bit of malt. The finish is crisp and mildly bitter. One of the better brewpub Light beers I have had.

Draft, on premises. A flowery, fruity hop nose is a good start. Otherwise, the taste is a little thin and watery, but you can still find a decent mouthfeel. A decent brewpub lager and okay as a light. (17 IBU's, according to the Lodge).

On tap: The aroma consists of mild cereal grains, honey, and a hint of grass. It�s a transparent gold with a small white head that fades to a minimal film outlined by a thin ring. There is some minimal webbing left on the sides of the glass. The flavor starts with a quick light honey and a hint of apple. The finish has mild grass and spice. It�s light bodied with mild carbonation. Overall, it�s a little on the sweet side for my preferences.
On tap at Redwood. Poured a yellow color with a small sized head. Grainy and on the very sweet side. Corny.
Pours a pale gold with a thin white head. Aroma is fruity, earthy, and bread. Flavor is sweet fruit, earthy, and bread. Very crisp. I enjoyed this slightly more than their Kolsch. Quite good.
Draft - Earthy vegative nose. Clear gold with a decent white head. Earthy and vegative, also just not nice.

This beer pours a dark brownish amber color, considerably lighter than most Doppelbocks. Medium off-white head with good staying power, and decent lacing. The aroma is roasted malt, nuts and hops. Medium-bodied with a robust toasted malt character, along with a good amount of hops and some spices as well. The finish is refreshing and crisp with a nutty aftertaste. Overall this beer doesn�t look like a lot of Doppelbocks but it does a good job just the same.
Very good. I was not impressed with any of the other Redwood beers, but this one stuck out as healthy and fresh and interesting.

Well, the sign on the wall claimed this as a dopple, though it is maibock light in color. It does have some smoky and spicy tones once you get it going, so it dopples a bit as it warms, with a generous, quick drying heat of hops. Interesting brown sugar note in the close. Definitely one of the most engaging and fun brews to try at this brewery.

Color is a great blackish brown. Aroma had some lactose and Malty nuts. A touch odd sweetness. Taste had a bitter mouth to balance the sweet. Not quite creamy but nice sweet combo. Mouth held the bitter and sugars together well. Tap
Draft. Pours black. Aroma and taste are roasted malts and some coffee, quite smooth.
On tap at Redwood. Poured black color with a small sized off white head. Roast, chocolate, and a lighter coffee.
Pours a dark mahogany with a thin off-white head. Aroma is roast and chocolate. Flavor is lots of roast and some chocolate. This is sweet and very satisfying.
Tap: dark dark black with tan head and spotty lacing. Coffee aroma with a strong charcoal taste.
Draft - Nice roast, mellow with some chocolate. Deep jet brown with a decent brown head. Bitter sweet chocolate and some light roast. Easy drinking and flavourful.
In tap at the resturuant, pours deep brown, slim silky cream hued head. Nose of roasted malt. Taste follows, slightly sweet, slick creamy mouth with a light body. As advertised.
Bomber thanks to tepp. Near black with a beige head. Light malt and chocolate. Really light with heavy malt and smoke.
Draft at GABF. Pours dark brown with tan head. Nose and taste of cream, chocolate and coffee. Medium body.
GABF 2012 Appearance: Black with a medium sized tan head Aroma: Chocolate and roasted coffee Taste: Roasted malts, grainy and coffee Nice and smooth
Bottle, alko. Unfiltered. Bit grain malty, malted wheaty sweetness on nose. Bit dry bland, weissy spices, all bit subdued tho. Sorta nice, easy drinkable.. feels dull still compared to some others
Mild hefiger, trocken bananig-w�ssriger Beginn. Geringe W�rzigkeit, dumpf, monoton. Trinkbar. 8/8/7/8/7/7
300ml tap @Bunte Gans, Vilnius. Hazy staw coloured body, filmy layer. Ripe fruit, vanilla and doughy. Sweet, quite full bodied and lasting.

(Bottle, 0.5 l - 08.10.2019, from Alko, 20181201) The beer poured golden and hazy. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had banana, clove and fruitiness. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were banana, clove, fruitiness, grass, malts and bitterness. Aftertaste was spicy, fruity and bitter. A decent spicy hefeweizen.

The yeast is tightly stick in the bottle. Light yellow and murky, a head is quite small and blond. Aroma has wheat, low fruitness of banana and citrus, more spicyness of clove. Taste has wheat, spicyness, low fruitness of citrus. Medium bodied, smooth. Good.
Bottle 500ml at home. BBE 2019-10-08. From Alko. Pours hazy light yellow, white head. Wheat, banana, citrus, yeast, spices. Medium to thin body, watery texture, average carbonation.

Bottled 500ml (Alko web) Pale yellow, hazy colour, mostly vanishing white head. Banana and clove in the nose. Light to medium-bodied. Crisp citrus in the front, then banana with some clove spiceyness. Very typical middle-on-the road hefeweizen. Christmas is only in the label.

500ml at the office, Munich, courtesy of Thorsten. Aroma is light yeast and very light banana. Appearance is cloudy yellow with a small white foam. Taste is light bitter and very light sour. Some astringent bitterness in the end. Overall a solid Weizen.

Really hazy yellow color with white head. Aroma is typical for the style: sweet wheat, banana and cloves. Taste starts with banana, a hint of astringent sourdough but fades towards the finish. Aftertaste lingers with grainy sweetness. Medium body and carbonation. A legit weizen leaning on the sweeter side.

330ml bottle as "Zoller-Hof Hefe-Weizen" bought at Great Food Hall in Pacific Place, Admiralty. Cloudy hazy straw light golden yellow colour with a thick ring of dirt-like yeast sediments; Explosive five finger head with crumpety white foam which lasts for 4 minutes; Good sticky lacing with fizzy carbonation; Very fragment aroma of light malt, with strong banana, vanilla, wheaty tartness, bubblegum, floral, sugar, strong cloves, spices, earth, bread, strong yeast, lemon and grass; Mid to light sweet taste of light malt, with strong wheat, light tartness, light banana, phenolic, floral, fair sugar, spices, cloves, herbs, light biscuits, yeast, lemon, light bitter hops and grass; Close to medium body. Slightly slick palate; Mouth Feel is light maltyness in a fairly runny background. Pretty estery and phenolic. Flowery with fair sweetness, spicy clovey, herbal biscuity with lemon to round. Solid!... Hoppiness is floral, spices, earth, lemon and grass in nose; Same in taste but stronger and woth herbs; Bitterness is low for an abrupt, light astringent sweet-bitter wheaty finish; Slightly dry after taste. Herbal spicy and quite easy to mouth. Comments: This one has a pretty impressive head (almost a gusher), nice estery / spicy aroma, and a lasting herbal hoppy taste. Better than expected and a stand-out among mid-range weissbier. Drinkable!

500 ml bottle at home, bb. 11.2019. Pours a clear amber with an off-white head. The aroma is lightly to medium malty and lightly hoppy - bread, toffee, hints of caramel, light herbal and earthy notes. Medium body with a soft to average carbonation, a light sweetness and a light bitterness. The flavor is similar to the smell lightly malty and lightly hoppy with bready malt, some caramel, some dried fruits and some earthy hops. Finishes with a light earthy hoppy bitterness. Aroma: 6 Appearance: 4 Taste: 6 Palate: 3 Overall: 11
Pours a clear yellow color. Aroma is grassy and light straw. Grassy and toasted malty. Grassy finish.

bottle from a shop south of nuremberg. pale golden, clear with a fluffy white head; plenty of grass in the aroma along with a light peachy malt tinge; decent amount of bitterness, tending towards the tinny; decent stuff
Klares dunkel goldgelbes Bier mit einer geringen wei�en Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, etwas Karamell, ansonsten ziemlich neutral. Geschmack fruchtig hopfig, malzig, minimal metallisch, w�rzig.

Ich trinke hier das bernstein- bis kastanienbraune Weihnachtsfestbier mit verhaltenem Schaum, malzig- toastbrotigem Geruch, aber recht leichtem Antrunk. Es schmeckt alkoholbetont mit wenig Rests�sse und interessanten R�staromen. Diese klingen dann auch recht harmonisch aus. Ein auf �Bums� optimiertes Festbier von interessanter Farbe.
very hoppy aroma,clear straw colour with small white head. Yeasty flavour, not a true pale ale more like a yeasty lager. Typical of Inddepentant, sweet and boring!!!

It has a soft nose with a faint whiff of hop and citrus. The colour is of a typical pale ale, clean and light amber. The head is good but I am drinking this in the wrong vessel so cannot be too hard on this. Taste is soft and fruity with a clean malt profile. A bit like Little Creatures from WA (sorry Western Australia)without the presence of real mouthfeel. A good beer nevertheless. The only problem is that the label has an eagle on it, so why stone crow? Geez, what about starving the lizards?
Tried this beer for the first time in 2009 and only just now getting to the rating. Pours light with a very mild body. Watery with a hint of sweetness.
this place really gives microbreweries a bad name if it could still be called one. chewy banana bread with vanilla essence and toilet cleaner
disgusting combination of super-sweet caramel/biscuit malt, grapefruity hops, and banana esters - bleaugh! revolting
Well it has some kick. A little too sour and not a great palate. Not my first choice.
Amber in colour, big white head, hoppy aroma, mild bitter taste with caramel hints. Certainly an Autum drink. Good seasonal from Mac's.

This started with little initial nose on the pour but the hop presence comes through in the taste. The colour is a pleasant deep amber that is true to the taste of Munich, Crystal malt and toffee. The mouthfeel belies the 5% ABV and like Copperhop it finsihes dry on the back palate. Good lacing in the glass.
Draft at Foster and Logan�s, Red Lodge, MT. Very drinkable dark amber altbier with lots of malt

Bottle received from Kevin. Pours clear deep tawny with a medium, frothy off-white head, short retention. Moderate toast and nutty malt, light earthy and woody hops and bitterness with a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

Sample at Mackenzie River Pizza Co., Bozeman. Pours hazy dark amber with a lasting, foamy, off-white head. The aroma contains malt, caramel, bread and some herbs, but is not that intense. It tastes light sweet and light bitter with a medium long finish. Light body, slick texture, fizzy carbonation. Enjoyable but underwhelming.
Bottle. Caramel malt and astringent hay aroma. Amber with small head. Mildly sweet caramel malt and mildly bitter/astringent hay flavor. Good body. A solid Altbier.
Bottle: Clear copper with a small off-white head. Caramel, roast aroma. Taste is rich caramel, a hint of peanut..... A husky, oily, earthy bitter. Nice body.... Very enjoyable.
Has a caramel accent, a bit earthy, and a touch of sweetness. Mellow, balanced, a decent amber, if not really like any altbier I know.

Poured from bottle into a pint glass Appearance � The beer pours an amber color with a huge billowy white head of thick foam. The head has a fantastic level of retention, very slowly fading to leave a ton of fizzy lace on the sides of the glass. Smell � The aroma is of a sweeter caramel and lightly toasted malt smell. A little bit of a grainy and slightly bready smell are there as well and are mixed with some hints of dark fruit. Taste � The taste begins with a sweet caramel and slightly bready taste with the bready having a bit of a toast taste associated with it. Along with these flavors comes some brown sugar and a little bit of a dark fruit taste. The roastedness increases at the end with the caramel fading a little bit at the expense of more dark fruits coming to the tongue. With a little bit of molasses joining the taste at the end, one is left with a sweeter and malty taste to be left on the tongue. Mouthfeel � The body of the beer is average in terms of thickness and creaminess with a rather average carbonation. Overall for the sweeter but more drinkable nature of the brew the feel is pretty good and makes for a smooth drinker. Overall � A pretty easy drinking and flavorful brew.

A clear deep amber coloured brew with a small head of foam. The smell is decidedly malTy with nice grainy notes and suggestions of fruit. Dang, the malt character in this Alt is so delicious. Backed by a good grain bill and again, more than a hint or 2 of fruit which I find mostly in the finish. Smooth mouthfeel. .I reckon I will buy more Glacier soon. A Very well crafted example of the style.
Pours a good medium amber with lasting head and good lacing. Mild roast, sweet malts - but only briefly. A little salty. Mild roast aftertaste with a smooth palate.
On draft at the grizzly bar in roscoe mt. Pours a clear dark amber with an ecru head. Malty nose. Lots if sweet caramel notes with a laid back hop profile. Crisp clean finish.

Color looks appealing--light foamy head and hazy appearance. Yeasty/spicey aroma, with hint of coriander. Light taste with yeasty flavor. Wheat malts and spice noted. Citrousy finish. Excellent effort, even if it is a bit more watery than I would like. Seems to me that this brewery takes a lot more care with its seasonal beers than with its standard offerings.
Cask at the Hole in the Wall. A very average Enlish bitter, with both maltiness and some bitterenss from the hops, but nothing here to lift it above the crowd,

Half pint on cask. Dark brown body with short-lived head. Marked dried fruit and spicy aroma. Herbal flavour with hints of dark berries. Nice bitter finish. Extraordinary and quite good (Served at room temperature at The Hole in The Wall, Waterloo, London 18.09.2006).
Cask at the Hole In the Wall. Soft fruity bitter with some floral notes but in poor condition and borderline vinegar.
Cask at Hole In the Wall London SE1 1 May 06. Mahogany colour. A white lasting creamy head. Fruity smell and taste. A modest bitter aftertaste. Not bad.

Cask handpump at �Hole in the Wall� Waterloo, London. Mid brown bitter, hardly any head to speak of, starts off wonderful with plenty of hops and spicy flavours kicking around but after a while I found it a little too sweet and realised it was�nt quite as good as I initially thought, nonetheless it�s a good effort.
Cask Handpump at the Ship & Mitre, Liverpool 13/06/2002 Mid brown coloured with some fruit and grassy aromas. Slihgtly dry lasting malt finish.

Cask conditioned at The Hole in the Wall, Waterloo, London. Orange amber beer with slight whispy head. Perfectly drinkable hoppy light session bitter with hints of grapefruit and a floral hoppy nose. Dry and bitter, an enjoyable beer.

[Cask at GBBF 2005] A hazy orange beer with a fast dying head. The aroma is sweet spicy - with ginger coming thru. The flavor is sweet - too sweet in my opinion - with some estery notes, leading to a dry end.
Cask conditioned, GBBF 2005: Buttery aroma. Malty palate. A nice, complex and refreshing brew. One of the better casks.
Cask@ The Hole in the Wall Near Waterloo Station. Pretty good session bitter slightly above average. more flavor than the Young�s bitter I had there.

Dark brown in the glass with a tan head Decent intensity in the aroma Mellow carbonation level and a decent sweetness Bready, some roast and some chocolate in the flavor [Cask at Quakerhouse in Darlington, England] Brewery #2105

Cask-conditioned at the Herefordshire & Worcestershire beeriodical, the Seven Stars, Bristol March 2013 as "Hereford Dark". Dark brown with a slight, off-white head. Sweet malts, caramel, some prune fruits and a gentle finish. Ok.
Cask at the Hobgoblin, Reading as Hereford Dark. Dark reddish copper with a thin white head; soft malty caramel flavour with a touch of chocolate. A pleasant mild.

Cask (handpump) at the Darlington Spring Thing Beer Festival. ABV is 4.0%. Medium dark brown colour, low head. Moderate nutty and slightly roasty aroma, also notes of chocolate. The flavour has also some mild roasty notes, malty with notes of chocolate.

Half, cask hand pulled and served at the right ambient drinking temperature at the Market Porter. Patchwork on the surface. Dark ruby body. Smell of liquorice-like malts. Chocolate and nutty malts in flavour, nicely balanced with hop resin. Fine integrated bitterness to the finish (London, 16.07.2010).
Red-black with almost no head. Very slight citrus hop scent. Slightly watery. Lots of sugar. Slight bitterness. Hint of coffee in the mouth.
Cask Conditioned, at the Market Porter, Cherry Oak colour, no head. Vial alcoholic aroma. Astringent and harsh. In summary �Battery Acid� (on the day).
Cask handpull at Market Porter, Borough. Ruby with beige head. Malty, chewy. Some dark malts. Bit of choc. Not much fruit, some prune/plum. Quite juicy malts. Quite a nice dark ale.
Cask Handpump at the Ship & Mitre, Liverpool 20/05/2002 DArk red coloured and slightly rich on the palate. Smooth with a hop finish.
Hand pulled at the Wellington, Birmingham. Superb, creamy smooth blended beer. Sweet, milky choc. Mmmmm. Really good, wonderfully moreish, with a milkshake feel.
Cask Stillage at the Boundary, Audenshaw 19/06/2003 Amber coloured slightly sweet and fruity. Some dryness in a hoppy malt finish.

Cask, Theobald Arms, Grays, Essex. Dark stawberry colour. Fruit hit is huge, sweet and slightly sticky - not that pleasant. Some oak tones and a vague kriek flavour add to the general confusion. A strange brew.

Bottle at The Roebuck, Leek (Titanic) Pours a clear deep golden colour with a thin white head. Aroma of lemon, orange, some biscuity malts, slight apple and subtle grassy hops. Taste of lemon, orange, some apple, slight biscuity malts, a little butter and subtle honey. Medium bodied and soft carbonation. A slight orchid fruit bitterness in the finish. It�s fresh and pleasanty fruity but average.

Cask, 1/2 pint, hand-pulled at Bon Accord, Glasgow on 26 Sep 2016, sour resin, citrus aromas, golden with a thin bubbly white head and negligible lacing, creamy, sour aftertaste (re-rate, end of cask).
Cask. Appearance is clear and golden with a small white head. Aroma of citrus, hops, cut grass. Very bitter hops in the taste, fruity, zesty orange undertones.
500ml bottle at 4.8%. Pours bright gold with a small frothy head. Aroma is buttery lemon and biscuit. Taste has straw and lemon with a buttery finish.

Bottle from Cellar Door, Four Oaks, Sutton Coldfield. Pours golden orange in colour, single finger white head. Aroma of light hops, light malts, fuggles maybe. Taste of initial lightly toasted malts, caramel, toffee, then orange, some grain, light yeast, light smokiness, some fruits, biscuit. Nice overall though!

Bottle from a National Trust location in England. Brighter amber-gold in colour with a small head. It�s very lightly spiced with a small berry fruit evient. It�s mainly a well balanced ale that�s very drinkable.

500ml bottle from Mitchell�s Wines, Meadowhead - Straw yellow body, thin white head. Nose is floral and sweet citrus, taste starts sweet then has a pretty dry finish, with hints of grapefruit. This one is on the rich side, thick mouthfeel, and very refreshing too.

From Baccus Wines, Olney, Bucks. Soapy head, elderflower aroma, straw coloured. sweetish, a little cloying. Finish is pleasant hop, light malt, honey. It�s 4.8% now, that�s what it says on the label..

500ml bottle at home. Pours clear gold, thin white head. Aromas of apples and lemon, little soap. Taste had a light malt sweetness and gentle balancing bitterness. Medium carbonation, clean finish. Nice.

50cl bottle from Brown & Green, Trentham, Staffs. A sparkling pale golden pour with a thin white head; slightly musty, orangey citrus aroma; crisp, sharp grapefruit taste wirh some fruity sweetness; and a zingy finish. An excellent golden ale.
Cask Stillage at the Intake Club, Mansfield 12/04/2008 Fruit and hop aromas. Golden coloured fruity and hoppy with a crisp and slightly dry bitter finish.

Bottle conditioned. Amber gold with a faint haze, excellent rocky white head and moderate condition. Good hoppy aroma, some yeastiness and a low sulphur eggyness. Good sweet malt tempered with hop flavour in the mouth, quite full bodied. Sweet finish with a delicate yeastiness that never becomes obtrusive, some hop bitterness.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Backlog rating LCRBM/Bruxellensis trip 2006: Milky cloudy brown, golden head. Underattenuated. Bready banana notes, spicy berries. Medium body. Banana aftertaste. A dunkelweizen hybrid??? Kind of nice though.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Average Belgian amber beer. Has fruits and some caramelised malt. Same old.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Thin head. Medium carbonation. Light malt, waterish aroma.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Draft. An amber beer with a beige head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel as well as lighter notes of fruits. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, and wet hay.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Sample at the brewpub. Hazy orange colour with a small white head. Light caramel and malts in the aroma. Flavor haqs caramel hints, toasted malts and a slightly bitterness in the final. Carbonation and body are medium.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Pours amber in color with an off-white head. A very buttery aroma with just about as much metal. Water, some bread sweetness, and a bit of sugar. Really quite bad. The flavor is just as buttery. Tons of metal, a mild malt sweetness, some water, and a bit of sugar. Barely drinkable.

column4: Les Brasseurs de la Grand Place
column5: Draft @ the Brewpub - split a 120 ml. with ChinoSkillzian, t0rin0 and Womencantsail with enough beer left to spill for the fallen homies - the flavors caught us by surprise and we couldn�t handle it. A amber beer made by a brewer whose name in English means Brewer at the Brewers of the Grand Market - to bad they got dizzy from their creativity before making this beer. It does look amber - which if I understand the RB rules qualities as a 5/5 for appearance because their name clearly indicates this should look amber - with something that could be a white head. Smells of grains, burned candy and cough syrup. Metallic, caramel, stark, herbs, sweet metallic cough syrup, pain, malt, toffee,... Light bodied - I like it less than the Blond one but the ratings just show how ignorant I am - too ignorant to fully appreciate this.
Cask conditioned @ Humble Plumb, Soton. Fruity hops with a hint of citrus. Light but tasty malt and tangy bitterness which lasts well in the finish. Quite good.

Cask-conditioned at the Bag O�Nails, Bristol 23/6/07. Deep gold colour with slight head. Aroma of green fruit with a whiff of hops. Flavour of earthy malt with a decent hoppy finish. Ok, but it didn�t really come together.

Cask at the Red Lion, Cricklade, Wiltshire 09-06-07. Poured golden in colour, had fruity nose, but after a few sips this beer came across as being very tired and well past its best, credit to the landlord who totally agreed with me and changed it immediately, shame as might not get the opportunity to try this again very easily. Had this beer again at the Swan, Bicester, 17-06-07 tasted much much better, nice citrusy hoppiness, good fruity flavours very nice session beer.

Reading 2007. Light brown with a creamy head. Potently hoppy, slightly ganja-ish snout. Chewy, malty, bitterly hoppy. Burnt caramel bitterness with sweet biscuity afters. Fairly full bodied, fruity bitter.
A Mes rate: Cask at The Hobgoblin, Baker St. Yet another poor offering from Wychwood served some way from good condition at the �Goblins Nob�. Really I just can�t be bothered.
Cask Handpump at the Bhurtpore Inn, Aston 04/07/2003 Golden coloured with some sour fruit aroma. Slightly bitter smooth malt finish.

Cask Conditioned at The Hobgoblin, Bicester. I can't believe that Nuffield calls Cricket boring, it is gods game, a tactical battle played out between warriors over 5 days of concentrated pleasure. Rather unlike this light one dimensional beer that tastes mildly of boiled sprouts. A hoppy finish saves the day.

For those who have never had the pleasure of making themselves familiar with the wonderfully boring but gentlemanly game of cricket, the cry of "owzat?!" (short for "How is that?") is the proper language when you want to encourage the umpire to make a call--sort of like if all the fielders in baseball yelled out to call for a called third strike. There is no question about this beer, and that is a welcome relief because the Wychwood beers I've had before are nothing better than bench-warmers, and at worst deserve to be minor leagues or minor counties (depending whether you're playing baseball or cricket). Lighter golden color, decent head on a hand-pull, with a fruity balance and excellent level of carbonation. Fruity hoppiness pervades in excellent balance. In fact, I had another half-pint of this to finish the evening on a good note. (on tap, Turf Tavern, Oxford)
Bottle from the brewery shop, South Woodham Ferrers. Milky taste. More hops. Meh

Pours gold from the bottle. A thick, frothy white head clings to the glass and lingers. Aroma is a subtle blend of tropical fruits, but sweetish, more peach and honey mellon than citrus or pine. There�s also an odd hint of something I can�t quite place but reminds me of dishwashing liquid. Taste is mildly sweet, turning mildly bittersweet at the finish. Body is to the lighter side of medium, carbonation is mild. Overall, good.

Cask. Warning - this may be a dodgy sample. But the main "wonderful" thing about the aroma is its absence. It's lightly hoppy. Also it's a cloudy orange where others have had it clear and golden. The top is lace but fleeting. Fortunately, the taste is okay. Fruity, but with a pleasant and moderate bitterness. The texture is slick and the body medium to light. Carbonation soft and bitter finish. I have said my prayers.
Cask@St Albans BF. Decidedly soapy mouthfeel. Some nuttyness and generally pretty full flavoured, but the soap gets in the way.
red coloured ale with small head. Aroma is sweet and malty. Flavor starts off sweet and ends with a nice dry finish.

Cloudy copper colour. A malty beer in the autumnal style, but I found it a bit dull. The condition may have been to blame, but it certainly didn�t come over as one of Crouch Vale�s better efforts. Cask (gravity dispense) at St Albans Beer Festival 2004.
Cask at the Swan in the Rushes, Loughborough. Amber colour with white frothy head, good lacing. A roasty, bitter flavour. Light bodied. Not a bad session beer.
Cask Conditioned @ the Saturday session, St Albans Beer Festival 2004. Beer #6. Possibly in fairly poor condition, slighly soapy and sour. Not great!
Handpump At The Old Cannon Brewery.Another nice roasty bitter brew from this great brewery,easy session,great.

From the Alex in Derby. Nice beer, not much of a Red colour to it really, more of an Auburn/Brown. Strong taste though lacking for something, maybe dry hopping would have helped brin gout the character more?

Cask at the Ipswich Beer Festival 2004, gravity dispense. Crouch Vale�s attempt at a red Irish style ale - not a bad try IMO. Reddish colour, malty / toffee / caramel aroma, hints of oak. Malty caramel flavour with a surprisingly hoppy bitterness. Very good. A great combo with burger & chips.
Maidstone Fest. Roasty Irish Red. like a cross between a stout and a bitter. But more inclined to the bitter. Nice.

Cask Conditioned, at the Wenlock Arms, London. Clear ripened amber colour with a full frothy head, flat otherwise. Fruity hoppy aroma. Soft,sweet malt flavours with a smooth hope finish. In wonderful condition.

Light gold. Not much head. Kind of an appley aroma. Harsh and grainy. Not that good. It lack bitterness, but doesn't replace this with sweetness. Despite the references to eastern Europe, I don't get any of that character in this beer. Just another industrial lager, but maybe more of a low rent one, because it does use sugar and that brings acetaldehyde to the table in a way that eastern Europe's classics just don't have.
holliday in Tazania 0.50 bottle gold blond colored body with a white head and a spicy hoppy aroma a spicy malt hoppy taste with a bitter finish
Crappy and just wrong, a light lager with little body, no hop flavour. Only flavour coming through loud and clear is the alcohol. Stay away from this shit.
Piwo o jasnej ��tej barwie piana bia�a szybko opadaj�ca, bardzo s�aba goryczka, posmak orzech�w w�oskich, s�odkiej kukurydzy, wodniste, jak dla mnie bardzo s�abe piwo.
I had this at Global Brew. Pours gold with a white head. Taste light, smooth, malty, sweet. I thought this was good. I would drink this again. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Clear yellow body with a light white head. Grassy floral aroma. Taste matches with a sweet finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
I had it in Kenya in 1992. Clean, well-made and above average lager (by african beer standard at least)
A slightly grainy little international lager with little else to differentiate it aside from the label on the bottle.
As the name suggest this is a very light boring little lager and not fit for ratebeerians.

Cask Conditioned at The Woodmans Arms, Hammerpot, W.Sussex. Orange amber beer with thin head. Lacking condition, but nevertheless a fruity hoppy beer, good alcohol notes, there is a nasal whisky character.

[Cask at Charlie's Bar] The aroma is very light with slight notes of fruit - a somewhat weird aroma. The color is a slightly hazy orange and it has a small fine head. The flavor is soft, a little flat (cask), rich on fruit, warming, sligthtly prickling with notes of oranges. It ends on a slight bitter hop. A very fresh ale - very easily drinkable.

Spelt beer referring to the Gallo-Roman age, with yellowish white, dense, moussy head and orangey peach blonde colour, misty, brownish with deposit. Spicy aroma of ginger, nutmeg, grains including spelt, grapefruit; spicy, dry, fruity and yeasty taste, completely ruined by bacterial lactic acidity, clearly the result of an infection.

Cask at The Farmer�s Arm Inn, King�s Lynn, July 2012 Light amber color. Mild aroma, with a lemony trace. Light body, simple flavour, with good bitterness and light lemon trace; the final is correctly bitter, maybe too dry. Simple but refreshing enough.

Cask at Wild Swan (Shepherd Neame). Clear golden pour with a small white head which quickly disappears. Some light citrus on the nose with balanced biscuit and a touch of zest. Orange and lemon in the taste - citric fruits seem to be the focus, light biscuit, orange rind. Very easy going. Quite a decent mid

Cask at the Bishop�s Finger - Smithfield, London. Pours perfectly clear gold with a fine, creamy head. Light citrusy hops in the nose, fine biscuity pale malts. Light sweet flavor with mellow orange rind, other pithy citrus, restrained pale malts. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Fair balance onthe finish, slight leafy bitterness, further dry citrus, touhes of dry, pale malte. Nothing that wrong here, although the character is on the wimpy side.
On tap in Kent. Awaited a bit more but got still a full bodied flower aromatic beer. Colour was a bit to clear amber but all around this is a well done beer.
On tap in Kent. Beer pours in deep golden brown with a light but steady head. Tastes mild of roses, straw and is quite bitter and dry. Not carbonated at all.

Tasted this in the Bon Accord, Glasgow in November 2008. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear pale tawny in colour with a thin white head. Lemon peel present in the short tart aroma. Thin resiny mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malts give a juicy grapefruit flavour with lemon grass notes. Dry dusty bitterness floods into the aftertaste with floral zest. Finish is hoppy with a metallic tang strong in the palate. A poor session bitter and not for me.

Had on tap in a Shepherd Neame pub in Canterbury. There are thousands of �em. I did not get on well with this at all. It looked slightly opaque in the glass and tasted overwhelmingly of vegetation. Not even any particular vegetable, which might have been interesting, just... leaves. It smelled like an elderly forest, in the worst possible way, and tasted dreadful. Avoid like the bloody plague.
Cask, this one was very thin and weak, the colour was light and the taste was not enjoyable, I wasnt a fan
Cask in London, England. Light brown with little head. Slightly carbonated with light mouthfeel and somewhat hoppy finish.

I apparently liked this beer more than most. It was a very light, golden orange color with a minimal head that goes away over time leaving this ugly lilly pad looking bubbles that only a beer geek like you and I can appreciate. There is a light hoppy aroma.I liked it, the flavor was a little hoppy as well - very hoppy for a british bitter.
Bottle from a now unrecalled source (historic rating). Poured an amber colour with a white head. Aroma of malt, caramel and light hop. Moderate sweetness, and light bitterness. OK...
330ml, BBF 26 11 08 Rating from 2008. Gold-br�unlich im Glas ist das bier tewas w�ssrig. Leichte Malzaromatik zu erkennen, im Nachgeschmack leicht feinherb. Nett, aber nichts Besonderes.
Orange i f�rgen, vitt fint skum. S�ta malttoner med karamell apelsin, honung och gr�s. Smakar balanserat med inslag av kakor gr�s kola karamell. Trevlig
The aroma is fruity and malty with some light caramel. The taste is malty with an appealing fruitiness. Pleasant aftertaste.

Brown 330ml bottle, this beer was brewed by a German originally, or so I am lead to believe. I have a feeling this bottle may have been brewed at the Celtic brewery in Ireland and then sold under license in the UK? Best before 5th August 09, drank March 09. Poured into a stemmed �La Chouffe� tulip glass (my current favorite). Certainly looked like a Vienna lager. Deep amber, old gold in colour, sparkling and with an slightly off-white head. Crisp and clean tasting but dull in the flavour stakes. An average Vienna, but a good one if considering its history (Mongolian or Irish). An OK beer that I couldn�t really recommend it to anyone, unless they are drinking round the world like me (and I�m not over confident this counts as a beer from Mongolia anyway!).
floral, cooked vegetables, toast, amber, clear, minimal head, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium body, thin feel, bitter,

Misty red brown thin head carbonation medium aroma rich caramel nutty citrus flavour hoppy citrus and bitter caramel nutty taste vanilla very pleasant tasting sharp crisp finish crisp tasting leaving a good bitter aftertaste as well as the malt

Bottle. Pours a semi-cloudy, amber-orange with a foamy white head. Malty aroma with some honey and caramel. Crisp malt character, more honey, some citrus and pine hops. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Finishes sweet, lightly syrupy with some bread and lingering, fruity bitterness. Not bad.

Bottle. A - Lighter caramel color with a smaller than average, bubbly and foamy, slightly off-white head. Doesn�t last too long and leaves a thin patchy lacing. S - Tart apple along with some citrus and other juicy fruity aromas. Competing and almost equaling it is a sweet caramel malt with a touch of bready aroma. Hints of bitter, floral hops come out as well. A nice diversity of aromas. T - Citrus, tart apple, and earthy and floral hops mix with some caramel and bready malt. These come in and out with varying strength through out the sip. Overall, I think the bitter/tart flavors are just a touch more prominent and linger just a bit longer. M - Light body with a good amount of carbonation. Fizzy and crisp with a bit of a drying finish. D - Pretty drinkable beer that is well balanced between bitter, tart, and sweet. Also fairly refreshing. Notes: Best before 06/2010. A decent beer that was better than what I was expecting. Well balanced between the flavors. Not amazing by any means, but a solid/decent beer.

0,33 l bottle, bought at BeerImperium., Vienna Hazy deep golden-amber body with a foamy offwhite head. Aroma of honey and hay, some caramel and straw, some grassy hop and an unpleasant flesh character. Honey and caramel in the flavor with a strong grassy hop that remains in the aftertaste.
Bottke 33 cl. Clear golden with a small white head. Boozy nose. Rich, sweet malty body, distinct alcohol burn. An alcoholic�s dream beer.... 050919

column4: Castlemaine Perkins Brewery (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Restrained aroma in a golden pour. Laid back hop forward balance with Little to differentiate from a mass market lager. Except for the relatively low strength - which is always a plus in my book.

column4: Castlemaine Perkins Brewery (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: From old tasting notes. Bright honey gold color. Thick bubbly white head. Zesty citrus malt nose. Light dry malty flavor. Spritzy citrus fruit hop finish.

column4: Castlemaine Perkins Brewery (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: It is a real shame that the older versions of these beers were much better. Not simply because I yearn for the 'good old days' but really because they were better. I think that one of the problems is that the excise tax on beer in this country is linked to the ABV so to keep prices down the brewers have reduced the alcohol. Add to that the cost of cheap adjuncts such as cane sugar there is a real diminution in flavour. I agree that the hop presence isn't bad but there is a real thinness in this beer.

column4: Castlemaine Perkins Brewery (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Import Bottle. Not bad at all. Clean flavor with a good malt taste, color is a little light for the style. Hoppiness is a little light, too.

column4: Castlemaine Perkins Brewery (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Pale yellow liquid with a small quickly disappearing head. Good sharp hop aromas are enticing. Nice crisp yet malty flavor that finishes nicely. Nice fluid mouthfeel. Good and Happy.
A light and crisp lager similar to a er light. Pours a light yellow in color and is pretty bitter ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Golden with creamy, white head. Decent lacing. Faint aroma, mildly grain and floral. Lite bodied, mild hop presence. Mild bitter up front and no finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at the brew pub. Pours a clear gold with a white head that dissipates quickly to the edges. Aroma has grain and bread notes with a bit of backing sweet cereal. Flavor is similar with sweet grains and bread with a hint of corn.

On tap at Moosejaw brewpub. Crystal clear pale straw yellow with a medium white head. Aroma of grassy hops, sweet malt and corn. Taste of sweet malt, corn and mild grassy hops and a clean metallic finish. Thin bodied and macroesque.

On tap at the brewpub, pours a clear pale yellow, no head. Typical sacrificial light beer offered in a tourist town where people panic if there�s no budllercoors in the bar. Watery, very little corny flavor.

On tap at Moosejaw. Poured pale straw golden with a sticky white head. The aroma picked up toasted pale malts with grassy accents.. very weak presentation. The flavor found honey and pale malts at the core with very light grassy bitterness.. dry finish. Light-bodied and grainy across the palate.. OK flow.. drinkable, but not desirable.

On tap. Pours a clear light yellow. Nose is grassy malts, some rice, very light piney hops. Taste is a typical watery pale lager with slightly more hop character than most macros and a more flavorful grassy malt background. No finish to speak of.

On draught at the Moosejaw brewpub in Wisconsin Dells, WI. Pours a clear golden pale colored brew with a thin white head that slowly dissipates and leaves behind some nice lacing. Aroma of light fruity golden grain malt, some Crystal malt, mild citrus hops and a touch of grass. Taste is light to medium bodied, a little fruit and light grassy hops. Finish is light, crisp with a mild sweet golden grain malt aftertaste. Quite similar to the Heileman Kr�usened Old Style Lager I remember from my college years. Very refreshing.
Brewery located in Wisconsin Dells, WI. Clean, easy to drink. Would drink again.
Pours a clear light gold with a thin white head. Hints of DMS in aroma. Typical lager flavor. Light body, slightly dry finish. Spot on for a lager.

column4: Grumpy Troll Brewery, Restaurant and Pizzeria
column5: Clear amber with medium off-white head. Aroma is weak -- floral and herbal. Taste is mildly sweet, floral/herbal bitter, with little balance. Medium body.

On draught at the brewpub/brewery in downtown Chilton, Wisconsin. Pours a semi-clear reddish amber brew with a creamy off-white head that quickly dissipates to a fine film and white ring. Aroma of powdered amber malt, a touch of light yeast and citrus and piney hops. Taste is light to medium bodied, some fruity character of apples/pear, light caramel malt and citrus zest hops. Finish is slightly dry with a light metallic texture and thin caramel malt aftertaste. Almost identical to the Irish Red Ale but this one is a little hoppier.

On tap. Clear medium reddish-orange pour with a short, rocky beige head. Aroma was a little weak, but harbored a significant amount of beery goodness... caramel, spices, and a hint of honey were in there, along with some floral hoppage. Smooth spice and caramel malt blend across the middle of the palate with bitter floral hops at the edges and finish. Medium-bodied, crisp around the edges and at the finish, and creamy-smooth across the middle. Medium-length finish with caramel, toffee, and light spices. Very fine brew!
Smooth. Fairly hoppy for one of Bob�s brews. Very easy-drinking and likeable.

Maybe I just drank this a little too late in the night, but this brew had a sour-mash taste to it. I kinda liked it, but once again not a tradional Red. Then again, that�s what makes this brewery so freakin� great. Flavors of two distinct beer styles mixed together to make one uber-beer (see Calumet Bock). Need to get up here again for work sometime soon.

tap at brewery back in April-this beer was not listed on the database when sampled. pretty much a basic red ale, but not to thin for the style-cascade hop aroma with some roasted carmel notes. nice finish.
Red brown body, clear, medium beige head. Aroma is toffee/caramel, mild sweet. Taste is light sweet, toffee, mild finish. Light/medium body.

A wonderful and quite aromatic Wee Heavy. Probably the best of the 30+ local micros that I enjoyed on this trip. The peated malt and caramel nose was strong and proud, boasting a barrel aged-like woodiness. The rich malty flavor hinted of bourbon, caramel and campfire smoke. The easy finish left malty, tangy aftertastes.

Rich dark amber color, light brown head. Caramel malts, earthy and sweet with fruity undertones. Chocolate, caramel, dry and toasty. a hint of yeastiness. Good malt presence, slightly smokey, a hint of cherries. sweet, creamy and full. not bad, but could use a bigger hop profile.
Clear copper body with small beige head. Aroma is caramel and lightly smoky. Taste is mild sweet, malty, caramel, toasty and light smoky. Medium body.
Flasche 50cl. Goldfarbenes Helles mit sch�nen Honig- und Karamellnoten. Vanille. Erfrischend im Abgang, sehr lecker!!

On draft as Helles Vollbier. Utterly moreish with a fine, sweetish, honey-like touch of malt balanced by some minerality and light, elegant bitterness, leading to a dryish finish that leaves you wanting another gulp. Plain, elegant and excellent.
Clear golden body with a tall white head. Cripy aroma of corn, cereals, grass. Taste is mild malty with grassy notes. Crispy finish. Medium body, flat carbonation, soft texture.

resin, floral, grass, spruce, citrus, herbs, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, salty, umami, heavily sour, lightly sour, lightly bitter, light sweetness, light body, medium body, fizzy, average carbonation, lively,

On tap at Oslo Mikrobryggfest. Has a hazy yellow colour with an off-white head. Lots of phenols, yeast, banana, white bread and wheat.
