The flavour is similar but with more pale malt, hay and a sweet background. Has a slick mouth feel, light body and a light bitterness. Sweet and decent hefe-weizen but the phenols are quite dominant though.

Hazy, pale yellow body with a small, white, short-lived head. Strong aroma of hefeweizen yeast, here be bananas! Strong flavour of banana, candy, sugar and some citrus. Moderate sweet taste with a light bitter finish. [20 cl from tap@Oslo Mikrobryggeri]
On tap at source. Golden color, slightly hazy- good foam. Medium aroma intensity, fruity, banana, light citrus. Medium body & complexity. Well balanced. Enjoyable ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at Oslo Mikrobryggeri. Light hazy golden colour with a white head. Light wheat and banana nose. Yeasty flavour, light sweetness, some banana and citrus.

Tap @ Oslo Mikrobryggeri, Oslo. Pours a light near-clear golden-yellowish body with a small sidesticking off-white head. Aroma is light sour with something that actually reminds me much of wild-yeast. Also hints of hay, wood and cherries. Strange stuff.. Light-bodied, average to soft carbonation and it has a mild watery texture. Tastes just as sour and acidic as the aroma suggested, with notes of hay and sour grapes. This actually can bear resemblance to a mild lambic. Liked it, even though it was a bit light-bodied and I think a bit to sour for a hefe.

On tap at the brewpub. Light yellow hazy, thin white head. Smells of apples, citrus and hints of banana. Taste is very light. Does not feel heavy at all. Some malt but not very sweet eighter. Good acids and a nice dry mouthfeel. Finis his not very bitter. After a while the aroma gets sulfide tendensies, but my rate is based on the first impression
Nice, probably the best one. Very refreshing and very aromatic alike the German ones. Not in the list that day.

24.11.2010. On tap at Oslo Mikrobryggeri. Pale yellow, almost white colour. Fresh wheaty aroma with a lot of summer freshness. Bitter hoppy finish that lasts. Very nice hefeweizein in a very nice brewpub.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours cloudy and hazy straw colored with a small white head. Hefeweizen aroma, banana and cloves, and yes also some yeasty notes. Taste is moderate yeasty notes, with a pleasant citrus aftertaste.
2019 bottle from Dan Murphy's Butler Nice stout, not very sweet, taste of heavy malts and burnt caramel. Subtle finish.
Bottled. A black beer with a brown head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, oats, and bread. The flavor is sweet with notes of oats, roasted malt, and chocolate, leading to a bitter finish.
Appearance: jet black, slight head Aroma: light coffee and roast malts Palate: medium mouthfeel, low carbonation Taste: roast burnt malts, coffee, fairly bitter on aftertaste Overall: not bad

Taster at Union Hotel, Newtown. Pours a jet black with a beige head. Aroma: roasted malt, oats, mild cocoa notes. Taste: roasted malt, cocoa, oats, mild earthy flavours. Medium bodied. Smooth. This was quite decent.

Bottle at Paus Craft Beer Bar, Kuala Lumpur. Poured a clear dark brown colour with a frothy tan head. The aroma is roasty malt, light chocolate, coffee, liqouirce. The flavour is moderate sweet, light liquorice bitter with a dry roasty coffee, chocolate, charcoal, liquorice dry light floral hop palate. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.
33cl bottle at the Paus, KL. Thin tan head. Clear almost black pour. Lots of coffee. Tasty

330 ml bottle. Appears opaque black, with a moderate but transient head of sticky tan froth. Aromas are subdued, especially when cold, but there are roasted malts, chocolate and a little coffee. Taste is similar, sweet mixed with bitter in the finish, roasted dark malts, and chocolates mainly. Some carbonation sting, but smooth and medium bodied mouthfeel overall.

Draught @ The Local Taphouse, Sydney, Australia. Pours black with huge brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, caramel, light dark chocolate. Flavor is light sweet, light bitter, roast malt, caramel, coffee, dark chocolate. Medium body, soft carbonation, dry and light bitter finish. 100317
Black, almost opaque colour in the glass. A hint of coffee in the nose but not much else. Strong chocolate flavour to begin with which develops into intense coffee. Thick, creamy feel mouth feel.

330mL bottle from Booze Bud. BB 30/08/17 Deep opaque black body, holds a creamy dark tan head. Doesn�t give away much on the nose straight up - roasty, burnt toast sort of notes, black coffee. Surprisingly medium bodied, drying roastiness, some smoothness/slickness from the oats but not much. Palate reveals notes of chocolate, black coffee, licorice, browned cereals/oats/bread crust sort of thing happening. Dry finish, lingering roasty note, moderate-high bitterness. Pretty good - a more "session-style" stout, despite it�s strength and oatmealiness.

Bottle (couple of years old I expect) at home. It pours hazy cloudy golden-amber with a thick white head. The nose is soft bready malt, spice, hay, sweet apple and pear drops. The taste is hay/floral, dough, spice, touch of toast, candy, apple, green banana and citrus peel with a dry finish. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Decent balance. An OK Belgian ale at best.
Clear dark golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity, yeasty and light herbal. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 130612

0.33l bottle shared with ClubGonzo and Inbreak. This is a blurry honey-orange colored beer with a small white, lacing and light bubbly head. It�s aroma has tones of honey, zest, flowers and something fruity and acidic as well. It has a oily texture and a average carbonation. Flavors are at first a little bit acidic, and I actually get some flower water mixed with caramel. There�s also something undefined with this one that I just can�t get my head around what is, so will stop trying and just enjoy tasting. 18.04.2012

Bottle, shared with Palme and Inbreak. Pours a dark, hay-hued hazy orange body with a dense medium white head. Nose is pale malts, fruity fusion tones of honey, strawberries and apricot. Taste is light malty tones with a considerable smoothness with hints of red berries, honey and faint grapefruit in the back. Medium to full mouthfeel, lively carbonation. A pretty nice beer, though not spectacular in any way.
Bottled. Golden coloured. Unclear. Dense off White head. Herbs fruits sweetness, spice in the aroma. Flavour of yeast, sweetness fruits. Medium bodied. Sweety and fruity end.

Golden cloudy, big white head. Boozy nose with apples and haylike hops on the nose. Sweet almond, booze, hay dried apples and a little hop bitterness that ties it all together. Still a rather ordinary blond that is a bit to boozy and sweet for my taste.
Bottle. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is floral, hay, malt. Flavour is fruit, malt, hay, alcohol, apple, flower, yeast. Medium body. Ordinary beer.

Bottle.Pours pale golden with a white head.Aroma is floral, hay, honey , malt and yellow apples.Flavor is sweet and somewhat bitter with some floral and malty notes.Medium to thin body, average carbonation.

Bottle. A clear one, golden in color and with a finger-thick white head leaving nice lacings. Fruity-sweet, peachy aroma with an unpleasant chemical-like touch. It�s medium bodied and semi-sweet, pleasantly carbonated. Fruity, slightly bitter flavor with some of the same chemical notes found in the aroma. Sort of nice, sort of not so nice. Like visiting the dentist. 110621

column2: Holly Springs, North Carolina, United States
column5: Straw colored appearance with thin but lingering head. Very hoppy aroma, with strong pine and citrous odors. Taste is similar to aroma--at least in terms of the hops. Has dry finish. Hops are very strong in the aroma and flavor but they are not overpowering.

Originally rated on 1/26/09. A bit of a let down here, it looked, smelled and had the mouthfeel of a traditional lager, with the aroma having faint hints of yeast. The taste was not good, a sweet yeasty start and a bitter and a foul aftertaste. I wont try this one again.

From old tasting notes. Brewed in Austin Texas. Brilliant yellow gold color. Bubbly white head. Complex malt aroma with hints of citrus and spice. Spicy fruit malt flavor has notes of orange peel and anise seed. Very good.

Medium straw, cloudy. Assertiveeasty nose. Medium body, moderate flavor, refreshing mouthfeel, good length. Moderate bitterness and sweetness, adequate acidity. Coriander stands out, tangerine, blood orange. Very pleasant, grows on you. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bready coriander spice aroma. The body is a hazy yellow with a hint of amber. Thin covering of white foam blankets the top. Bread malt taste with a touch of coriander and spice. . Smooth silk feeling. Warms the palate. Pleasant and drinkable.
Light yellow in color no head. Notes of grass, Apple, malts, spicy hops. A nice strong ale for the price

Tallahassee, Fl - New Leaf Market - 12 oz bottle. Slightly murky medium golden, little to no head. Aroma of bubble gum and sugar water, Flavor is decidedly sweet with some Belgian candii sugar notes, some cotton candy, a touch of bubble gum. Mouthfeel has a decent stickiness to it. Passable.

Misty patch-amber, standard 12 oz longneck, OK label. Sourish, slightly plasticky, plummy, yeasty aroma. On the front end, I thought it would do better. Woody saison thing. Mossy, a little diacetyl, yeasty, mineral, sour fruit. Has interesting flairs here and there, but also blows the shift at times, too. New Leaf Market.

"i realized when pouring this i�ve never had a light Grand Cru before...til now. cloudy straw yellow, aroma of grassy hops, herbs and spices, belgian yeast. pretty basic, but light and refreshing. not enough going on to go back for more, though."

Bottle. From old notes. With herbs and spices, by the original maker of Hoegaarden. Very similar to Hoegaarden Grand Cru, but not quite as good. Not as rich and malty, the flavor just is not up to the other, although it is a pretty pleasant beer.

This seems to taste like a strong version of Celis white! Bright, light golden color with a thin white head. Fresh vegetal/celery aroma and taste with coriander notes and some black pepper. Smooth, creamy malt background with a slight nuttiness. Good alcohol bite that I think seems stronger due to the spice herbaceousness. Spices last long after the sip. Another great Celis beer that I�ll be hoping makes a comeback soon!

Sicherlich nicht die Krone der Sch�pfung, aber eben so sicher ein klassisches und trinkbares Pils. Herb, leicht im Hopfen, akzeptable Bitterkeit, ein wenig Getreide. Zum Schluss hin etwas d�nn, aber alles in allem ganz ok.
From bottle. Transfer of an earlier rating without text recorded, rating only.

Das Bier hat eine klare goldgelbe Farbe und eine geringe wei�e Schaumkrone. Geruch grasig hopfig, leichte W�rze, minimal metallisch. Geschmack leicht metallisch hopfig, im Hintergrund s�� malzig, dezent hopfig bitter.

Sehr s�ffig-s��liches Bier. F�r ein Pils aus BaW� erstaunlich wenig Herbe erkennbar, die S��e dominiert. Allerdings ist es f�r mich eher ein durchschnittliches Pils, dass etwas mehr Tiefgang gut vertragen k�nnte. Test vom 8.3.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,7,10,7,12,8 - 8,60
Not too bad, i heard it was really good, so in that respect it was dissapointing. Very drinkable however.

Bottle: Small and quick disappearing white head on top of a clear golden colored beer. Smell malts, some hops and grainy herbs. Taste is a mix of hops and something very very light fruity, some grains like malts and some corn. Low to more medium bitterness. Decent and ok for a hot day.

Herb-grasiger Antrunk, eher mild. Im Mittelteil erfolgt kaum eine �nderung, der erkennbare hopfige Part wirkt jedoch zunehmend k�nstlicher, Hopfenextrakt? Im Abgang hopfiger, nur sehr leicht bitter, hier wirkt das Bier am kr�ftigsten, bleibt dennoch auf einem insgesamt milden Niveau. In Ordnung. Danke an den Doppelbock f�r das Bier. Test vom 12.8.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 8,8,8,8,7,8 - 7,95
bottle, bought at the brewery. Clear pale yellow colour with a dense and creamy white head. Hoppy nose. Solid malty background and lots of aromatic and resiny-bitter hops. Lingering hoppy finish.
50 cl bottle at yngwie�s tasting at the ferry Christian IV. Abv is 4,8%. Golden yellowish color, disappering white head. Aroma is malty, grainy. Flavor is malty with ok bitterness and some fruit.

column2: West Lebanon, New Hampshire, United States
column5: Light gold. Hints of orange No distinguishable scent Very weak lager taste. Meh malts. Tastes like every other ice beer. 20% carbonation. Light body. Stale finish. 30/100

column2: West Lebanon, New Hampshire, United States
column5: A golden ale with a thin white head. Light malt aroma with soapy notes. In mouth, a light ale with faint malt and light British hops. Watery. On tap at the brewpub, Dec. 27 2009.

column2: West Lebanon, New Hampshire, United States
column5: on tap-pours a thin white head and yellow color. Aroma is mild light malt/grain-some sweetness, musty. Taste is light malt/grain-some sweetness, musty, lemon, some perfumy/spice hops.

column2: West Lebanon, New Hampshire, United States
column5: [Tap] Poured a clear yellow with very little head. Aroma was mild and not very distinct. Just smelled like beer. Taste was a little malty and just a touch of hops. Finish was hard to describe and just odd.

column2: West Lebanon, New Hampshire, United States
column5: Cloudy golden pour with a thin white head. The aroma is slightly sweet. Average flavor of mild hops and honey sweetness. The body is light to medium with a creamy texture and gentle carbonation. Quite boring...

column2: West Lebanon, New Hampshire, United States
column5: Pours gold with a white head. Smells of some stray hops, and hay. Tastes of nuts, some hints of bitterness. Reminded me of a watery version of their cream ale.

column2: West Lebanon, New Hampshire, United States
column5: 8 ounce draught glass at the brewery. Very clear light gold, bubbly, no head at all....grassy, faintly herbal aroma, a touch of diacetyl, pretty close to nonexistent when cold -- you really have to let it warm up to smell much of anything....lightly sweet, buttery flavor, biscuity malts with mild earthy hops, reasonably crisp and clean but really dull.....a bit mineralic/metallic to finish, almost unpleasant when warmer. What an exciting clientele they must have, to have this and a cream ale on at the same time....

column2: West Lebanon, New Hampshire, United States
column5: Sampler at the brewpub - Poured a bright, clear yellow in color with a small white head. Aroma was slightly malty with no hops. Flavor was somewhat malty, but had some "weird" flavors on the backside that were not that great. Finish was clean. Drinkable, but only if nothing better was available...

column2: West Lebanon, New Hampshire, United States
column5: Aroma:Sweet malt..... Appearance:Clear gold,no head..... Flavor:Light malt and bitterness...

column2: West Lebanon, New Hampshire, United States
column5: Golden body. Pale malty nose and flavor. Mild woody hop quality. Metallic and plastic elements detract. A sub-standard beer, but I don�t think that they�re aiming very high with this one.

column2: West Lebanon, New Hampshire, United States
column5: Pours a clear golden color with a thin white head. Aroma of malt and caramel. Flavor of malt and caramel, The body is light with a creamy texture and moderate carbonation. Average.

column2: West Lebanon, New Hampshire, United States
column5: Draft at the brewpub - Poured a pale amber in color with a medium white head that faded quickly. Aroma is malty and quite sweet. Flavor is also very sweet with a strange astringent aftertaste hanging on with the clinging sweetness at the end. Not very good...

column2: West Lebanon, New Hampshire, United States
column5: Aroma:lightcaramel nose... Appearance:orange light head.... Flavor:Waterylight sugar flavor....

column2: West Lebanon, New Hampshire, United States
column5: Sample at the brewpub. Light, creamy & very pale to look at. Slim oaky nose. Oak in flavor, and brown sugar, lots of brown sugar. Cloying towards the end.

column2: West Lebanon, New Hampshire, United States
column5: Nice coppery color with small white head. Mildy malty throughout with bready presence initial taste and rising sweetness at finish. Would be excellent but for a slight acrid chemical-like character in aftertaste which ruins the experience.

column2: West Lebanon, New Hampshire, United States
column5: Draft at brewery - This is one of their "cask conditioned" seasonals offered at hte brewery. Pours a medium amber with very little carbonation. Aroma is hoppy with a slightly citrus tone. Flavor is disinctly citrus hops and medium bitter. Finish is hop bitter and slightly sweet. Ths was enjoyable and I hope they make it again.

column2: West Lebanon, New Hampshire, United States
column5: Hint of apricot in nose. Malty beginning with hop bitterness rising to a crescendo at the swallow. Apricot becomes more apparent in flavor at end of glass.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: On tap at the brewery. Golden color with steady carbonation and a trim white head. Smells and tastes of grassy pils malt, canned peaches, and mild citrus from the hops. Floury. Not a fan.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: On tap at Squatters downtown Appearance: Slightly cloudy yellow with a small white head and some lacing Aroma: Banana and citrus Taste: Fizzy mouthfeel of bananas, wheat and citrus with a dry finish Nice refreshing

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: Now called Kindig Weisse, this may or may not be a different brew than the other Krystal Weisse, but for now I will consider it the same. On tap at the brewpub in SLC. Pours a clear gold body with a fizzy body and a light white colored head. The aroma is light banana and wheat notes. The taste was somewhat dry and full of grain/wheat flavors with some light banana and a zesty mouthfeel. Quite nice.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: Clear and light, very bubbly. Surprisingly lager-like with little wheat character. Malty, only lightly flavored.
On tap at Groggs Cloudy amber with a medium sized off-white head, good lacing. Aroma of caramel, malts and bready. Taste is malty, caramel, bready and citrus Decent

On tap, at Grogg�s in Helper/Price. Pours a medium amber color with a white head. Decent head retention with a mild hop aroma. Not much of a sharp attack, but a smooth drinking ale with a semi-sweet finish and a mild aftertaste. A decent Utah microbrew.

On tap at the brewpub in Utah. Pours a clear amber with a white head. The aroma and taste were similar; a sweet and smooth malt, some very light hops, no bitterness, and overall, like a weak amber ale. Drinkable for sure. Just not a stand out beer.

[Colorado Road Trip � 2006] This was a light colored straw yellow with a hint of hops in the nose. This was a grain build of rice and very little good malts. The hops did not exist and I felt I was drinking a bad lite beer. They need to get a new contract brewer.

Copper and clear. Lots of fizzy white lacing... flavor is grainy and mineraly... fizzy palate, light flavors of grain and gravel. Nose is a putrid weed/compost/vegetable concoction... not to be too harsh, but this is one of the worst beers I�ve ever tasted.
Yellow-orange, thin head, and a peachy aroma. Sweet flavor for a pale. Very smooth. Eh ...

[Colorado Road Trip � 2006] A nice brew t was a light amber color with a nice malt build and the hops where a tad light. This was a better beer to drink at this place. They need to reevaluate there contract brewing.

Dark orange, sour grain, bad and sharp maple syrup... seriously it tastes like maples syrup that was squeezed from some macabe maple compost pile. Some black licorice... with a lingering licorice finish that is not one bit enjoyable. Nose is the worst part, with a rotting wood and wet dog aroma.
Dark amber color with a good milky head. Smooth, velvety. Odd bittering agents, but it's OK.

Wow... Okay people, Dick Marcincko was a Navy SEAL and founder of SEAL Team 6. He has written books, had books written about him, star of a video game and many other things. His book is called Rogue Warrior, hence the name of the beer and his picture. The man is an actual badass worthy of his own beer... Not some damn entertainment wrestler.

I picked up the bottle at the Brewery in 2004. It had a cool label on it. I honestly don�t remember what the beer was like. But I have the bottle to prove that I had it. I remeber it being basic but still great.!

Overly soft again for style. Low bitterness with some grassy hop notes. Somewhat English malt nose with some caramel and toffee notes. Hops seem somewhat downplayed for the style. Clean and drinkable session beer.

We begin our appreciation of the presentation by admiring the biceps of the manly man on the silkscreened label, presumably the Richard Marcincko that the beer is dedicated to, and what else does Mr. M. have to say? "Thou shalt not like it, thou hast just to do it. Thou shalt Keep It Simple, Stupid. Thou shalt never assume. There are no rules- thou shalt win all all costs." Hokay, without even cracking the crown, I've got my program before me! I'm guessing Richard M.'s a wrestler? I've also checked the ingredients in all my saved Rogue bottles to be sure that this is not a re-bottled something else, and it doesn't match up, so here we go... Appearance: a hazy, solid peach color, good, fluffy white head. Aroma: zesty, citrusy (grapefruit, orange, peach, more?), very fruity, sweet, richly aromatic, earthy and rare. Taste: unique! Substantial, yeasty, citric, delicious! Lots of sweet and tart hops dancing on the tongue, plenty of malt at work, gobs of yeast, still lively. Damn! Great tasting! Full malt, full hops, this brew ain't missing nothing is it? Feels a bit like Dead Guy...hmm, that bottle's missing from my collection...I'm not drinking re-packaged Dead Guy, am I? (It's been nearly 6 months since I've had one). No, I don't think so, though I welcome anyone to correct me. This is a substantially fruity ale, a fuller amber, a bolder pale, but great tasting to THE EXTREME!!! Another nice one from Rogue!

Clear amber medium bubbled almost white head. Mild sweet aroma a combination of hops and grain giving this a different aroma but maybe I just getting to comfortable with hop monsters. A hop monster this beer is not. Medium light bodied beer smooth drinking a definite grainy flavor but not an unpleasant one. A floral hop flavor comes though a balanced beer and a great session beer

Hazy,oarnge/brown. Usual,Rogue,head. Lots of hops in the aroma with just as much caramel/bready malt aromas.Buttery,full,body. Starts hoppy,lots of malt in the flavor. Leafy hops and bready malts.Lingering leafy,hop finish. Dry and refreshing. Very drinkable beer,nothing fancy. Thanks Andre'!
I swear this is a re-bottling of the amber ale. Oh well, still very dank beer. Perfectly balanced hop profile, sweetness to match the malt body, and a slighly bitter aftertaste that is great.

I thought this was an extremely unique take on what has become a very boring and standard style. Nicely balanced with sweet malts and very tasty hops. Very drinkable with that aftertaste that only Rogue can produce.
Aroma is very hoppy with a perfect balance of malt, lots of cinammon. Wow! APA?! Nice for this style! Flavor is slightly cobwebby with a dry hop finish. Very unique hop flavors, not bad.
Cloudy amber,small beige head.Light citrus hop and malt nose.Lots of malt to start with good medium long lasting hop end.Well balanced

22/11/2019. Bottle from Tesco, Saxmundham. Pours pale reddish amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of strawberry and cream sweets, strawberry syrup, vanilla custard, touch of sweet caramel. Medium to heavy sweetness, light tartness. Moderate body, oily watery texture, soft carbonation.

On tap. Hellrotes Bier, rosa Schaum. Nase rein in den Topf mit der frisch gekochten Erdbeermarmelade! Irre. S�sser Erdbeer Geschmack. Dann viel Vanille und Kokos. Ist das echt alles nat�rlich? Wenn ja, nochmal:irre!
Taste very nice. Super easy to drink. I felt almost like drinking strawberry juice. I can feel hop at the end of the taste.

tall glass at barley�s casino: pale yellow with a creamy white head, some haze left in it still-either a starch or protein haze, but of course doesn�t have a bad effect on the flavor. light and crisp flavor like a kolsch should have, fairly thick i�d say. leaves an interesting aftertaste in the mouth i can�t quite describe. Not the best, but I�ll definitely go back to try it again and see how it matures.. may need more cold storage.

Deep yellow with standard white head, authentic-looking at least, but maybe a bit too still. This is grainy, and notably more malty than my favorite Cologne beers, but I think this is one of Michael's best efforts.

Strangely, it was darker in color (dark golden -- almost amber) than any other kolsch I've had before. A little maltier than I expected also. How can they call this a kolsch? Anyway, mouthfeel was kind of creamy with some watery notes; medium carbonation. Honey sweetness exuded in the malts. Rather spicy, herbal, zingy hops caught me off guard. Had some rye-like qualities to it also. Only a mild bitterness, but the hops became more and more "electric" in the mouth. Curiously, they actually started growing on me. Overall, I enjoyed the beer, which tasted more like an experimental homebrew (which isn't necessarily a bad thing). But it didn't seem to fit kolsch style guidelines by any means.
Bernsteinfarben, luftiger Schaum, im Geruch ma�zig getreidig ne Spur rauch, sch�ne r�stmalz Aromen Karamell im Geschmack, gef�llt mir ganz gut

Flasche gekauft bei Hopfen und Malz. Klares rot braun, kein Schaum, kaum Kohlens�ure. Aroma: Malz, Kaffee, dunkele Schokolade, alles dezent. Geschmack: W�ssriger Antrunk, Bitterschokolade, etwas Karamell. Etwas d�nn, fehlt das Volle

Amber/brownish body with a tall, creamy and collapsing white head. Malty and hearty aroma. A bit of wood. Taste is nuts, caramel, figs, dark bread. Nice bitter finish. Medium body, soft carbonation, tiny texture.

Pours brown from the bottle. Frothy off white head that fades. Aroma is caramel, tea, mineral water. Taste is mostly sweet with artificial cherry notes that come up at the finish. A metallic tinge lingers afterwards. Body is medium and a somewhat prickly carbonation accentuates the cherry pop flavor. Overall pretty nasty stuff. Even the less discriminating drinkers in the family wanted no part of it.
Good Franconian-standard brew, dark, malty, sweet-and-sour flavors. Enjoyable.
Bottle. Bready, light roast, caramel popcorn. chestnut, red, off golden white head. Hard roasted caramel, eggy mineral water. Medium light body. soso

Clear brown/copper with little white head. Aroma is some smoke, cherry pips, fruchtgummi, chalk, corn. Taste is quite sour, with a malty chalky sweetness. Not so great. Abrupt finish, not very heavy. Too few of everything.
Bottle. Reddish-dark amber color with tan head. Aroma is chocolate, some breadcrust. Taste is chocolate, breadcrust again, quite delicate. Oily mouthfeel. Quite light, but nice.
500ml Bottle - Copper in colour. Sultanas, caramel, rye bread and nuts in the aroma. Fruity and malty taste with sultanas, raisins and caramel standing out.
50 cl bootle. Copper color. Medium off-white head. Caramel , malt, toffee, Medium sweetness Nutty and malty flavor.

On tap at Weekend der Spontane Gisting, Opstal, Belgium. Shared with lovely Anja. Dark ruby red to purple, minimal head. Aroma is fruity, gluey, dark cherry, cherry brandy. Sour cherry flavour, cherry candy, light and watery, some acidity lingers on. Some leather, fruit jam, acetic acid in the finish. Soft carbonation. Very nice fruity character. Some sweetness.

En copa, cerveza rojo brillante con una generosa capa de espuma rosada. Aroma muy dulce a cerezas, junto con piel de c�tricos y algo de caramelo. En boca, textura ligera y acuosa, de carbonataci�n media/alta y amargor inexistente. Sabores muy dulces a cereza, con un toque de �cido c�trico. Una Lambic de frutas que m�s bien parece un zumo que una cerveza. No es ninguna maravilla, pero quita la sed y es muy refrescante.
Fizzy drink with cherry. Definitely overpriced, especially for a 0.33 bottle. Honestly does not feel like a genuine fruit beer, more like some chemical imitation.

Barwa czerwono-r�owa, klarowne. Piana obfita, d�ugo si� utrzymuje. Wysycenie �rednie. W aromacie nie za wiele si� dzieje. Kwa�ne wi�nie, nieco landrynek i w zasadzie to tyle. W smaku podobnie, gorzko-kwa�ne wi�nie, na finiszu skontrowane s�odycz�. Smaczne piwo, ale niesamowitych dozna� nie ma si� co spodziewa�. Konkurencyjny Lindemans lepszy.

09.05.2018, 0,75l bottle (1990 vintage) sampled @ 1420 "The great geriatric geuze get-together" tasting: Small fizzy-creamy mediumlasting head, slightly cloudy. Aroma is dry mineraly, old cork, old cellar, minerals, alcohol, wet paper, unripe banana, sawdust, old glue, bark, grass. Taste is slightly dry sour-ish, citrus acid, hay, oak, minerals, sorrel, old dusty cellar, berry skin, sawdust, wet paper, green apple peel, unripe berries. Medium bitterness, dry sour-ish dusty mouthfeel with a tiny fizz. Interesting, but that's it...
On tap at Lambiczoon, Milan, Italy. It pours clear golden with a minimum white head. Aroma is earth, grass, funky, lemon. Taste is light bitter and medium sour. Body is light, carbonation is is fine.

Rami Rami is drinking a Gueuze 1981 by Brouwerij De Troch at Groch�w Duzo kwasnosci, bez octu, nieco owocow a la jablka, prawie plaskie co2, nieco obory, nieco skory, ale malo, sciagajace, pojawia sie slodycz (w sensie slodki aromat, te jablka chyba) Rami Rami: W cholere wytrawne w ustach Rami Rami: Nawet z minusem ta czworka, ale niewatpliwie doswiadczenie mistyczne Rami Rami: Piwo z przed stanu wojennego :)
Kapsel is drinking a Gueuze 1981 by Brouwerij De Troch - Fajnie kwa�ne, lekkie owoce, praktycznie bez wysycenia, lekkie nuty stajenne. Niesamowite do�wiadczenie.

37.5cl bottle shared at DHVL. Bottle from the 90�s. It pours a clean orange color with a minimal layer of white bubbles. Aroma is lightly sweet with oxidised notes of caramel and toffee and medium tangy funky, lightly acidic, with basement mold, musty notes. Taste is more geared towards the sweet caramel notes, with soft stone fruits, melon, lemon peel, green apples, some funk and barnyard. Light to medium bodied, with a silky mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Overall, very interesting and glad to have had a chance to try

375mL bottle shared by Vtafro on 8/13/16, unsure of exact date, but is said to be from the �80�s. Wine cork full insertion, with no cage. Fill is good; mid-neck. Deep copper-orange, good clarity, with a small film of white bubbles that show low retention. Very earthy, somewhat funky (horseblanket, sweat, cellar, must) nose is fairly well integrated between various acids and does show a touch of brett even. Seems fairly lactic, with a hard, yogurt/cheese rind-like character that is somewhat softened by a honey-caramel sweetness itself being a bit stale/oxidized. In the mouth, it�s sweet again, with a strong honey-like backbone, with notes of oxidized caramel and bits of simple sugar. Quite fruity and oaky, with strawberry, apple and lemon notes leading to a bit of sour acetic character and ending moderately lactic, acidburn lingering. Fairly well-balanced, quite easygoing, but with enough acidity to signify a lambic. Carbonation is light, but still apparent, giving a frizzante-like character. No alcohol noted. Interesting, and in strong condition for its age, but nothing terribly compelling here and a bit sweet/saccharine-like at points.
Bottle - 1980s - Generation Lambic Share - pours orange gold white head - nose and taste of lemon, horsey funk, basement must, lactic acid and woody funk / medium body
Bottle. 1980 vintage? Sediment in an orange pour. Actually some carbonation. Light fruit, tart, wild aromas. Flavors are funky, wild tart and oak tones.

Small sample from bottle in the Beer Geeks bus from Vleteren, apparently 28 years old? Yallow color, hazy. Aroma�s: sour, wood, tannines. Flavor is sour, woody. Light bodied, enough carbonation. Just a good gueuze, hard to believe this was that old.

Bottle 750ml. [1999 vintage] Pours clear blond/golden with low to no white head. Aroma is of apricots, vegetables, apples, menthol, cardboard. Taste is of menthol, some citrus, cardboard. Palate: Very low carbonation. Light body. Overall: Over the hill, by alot it would appear. Feels old. Not gross considering the age.

Clear amber body with a soft, frothy white head. A unique aroma of strong hops and sourdough bread. Not too sweet or malty and also not too crazily hopped or bitter, but certainly interesting. The body is fairly light, but good for the style and good for the spring. The flavors are fairly well balanced and the sour aspects seem to drop out here, leaving nice, citrus hops, a touch of pine and some dry bread. A fairly tasty beer that�s rather reminiscent of some other Two Brothers beers: good, but not great.
Orangey-amber. Cascade aroma, with a touch of amber malt. Lemon, whole grain bread...typical straightforward APA. Good for what it is.

Reviewed from notes. The appearance had a golden yellow body with no head probably because the bartender filled it to the brim (no worries). No lacing was seen. Gentle carbonation slowly rose. The smell had a bland sort of wheat. After it warmed up a bit, there were some light fruits and then the malts came out a bit. The taste was the same as the smell, nothing really different. On the palate, it sat very light with a decent amount of carbonation, sessionable. Overal, this is a decent summer offering by Sea Dog�s. Though I�d probably only have it again on tap.
Draught at the brewpub in Orlando. Clear amber colour with a white head. Aroma and flavour of spice, malt, caramel, hops and floral notes.

Clear medium amber, full one finger head, sheets of lace. Honey caramel malt lasts entire length with only the lightest bittering showing up to settle matters. Midway through the palate a touch of mild spice appears. Even though the hops are mostly absent, this is still a drinkable brew.
A nice, smooth summer ale with a semi-sweet maltiness. Pours rich golden with a short head. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours clear deep golden. Toffee and citrus fruits in aroma and flavor. Softly carbonated. Very "English". Finishes lightly dry and citrusy. Balanced.

Draught @ Sea Dog, Bangor, ME: Pours almost yellow/amber, no head to speak of. Grainy, sweet, vegetal aroma. She is no good. Harsh, very biscuity taste with a light, straw character. Not so good. Ugh.

On tap at brewpub in So. Portland. Poured a nice, golden color with a very small, white head. Slightly hazy with no particles. Doesn�t smell too much like a typical summer ale; no real wheat to speak of. Smooth on the palate with a medium-lasting aftertaste, and a nice flavor (some citrus?). Goes down very easy; a good summer beer, but nothing really special to set it apart from all the other summer ales out there.
Pours yellowwith a thin white head. Smells of wildflowers, dry malt. Tastes sweet and perfumy with a soft finish.
Strong and fresh cranberry aroma, outrageously tingly and lightly sour taste...good for a cranberry, not overdone, but not one of my favorite Kraftbrau's...

Just a hint of a soft malt base and some German hop character rise through pretty subtle (as fruit beers go!) cranberry in the nose. Nice tingly blend of fruit and good lager underneath; not a world killer. Sour at the finish.

RBSG2003(extended) (On tap at the brewery) This beer rocks! Light golden, slightly hazy lager. Small, quickly diminishing, white creamy head. I smell no cranberry, but plenty of citrus fruit, yeast, pepper and coriander. The flavor is very geueze-like! No fruit, other than lemon. Lightly bitter. Well- balanced and tart... lightly tart. Light-bodied with an oily mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Short, tart, lightly bitter, astringent finish. Fun brew! Very Lambic/Flanders Red-like. It's a fruity lager, so that makes sense. World-class in my book.

On tap at the brewery. Pour a relatively clear golden amber with a medium sized white head. Soft malt and toast on the nose, a touch of vague citrus. Medium bodied, soft and sweet, malty fruit. Sweet fruit into the finish with a soft hint of citrus and slight bitterness. Not much going on here.

On tap at the sea dog local near the Portland airport. Pours translucent Amber, minimal head or lacing. Pretty much malt based, toast, light flower hop presence. Slightly sweet that lingers in the Finnish.

Pours clear amber with very tan head. Nose is caramel. Aromas are light citrus and bread. Oily texture, medium carbonation. Where are hoppy aromas expected in a pale ale? Quite disappointing. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Reviewed from notes. The appearance had a hazy golden orange colored body leaving a thin white head that dissipated within a minute and left a small square bubbly looking head that lasted a good five minutes, didn�t leave any lacing or rings around the glass. No carbonation was seen rising. The smell had some light hops I thought they were more subdued than most APA�s. There were some light traces of citrus in the smell. The taste was mainly the malts with the hops and citrus mainly combined and subtly coming back in the taste. On the palate, it sat at/about a medium, slightly creamy with average carbonation felt. This was mainly a drinkable beer. Overall, this was a pretty good brew that I would have again.
Draught at the brewpub in Orlando. Clear amber colour with a white head. Aroma and flaovur of hops, fruit and malt.
Draught. This is a bad EPA - its akin ot wet cardboard - no flavour just a hint of malt.
Pours a dark�ish golden color, light head, medium lacing. There�s a citrus/tangy taste on the palate. Not at all what I would expect from a pale ale, short finish.

3 oz. draft sample. Like most of the Sea Dog brews, this looked great with big long lasting head, good lacing and carbonation. Bready smell. Taste was bread malt with a mild bitterness. Light body, very sessionable. Overall, probably my favorite of the Sea Dog flight.
Also known as Bangor Pale Ale. Nothing incredible, but I enjoyed it well enough.

Draught @ Sea Dog, Bangor, ME: I�m quite sure this was listed as "Bangor Pale Ale", so why the same company is also calling it Topsham Pale Ale is beyond me. Crazy Americans. She came a light pumpkin colour with a clingy white head and awesome lacing. I couldn�t pull any aroma at all. Tastes like a hoppy pale ale with straw, white bread and grass notes. Bitter and some spicy white pepper. Sounds better than it tasted, though.

On tap. It poured a yellow color with a white head. The aroma was of cereal, crackers and toast. The taste was similar to the aroma with more cereal, crackers, toast and medium carbonation with a light mouthfeel. Ok.
Draft at Sea Dog Brewpub in Conway, NH. Clear bright yellow color. Light body and flavor. Sessionable. Good flavor for only 3.2 ABV.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear gold with a medium sized white head. Soft grain, a bit of sweet cracker notes, but I�m searching. Medium bodied, soft grain, a touch of sweetness, crackers and toast. Crisp into the finish, soft grain. Crisp on the finish.

On tap at Sea Dog Brewpub, Bangor, ME - pours clear golden with almost no head. Caramel nose. Cereals and caramel aromas. Dry and short finish. Refreshing but nothing interesting here. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Reviewed from notes. The appearance was a transparent golden colored body with no visible head (that might have left before I recieved my beer, it was an on tap pour). The lacing was lightly spotty and left no visible rings. The smell had some pale malts and just a touch of hops. The taste had some malts and the hops, but nothing particularly interesting. On the palate, it was very light, very sessionable, no harshness on the tongue, no aftertaste, crisp, clean finish. Overall, it was not a bad beer and I think I would have this again, but nothing to scream about.
Draught at the brewpub in Orlando. Clear amber colour with a white head. Aroma and flavour of malt and hops.
Draught. This is a typical thin pale lager but it lacks the hopping and fresh faint malt flavour I enjoy in this style.

Clear light amber, light edge head, thin swirls of lace. Taste is an unassertive malt that moves through the palate to the finish without growing, changing, or adding hop bitters. My non-beer drinking wife claimed it was one of the better brews she has tried. �Nuff said.

Poured as part of a taster at the Woburn brewpub. Poured with a very large head which rapidly dissipated leaving almost no lacing. Very mild hop aroma plus something else I can�t identify. Taste is thin and empty. I wouldn�t order this again.

3 oz. draft sample at Sea Dog in Bangor. Worst of the sample flight, has a faint perfume order or none at all. Pale yellow colour, no head, a trace of lacing. Taste is weak, some grain and fruit juice. Body is watery. Despite my fondness for owls, this isn�t a step up much from a macro lite.

I didn't care for their regular pale ale at all, but found this quite decent and drinkable. The dry-hopping and whatever else they do for the "APA" qualities work wonders. Still about average for the style though, and not really worth seeking out with all that's out there.

Pours a slightly hazy golden brown on tap with fluffy off-white head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma of nice citrus and diesel dry hop notes over a mild caramel and bready malt base. Taste follows, clean and hoppy, nothing offensive or over the top, but not bad. Definitely towards the old school, but I don't hate it.

12floz, BOD: 07.31.2017, $13 paid for a Schlafly mix 12-pack, nonic glass. Brass gold in appearance with a good frothy head. Smells like a mixture of honey, pine, and grapefruit. This is a very good all-around APA that I've had many times before. It's unfortunate Schafly has removed this from their six-pack rotation in favor of some dumb sub-par IPA they want to put out. Great toasted (a little sweet) maltiness matches the mild chewiness of resiny hop flavor. This was one of my favorite go to beers that I knew would be available in stores and often on draft...but I am only one beer drinker.

On tap at Shamrocks. Pours a golden color with a decent head. Aroma of citrus, bit of malt sweetness and grain. Taste citrus and light caramel sweetness and grain. Some bitterness and a clean finish. Medium body and fairly smooth. Fairly average. Earlier Rating: 7/27/2010 Total Score: 3.7 Bottle- Pours a golden color with a decent head that slowly fades. Not much aroma, just a trace of citrus and hint of sweetness. The taste is citrus with a lingering bitterness, which is not a bad thing. It has a medium feel, continued carbonation and mildly dry finish. A respectable mid-range APA. I would like to try this fresh on tap to compare.

On tap and made exclusively for Shamrock's. It poured a golden color with a white head. The aroma was of malts, florals and hops. The taste was similar to the aroma with more malts, florals, caramel and hops. It had a medium body with smooth carbonation. Decent. Earlier Rating: 2/13/2011 Total Score: 3.6 It pours a transparent amber bronze with a thin white head. Aroma of lightly crystal malt and a big grapefruity hop presence. Body starts with a nice pale malty sweetness balanced with crisp, citrus hops toward a bittersweet drier clean finish. Very drinkable without lacking in flavor or body. A good APA.
Solid apa. Lots of mild flavor. Very smooth and incredibly drinkable. Will definitely look to have this again ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Trying to remember the various great beers I had while bicycling cross-country last year. This one seems not too well known outside it�s local area, but is a damn good beer. I hadn�t been in the States for some years and was quite impressed with the improvements and availability of good craft beers (you are excused, Utah) and I recall going into a bottle shop somewhere in Middle America, land of Bud Light, and asking for something �dry hopped�. The knowledgeable guy in the shop sold me this. Full flavored, well hopped, not straying far from its style, it is a fine one!

On draft at the airport because I needed it. Pours clear amber, little head retention. I have very little to say about the aroma...barely discernible. Hoppy with an almost pilsner-y malt aftertaste, finishes bitter. Overall ok to drink but nothing spectacular, like most Schlafly brews imo.

Slightly hazy perfectly coloured body of copper and bronze with a glowing orange tint and a thinnish one centimetre tall off-white head. Aroma of crisp fresh grassy and very herbal hops with some noticeable malt and alcohol. Medium-bodied; Strong grassy and very herbal hops with a bitter kick and some nicely balanced malt right behind. Aftertaste is rich and robust with the grass and herbs still very noticeable, but also with the malt and the bitterness. Overall, a nice APA with a big bitter taste and profile that shows well and lasts very long! I sampled this sixteen ounce pour on draught during a tap takeover at Whole Foods in Pentagon City (Arlington), Virginia on 13-February-2017 for US$4,00 at the end of my driveway.
From the Bonfire Box. Didn�t drink as fresh as I should have, but still is a nicely balanced mellow apa. Grapefruit, pine, grass, caramel and a touch of biscuit/bread. Moderate bitterness.

12 oz bottle: Smells like artificial vanilla and a bit of honey and just has an artificial stench to it. Poured a pale golden color with a small bubbly head that disappeared after about a half of a second. Lets taste this bad boy...Bubbly on the palate. A big artificial flavor and adjunct taste to it. This is pretty bad. Just noticed at the bottom it said " Malt beverage with Honey and artificial flavors." Figures. Booooo!
I liked even though most here bashed it...I would down a sixer of right now if it was in front of me!!!

In the bottle from a cheapo sixer ($4.99). While this says "light beer," I�m not so sure that it has any different formulary than any other Lawson Creek beer. Dark golden/pale amber color with virtually no head retention. Faint aroma of honey and an unusual odor that I can�t discern- certainly not almonds. Remarkably, this beer does not suck, if you consider that it is a light beer. I�m just skeptical that Gluek is pulling something over us here.

I�m diabetic and I should be drinking light beer but don�t, take my feet but don�t take my craft beer. I always try something I haven�t had before, so I gave LC HA a try. The aroma was pretty nice, sweet, an apple cider smell. I took a swig immediately and lind of liked it. Very cider like. Lemon/apple/almond flavors. Things went down from there. Once my thirst had been quenched from the first drink, all I was left with was a bland, extremely flat, near watery tasting cider like drink. I couldn�t even classify this as a lawnmower beer because of the flatness.

Not really a head forms, just a small amount of scattered white foam on the top that looks like Greenland. Body is an light amber. Aroma is honey, and there is almond that smell veeeeery fake and extract like. Taste is fake.

Bottle. Says light beer but not %. Honey and artificial flavour added. Hmmm artificial almond! Looks like a glass of dark apple juice. Almost no head. Funky sweet aroma at times like honey, possibly nuts and chemicals. Tastes like a macro beer and grape nuts. Too thin, not enough malt flavour, ruined by the artificial flavours. Glad I only have the one.

Pours a golden color. Has a really strong scent of some sort of artificial sweetness. Has a really strange taste, something between a bad cider and crunch and munch. It is different I will give it that, and it�s drinkable. Not really a quality effort but I�ll drink the sixer.

This is a okay beer in my book. The label doesn�t say anything about it being a light beer like someone had stated but it does say brewed in America, and thats why i picked it up. Its a pretty decent lager that has me telling myself to pick it up if its ever 5 dollars a 6 or chepaer.
Smells winey. Interesting twizzler taste, however, keeps me slightly amused.
I have to agree with the previous rating. This really does taste like a light beer with honey and butter. Watery and syrupy sweet malts predominate. I would never drink another bottle of this again.
Citrusy aroma. Not very hazy for a wheat. Dull citrus start with a nice malt finish. Extremely good weiss beer.
On Tap. Color is cloudy golden with good size white head. Aroma is fairly yeasty. Taste is very light and crisp as the description says. Pretty good beer for a hot day.
Has a clouded golden/yellow color and a yeast/wheat smell. Taste is somewhat sour and finishes fairly smooth. Overall a typical weak american wheat. The Germans do it much better.
Pleasant looking, nice whitish head. Strange, unappalng nose. Thin bodied, fairly sour, light body. Not terribly impessed with this one.....sorry!

Cask conditioned at The Woolpack, Banbury, Oxon. Brown amber with thin head. Paricularly malty bitter, quite heavy in character with a sour fruitiness in the body. Some bitterness on the finish, but quite vague flavours.

Half pint pulled at The Lower Red Lion in St Albans (Hertfordshire), a slightly cloudy yellow-straw with a filmy head that laced well down the glass. A strong sour pollen hop aroma. Strong fruity hops in the flavour, quite a smooth mouthfeel with only a touch of bitterness.
Cask Handpump at the Beer House, Manchester 06/11/2004 Amber golden coloured and pale. Some sour fruit and a crisp malt finish.
Cask Conditioned, at the Wenlock Arms, London. Slightly cloudy but an attractive beer none the less. Amber colour with good bitterness. Nice palate that lingers.

Cask, The Elephant, Faversham. This has a photo of one of the locals on the pump clip. Served slightly warm (again!). Slightly murky orange colour with a dull glow which eventually cleared (near end of barrel?). Soft fruity orange with a watery finish. Gentle acidity. Some cider notes on the aroma. Below average bitter.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: On tap at the brewery. Comes a cloudy gold with an average white head. Aroma of malt, grain, and spice. Taste is malt, grain, banana, and some clove. Enjoyable.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Draft @ the brewery. Pours a hazy yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy banana aroma. Fruity wheat malty spicy banana flavor. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy banana finish.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: 9/19/17: 12 ounce pour into plastic cup, comped on casino floor w lemon slice. Flat white head, cloudy golden yellow pour, mild carbonation. Orange lemon aroma. Light nominal taste, lemon wedge primary taste. Mouth feel medium, very easy drinking. Overall OK offering.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Draft sample at the source. Pours, straw yellow witha white head. Aroma is band aid, banana, funk. Flavor is dry banana, funk, a bit of pepper. Not good.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Draft at the source 12/28/13. Murky, chalky yellow color. Aroma of lemon and raw eggs. Taste is similar. Odd.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Typical cloudy brew lemony phenolic slight Band-Aid very well carbonated nice lemon zest aroma good summer drinkable beer

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Draft sample. Poured hazy yellow color with an average fizzy white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate banana, clove and wheat aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a solid sweet finish of moderate duration. Good refreshing brew.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: ~ 16 ounce draft at the Triple 7 Brewpub at the Main Street Station, Las Vegas, Nevada. The pour is a very hazy yellow golden with a small white head. The aroma is soft wheat grain, perhaps a faint clove yeast. The taste is wheat, grain, light hay, and subtle clove and banana yeast. The palate is unfiltered, light bodied, clean finish. Easy drinking, but a bit plain. The yeast character was really dialed down on this.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: On tap as Double Down Hefeweizen. A hazed pale blonde weizen with a thin white head. In aroma, banana and cloves with light chalky notes. In mouth, a smooth sweet and creamy weizen with light bananas and berries, nice. On tap at brewpub, August 9 2012.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Tons of banana in the aroma. A yellow almost Belgian-wit style color. The flavor is pretty light yet still good. A nice light hefe.

Draught, in Barcelona. I'd been in search of good beer all through Barcelona, and finally I found something that was drinkable. In my best Spanish, I made some enquiries as to the origin of the beer. There was next to no English on offer in this place and I had my reservations about the authenticity of this beer. Then after much persistence and a flash of my tasting notes the owner of the bar was summoned. He proudly explained that he brewed it down stairs and proceeded to top my glass up quicker then I could drink it. All of this fun aside this beer was the best local beer sampled in Barcelona. Pale gold colour, with a slight white that leaves a sexy, lacy white trail down the tall thin glass. Refreshing malty aroma, malty, hoppy taste. Lovely finish.

Bottle. Orange and very clear. Minute head upon pouring. Fruity bitterness with a medium body.Some trace of citrus. Quite nice and certainly better bottled than some of their other beers I have tried.

Bottled. Hazy golden coloured, small white head. Somewhat hoppy nose with some malts, oranges and wet paper. Bitter and dry flavour, not very outspoken. Nothing special. Thanks to my girlfriend for bringing this from Cambridge.
Bottl conditioned from ronnie. Aroma is minimal but whats there is cardboard and oranges. Taste is similar with hints of spice, lacking in condition slightly but still a nice ale.

A Mes rate: Cask from that pub we stopped at in Cambridge. Sweet malty nose. Sweet and brief malty flavour with a hint of tobacco. Malt is even more apparent in the finish which is also slightly peppery.
Bottle. Quite decent. malty start, light toffee and grainy malt notes. Finish is orangey and lightly bitter, very pleasant.
From A Bottle.Dark amber in colour with a large head,aroma is of hops and lemon, taste is malty with some fruit and a light hoppy dry finish.
Bottled. Pale amber, small head. Lightly fruity. Sweetish with clean, rounded mouthfeel and grassy, salty finish. Not an attention grabber.
Golden brown. Aromas are sweet hops, yeast and some spice. Flavours are sweet malts with some nice hops followed by some soapiness. Soft and delicate with quite a dry finish. Its OK.
Cask Conditioned, at the Wenlock Arms, London. Nutty amber colour with a slight lacy head. Musky, yeasty flavour. A little bit too much like home brew this.

...and three years later, a new rating. Bottle, picked up somewhere in north Norfolk. Deep gold. Nothing really that you call a head. Nose has toffee. Sweet wort. Hint of dessert apple. Taste is significantly better than the aroma, and is punchy, pithy bitter, with a little toffee sweetness. Pretty flat and dull mouthfeel. Pithy bitterness to finish.

A perfectly acceptable Golden Ale from Norwich. Hazy golden pour from a 500ml bottle with BBE of 1/16. Small white head that laces poorly. Nose has pale malt sweetness, floral hops and a touch of citrus. Palate is balanced bitter sweetness with a pleasant citrusy hop finish. Medium bodied with soft carbonation and easy drinkability.
licorice smell, pale gold amber body, tastes just like warm water. very bland.

Hand-pulled pint in The White Horse, Upton (Norfolk) on 26th Oct 2013. As the name might suggest, this was golden in colour: the small white covering stayed around for a while before retreating into a wisp and collar formation. A little more Pale Malts than anything else in both the aroma and taste: semi-sweet with a mild citrus note in the background. No huge flavours but a pleasant enough blend, refreshing and gulp-able.

How: Cask. Where: Great British Beer Festival (GBBF), 2013. Appearance: Golden colour with a white head. Aroma: Fruit, hops, malt, grass. Body: Medium body, low carbonation. Flavour: Sweet malt, hops, citrus.
Deep golden color. Malty sweetness and apricots in the nose. Fairly sweet but not that interesting. Ok.
Cask at GBBF 2011. Golden with a small white head. Weak floral and grassy hop aroma. Sweetish grassy flavour with a good, bitter finish
cask at gbbf 2011 ... golden amber ... thin white head ... sweet toffee hop nose ... dull soft fruity ... ligh hop.
Cask @ GBBF, 2011. Pours clear golden with bubbles on top. Hay and citrus. Dry and fairly crisp flavor. Ends dry. Smooth.
Cask at GBBF 2011 - Tuesday. Clear golden/yellow - white head. Toasted, fruity, light nutty, citrus, notes of grape fruits, light malty, light bitterness, dryness.
Cask Stillage at Lewisham Theatre, Catford 14/06/2001 Light and slightly sweet on the palate. VEry hoppy.
Clear light amber, no head. Sweet banana aroma. Molasses, banaba and roasted malts in flavour. Dry hoppy bitterness. Thin on palate.

Maidstone Beer Festival, 2005. This is a beautiful drinking beer. The flavours are clean, fresh, soft and very inviting. The delicacy is breath-taking, yet the flavours wrap around the tongue like a soft quilt. This is really what drinking beer is all about. A lovely day, a lovely setting and beautiful soft flavoursome drinking beers in the prime of condition. Perfick.
Cask conditioned. Delicate, fresh, drinkable. Flavours fill the mouth. Stunning. ****

Gravity cask at Maidstone BF. Used to have this a lot at The Mogul in Dover but haven�t had it in a bit and had almost forgotten how good this beer is. Terrific 3.8% session bitter. Dark gold really nice intense hop aroma, with some aramel and a bit of fruit to carry it through with some red berry fruit flavours and a crisp enjoyable hoppy dry finish. Excellent
[Cask at GBBF 2004] An orange beer with a huge beige head. The aroma is sweet and fruity. The flavor is sweet with a nice bitter end.
[Cask conditioned] Pale brown coloured. Rather hoppy aroma. Quite bitter flavour and finish.

Cask Conditioned, at the GBBF, 2004. Sulphurous but just a bitter. We seemed to have run aground with the beer choices at this point. Not that chris_o and I minded particularly but it would have been nice to try some more varied beer. My fault I should have been at the festival for more then one afternoon.

I found this a little disappointing. I suspect it wasn�t perfectly conditioned. Pale gold colour. Sulphur, and not much else, on the nose. Dry palate, but not that hoppy or bitter - just a touch of citrus. Clean finish, but a bit soft. I�m sure I�ve enjoyed this more in pre-RB days. Overall, an average session bitter. Cask, GBBF 2004, day 1. (6/3/6/3/11 - 2.9) RE-RATE 22/04/05. Cask (handpump), The Black Boy, Winchester. Much juicier and fresher than my previous tasting, which bears out my suspicion that it wasn�t in peak condition when I had it before. Quite fruity and flowery aroma. Plenty of hop bite coming through, but mellow mouthfeel. Slipped down very easily. Nice. Previous rating discarded.

Apr 06 Gravity Cask @ The Flower Pot Inn. One last visit to the Flower Pots whilst cheriton beers were still available and some had been pending a re-rate. An excellent session beer combining delicate flavours with lots of drinkability. 4.2 Oct 05 Cask conditioned @ Black Boy, Winchester. Perfumey floral hops and juicy malt. Quite simple but everything works together excellently. 3.8 Mar 04 Cask-conditioned at Flower Pot Inn. Flowery hop aroma with faint grassy and fruit notes. Hoppiness continues in the mouth with almost sweet full malty mouthfeel and suprisingly little bitterness. A good session bitter which could have done with a touch more bitterness for me. Must be sampled fresh. 3.6
Cask Handpump at the Ship & Mitre, Liverpool 16/06/2002 Straw golden coloured with floral and citrus aromas. Slightly dry hop finish.
[Cask at GBBF 2005] A pale hazy yellow with a thin white head. The flavor is sweet flowery combined with light notes of fruit. The flavor is flowery combined with lemon and grapefruit.
Sweet bitterness with notes of elder flower in aroma and flavour. Fruity aftertaste. Quite fresh and sparkling palate.

Cask@The Red Lion, Isleworth. Very pale in colour. Malty, grainy start, weakish body, twist of lemon at the end, didn�t notice anything particularly floral about it. Was nice because it was light and it was a hot day, but otherwise i might not have it again.

Cask-conditioned @ Flower Pots, Cheriton. Summery aroma - flowery hops, citrus fruit, a hint of elderflower, some woodiness and rising bread. Some sweetness but well balanced full, refreshing body. Getting near the end of the cask-not crisp and fresh enough.
[Cask conditioned] Lovely aroma of hops and elderflower. Very good summer brew. Loads of hops in the flavour with a very pleasant touch of elderflower.

Wow. Intensely floral. In fact, one of the most floral beers I have ever tasted. Lots of aromatic hops, but also elder flowers apparently. Very pale, very refreshing, with some bitterness, but overall very easy drinking. Citrus overtones. Spectacular, or was the fact that this was the 12th and last beer (halves only) of a Great British Beer Festival session clouding my judgement. Remind myself to sample it on its home ground at the Flower Pots Inn (an excellent pub) next to the brewery. August 2003
Cask, GBBF 2003 Golden Summer Ale. Citric aroma. pale golden appearance with wheat enhanced head. Good citric flavour; some woody, yeasty tones.

I had this beer with the cellar master of the Wenlock Arms. Beautiful aroma, hoppy, orange, lemon, floral. Theh flaovr lets it down some. Thinnish, slightly astringent, and chalky at the end. Yellow with nice, irregular head. (cask at GBBF 2003)
A beautiful ale from Cheriton. The elderflowers underpin the hops in a way that is quite remarkable. Great spice and aroma. A multi-award winning beer, with good reason.
Cask Conditioned at Reading BF 2006. Copper coloured. Malty and very hoppy bitter. Slightly fruity and a flowery hop aftertaste.
Cask @ St Albans 05: Nice ruby with a beige head. Malty caramel nose. Bit bland, roast and caramel but drinkable.
Cask@St Albans Beer Festival. Sweetish flat, toasty crystal malt type character. Caramelly, some raisin, lemony finish. Not quite all there for me.

Cask (gravity dispense), St Albans Beer Festival 2005. Chestnut brown colour - rather dark for a bitter. Caramel, dark malt and nuts, with some decent balalncing hop bitterness. An unusual best bitter - full bodied and very tasty. Showed very well despite imperfect condition.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - St Albans BF - A mid brown beer with a fruity malty raisin aroma but also a little sulphur. The taste has fruity malts but again is tainted, like so many beers at this festival by a little fartiness. Shame as Cheriton is top.

Cask (gravity dispense), St Albans Beer Festival 2005. Another cracker from this top brewery. Reddish brown colour with good malt/hop balance. Bit of choc and good hop flavours. Superb. Really nice flavours throughout and excellent dry hoppy finish. Gorgeous.

Chappel Fest. The Flower Pot was closed for lunch when we went there, which left us in the lurch a bit. So I was pleased to pick this up at Chappel. It�s a toffee drenched best bitter with some balancing bitterness. Probably better at the brewpub.

Apr 06 Gravity Cask @ The Flower Pots Inn, Cheriton. Whilst drinking this the casks from the brewhouse were being stacked outside ready for taking away to their new home. A light bodied bitter with dark malt flavours and a good hoppy finish. Works quite well. 3.7 Mar 04 Cask conditioned @ Flower Pots. Dark dried fruit and malty aromas. Toffee flavours and bitter finish. Quite flavoursome and full bodied for its strength. 3.6

Cask Conditioned at The Flower Pots Inn, Cheriton. A dark brown bronze beer with thick lacy head. Malsts and soft fruit, sultanas dominate this beer. Some nuttiness in the second phase of the flavour. Harder to drink than the Pots Ale but more of a sipping bitter.
